column2: The appellant appealed his conviction for dangerous driving and alleged that his estranged wife and daughter lied. The appellant had been represented at trial by experienced counsel but undertook the appeals himself. HELD: Appeal dismissed. The appellant had not followed procedures that must be followed if one intends, on appeal, to challenge the competence of trial counsel or to adduce fresh evidence.
column3: The appellant appealed his conviction for dangerous driving to the Court of Queen's Bench and, having failed, then appealed to the Crown. He contended that he was the victim of a miscarriage of justice inasmuch as he had evidence that his estranged wife, out of a desire for revenge, had lied about what occurred. The trial judge found both to be credible witnesses. The appellant also rejected the appellant's account that he had intimidated their daughter into testifying against him. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)There are procedures that have to be followed if one intends on appeal, on appeal or to challenge the competence of trial counsel or to adduce fresh evidence. These procedures were not followed and there was nothing before the Court upon which it might act. 2)The Court of Appeal had no basis for allowing the appeal, setting aside his conviction, and ordering a new trial.

column2: The corporate defendant moved (under Rule 44.10 of the 2008 Rules) for an order terminating an attachment order made against it, and under Rule 32.02(3) to change the venue from Halifax to Windsor. The latter was not opposed. There was also an issue regarding an affidavit filed by the respondent, which referenced but did not attach the applicant's defence. The respondent argued it was unnecessary to attach a document already filed with the court. Change of venue granted in part: the applications will continue to be heard in Halifax, but the trial will be held in Windsor as requested. Neither party has a connection to Halifax. The respondent operates from Stewiacke and the dispute arose in Hants County. The attachment order is terminated, with costs of $1,000 to the applicant. An attachment order is an intrusive pre-trial remedy and will hinder the corporate applicant's attempts to resume/expand operations. Here there is no conduct to justify maintaining the order. The mere allegation of a connection between the individual and corporate defendants is insufficient to cause the court to pierce the corporate veil. The respondent has failed to establish any of the relevant grounds governing attachment orders. The Rules require facts, not allegations or suspicions. The affidavit in question was flawed. It should have attached the defence in order to properly incorporate the references to it.
column3: The plaintiff moved for an order terminating an attachment order against it pursuant to Rule 44.10. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant had interfered with the plaintiff's timber harvesting contract and sought a change of the place of proceeding. The defendant argued that the attachment order was an intrusive pre-trial remedy and that its existence would hinder any attempt by the plaintiff to resume or expand its operations. The applicant sought costs. The court found that the affidavit of the plaintiff did not properly incorporate the contents of the statement of claim. The mere allegation of a connection between the individual and corporate defendants was not sufficient reason to dispose of the corporate veil. The affidavit of a corporation that is not registered under the Corporations Registration Act did not establish any of the grounds for the attachment. The only grounds for termination were that the plaintiff had not established any of them under Rule 44 and that the plaintiffs had not shown any principled basis to do so. The fact that the defendants had not made sufficient efforts to bring the claim to final determination was not enough grounds to terminate the attachment and the plaintiff was not acting in any way that necessitated security for the plaintiff. The Court awarded costs to the applicant of $1,000 payable in any event in the cause.
column4: [1] C & R Sterling Farm, one of the defendants in the main proceeding, moves for an order terminating an attachment order against it, pursuant to Rule 44.10. Sterling farm also seeks a change of the place of the proceeding, from Halifax to Windsor NS. Sterling Farm says neither party has a connection with Halifax, and argues that the matter should be heard in Windsor, in the area in which the dispute arose. In the hearing, I directed that applications would continue to be heard in Halifax, and the main action – i.e. the trial – would be held in Windsor. [23] I conclude the affidavit of February 28, 1991 does not properly incorporate the contents of the statement of claim. Conclusion [29] I am not satisfied that Sierra has established conduct on the part of Sterling Farm to justify the maintenance of the attachment order. An attachment order is an intrusive pre-trial remedy, and I am satisfied that its existence will hinder any attempt by Sterling Farm to resume or expand its operations. The mere allegation of a connection between the individual and corporate defendants is not sufficient reason to dispose of the corporate veil. [30] Ultimately, I do not believe that the plaintiff has established any of the grounds available under the rules governing attachment orders. On that basis, I am satisfied the attachment order must be terminated. [31] I award costs to the applicant of $1,000 payable in any event in the cause.

column2: The accused was charged with driving a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol level exceeding .08. The Crown filed a certificate of analysis pursuant to s. 258(1)(g) of the Criminal Code for the purpose of proving the accused's blood alcohol level. The word and symbol 'Breathalyzer' had a line drawn through them and above the same was written 'Intoxilyzer'. There was no symbol with it. In the blank that followed was written '5000C'. This change was not initialed. The issue was whether s. 258(1)(g) of the Code requires that the approved instrument be identified by way of make and model. HELD: The charge was dismissed. The Court found the Crown could not rely on s. 258(1)(g) of the Code and there was no evidence of the accused's blood level. 1) The Court found that in order for a certificate of analysis under s. 258(1)(g) of the Code to constitute evidence as set out in that subsection, the make and model of the approved instrument has to be set out in the certificate or be proven by other evidence.  2) It was not possible to know who made the alteration. The use of a certificate is a shortcut afforded to the Crown. If it is to be employed, it must be employed correctly. In the circumstances, the approved instrument was not adequately identified as to make and model.
column3: The accused was charged with driving an automobile with a blood alcohol level exceeding eighty milligrams of alcohol in one hundred millilitres of blood. The Crown filed a certificate of analysis pursuant to s258(1)(g) for the intended purpose of proving the accused's blood alcohol levels. The certificate indicated that the samples were taken at 2:40 and 3:01, with results of 120 milligram and 110 milligres, respectively. There was also an initialled change to the year from 19 to 2003. HELD: The accused was found not guilty. 1)It is not a requirement of s258 to constitute evidence as set out in that subsection. The make and model of the approved instrument has to be set out either in the certificate or be proven by other evidence. 2)The accused did not make any unusual or unusual changes to the instrument. The technician did not advance any unusual model. The accused's model was not sufficiently developed to advance any of the other models. The court noted that the accused was not qualified to make the model. 3)The Crown did not intend that there should be a requirement that the instrument be identified, provided that the qualified technician states in the Certificate that an approved instrument was employed. The technicians did not use any unusual models. 4)The use of a certificate is shortcut afforded to the Crown. The use of the certificate is rarely, if ever, adequate to meet the burden borne by the Crown in criminal trial. The type and model used in the approved instruments has to have been set out and proven by the other evidence, and the make and models of the inspected instrument have to be sufficiently similar to those used in a similar case. The equipment was not designated for the purpose of identifying the accused. The model was a model that was not properly designated. The instrument was not to be identified by the make or model of an approved device.
column4: [1] The accused is charged with driving an automobile with a blood alcohol level exceeding eighty milligrams of alcohol in one hundred millilitres of blood. [3] The Crown filed a certificate of analysis pursuant to section 258(1)(g) for the intended purpose of proving the accused’s blood alcohol level. 1. Is it a requirement of subparagraph 258(1)(g)(i) that the approved instrument be identified by way of make and model? Accordingly I must and do take the law to be that in order for a certificate of analysis under paragraph 258(1)(g) to constitute evidence as set out in that subsection, the make and model of the approved instrument has to be set out in the certificate or be proven by other evidence. Under the somewhat unusual circumstances of this case, I find that the approved instrument is not adequately identified as to make and model by means of the certificate. [11] It follows that the Crown cannot rely upon paragraph 258(1)(g) and accordingly there is no evidence of the accused’s blood alcohol level. [13] The charge is dismissed.
column7: The accused was charged with driving a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol level exceeding .08. The Crown filed a certificate of analysis pursuant to s. 258(1)(g) of the Criminal Code for the purpose of proving the accused's blood alcohol level. The word and symbol 'Breathalyzer' had a line drawn through them and above the same was written 'Intoxilyzer'. There was no symbol with it. In the blank that followed was written '5000C'. This change was not initialed. The issue was whether s. 258(1)(g) of the Code requires that the approved instrument be identified by way of make and model. HELD: The charge was dismissed. The Court found the Crown could not rely on s. 258(1)(g) of the Code and there was no evidence of the accused's blood level. 1) The Court found that in order for a certificate of analysis under s. 258(1)(g) of the Code to constitute evidence as set out in that subsection, the make and model of the approved instrument has to be set out in the certificate or be proven by other evidence.  2) It was not possible to know who made the alteration. The use of a certificate is a shortcut afforded to the Crown. If it is to be employed, it must be employed correctly. In the circumstances, the approved instrument was not adequately identified as to make and model.

column2: FIAT: The respondent applies for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties' two children and child support retroactive to the date of separation being October 2005. The petitioner seeks joint custody with specified access. The petitioner acknowledges an obligation to pay child support but there is an issue with respect to his income and whether the interim order should be retroactive. The children are ages 3 and 2.HELD: 1) Section 3 of The Children's Law Act 1997 provides for a presumption of joint custody where parents of a child have cohabitated after the birth of the child. That is the situation here. There is nothing in the evidence to rebut that presumption on an interim basis. In making interim orders, the Court tries to disrupt the lives of the children as little as possible. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement between the parties entered into after their separation. That is the petitioner would have the children every third week during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. This seems reasonable on an interim basis. This agreement did not address the fact that the petitioner shall be laid off for two months in the spring. It is reasonable that during this period his contact with the children should be increased. The petitioner has not seen the children for 10 months. He will have to be re-introduced to them. A phase in period is required. 2) The petitioner has worked for the same drilling company for about 6 years. His gross income in 2006 was $112,064. This is verified by his year to date income statement from his employer. The petitioner attests that $9,600 of his income is a 'living allowance' paid to cover expenses for his truck, fuel, vehicle maintenance and meals and should be deducted from his Line 150 income to arrive at his current income for child support purposes. This is a matter for the trial judge who will have the benefit of the 2006 tax return and notice of assessment and better evidence of the expenses and their purpose and make any retroactive adjustment deemed necessary. The petitioner's income for child support purposes is $112,064. 3) The claim for retroactive child support is a claim for child support payments which pre-date service of the notice of this application. The petitioner was served with the application in September 2006. The petitioner lived up to the parties' verbal agreement to pay child support of $1,200 per month starting October 2005. He unilaterally stopped paying child support in January 2006. He attests that his reason for doing so was because he was not having access to the children. The obligation to pay child support is not contingent on a payor's ability to see their children.  The respondent's income is substantially less then that of the petitioner's. The child support was necessary to meet the children's basis ongoing needs. The petitioner knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence that a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. There is evidence that a request for change in child support preceded the commencement of this application. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 2006 is warranted.
column3: FIAT: The respondent applied for an interim order granting sole custody of the parties' two children and child support, including s.7(a) child care expenses retroactive to the date of separation, being October 2005. The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requested joint custody with specified access. While he acknowledged an obligation to pay child support and there was an issue as to his income and whether the interim order should be made retroactive, the petitioner had not received any income from the company prior to the separation. The parties had a verbal agreement that the petitioner would have access every third weekend during his week off. The verbal agreement between the parties had not been made public and the petitioner was not prepared to change it. HELD: 1) The Court was satisfied retroactive child support was warranted. 2) The status quo in this case was represented by the verbal agreement which the parties entered into following their separation. 3) The petitioner's income was substantially less than the respondent's. Given the age and circumstances of the children, there was no evidence as to the respondent’s income and the interim orders should be retroactive. 4) The court was not able to determine whether the petitioner’ s income was significantly less than that of the petitioner. 5) The parties’ verbal agreement was not breached. The respondent”s income was substantial less than his income. 6) The respondent was not required to pay any child support.
column4: 1) The respondent, Nevada Pateman, applies for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties’ two children and child support, including s. 7(a) child care expenses retroactive to the date of separation, being October, 2005. The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requests joint custody with specified access. 8) There shall be an interim order that the petitioner and respondent have joint custody of the children, Kayden Marie Gavelin, born February 28, 2003 and Nolan Evan Gavelin, born December 28, 2004, with primary residence and day-to-day decision-making to be with Ms. Pateman. There shall be an order that Mr. Gavelin pay support for his children, Kayden Marie Gavelin, born February 28, 2003 and Nolan Evan Gavelin, born December 28, 2004 of $1,531 per month commencing February 1, 2007 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter for so long as the children remain children within the meaning of The Family Maintenance Act or until further order of this Court. Mr. Gavelin knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. I am satisfied in the circumstances that retroactive child support is warranted. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 1, 2006 is warranted.

The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requested joint custody with specified access. While he acknowledged an obligation to pay child support and there was an issue as to his income and whether the interim order should be made retroactive, the petitioner had not received any income from the company prior to the separation. The parties had a verbal agreement that the petitioner would have the children during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. While the parties had not lived together for some time, the parties entered into verbal agreement regarding the petitioner having access to the children. The agreement stipulated that the respondent would pay one-half of the child care costs. The respondent was to pay $185 per month directly to the Child Care Provider, representing 1-2/3/3 of the children's current child care expense. The interim order granted retroactive child support to January 1, 2006. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement between the parties that the living allowance would be deducted from the petitioner's Line 150 income to arrive at his current income for child support purposes. Given the age and circumstances of the petitioner and the respondent, there is an issue regarding his income, whether he should be allowed access or not. HELD: 1) The Court found that retroactive support was warranted. The Court was not prepared to impose a retroactive order on the petitioner. 2) The petitioner's income was substantially less than that of the respondent's. Given his income the petitioner was not having access. The child support was necessary to meet the children’s basic ongoing needs. 3) The court found that the parties’ verbal agreement was not in dispute. 4) The parties agreed to a period of time when the petitioner’d have access. 5) The respondent had not seen the children for ten months. The court ordered that the child support should be increased to reflect his 2006 income. 6) The order was discretionary. The purpose of interim orders is to establish a temporary parenting arrangement pending trial or final resolution of the matter.

That is the situation here. There is nothing in the evidence to rebut that presumption on an interim basis. In making interim orders, the Court tries to disrupt the lives of the children as little as possible. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement between the parties entered into after their separation. That is the petitioner would have the children every third week during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. This seems reasonable on an interim basis. This agreement did not address the fact that the petitioner shall be laid off for two months in the spring. It is reasonable that during this period his contact with the children should be increased. The petitioner has not seen the children for 10 months. He will have to be re-introduced to them. A phase in period is required. 2) The petitioner has worked for the same drilling company for about 6 years. His gross income in 2006 was $112,064. This is verified by his year to date income statement from his employer. The petitioner attests that $9,600 of his income is a 'living allowance' paid to cover expenses for his truck, fuel, vehicle maintenance and meals and should be deducted from his Line 150 income to arrive at his current income for child support purposes. This is a matter for the trial judge who will have the benefit of the 2006 tax return and notice of assessment and better evidence of the expenses and their purpose and make any retroactive adjustment deemed necessary. The petitioner's income for child support purposes is $112,064. 3) The claim for retroactive child support is a claim for child support payments which pre-date service of the notice of this application. The petitioner was served with the application in September 2006. The petitioner lived up to the parties' verbal agreement to pay child support of $1,200 per month starting October 2005. He unilaterally stopped paying child support in January 2006. He attests that his reason for doing so was because he was not having access to the children. The obligation to pay child support is not contingent on a payor's ability to see their children.  The respondent's income is substantially less then that of the petitioner's. The child support was necessary to meet the children's basis ongoing needs. The petitioner knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence that a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. There is evidence that a request for change in child support preceded the commencement of this application. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 2006 is warranted.
column18: FIAT: 1) The respondent applied for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties' two children and child support, including s.7(a) child care expenses retroactive to the date of separation, being October 2005. The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requested joint custody with specified access. While he acknowledged an obligation to pay child support and there was an issue as to his income and whether the interim order should be made retroactive, the petitioner had not received any income from the company prior to the separation. 2) The parties' verbal agreement at the time of separation was that the petitioner would have the children during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. There was nothing in the evidence before the trial judge that rebutted that presumption on an interim basis. The purpose of interim orders is to establish temporary parenting arrangements pending a trial or final resolution of the matter. In making such orders, Courts try to disrupt the lives of the children as little as possible and, for that purpose, often adopt the'status quo' subject always to that arrangement being in the best interests of the child. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement which the parties entered into following their separation. 3) The petitioner's income was substantially less than the respondent's. Given the age and circumstances of his children, there is an issue regarding his income. 4) The interim order granted retroactive child support to January 1, 2006 was warranted given the circumstances of the case. 5) The Court was not prepared to impose a retroactive order on the petitioner based on his income for the previous year as that was the basis for the original October 2005 agreement. The parties based their October 2005 verbal agreement on his 2004 income. The respondent had not seen the children since October 2005 when the parties separated. It is common for support provisions to be based on the prior year's earnings, as the best evidence of income is often year end income statements and/or tax returns. 6) Section of the Children's Law Act provides for a presumption of joint custody where parents of child have cohabited after the birth of a child. That presumption is the case here.

column2: The tenant's year-to-year lease ran from September 1 to August 31. Four months before it was set to automatically renew, he notified the landlord he wished to convert to a month-to-month tenancy. The landlord refused, saying vacancies were hard to fill at any time other than September 1st. The three bedroom rental was in an area with a large university student population and was targeted at individuals sharing not families. It was a high-end rental, and would not necessarily appeal to students. The landlord provided evidence that the last time it was on the market in winter, it was vacant for several months. After a Residential Tenancies Board hearing, an officer declared the tenant successful. The written decision did not mention the landlord's reasons for refusing consent, nor did it say they were arbitrary or unreasonable. The landlord appealed, but offered to compromise by allowing the tenant to terminate the lease any time between May 31 and August 31 without penalty. The officer erred in law. The Act allows the landlord some discretion to refuse a request to convert to month-to-month, providing the refusal is made reasonably. The landlord's reasons were neither unreasonable nor arbitrary, given the reality of the market and his past experiences with a winter vacancy. There may be other situations where consent could reasonably be withheld. The tenancy is declared to have been renewed for another year (with the understanding the landlord will allow the tenant to terminate at any point after May 31). Both parties acted in good faith and, while it might seem unfair to lock the tenant into a lease he believed had converted to month-to-month, the court must make the order the officer should have made in the first place.
column3: This was an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director of Residential Tenancies giving him the option to convert what had been a year to a month lease to a new one. The lease had been renewed for one year and the landlord refused to renew. The Landlord appealed. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy had not been converted into a month to month. The landlord refused the application and refused to consent. The appeal allowed and declared that the lease had not expired. The landlord had not withheld consent in an arbitrary or unreasonable manner. The reasons for withholding consent were not given. The Court found that the Landlords refusal to grant an early termination was not unreasonable. The issue was whether the Landowner was being arbitrary or unreasonably unreasonable in refusing consent.
column4: [2] This is an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director dated August 31, 2009. That order effectively permitted the Tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month one. About four months before the expiry of the second year, the Tenant gave a proper notice that he wished to convert the tenancy into a month to month tenancy, pursuant to the provisions of s.10A of the Residential Tenancies Act, which provides: [5] The Landlord responded within thirty days and refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed that it was not in his interest to have a month to month tenancy. [7] The Residential Tenancies Officer stated in his reasons that based upon his reading of the Residential Tenancies Act, the Landlord “may not deny the tenant’s request that the lease be changed from a year to year lease to a month to month effective September 1, 2009.” In so failing to consider the Landlord’s reasons, I believe that the Residential Tenancy Officer erred in law. It places the Landlord in the centre of a consenting process and allows the Landlord to exercise some judgment, with the constraint that it not be arbitrary or unreasonable. [13] The reasons of the Landlord here are that, in his experience, this particular flat is much more difficult to lease out at any time of the year other than September 1, which has become almost a standard moving day in south end Halifax, in part because that is the start day for most student apartments. [17] In the result, I allow the appeal and declare that the tenancy has not been converted into a month to month tenancy, because the Landlord refused his consent in a timely manner, for reasons that were neither arbitrary or unreasonable. [22] The Landlord wants the lease to terminate on August 31, 2010, but to alleviate hardship he has unconditionally undertaken to accept an early termination on any date from May 31, 2010 (his undertaking refers to 2009, but I believe that is a typo) until August 31, 2010.

column2: FIAT. At issue was whether there a change of circumstances, which would warrant a variation of the 2002 child support order; whether the 18 year old continued to be a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act; does the father have an obligation to contribute to his daughter's riding lessons; the father's income for child support purposes; should the 17 year old son's s.7 expenses be increased; costs. HELD: 1)The daughter had ceased to be a child of the marriage within the meaning of the Divorce Act and the father's obligation to provide on-going support and his contribution for s.7 expenses relating to her riding lesson terminated in March 2003. 2)The father shall pay $308 per month for support of his son commencing April 1, 2003 and every month thereafter so long as he remains a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. 3)The mother's application to increase the father's contribution for the son's extracurricular activities was dismissed. The father shall pay $54 per month for hockey expenses commencing June 2003 and every month thereafter. 4)The mother was to forthwith pay costs of the application fixed at $250.
column3: FIAT. The parties' oldest child, Jasmine, was no longer a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. The father was laid off from his employment and the parties' youngest child, Sloane, was not attending school. The mother sought to vary the support order. HELD: The child ceased to be a child of the marriage within the definition of the Act. 1)The father's income had decreased since the May 2002 consent judgment. The wife's application to increase the father's contribution for her son's extracurricular activities was dismissed. 2)The parties' current hockey expenses were $1,161.29 per annum. The husband's obligation to contribute to the child's riding lessons was terminated. 3)The mother's application was dismissed with costs to the father.

She opposed the application arguing that the layoff was only temporary and that Jasmine continued to be a child of the marriage and that her contribution for her son's extracurricular activities was not being made. HELD: The child was to continue her s. 7 (f) hockey and golf lessons until September 2003. The father's income for child support purposes was set at $39,219 and he was ordered to pay child support of $534 per month for Jasmine and Sloane commencing September 1, 2001 plus $70 per month to Jasmine's riding lessons and $60 for her hockey, golf and baseball expenses. Should Jasmine follow through with her plan and actually commence post-secondary education she may requalify as 'child of the married' under s. 8(f) of the Act. Should the father be required to contribute towards the costs of her riding lessons pursuant to s.7(f)? 1)The parties' eldest child (Jasmine) was 18 years old at the time of the May 2002 consent judgment. She was employed full-time earning $8.50 per hour. 2)The father had been unemployed for over 2 weeks with vague knowledge of when he would be rehired. His income had decreased since the May, 2002 consent order because he was laid off his employment. The unreasonableness of the father's position in calculating his share of the child support and his contribution for the expenses relating to his riding lessons was reprehensible. 3)The mother's obligation to contribute to the expenses of her son was terminated as of that date. She did not have an obligation to pay the father his proportionate share of that expense which would warrant a variation of the support order.

column2: The applicant applies for leave to appeal a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board on a question of law pursuant to s. 33.1 of the Municipal Board Act. The issues raised by the applicant relate to abnormal obsolescence for size and the refusal of the Assessor to apply abnormal obsolescence to the owner's property. The issues also relate to 15 other properties and as the issues are the same for each property they were decided by the Assessment Appeals Committee on one appeal. The Assessment Appeals Committee dismissed the appeals, finding the issue not to be a matter of the Assessor's Discretion but a matter of professional interpretation of data. The Committee found the Board of Revision did not err in its decision to dismiss the appeals and found the Board did not err on the issue of abnormal obsolescence for size. HELD: Leave to appeal was granted on two questions of law.  1) Did the Committee err in its interpretation and application of the Saskatchewan Assessment Manual by failing to find that economic obsolescence for size must be categorized on a MAF by MAF basis? 2) Did the Committee err by failing to find the Assessor should have used the comparable unit method to determine whether an adjustment for obsolescence for size should be applied to the applicant's property? 3) On the use of invalid sales leave was denied on the basis the question of the sale is a question of fact and in argument the applicant said for its purposes the impugned sale did not matter. 4) Leave to appeal was denied on the issue of the standard of proof that there was no error demonstrated.

column2: The accused, a young offender, was convicted of escaping lawful custody, theft of property valued in excess $1,000.00, dangerous driving and being in possession of stolen property. A Provincial Court Judge sentenced him to 5 months closed custody concurrent with a sentence of 9 months open custody which he was serving at the time of his escape. The Crown appealed. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The accused had a lengthy record as a young offender and turned 18 two days after the commission of the last of the offences for which he was being sentenced. 2)The Court substituted a sentence of 12 months closed custody, concurrent with the 9 months open custody which he was already serving.
column3: The Crown appealed the disposition of a young offender, who pled guilty to four Criminal Code offences following his guilty plea to four criminal Code offences. HELD: The Court of Appeal reduced the sentence to 5 months closed custody and 1 year secure custody, concurrent to the 9 month open custody sentence. 1)The offender had been involved in a series of offences. He had been convicted of sexual assault, five counts of sexual assaults, five count of theft or possession of stolen property and four counts of failure to comply or to appear. 2)The Crown had appealed the sentence imposed on the offender following his plea to 4 Criminal Code charges. 3)The Court of Queen's Bench had previously upheld the sentence of 5 months open custody and one year secure and 1/2 year secure.
column4: Appeal Allowed: The Crown appealed the disposition imposed on B.D.L., a young offender, following his guilty plea to four Criminal Code offences. For these offences, B.D.L. received, in total, a five months closed custody disposition on October 17, 1994 concurrent to a nine month open custody disposition previously imposed on September 17, 1994. We are all of the view, having regard for the age of the offender, his previous record and the nature of the offences committed, notably the escape custody and dangerous driving, that a five month secure custody disposition, concurrent to an existing disposition, was not fit. Accordingly, the disposition of five months is set aside and one year secure custody, again concurrent to the nine month open custody sentence, substituted.

column2: The 21 year old appealed his conviction of armed robbery, the sentence of three years imprisonment and a ten year s.100 order. HELD: The conviction appeal was dismissed, the sentence appeal was allowed and one year incarceration with a ten year s100 order were imposed. The Crown was correct in characterizing the incident as technically a robbery which was at the low end of the scale of seriousness. What originally would have been a shop-lifting became more serious because of the altercation between the clerk and the appellant.
column3: The 21 year old appellant appeals his conviction on a charge of armed robbery pursuant to ss. 343(d) and 344 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to three years imprisonment and a ten year s. 100 order. HELD: The appeal against conviction was dismissed. The Crown conceded the incident was technically a robbery and was at the low end of the scale of seriousness. The appeal was allowed and a sentence of 1 year incarceration was imposed along with a ten-year s.100 order. 1)The Crown conceded this was a 'technically robbery' and was 'at the low' end of a scale of serious. 2)The sentence appeal was granted and a reduction sentence to 1 year imprisonment with a 10 year s100 order was imposed.
column4: Appeal as to conviction dismissed: December 10, 1996 (orally) LANE J.A. The 21 year old appellant appeals his conviction on a charge of armed robbery pursuant to ss. 343(d) and 344 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to three years imprisonment and a ten year s. 100 order. We are all of the view the Crown is correct in characterizing the incident as “technically a robbery”. The appeal against conviction is therefore dismissed. We also agree with the Crown the robbery was at the low end on a scale of seriousness and what originally would have been a simple shop-lifting became more serious because of the altercation between the clerk and the appellant. The conviction appeal is therefore dismissed, the sentence appeal is allowed and a sentence of one year incarceration is imposed along with a ten year section 100 order.

column2: The parties separated shortly after relocating from the United States to Nova Scotia. As part of the divorce, the Supreme Court ordered a division of assets. Both parties appealed the asset division; in the process, both parties sought to introduce fresh evidence. The wife also questioned the level of assistance offered by the trial judge to the husband who was self-represented at trial. Appeal and cross-appeal dismissed with the exception that the wife is to be given immediate access to her personal belongings; both applications to introduce fresh evidence dismissed; on the sparse record before him, the trial judge did not err in his division of assets and did not offer the husband unwarranted assistance as a self- represented litigant. Faced with two competing claims as to the amount of the proceeds of sale, if any, of one of the parties' properties, the trial judge committed no error in finding the amount owed to be half-way between the two claims and then setting it off against the amount owed to the other party.
column3: The parties were divorced in 1994. They purchased a home in Nova Scotia. The wife took issue with the division of assets. She alleged that the judge rendered too much assistance to the husband. The husband also cross-appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1)The Court found that the amount owed for the sale of the Chicago property was approximately half-way between what the parties were owed and what the appellant was claiming was owed. 2)The court found that in the circumstances the judge had underestimated the value of the assets and thus had no reversible error. 3)The judge committed no reversible errors in finding the amount owing for the proceeds was approximately a half-point between what was owed to the appellant and what was actually owed. 4)The evidence was found to be of sufficient relevance to the issues at trial.
column4: Held: Appeal and cross-appeal dismissed without costs, per reasons for judgment of MacDonald, C.J.N.S.; Freeman and Fichaud, JJ.A. concurring. I would dismiss both the appeal and the cross-appeal without costs. [37] Ms. Murphy asserts that the judge offered too much assistance to Mr. Wulkowicz as a self-represented litigant. I disagree. In this context I conclude that the judge in guiding Mr. Wulkowicz did no more than was necessary to ensure that the trial proceeded fairly and efficiently. [39] Except for Ms. Murphy’s claim to access her personal belongings, I would dismiss her appeal. I would dismiss his appeal. [41] Aside from a direction that Ms. Murphy be given immediate access to her personal belongings, I would dismiss both the appeal and the cross-appeal in the circumstances without costs.

column2: The respondent applies for an order varying the custody order by changing the primary residence from the petitioner to the respondent. HELD: 1) The present circumstances are remarkably similar to the circumstances in Bzowey v. Bzowey, 2005 SKQB 12. In both cases, the Court is asked to make the change based solely on the wishes of the child. There is even evidence from the custody and access report from 2005 that the children, or at least the older child, Jill, expressed similar sentiments about living with her mother. It cannot even be strenuously argued that the wishes of the child, Jill, have in fact changed. Those considerations were before the Court in the form of the custody and access report when the decision was made in 2005. 2) The Court should be loathe to make a variation order solely on the expressed wishes of a child of 11 or 12 years of age without some evidence as to why that current expression of interest has been stated. It may well be that the child truly does wish a change. It may also be that the child, as was referred to in the custody and access report, may be simply reflecting the views and therefore the pressures placed on the child by the non-custodial parent. 3) No evidence has been put forward about the negative impact of the continuation of the current order. There is no information before the Court to suggest that the current situation is no longer in the best interests of the children. No material change has been demonstrated. The application is dismissed.
column3: The father brought an application for an order varying the child support order granted by the court. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)There was no evidence that the change in circumstances had affected the child's needs or ability to meet those needs. 2)No material change was demonstrated. 3)The court found that no material change had been demonstrated.

column2: The defendant council, charged with the general oversight and administration of matters under the Natural Products Marketing Act, delegated certain authority to commodity boards such as the plaintiff. The plaintiff requested that the defendant hold a show cause hearing to determine whether certain producers had contravened their licence but when a procedural breakdown occurred as to how that hearing would be conducted, with the plaintiff seeking and being denied an adjournment, the hearing was held without the plaintiff's participation. The plaintiff brought an application for mandamus to compel the defendant to hold a new hearing and filed two affidavits providing some detail and background information as to its reasoning for its failure to attend the hearing and the parties' differing positions regarding their respective roles in the application of the management plan. The defendant brought an application to strike certain of the affidavits filed by the plaintiff on the basis that they were an attempt to put evidence to the court on matters not forming part of the record. Application to strike affidavits dismissed; the Rules do not preclude the admission of affidavits on an application and, in the present circumstances, reason and fairness militated against ruling the affidavits inadmissible. There was no authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits should this application proceed as a jurisdictional dispute and, should it proceed by way of an error of law on the face of the record, the affidavits were also admissible to complete the record.
column3: The applicant board applied to have the affidavits of the applicant board's president and president struck out as an attempt to put evidence to the Court on matters not in or forming part of the Record of the Council. The applicant sought to have two affidavits struck as evidence of the Board's failure to attend the hearing and for their differing positions regarding their respective roles in the management plan. The Board had refused to appear at the hearing because their request for adjournment had been denied. The plaintiff appealed the decision and the parties put forth the proposition that it is improper to introduce “facts” by way of affidavit evidence in a judicial review proceeding, especially in an application for certiorari. The issue is procedural, it is being argued that the reception of the two affidavit into evidence would be inappropriate and contrary to case precedent. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The affidavits were admissible but not admissible to complete the records. 2)The Court was not able to determine whether the affidavit were admissable to complete records. 3)The issue was whether affidavit evidence is admissible on an application to certiorar. The issues were whether affidavits should be struck on an applications for cert. 4)The applicant Board had failed to attend a hearing on matters set out in the Notice. The Court was unable to determine the Board’s position on the management plans. The affidavits did not appear on the record.
column4: [7] The Board made a further application Inter Partes (S.K. 277508) seeking writs of certiorari and mandamus requiring the Council to hold a new hearing. The Applicants seek to have the affidavits of Sonya Lorette, dated January 22nd, 2007 (in aid of SK 276502) and February 9th, 2007 (in aid of SK 277508), struck out as an attempt to put evidence to the Court on matters not in or forming part of the Record of the Council Panel in its adjudicative setting. [18] If I review this present application as a jurisdictional dispute (which seems to be the position of all parties). [22] The application to strike the two affidavits is denied for all the above reasons.

The applicant board had refused to appear at the hearing because their request for adjournment had been denied, leaving council with no decision to make. The board applied for declaratory judgment, which granted the board certiorari and mandamus, and ordered that the affidavit evidence be struck out. The court found that the affidavit evidence was not admissible on the basis of an error of law on the face of the record and that the error must appear. The issue was procedural, it was being argued that the reception of the two affidavits into evidence would be inappropriate and contrary to case precedent. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The affidavits were admissable to complete the records. 2)If the Court reviewed the present application as a jurisdictional dispute (which seems to be the position of all parties), it would not find authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits. 3)If it was to be denied on the grounds of error of a law on a face-of-the-record, affidavit evidence is admissible but is not admissible to complete records. 4)The issue was whether affidavits are admissible in an application for certiorar. If so, the quotation does not form authority for denial of the use.

column13: The applicant board brought an application to have the affidavits of two of the applicant board members struck out as an attempt to put evidence to the Court on matters not in or forming part of the Record of the Council Panel in its adjudicative setting. The applicant board had refused to appear at the hearing because their request for adjournment had been denied, leaving council with no decision to make. In its original application (S.K. No. 276502), the Board sought declaratory judgment raising these questions: 1) does the board have jurisdiction to hold a hearing on an application for certiorari; and 2) if it does, is it admissible to show that the record was incomplete, as for instance, that the conviction omitted the evidence of one of the witnesses; and if it is to be denied on the basis of error of law on the face of the record, affidavit evidence is admissable to complete the records. The issue is procedural, it is being argued that the reception of the two affidavits into evidence would be inappropriate and contrary to case precedent. The Board made a further application pursuant to Civil Procedure Rules 14.25(1) and 38.11 to have these affidavits struck. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The affidavits were admissible but not inadmissible. 2)If the Court reviewed the present application as a jurisdictional dispute (which seems to be the position of all parties), this quotation does not form authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits. On the other hand, if it was to be granted on the ground of want of jurisdiction, or bias, or fraud, affidavits are admissible. 3)The issue was procedural. The Court could not restrict itself to considering the record as produced by the tribunal. 4)It was not necessary to substitute its own views for those of the tribunal, as the tribunal leaves it to the tribunal to hear the case again and in proper case, may command it to do so. 5)The Court had no authority to deny the parties access to the record.

HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The affidavits were admissable to complete the records. 2)If the Court reviewed the present application as a jurisdictional dispute (which seems to be the position of all parties), it would not find authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits. 3)If it was to be denied on the grounds of error of a law on a face-of-the-record, affidavit evidence is admissible but is not admissible to complete records. 4)The issue was whether affidavits are admissible in an application for certiorar. If so, the quotation does not form authority for denial of the use.

column2: The defendant obtained a tender to bank, blend and load coal at the plaintiff's coal preparation plant. In performing the contract, the defendant experienced equipment problems resulting in the plaintiff having to rent other equipment. The plaintiff terminated the contract without any prior warning or notice to the defendant and brought an action for reimbursement of monies advanced under the contract and expenses incurred for the equipment rentals. The defendant counter-claimed for damages arising out of the termination of the contract, for services performed under the contract and for extras which had not been paid. The court found that the plaintiff was entitled to reimbursement for overpayments and equipment rentals and that the defendant was entitled to fair and reasonable compensation for extras for which the court awarded the sum of $10,000. Both parties were found to be in breach of the contract, the plaintiff's breach occurring because the volumes of coal supplied did not approximate the tonnages represented in the contractual documents. The clause excluding liability for errors in the forecast did not excuse the plaintiff because the actual volumes were not even approximate to the forecasted tonnages and the rates bid by the defendant were directly related to the anticipated tonnages. Absent evidence as to how the plaintiff arrived at the information used in the calculation of the forecasted tonnages, no negligent misrepresentation could be found, as there was no evidence that the information was negligently obtained. Both parties appealed. Appeal and cross-appeal dismissed; the trial judge's finding that the defendant had fundamentally breached its contractual obligations which entitled the plaintiff to terminate the contract without notice should not be disturbed; thus, the trial judge did not err in awarding the plaintiff damages for the defendant's breach of contract. The defendant did not establish that the plaintiff had been negligent in making the tonnage estimates and thus, the judge did not err in dismissing the defendant's claim for negligent misrepresentation. Although the trial judge found that the plaintiff had also committed a fundamental breach of the contract (in failing to provide the approximate tonnages referred to in the contract), the defendant had not chosen to terminate the contract and the plaintiff's breach did not undermine its right to terminate the contract as a result of the defendant's breach.
column3: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant to handle the banking, blending and lifting of coal at its coal preparation plant. The defendant sued, claiming damages for breach of contract, negligent misstatement and breach of the contract. The plaintiff cross-appealed, claiming that the defendant had not performed the contract and that it was not entitled to rely on the exclusion of liability provisions in it. The trial judge awarded the plaintiff $270,307.05 in damages. The award of $10,000 was awarded to the plaintiff. The court found that the plaintiff had not breached the contract by failing to perform and that the trial judge did not hold that the Defendant's own breach of a contract in any way undermined its right to terminate the contract as a result of Roper's breach. The plaintiffs cross-claimed in negligent misstatements and in assessing damages as he did. The judge found that there was nothing inherently wrong with the plaintiff's equipment. The only issue was whether the continued activities at these tracks entitled the plaintiff to some reimbursement for any additional cost or expenses incurred by the continued use of these tracks. The jury found that both parties had breached the contracts and that they could not rely on an exclusion of the liability clause. The Court awarded the defendant $10 million in damages for the costs incurred by Devco in obtaining substituted performance of the contracts. The Judge also awarded $10k damages to the defendant.
column4: Held: Appeal and cross-appeal dismissed per reasons for judgment of Cromwell, J.A.; Oland and Hamilton, JJ.A. concurring. [6] In my view, the appeal should be dismissed. It is, therefore, not necessary to address the issues raised by cross-appeal and it, too, should be dismissed. [35] A “fundamental breach” of the contract by Devco would have given Roper the right to terminate the contract, but Roper did not do so. The trial judge did not hold that Devco’s own breach of contract in any way undermined its right to terminate the contract as a result of Roper’s breach. I reject this submission for two reasons. Any breach by Devco, therefore, did not undermine Devco’s ability to terminate the contract as a result of Roper’s breach. [76] I would dismiss the appeal with costs fixed at $5,000.00 plus disbursements. I would dismiss the cross-appeal without costs.

column2: HELD: The application was granted. The court ordered the removal of the respondent as an executor in the grant of probate and ordered that the applicants remain as executors but that they should take no further steps to distribute the assets of the estate. It found that there were “special circumstances” within the meaning of s. 17 of The Administration of Estates Act. The respondent was entitled to challenge the validity of the will but not entitled to remain as an executor.
column3: The applicants sought to remove the respondent as executor of their estate. They argued that the respondent was refusing to co-operate in the administration of the estate and was not entitled at the same time to remain as an executor. The respondent brought an application challenging the validity of the Will he was presently an executrator of. The application was brought by the respondent's nephew and the executor's sister. The applicant brought an originating application seeking, inter alia, an order removing the respondent from the position of executor and removing him as an inter executor pursuant to the grant of probate. The applicants sought a revocation of the grant and an order that the executors be proven in solemn form and related relief. The executors were to continue as executors pursuant to that grant. The court ordered that the applicant be removed as an agent of the will and that the three executors of the respondent be removed from the office of executors. The Court ordered that he be removed by the court as an acting executor in the grant granted to them in respect of the deceased's Will. The judge deciding the application could extend the direction.
column7: HELD: The application was granted. column8: FIAT: The applicants seek to remove the respondent as an executor of the estate of the deceased. The respondent is a nephew of the late Ms. Jones and is refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will of Edna May Jones as admitted to probate. HELD: 1)The respondent is removed as executor in the grant of probate ordered by Gabrielson J. on July 20, 2016 and he is not entitled at the same time to remain as an estate executor. 2)The applicant is entitled to challenge the validity of the Will, as he has done in his application, but he isn't entitled at that time to stay as executors of the will. Unless and until the grant is set aside and proof in solemn form is ordered by this Court, the grant will remain operative and carries with it the obligation of the executors to continue to administer in accordance with the directions. 3)The court ordered that the respondent be removed as a executor and that he be removed from the position of trustee.

column13: FIAT: The applicants seek to remove the respondent as an executor of the estate of Edna May Jones. Their grounds are that the respondent has brought an application that effectively challenges the validity of the Will he is presently in and he is refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will. Unless and until the grant of probate is set aside and proof in solemn form is ordered by the Court, the application will be dismissed and the respondent is not entitled at the same time to remain as executor. HELD: The application is dismissed.  1)The Court has the jurisdiction to remove an executrator of an estate both pursuant to its inherent jurisdiction and pursuant to s. 17 of The Administration of Estates Act. While there is dissension or disagreement between the executors and the parties involved, the granting of a probate remains operative and carries with it the obligation of the executor to continue to administer a estate in accordance with the directions. 2)The respondent is entitled to challenge the validity and the Will while he has done in his application but he isn't entitled at that time to stay as executors of that Will.  3)There is no evidence before me that either of Kent or Rodney have acted contrary to their obligations to administer this estate. If they have, they will continue to properly do their duty.
column17: HELD: The application was granted. The court ordered the removal of the respondent as an executor in the grant of probate and ordered that the applicants remain as executors but that they should take no further steps to distribute the assets of the estate. It found that there were “special circumstances” within the meaning of s. 17 of The Administration of Estates Act. The respondent was entitled to challenge the validity of the will but not entitled to remain as an executor.
column18: FIAT: The applicants apply to have the respondent removed as an executor of an estate pursuant to a grant of probate and an order that the Will be proven in solemn form and relief. column2: HELD: The application was granted. The judgment was set aside and the defendant given leave to file its statement of defence. The court found that the judgment should be set aside as a matter of right because it was in excess of the amount due. The judgment was also set aside on the merits. It found that the time between service of the statement of claim and the default judgment was not sufficiently long to prevent the defendant from defending the action. As well, the defendant had provided an arguable defence to the claim in that it pled in its proposed defence of non-compliance with s. 2(3)(b) of the Indian Act. The delay had not caused the plaintiff irreparable harm.
column3: FIAT: The plaintiff obtained a default judgment against the defendant, The Key First Nation. The plaintiff sought costs on the basis that the default judgment was set aside ex debito justitiae. The defendant applied to set aside the default judgement on the grounds that it was too long for the court to prevent the plaintiff from defending the action. HELD: The application was granted. The court found that the delay had not caused irreparable harm, and the plaintiff demonstrated an arguable defence to Sollows' claim. The Court held that a time frame of 28 days is sufficiently long for a court to deprive the plaintiff of defending the actions. The time frame from March 2016 to March 2018 is a total of 723 days, not 725 days. The date Sollow's counsel responded to the action soon after default judgment had been entered is July 19, 2018. The application is granted. Costs shall follow the cause.
column4: [2] Pursuant to Rule 10-13 of The Queen’s Bench Rules, Key’s counsel now applies to set aside that default judgment and seeks leave to file defence in the form of the draft filed with the court July 19, 2018. As a matter of right, Key is entitled to have the default judgment set aside. [5] In exercising my judicial discretion under Rule 10-13, I must also conclude that Key is entitled to have the default judgment set aside on its merits. [16] I cannot accept that a time frame of 28 days is sufficiently long for the court to prevent Key from defending the action. [21] In short, I find that the delay has not caused Sollows irreparable harm, and Key has demonstrated an arguable defence to Sollows’ claim. This is an appropriate situation to exercise the judicial discretion provided by Rule 10-13 and set aside Sollows’ default judgment. Key is granted leave to serve and file its Statement of Defence, in the form of the draft filed July 19, 2018. [23] The application is granted.

column8: FIAT. The plaintiff obtained a default judgment against the defendant, The Key First Nation, totalling $102,703.62 plus costs of $1,598.50. The defendant held funds seized under the enforcement proceedings following the entering of the default judgment. Sollows' counsel applied to set aside that default judgment on the basis that it was too long for the court to prevent the plaintiff from defending the action. HELD: The application was granted and the plaintiff was granted leave to file a Statement of Defence. Costs were to follow the cause. 1)The plaintiff had not demonstrated an arguable defence to its claim. The delay had not caused irreparable harm, and the defendant had demonstrated an argumentable defence to the plaintiff's claim. 2)The defendant was warned that a time frame of 28 days was sufficiently long for it to prevent it from defending its action. The time frame from March 22, 2016 to March 15, 2018 is total of 723 days, not 725 days. The trial judge calculated two extra days of interest on one of the invoices. He calculated 2 extra days interest at $8.54. This time frame is 7 days past the date the action for default was entered. Given that the defendant's then counsel responded to the action soon after default judgment was entered, this delay was insufficient to deny the plaintiff its day in court. 3)In exercising judicial discretion under Rule 10-13, the applicable principles in considering Rule 10 are the same as the former Rule 346. The fundamental principle relevant to the exercise of judicial discretion in these cases is that it is necessary to ensure that the application of the Court's rules and principles does not violate the principles of fundamental justice and equity. The logic and the law relating to ostensible authority cannot supplant this clear statutory direction as to how and when band councillors are entitled to make decisions. 4)The court cannot accept a time period of 28 day for the Court to prevent a defendant from defending his action.

column2: The respondents were charged with possession for the purposes of trafficking and cultivation of marijuana, contrary to s. 4(2) and 6(2) of the Narcotic Control Act. RCMP had investigated a tip that a large crop of marijuana plants was being grown on a private property located in a clearing off a woods road. They did not have a search warrant to enter the property, and arrested the respondents after observing them care for the plants. At trial, the court held their right to be secure from unreasonable search and seizure had been violated, and acquitted them. The Crown appealed the acquittal. Per Roscoe, J.A., Chipman, J.A. concurring, allowing the appeal and ordering a new trial, that there was no s. 8 breach because the respondents did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the field where the marijuana crop was growing. The court reviewed case law regarding 'open fields', and 'uncultivated' lands, and adopted the reasoning in Oliver v. United States, 104 S.Ct.1735(1984) in reaching its conclusion. Per Pugsley, J.A., dissenting, dismissing the appeal, that the respondents had a reasonable expectation of privacy in activities carried on by them on their private property. As there were no exigent circumstances, the search was not reasonable and the evidence should be excluded.
column3: The respondents were charged with possession for the purposes of trafficking and cultivation of marijuana contrary to s. 4(2) and s. 6(2)(b) of the Narcotic Control Act. At trial, the trial judge found that the respondents had not a reasonable expectation of privacy in the clearing where the marijuana plants were growing and therefore there was no breach of their s. 8 Charter rights. He also held that the search of the respondent's property was unlawful and that the warrantless search violated his s.8 Charter rights because it did not disclose personal and confidential information. The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered.
column4: THE COURT: The appeal is allowed and a new trial is ordered as per reasons for judgment of Roscoe, J.A.; Chipman, J.A. concurring and Pugsley, J.A. dissenting. The issues raised by the Crown\'s appeal of the acquittal are: I adopt the reasoning of Justice Powell expressed in Oliver in concluding that the respondents did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the clearing in the woods where the marijuana plants were growing and therefore there was no breach of their s. 8 Charter rights The appeal should therefore be allowed and a new trial ordered. Summary: To summarize, in conclusion, in my view, there was no breach of s. 8 of the Charter because the respondents did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the field where the marijuana crop was growing. Accordingly, the appeal should be allowed and a new trial ordered.

HELD: The appeal was allowed. A new trial was ordered. 1)The court adopted the reasoning of the United States Supreme Court in Katz v. United States (1993) and found that the police acted in good faith, whether it was a technical or inadvertent breach, whether the breach was motivated by urgency to prevent the loss of the evidence and whether the evidence could have been obtained without a Charter violation. 2)The respondent's admission that they 'occupied and possessed' the land at the time of the search went beyond that referred to above and there was also an admission that there was a prima facie breach of s. 10 of the Charter because there were warrantless searches. The warrantless search was unreasonable.
column24: THE COURT: The appeal is allowed and a new trial is ordered as per reasons for judgment of Roscoe, J.A.; Chipman, J.A. concurring and Pugsley, J.A. dissenting. The issues raised by the Crown\'s appeal of the acquittal are: I adopt the reasoning of Justice Powell expressed in Oliver in concluding that the respondents did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the clearing in the woods where the marijuana plants were growing and therefore there was no breach of their s. 8 Charter rights The appeal should therefore be allowed and a new trial ordered. Summary: To summarize, in conclusion, in my view, there was no breach of s. 8 of the Charter because the respondents did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the field where the marijuana crop was growing. Accordingly, the appeal should be allowed and a new trial ordered.
column27: The respondents were charged with possession for the purposes of trafficking and cultivation of marijuana contrary to s. 4(2) and s. 6 of the Narcotic Control Act. At the commencement of their trial in Supreme Court, after the jury selection, a voir dire was held to determine the admissibility of evidence obtained by the police as result of the seizure of marijuana plants. The respondents argued that they did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the clearing where the marijuana plants were growing and therefore there was no breach of their s. 8 Charter rights. The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered.

column2: Following the close of the Crown's case on a trial of several weapons related offences, the defence moved for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence that the offences occurred on the date alleged in the Information. The Crown sought to amend the Information to change the date of the offences. Without ruling on the motion to amend, the trial judge granted the motion for a directed verdict. The Crown appealed. Appeal allowed; acquittals set aside; new trial ordered. The directed verdict should not have been granted as, in this case, the date of the offences was not an essential element of the offences. If the directed verdict was not based on the discrepancy with the date, than the appeal would have to be allowed on the basis that the trial judge gave insufficient reasons which prejudiced the Crown's right of appeal.
column3: The Crown appeals from acquittals entered by Judge Sherar of the Provincial Court on five charges relating to the possession and storage of prohibited weapons. The accused brought a motion for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence of one of the elements of the offence, that is, the date of the offences as alleged in the Information. Crown counsel applied to amend the Information with respect to the date and entered acquittal on all charges. The trial judge granted the motion for directed verdict based on the discrepancy between the date the accused was alleged to have been found and the evidence presented at trial because the date was not an essential element of the accused's evidence. The Crown argued that the trial judge erred by granting the motion based on a discrepancy between what the accused alleged in Information and the actual evidence presented. The court found that the error of law was reversible. The appeal was allowed and the acquittallals were set aside and a new trial ordered.

[21] The appeal is accordingly allowed, the acquittals are set aside and a new trial is ordered.

column8: The Crown appeals from acquittals entered by Judge Sherar of the Provincial Court on five charges relating to the possession and storage of prohibited weapons. The Crown brought a motion for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence of one of the elements of the offence, that is, the date of the offences as alleged in the Information. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The trial judge erred by granting the motion for directed verdict based on the discrepancy between the date the offence was alleged to have been committed and the evidence presented at trial because the date was not an essential element. 2)Criminal law provides for an error of law in giving reasons for a decision. The trial judge made an error in the fact that he did not consult the evidence properly. 3)The evidence presented by the Crown was not sufficient to meet the required test of reliability. 4)The court found that the trial judge had erred in giving the wrong reasons for granting a motion. 5)The Court found that if a trial judge granted a motion based on a discrepancy between a date of alleged offence alleged in Information and evidence presented, there was an error. The Court found the trial court erred on the ground that the evidence was not material with respect to (a) the time when the offence is alleged to be committed, if it was proved that the indictment was preferred within the prescribed period of limitation, if any; or (b) the date for the directed verdict was too late to amend. 6)The appeal was allowed with reasons to follow.

column13: The Crown appeals from acquittals entered by Judge Sherar of the Provincial Court on five charges relating to the possession and storage of prohibited weapons. The Crown brought a motion for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence of one of the elements of the offence, that is, the date of offence as alleged in the Information. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The trial judge erred in allowing the directed verdict motion even in the absence of an amendment and that the date was not the only insufficiency. 2)The evidence presented by the Crown was not sufficient to meet the required test, whether there was any evidence upon which a reasonable jury, properly instructed could return a verdict of guilty. 3)The court found that the trial judge had erred by granting the motion for directed verdict based on the discrepancy between the date the offence was alleged to have been committed and the evidence presented at trial because the date wasn't an essential element. 4)The appeal was allowed. 5)Criminal law provides for an error of law in giving a verdict on a date which is not essential to the offence. 6)The Court erred on the issue of whether the accused had been misled or prejudiced. 7)The reasons for granting a motion were inadequate that they do not meet the test for sufficiency of reasons. The trial judge made an error in law. The evidence presented was not material with respect to (a) the time when the offence is alleged to been committed, if it was proved that the indictment was preferred within the prescribed period of limitation, if the reason for the motion was that it was too late to amend, that was a reversible error. 8)The appellant relied on s. 601(4.1) (which pursuant to s. 572 also applies to trials of indictable matters without a jury), which contained the factors that should be taken into consideration on an amendment application.

column18: The Crown appeals from acquittals entered by Judge Sherar of the Provincial Court on five charges relating to the possession and storage of prohibited weapons. The Crown brought a motion for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence of one of the elements of the offence, that is, the date of offence as alleged in the Information. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The trial judge erred in allowing the directed verdict motion even in the absence of an amendment and in failing to grant the motion to amend. 2)The evidence presented by the Crown was not sufficient to meet the required test, whether there was any evidence upon which a reasonable jury, properly instructed could return a verdict of guilty. 3)Criminal law provides for reasons for an error in law, including whether the accused has been misled or prejudiced. 4)The reasons for granting the motion were so inadequate that they did not meet the test for sufficiency of reasons because they do not provide any indication of why there was insufficient evidence.  5)The appeal was allowed. 6)The Court reviewed the evidence presented at trial and found that it was not necessary to amend the Information because the date was not an essential element. If the reason for the motion was too late to amend, that was also a reversible error of law.

column23: The Crown appeals from acquittals entered by Judge Sherar of the Provincial Court on five charges relating to the possession and storage of prohibited weapons. The Crown brought a motion for a directed verdict on the basis that there was no evidence of one of the elements of the offence, that is, the date of offence as alleged in the Information. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The trial judge erred in allowing the directed verdict motion even in the absence of an amendment. There was no suggestion that the amendment of the date would mislead or cause prejudice or injustice to the accused. 2)The evidence presented by the Crown was not sufficient to meet the required test, whether there was any evidence upon which a reasonable jury, properly instructed could return a verdict of guilty. 3)Criminal law provides for an error of law in giving reasons for a delay in a trial. In this case, the delay was due to the fact that the trial judge had not specifically ruled on the motion to amend, granted the defence motion and entered acquittal on all charges.  4)The appeal was allowed. 5)The Court erred by granting the motion for directed verdict based on the discrepancy between the time of the alleged to have been committed and the evidence presented at trial because the date was not an essential element of the offences. 6)The reasons for granting a direct verdict were inadequate that they do not meet the test for sufficiency of reasons. If the motion was granted on a basis of insufficiency of evidence, the reasons are inadequate and if the reason for the ordered verdict was that it was too late to amend that was also a reversible error.
