column2: The accused were both charged with assault contrary to s. 266. The complainant admitted that he threw the first punch but said that he did so because the male accused had already broken the windows in his car and punched his passenger and was not 'coming to apologize.' HELD: The accused were convicted of assault. Whether the physical altercation was precipitated by jealousy or a drug deal, there is no doubt that the accused was the aggressor throughout. He smashed one, if not two, car windows. The accused's behaviour was threatening and the Court accepted that the accused had not attended the house to apologize. The complainant took necessary and lawful action to protect himself and his family under s. 37 of the Criminal Code.  While the Court did not believe that either complainant used a weapon, if it did occur it would have been justified in the context of the assault. The accused was acquitted of mischief because the Crown failed to prove the value of the broken windows.
column3: The accused were charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. The accused were both charged with wilful damage to the car contrary to ss. 430(4) and s. 430 (4) of the Code. HELD: The accused are both guilty of assault upon the complainant contrary to the Criminal code. The physical altercation in this case was precipitated by jealousy or by a drug deal gone bad. The actions of the accused were aggressive. The defendant smashed in one, if not two, car windows. The complainant said that she felt threatened. The two accused were driving around the trailer park when the altercation occurred. The third accused, who was driving his mother's car, was also charged with assaulting the complainant. The second count was wilful damages to the windows.
column4: [1] Jeremy Angelo Mayer (Mayer) and Aimee Lynn Dagenais (Dagenais) are charged on separate informations with assaulting Jared McIntyre contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. [20] Whether the physical altercation in this case was precipitated by jealousy or by a drug deal gone bad, there is no doubt that Mayer was the aggressor throughout. This was threatening behaviour and I believe McIntyre when he said that he felt threatened. DECISION [25] I find both the accused guilty of assault upon McIntyre contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. There being no evidence of an essential element of the offence, I find Mayer not guilty of the second count on information 24414281.

The damage was caused by a fistfight between the accused and the complainant. The complainant claimed that the altercation was precipitated by jealousy or by a drug deal gone bad. The two accused were the aggressors throughout. The defendant smashed in one, if not two, car windows while the complainant was in the trailer. The assault was threatening behaviour and the accused were not there to apologize. The Crown was unable to prove the cost of repairing the windows was under $5,000. The second count was dismissed on information 24414281.

HELD: The accused were convicted of assault. Whether the physical altercation was precipitated by jealousy or a drug deal, there is no doubt that the accused was the aggressor throughout. He smashed one, if not two, car windows. The accused's behaviour was threatening and the Court accepted that the accused had not attended the house to apologize. The complainant took necessary and lawful action to protect himself and his family under s. 37 of the Criminal Code.  While the Court did not believe that either complainant used a weapon, if it did occur it would have been justified in the context of the assault. The accused was acquitted of mischief because the Crown failed to prove the value of the broken windows.
column13: HELD: The Court found both accused guilty of assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. The accused were both charged with wilful damage to the car. The damage was done to the vehicle from the altercation between the accused and the complainant. The complainant claimed that he and the accused were involved in a fistfight and that the altercation was precipitated by jealousy or by a drug deal gone bad. The two accused argued that they were the aggressors throughout and that they had smashed in one, if not two, car windows. Both accused admitted to breaking the rear window of the vehicle. The Crown was unable to prove the cost of repairing the windows was under $5,000. The Court also found the accused not guilty of the first count on information 24414281. The second count was also dismissed.
column14: [1] Jeremy Angelo Mayer (Mayer) and Aimee Lynn Dagenais (Dagenais) are charged on separate informations with assaulting Jared McIntyre contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. [20] Whether the physical altercation in this case was precipitated by jealousy or by a drug deal gone bad, there is no doubt that Mayer was the aggressor throughout. This was threatening behaviour and I believe McIntyre when he said that he felt threatened. There being no evidence of an essential element of the offence, I find Mayer not guilty of the second count on information 24414281.

The actions of the accused were aggressive. The defendant smashed in one, if not two, car windows. The complainant said that she felt threatened. The two accused were driving around the trailer park when the altercation occurred. The third accused, who was driving his mother's car, was also charged with assaulting the complainant. The second count was wilful damages to the windows.

column2: The appellant was convicted of sexual assault, with the only live issue at trial being whether the Crown had proved the absence of the complainant's consent beyond a reasonable doubt. Appeal dismissed; the judge's reasons disclosed that he applied the reasonable doubt standard to the evidence as a whole; although the reasons for judgment were very brief and open to criticism, they did not preclude meaningful appellate review. The test for legal error in a judge alone case is not the same as would apply to a judge's charge to a jury on the issue of reasonable doubt. It was not an error for the judge to assess the credibility of the appellant in relation to that of the complainant as long as he went on to take the next step, as he did in his 'short-hand reference' to the evidence.
column3: The appellant appealed his sexual assault conviction on the basis that it was unreasonable, was based on misapplication of the burden of proof and that the judge's reasons were so deficient as to constitute an error of law. The appellant agreed with a number of propositions that the court accepted as the Aadmissions@ to which he referred. The judge applied the reasonable doubt standard to the whole of the evidence as he was obliged to do before entering the conviction. The appeal court found that the trial judge erred in his decision to not apply the proper test and therefore did not apply his or her mind to the possibility that despite having rejected the evidence of the appellant, there might nevertheless be a reasonable doubt about his guilt.
column4: Held: Appeal dismissed per reasons for judgment of Cromwell, J.A.; Bateman and Saunders, JJ.A. concurring. [44] I would dismiss the appeal.

column2: A complaint was made in 1991 to the Human Rights Commission that the Gallery could only be entered by stairs and was inaccessible to wheelchair users. A Board of Inquiry appointed under the Saskatchewan Human Rights Code concluded in 1993 that the appellant's complex impeded physical access to the premises, facilities and services and lacked proper amenities for persons who are wheelchair-reliant. The Board specifically ordered it remained seized of the matter and the hearing would be reconvened to hear further evidence. The Court of Queen's Bench confirmed the Gallery continued to discriminate against disabled members of the public by failing to provide access and accessible services and ordered the appellant to construct or renovate washrooms to meet requirements of the National Building Code of Canada. The Court of Appeal set aside the Queen's Bench decision and restored the Board's decision. During those proceedings, the property was transferred to HKR, which undertook further renovations. In 1997 upon request by the Commission, the Board reconvened and concluded there had not been compliance, which was confirmed by the Court of Queen's Bench. This was not appealed. An appeal of the Board's 1998 order to construct or renovate the bathrooms was dismissed and it was found the Board did not err in adding HKR as a party nor exceeded its jurisdiction in finding the appellant had not complied with the original order. The appellant appealed that judgment principally on the ground of error in not finding the Board exceeded its jurisdiction in making the order as the original order did not include a requirement that it construct wheelchair accessible washrooms. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with costs on double Column V. The Queen's Bench judge did not err in finding the appellant could not, at that stage of proceedings, question the original order made by the Board in 1993 (ordering the appellant to cease impeding physical access to the premises, facilities and services). The issue had been previously determined and the order was reinstated by the Court of Appeal. The Board acted entirely within the terms of its original order. It retained jurisdiction to confirm compliance. The original order cannot be challenged at this late date.
column3: The appellant appeals a decision of the Saskatchewan Human Rights Commission confirming the second decision of Board of Inquiry appointed by the Minister of Justice under The Saskatchewan Human rights Code. The appellant contended that the original order did not include a requirement that it construct washrooms which were accessible to wheelchair reliant members of the public. HELD: The appeal is dismissed with cost on double Column V. The Board acted entirely within the terms of its original order, an order in which it had retained jurisdiction, to confirm compliance with the order and which had been confirmed by the Court of Appeal. The extent of the order, that is whether it was confined to external access of the property or to other 'facilities and services', and whether it had been complied with is the very question the Board reserved jurisdiction to determine. The original order cannot be challenged at this late date. The board acted entirely outside the terms and the terms thereof and confirmed compliance with it and confirmed its jurisdiction to the Court. The appeal cannot be brought on the basis that the Board erred in failing to find that the appellant had not complied with the original Order. The decision of Matheson J. did not err in so finding. The Court was all of the opinion that Mathesons J. acted entirely in the terms, that of an order, which it retained jurisdiction and confirmed the compliance with, and which was confirmed by this Court.
column4: Appeal Dismissed: The appellant appeals contending that the Board exceeded its jurisdiction in making the order that it did. [8] On May 29, 1998, the Board ordered that the appellant “construct or renovate bathrooms for both sexes, or a single washroom provided that it can be used by both sexes in accordance with public health and building regulations, which meet all the accessibility requirements of the National Building Code”. He found that the Board did not err in adding the company HRK Collections Fine Art Limited as a party and did not exceed its jurisdiction in finding that the appellant had not complied with its original order. The appellant contended that the original order did not include a requirement that it construct washrooms which were accessible to wheelchair reliant members of the public. The Board acted entirely within the terms of its original order, an order in which it had retained jurisdiction, to confirm compliance with the order and which had been confirmed by this Court. [14] In the result the appeal is dismissed with cost on double Column V.

column8: The appellant appeals the decision of the Board of Inquiry appointed by the Minister of Justice under The Saskatchewan Human Rights Code which found that the appellant continued to discriminate against disabled members of the public by failing to provide access and accessible services to wheelchair users and ordered the appellant to construct or renovate washrooms to meet accessibility requirements of the National Building Code. column12: A complaint was made in 1991 to the Human Rights Commission that the Gallery could only be entered by stairs and was inaccessible to wheelchair users. column2: A single vehicle accident occurred when the driver swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway. An action was brought against both the driver and the farmer who owned the land on both sides of the highway on the basis that the farmer owned the dog in question and was negligent in failing to keep it off the highway. The farmer contended that although he owned a dog, it was tied to a tree at the time and his was not the dog that had run onto the highway. When his application for summary judgment was dismissed, the farmer appealed. Appeal dismissed. At this stage of the proceedings, it was not necessary for the plaintiffs to prove that the defendant's dog contributed to the accident or the truth of the statements and evidence attached to the affidavit. It was only necessary to show that the facts were contested, there was some evidence to support their version of events and, if their evidence was accepted by the trier of fact, their action had some merit. Although the judge appeared to blur the two parts of the test on a summary judgment application, the Court found that the farmer failed to meet the first part of the test; namely, that there was no genuine issue of fact for trial as there was conflicting evidence as to the identity of the dog involved.
column3: The plaintiff and his sister, who were killed in an automobile accident, sued the defendants for negligence in the ownership and operation of the vehicle. The defendants brought an action against the defendants alleging negligence in failing to keep the dog off the highway. The plaintiff claimed that he swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway in front of the car. The chambers judge admitted and relied on the affidavit of the plaintiff's lawyer. The plaintiffs did not have to prove the truth of the statements and evidence attached to the affidavit. The court dismissed the application with costs. The Chambers judge did not err in his decision to blur the two parts of the test. The applicants did not need to prove that the statements were true or that they were evidence. The issue was whether the plaintiffs had proven the truth or if their evidence was accepted by the trier of fact.
column4: Held: Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal is dismissed with costs, per reasons for judgment of Roscoe, J.A.; [1] This is an application for leave to appeal and, if granted, an appeal from an order of Justice Glen G. McDougall dismissing a summary judgment application brought by the defendant, Theodore Hogeterp. [2] On April 18, 1996 a car driven by 16 year old Andrew Larkin veered off the road and struck a power pole on Route 359, Centerville, Nova Scotia. The driver said that he swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway in front of the car. They also named Theodore Hogeterp as a defendant. Mr. Hogeterp was a farmer who owned land on both sides of the road at the site of the accident. The application for summary judgment is therefore dismissed. The order of the chambers judge should be confirmed, although for different reasons. [41] I would grant leave to appeal but dismiss the appeal.

column2: Applicant applies for leave to appeal a Queen's Bench Chambers decision dismissing his application for relief under s.61 of the Queen's Bench Act. HELD: Leave to appeal denied. The respondent has costs at double Column V. The considerations to be applied in a leave to appeal application is 1)whether the issue raised by the proposed appeal is sufficiently important to the litigation before the Court or to the practice in general to warrant consideration by the Court of Appeal. 2)Whether the applicant's proposed submission to the Court of Appeal has sufficient merit to warrant the granting of leave. 3)Whether there is any delay in the proceedings which would be caused by the interjection of an appeal. Here the applicant has misconstrued the mortgage agreement. The applicant still has a right to redeem upon payment. No issue of importance was raised nor did the Court see any merit to the applicant's appeal

column2: The court concluded that the respondent was not a credible, trustworthy, or reliable witness for many reasons. The petitioner, on the other hand, was found to be a truthful and reliable witness. The court was also impressed with the petitioner’s witnesses because they were close family members, long-time friends, and her live-in partner. By contrast, the respondent’s witnesses were friends seen from time to time, neighbours, and his mother. The court found the respondent’s mother to be evasive and guarded at times. To determine custody the court reviewed the factors set out in s. 8 of The Children’s Law Act, 1997. The petitioner was found to be the primary parent of the child since his birth. The court was left with a degree of uncertainty as to the day-to-day activities of the child when he was with the respondent. The quality of the child’s relationship with the petitioner was found to substantially exceed that of the respondent’s relationship with the child. The court accepted that the child said disturbing things upon his return to the petitioner from the respondent. The child’s need for a stable, reassuring, and positive home were found to be met in the petitioner’s home. The court indicated that decreasing the respondent’s time with the child may ameliorate the adverse effect on the child’s emotional needs. The child was also found to be afforded more social fulfillment in the petitioner’s care. The petitioner also had more constructive plans for the child’s future. The respondent’s negativity towards the petitioner was found to negatively impact his ability to parent. The court concluded that it was in the child’s best interests to primarily reside with the petitioner. The petitioner was granted sole custody of the child so as to minimize further conflict between the parties. The respondent was given unsupervised access every other weekend. The court added $5,000 to the petitioner’s line 150 income for the personal component of her vehicle expense deduction. After determining the respondent’s income the court found that the s. 3 Guideline child support due by the respondent to the petitioner was $676 per month and that he should be responsible for 37 percent of the s. 7 expenses. The petitioner did not request child support but instead asked the court to consider it in the distribution of property. The respondent discharged the onus of establishing a common-law relationship of two or more years. The respondent’s pension value available for division was found to be $11,663.97.  The court did not find an extraordinary circumstance to warrant an unequal division of the family home. The value of the home was $360,000. The court used the date of application to determine the amount owing on the home. The petitioner also had rental properties and was given an exemption of $90,641.43 for those properties. After taking into consideration all of the property and exemptions, the respondent failed to prove that he was entitled to any distribution under The Family Property Act. The petitioner did not claim an equalization payment. Costs were awarded to the petitioner and the respondent was restricted from bringing a further court application until those costs were paid.
column3: HELD: The Court ordered interim shared custody of the parties. The parties had been together for four years. The petitioner had previously filed an Answer and Counter-Petition in 2012 contesting the respondent’s claims for sole custody, specified and supervised parenting time, and costs. The respondent had previously been granted interim shared parenting time. The Court found that the parties had not spoken since the parties separated. The court ordered the parties to proceed to an expedited pre-trial conference. The judge ordered the parents to have Z. on a shared week-on-week basis. The mother had moved out of the home and was now living with the petitioner. The father had been receiving Worker’S Compensation benefits and top-up from SaskTel. The wife had moved in with the husband. The husband had been living with his mother for several months. The two parties had reconciled in December 2012. The child had been in the mother’ s house for a few days. The relationship had been going on for some time. HELD: 1)The Court found the parties were not in a relationship. The children had been separated for four months. 2)The parties had a provisional agreement that the child would be in the interim care of the mother. The parents would have access to the mother when the trial could be held. 3)The court found that there was no evidence that the father had physically harmed the child. The evidence did not support the petitioner’d claim. The fact that the mother had physically restrained the child from the father was not sufficient evidence to justify the claim. 4)The evidence did support the parties’ contention that the respondent had physically assaulted the child and that the petitioner had been unable to contact the father. The agreement was not binding on the parties as the child was not a party animal. The only evidence that could be found was that the husband had physically abused the child for several days prior to the birth of the child, and that he had physically threatened the petitioner and her mother.
column4: I will now go through the factors set out in s. 8 of the Act. I find that despite what Mr. S. states, she was the primary parent of Z. since birth and continues to be so. Indeed I learned more (although not much) from his mother’s evidence as to the day-to-day activities. I am left with a degree of uncertainty. I accept that the child expresses these words. The child is in need of a stable, reassuring and positive home. I find that it is best provided in the mother’s home. I am concerned that Z.’s emotional needs have been adversely affected by the conduct of Mr. S. A lessening of Mr. S.’s time with Z. may ameliorate this. [145] Accordingly I am persuaded that Z. is afforded far more social fulfillment when in his mother’s care. I find that this adversely reflects upon Mr. S.’s ability to parent. [165] Therefore after carefully considering all of the above, I am of the view the following orders are in the child’s best interests, and I so order: (a) The petitioner, M.D.J., shall have sole custody of the child Z., born in June 2010, with his primary residence to be with the said petitioner. (b) The respondent, C.W.S., shall have alternate weekend access with the said child from Friday at 6:00 p.m. to Sunday at 6:00 p.m. to be extended to Monday at 6:00 p.m. in the event Monday is a school holiday. Therefore I accept the respondent’s argument and will add back into her income $5,000, which I consider to be fair. [170] I am satisfied that Z.’s s. 7 expenses for health, dental, activities and pre-school are about $5,061.35 per year (see P-28, tab 19 in P-8). I do not find the evidence supports an “extraordinary circumstance” as per s. 22(1)(a) of The Family Property Act (see Phillips v Phillips, 2010 SKCA 117 (CanLII), 362 Sask R 124). [186] Accordingly I accept that the exempt amount of the rental properties is $90,641.43 (i.e. $506,000 - $415,358.57). The result is that the respondent (petitioner by counter-petition) has failed to prove that he is entitled to any distribution under The Family Property Act, and I dismiss his counter-petition in this regard. (1) Ms. J. shall have sole custody of Z., with Z.’s primary residence to be with Ms. J. and Mr. S. to receive parenting time as set out above; (4) Mr. S.’s claim for spousal support is dismissed; (5) Mr. S.’s claim under The Family Property Act is dismissed without any distribution to either party;

[186] Accordingly I accept that the exempt amount of the rental properties is $90,641.43 (i.e. $506,000 - $415,358.57). The result is that the respondent (petitioner by counter-petition) has failed to prove that he is entitled to any distribution under The Family Property Act, and I dismiss his counter-petition in this regard. (1) Ms. J. shall have sole custody of Z., with Z.’s primary residence to be with Ms. J. and Mr. S. to receive parenting time as set out above; (4) Mr. S.’s claim for spousal support is dismissed; (5) Mr. S.’s claim under The Family Property Act is dismissed without any distribution to either party;
column27: HELD: The petitioner was granted interim shared custody with the respondent. The respondent was ordered to return the child to his mother. The parties had been in a relationship for some time. The petitioner had previously filed an Answer and Counter-Petition contesting the respondent’s claims for sole custody, specified and supervised parenting time, the request for restraining order and costs. During this time the parties had reconciled and the parties were able to spend some time together. However, shortly after the parties separated, the petitioner began to have serious problems with her father. She was concerned that the father was holding the child from her and that she needed to end the relationship. She telephoned the respondent the next morning principally to try and get the child back. He refused. The court ordered that the child be placed in the interim care of the petitioner and that the parties should proceed to an expedited pre-trial conference. HELD: 1)The parties had not spoken since. All communication went through their lawyers. 2)The petitioner had not seen the child for several days prior to the parties’ separation. 3)The respondent had not shown any interest in having the child with him. 4)It was clear that the petitioner was not interested in having him with her. 5)There was no evidence that the relationship was in danger of ending. 6)The court ordered the parties to have the child on a shared week-on-week basis for 6 months.

column2: The plaintiff, a specialty seed marketing company, claimed damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. Johnson Seeds entered contracts with growers prior to the seeding and harvesting to secure product for resale. After extended negotiations the defendant eventually signed and mailed the standard form contract but never received an executed copy. The price of the canary seed escalated substantially during 1993. The defendant thought that as he did not have a copy of the contract signed by the plaintiff it was not a valid contract and sold the seed to a third party for more than double the contract price. HELD: Johnson Seeds was awarded judgment for $50,850.05 and pre-judgment interest together with costs of the action. 1)There was a valid contract between the parties. Damages were assessed as of January 1994 when Johnson Seeds knew that the defendant was in breach of the contract. 2)The issue was whether communication by delivery of the fully executed contract was necessary to complete the contract. The parties communicated by fax, mail and telephone. There was no doubt that the defendant verbally confirmed that a contract did exist. Discussions prior to May 1993 were pre-contractual negotiations. 3)Johnson Seed knew that it was prepared to pay 10 cents only if delivery occurred after January 1/94. The formal contract did not expressly set forth these conditions. Both parties knew these terms were absent when they executed the contract but both considered that they had a legally binding contract in 1993.  4)Farr took a calculated risk and sold the seed which alleviated his immediate cash-flow problem. Johnson Seeds waited until the last possible day under the written contract terms to call the contract in an effort to position itself to claim increased damages for breach of contract.
column3: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for the resale of specialty crops. Part of the business was the buying and selling of specialty crop. Part was the selling of canary seed. The contract was not signed by the defendant but was signed by both parties. The plaintiff considered that they had a binding and legally enforceable contract in May and in November 1993. The defendant retained a fully executed copy of the contract. The parties communicated in person, by telephone and by mail. HELD: The plaintiff was awarded $50,000.00 in damages. 1)The issue was whether communication by delivery of the fully executed contract was necessary to complete the contract so that it could be legally binding and enforceable. 2)The contract was concluded in the instant case. The two parties communicated by telephone, by fax and by Mail. The issue was if communication by the delivery of a fully-executed contract was required to complete a contract so as to be legally enforceABLE.  3)The parties communicated orally, in person and by fax. 4)The plaintiff was not aware of the formal written contract. 5)The formal written agreement was not expressly set out in the contract and both parties knew at the time they executed the contract that these terms were notabsent.
column4:
The plaintiff, S.S. Johnson Seeds Ltd. ("Johnson
Seeds"), claims damages from the defendant, Barry Farr
("Farr"), for an alleged breach of contract. Farr and Johnson Seeds both considered that they had
a binding and legally enforceable contract in May and in
November, 1993. While it may have
been in the reasonable contemplation of Farr that he would
receive back a fully executed copy of the contract, there is
no doubt that in the telephone conversations he had with
Calcutt in November and December, 1993, he verbally confirmed
that in his view a contract did exist. satisfied. Further, Farr had verbally confirmed on at least
two occasions that he did have a contract with Johnson Seeds
and at all times Calcutt confirmed that such a contract did
exist. For all these reason, I find that there was a valid
contract between Johnson Seeds and Farr. I find that Johnson Seeds knew in January 1994 that
Farr was in breach of the contract and this is when damages
should be assessed. Accordingly, Johnson Seeds shall have
judgment against Farr for $50,850.05 and pre-judgment interest
calculated in accordance with The Pre-Judgment Interest Act,
S.S. 1984-85-86, c. P-22.2 together with costs of the action.

column8: The plaintiff sought damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. Part of its business is the buying and selling of specialty crops such as canary seed, peas, lentils, canola, and flax. The plaintiff sought to have the contract executed by the defendant. The contract did not expressly set out the essential terms of the contract. HELD: The contract was invalid. 1)The parties communicated in person, by telephone and by mail. 2)The issue was whether communication by delivery of the fully executed contract was necessary to complete the contract so that it could be legally binding and enforceable. In the instant case, the parties communicated by telephone, by fax and by Mail. 3)The contract was not a binding and legally enforceable contract. 4)The only executed agreement that the plaintiff could have obtained was that the contract was signed by both parties in May 1993. The formal written contract was never signed by either party. 5)The plaintiff was advised at the time of execution that these terms were non-absent. 6)Although the plaintiff had not received an executed copy of the agreement, it had been in the reasonable contemplation that he would receive a fully executed copy.

column2: FIAT Matrimonial property dispute. A previous order had prohibited the removal of any assets from the matrimonial home and the disposal of all other assets. By this fiat an order was granted pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 344 itemizing the household contents and personal items removed by the respondent from the matrimonial home in order to allow for a Writ of Delivery and prohibiting the respondent from disposing of any of the assets that the respondent had removed from the matrimonial home and also requiring him to pay all outstanding utility payments and other expenses associated with his occupation of the matrimonial home. The judge declined to cite the respondent for contempt.
column3: FIAT. Following a trial before me in November 1993, I issued a judgment dealing with a number of issues including the division of matrimonial property. When the evidence concluded but before heard argument, issued the following fiat: Order that there be nothing removed from the matrimononial home or any other assets disposed of until further ordered. HELD: The motion was granted. 1)An order pursuant to Rule 344 of the Queen's Bench Rules preventing the respondent from violating his order of November that nothing be removed from his matrimony home or other assets. 2)An Order prohibiting the respondent's possession of any of the household contents and personal items removed by the applicant from the home in order to allow for aWrit of Delivery. 3)An ORDER prohibiting the Respondent from disposing of any assets that the applicant claimed were missing. 4)An Orders prohibiting the return of household contents, personal items, and other items removed from matrimonia home. 5)An ordered order prohibiting the husband from disposering of any remaining assets that he removed from Matrimonial Home. 6)An Ordinance prohibiting the wife from having the rest of the family's household furnishings situated in the house. 7)An Executive Order prohibiting any order respecting the wife's removal of any items from the Matrimononon home. 8)AnOrder prohibiting the father from disposencing any of any property that the wife claimed was missing. 9)The respondent did not want to cooperate with the court. The court was left with no alternative but to assist the petitioner in regaining the assets taken out of the house by granting the order sought subject to one or two modifications.  10)Anorder prohibiting the mother from disposING of any other of the assets that she claimed were lost.  11)The wife's request for relief was granted on short notice. The motion for relief sought by the wife was granted in part. The mother's request was granted and the court was directed to make a list of household items and personal possessions removed by husband from matonial home.  12)The father was ordered to return the list of items referred to above. He was ordered not to dispose of any said items without leave of Court.

column2: The plaintiff bus driver was in a serious bus/motor vehicle accident that killed two people. He was charged with dangerous driving. His employer offered the services of its lawyer, who eventually transferred the file to the defendant who represented him at trial. At trial, the Crown introduced a video of a purported accident re-enactment. The defendant chose not to object to its admission, saying he felt it was a perfect example of the Crown's 'doomed to failure' theory. As for the problems (it was recorded in the daytime, while the accident happened at daybreak; it assumed the vehicle that was struck was stopped, although there was no proof it was; and it didn't show all of the vehicles at the original scene), he felt these could be addressed by cross-examination. The plaintiff was convicted. He retained a different lawyer to represent him on appeal, and won. Eventually, the charges were dropped. The lawyer's competence was not raised as an issue on appeal. In their decision, the Court of Appeal criticized him for not objecting to the admission of the video and other evidence. They found this evidence was inadmissible, highly prejudicial and should never have been put to the jury. The plaintiff sued in negligence and breach of contract. The parties introduced conflicting opinions from criminal law experts to support their respective positions. Action dismissed. The standard of care is that of a reasonably competent lawyer. Lawyers make strategic decisions and exercise judgment, but are not responsible to ensure a certain result. Sometimes the decisions are wrong: it is only negligence if it was outside the realm of acceptable possibilities in the circumstances of the case. The appeal panel had the benefit of hindsight - it is improper to judge the plaintiff's actions in light of their conclusions. While the experts were not helpful in establishing what a reasonably competent lawyer (as opposed to a specialist in the field) would do, their differing opinions illustrate how the admissibility of evidence can be the subject of much debate.
column3: The plaintiff was charged with dangerous driving causing death. Following the laying of criminal charges, the plaintiff's employer suspended him from work without pay. The plaintiff offered to use his legal counsel to defend him in relation to the criminal charges. The defendant refused and the plaintiff brought an expert's report. The expert's evidence was so favourable that it was not necessary to object to the admission of the still photographs. The court found that the expert's opinion was so accurate as to be of no relevance to the plaintiff’s case that it should have been admitted into evidence. The Court found that while the video re-enactment was a very good example of how the accident could have gone, it was also not a very convincing example of the Crown’ s flawed theory. The video evidence was not admissible and the court found the expert’d opinion was not supported by the evidence.

I am satisfied that the matter was not as clear cut as it now appears with the benefit of hindsight and the Court of Appeal’s decision. [61] The Plaintiff’s action will be dismissed.

The plaintiff offered to use their legal counsel to defend him in relation to the criminal charges. The defendant objected. HELD: The court found that the court erred when he failed to strike the offending evidence, and in allowing into evidence the opinion of the RCMP Traffic Analyst when there was an insufficient factual basis established for his opinion. The Court found that while the plaintiff had plenty of time to see the Chrysler and respond to its presence if he had been paying proper attention, the video re-enactment did not provide timely and accurate representation of the accident scene.

column2: The plaintiff alleges the defendant has injured his reputation and feelings, and has caused the plaintiff humiliation and distress, through her actions as Reeve of the Council of the Rural Municipality of Sherwood. The plaintiff claims general and aggravated damages of $5,000 for these injuries. Both the plaintiff and the defendant were elected to their positions. The plaintiff is a councillor. The defendant determined that the plaintiff was in a conflict of interest and asked the plaintiff to remove himself from the Chambers pursuant to s. 45(1) of The Rural Municipality Act. There was a further determination by the defendant that the plaintiff had misrepresented his situation to the council. The defendant then prepared a letter to the plaintiff in which she advised that until such time as he apologized to council and remedied the 'deficiencies' that created the conflict of interest he would not be recognized by the chair to speak or to move motions. HELD: The claim is dismissed. 1) Even if the defendant's decision did infringe on the plaintiff's Charter right to expression to some limited extent and could not be upheld pursuant to the section of The Rural Municipality Act (the Court made no conclusions as to which of the competing legal opinions is right) the Court was not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff pursuant to s. 24(1) of the Charter. While the plaintiff's decision might have been politically advantageous to her and her supporters in council, it was not without some justification because the plaintiff was in breach of the Building Bylaw, there could be a perceived conflict of interest, and the Reeve did have some evidence before her that the plaintiff had misrepresented his situation to council. The Court was not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff so he could gain a personal benefit from a limitation which only had a small effect on his right to represent his constituents. The dispute between the parties is a political one. A court should be reluctant to get involved. 2) With regard to the tort of misfeance in public office, even if the defendant acted without lawful authority in imposing the sanctions in order to be actionable, the defendant had to be aware that her conduct was unlawful. This requirement has not been met. The defendant was acting on legal advice from legal counsel to the municipality. There is no evidence, nor even the suggestion, that legal counsel did not act in good faith in providing advice to the defendant. As a result, the plaintiff has failed to establish that the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do what she did in imposing sanctions on the plaintiff. 3) With respect to the tort of negligence, the Court found that because the defendant was acting on the advice of legal counsel when imposing the sanctions upon the plaintiff, she has not breached the standard of care. Her actions were not negligent.
column3: The plaintiff alleged the defendant has injured his reputation and caused the plaintiff humiliation and distress through her actions as Reeve of the Rural Municipality of Sherwood. The plaintiff claims general and aggravated damages of $5000 for injuries suffered through her action as Reevey of the Municipality. HELD: The plaintiff was not prepared to award damages to the defendant and thus enable him to gain a personal benefit from a limitation which only had a small effect on his right to represent his constituents. The dispute between the plaintiff and the defendant was a political one. The defendant was acting on the advice of legal counsel to the municipality and in fact the lawyer representing the plaintiff was acting in good faith in providing advice to the plaintiff. The court found that the plaintiff had not acted with a personal interest in imposing sanctions on the defendant. The issue was whether the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do so. The Court dismissed the claim for negligent actions. The claim for general and/or aggravated damages was dismissed.
column4: CLAIM [1] The plaintiff alleges the defendant has injured his reputation and feelings, and has caused the plaintiff humiliation and distress, through her actions as Reeve of the Council of the Rural Municipality of Sherwood. [24] However, even if the defendant’s decision did infringe the plaintiff’s right to expression to some limited extent and could not be upheld pursuant to the sections of The Rural Municipality Act, 1989, relied upon in the R.M.’s legal opinion in the letter to the plaintiff August 11, 2005, and I make no conclusions as to which of the competing legal opinions is correct, I am not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff pursuant to section 24(1) of the Charter for the following reasons. While her decision may have been politically advantageous to her and her supporters in council, it was not without some justification because (1) the plaintiff was in breach of the Building Bylaw, (2) there could be a “perceived conflict of interest” in the eyes of MuniCode and ratepayers in the R.M. in the plaintiff’s tendering motion of January 13, 2005, and (3) the Reeve did have some evidence before her that he had misrepresented the situation to council. [28] Fourth, I am not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff and thus enable him to gain a personal benefit from a limitation which only had a small effect on his right to represent his constituents. The dispute between the plaintiff and the defendant is a political one. A court should be reluctant to get involved. I am satisfied that this requirement has not been met. As a result, the plaintiff has failed to establish that the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do what she did in imposing sanctions on the plaintiff. While it is clear that the plaintiff and defendant were in a relationship that created a duty of care, I find that because the defendant was acting on the advice of counsel when imposing the sanctions upon the plaintiff that she has not breached the standard of care. CONCLUSION [31] The plaintiff’s claim is dismissed.

HELD: The plaintiff was not prepared to award damages to the defendant. 1)Even if the defendant's decision did infringe the plaintiff's right to expression to some extent and could not be upheld pursuant to the sections of the R.M. There was no evidence, nor suggestion, that legal counsel did not act with good faith. 4)The plaintiff did have another remedy open to him which he could have acted upon immediately. He could have applied to the court of Queen's Bench for judicial review to quash Resolution 154/05 before the next council meeting.

The plaintiff claims general and aggravated damages of $5,000 for these injuries. Both the plaintiff and the defendant were elected to their positions. The plaintiff is a councillor. The defendant determined that the plaintiff was in a conflict of interest and asked the plaintiff to remove himself from the Chambers pursuant to s. 45(1) of The Rural Municipality Act. There was a further determination by the defendant that the plaintiff had misrepresented his situation to the council. The defendant then prepared a letter to the plaintiff in which she advised that until such time as he apologized to council and remedied the 'deficiencies' that created the conflict of interest he would not be recognized by the chair to speak or to move motions. HELD: The claim is dismissed. 1) Even if the defendant's decision did infringe on the plaintiff's Charter right to expression to some limited extent and could not be upheld pursuant to the section of The Rural Municipality Act (the Court made no conclusions as to which of the competing legal opinions is right) the Court was not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff pursuant to s. 24(1) of the Charter. While the plaintiff's decision might have been politically advantageous to her and her supporters in council, it was not without some justification because the plaintiff was in breach of the Building Bylaw, there could be a perceived conflict of interest, and the Reeve did have some evidence before her that the plaintiff had misrepresented his situation to council. The Court was not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff so he could gain a personal benefit from a limitation which only had a small effect on his right to represent his constituents. The dispute between the parties is a political one. A court should be reluctant to get involved. 2) With regard to the tort of misfeance in public office, even if the defendant acted without lawful authority in imposing the sanctions in order to be actionable, the defendant had to be aware that her conduct was unlawful. This requirement has not been met. The defendant was acting on legal advice from legal counsel to the municipality. There is no evidence, nor even the suggestion, that legal counsel did not act in good faith in providing advice to the defendant. As a result, the plaintiff has failed to establish that the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do what she did in imposing sanctions on the plaintiff. 3) With respect to the tort of negligence, the Court found that because the defendant was acting on the advice of legal counsel when imposing the sanctions upon the plaintiff, she has not breached the standard of care. Her actions were not negligent.
column13: The plaintiff alleged the defendant has injured his reputation and caused the plaintiff humiliation and distress through her actions as Reeve of the Rural Municipality of Sherwood. The plaintiff claims general and aggravated damages of $5000 for these injuries. HELD: The plaintiff was not prepared to award damages to the defendant. 1)Even if the defendant's decision did infringe the plaintiff's right to expression to some extent and could not be upheld pursuant to s. 45(1) of the R.M. Act, the requirement that the public official must have been aware of her conduct was not met. 2)The defendant was acting on the advice of legal counsel to the municipality and in fact in her own capacity. There was no evidence that legal counsel did not act in good faith in providing advice to the plaintiff. As a result, the plaintiff has failed to establish that the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do what she did in imposing sanctions on her. 3)The dispute between the plaintiff and the defendant was a political one. A court should not be reluctant to get involved.
column14: CLAIM [1] The plaintiff alleges the defendant has injured his reputation and feelings, and has caused the plaintiff humiliation and distress, through her actions as Reeve of the Council of the Rural Municipality of Sherwood. [24] However, even if the defendant’s decision did infringe the plaintiff’s right to expression to some limited extent and could not be upheld pursuant to the sections of The Rural Municipality Act, 1989, relied upon in the R.M.’s legal opinion in the letter to the plaintiff August 11, 2005, and I make no conclusions as to which of the competing legal opinions is correct, I am not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff pursuant to section 24(1) of the Charter for the following reasons. While her decision may have been politically advantageous to her and her supporters in council, it was not without some justification because (1) the plaintiff was in breach of the Building Bylaw, (2) there could be a “perceived conflict of interest” in the eyes of MuniCode and ratepayers in the R.M. in the plaintiff’s tendering motion of January 13, 2005, and (3) the Reeve did have some evidence before her that he had misrepresented the situation to council. [28] Fourth, I am not prepared to award damages to the plaintiff and thus enable him to gain a personal benefit from a limitation which only had a small effect on his right to represent his constituents. The dispute between the plaintiff and the defendant is a political one. A court should be reluctant to get involved. I am satisfied that this requirement has not been met. As a result, the plaintiff has failed to establish that the defendant acted with knowledge she had no legal authority to do what she did in imposing sanctions on the plaintiff. While it is clear that the plaintiff and defendant were in a relationship that created a duty of care, I find that because the defendant was acting on the advice of counsel when imposing the sanctions upon the plaintiff that she has not breached the standard of care. CONCLUSION [31] The plaintiff’s claim is dismissed.

column2: An application for a DNA warrant on the basis s.487.05 (the general warrant provision) of the Criminal Code with respect to DNA warrants does not refer to a form. The applicant suggested a tape recording would avoid the potential problems in bringing the application before a Provincial Court Judge. HELD: These concerns were raised in the January 21 decision concerning potential prejudicial or negative effects, which outweigh any requirement to swear the Information before a judge. An oath taken before a commissioner or notary is as valid as it is before a provincial court judge and avoids all the possible problems that relate to personal attendance. The intention is to make protocol work as flexible as possible, not impeding the police in their legitimate role, while making sure the court maintains its independence. Form 5.01 is specifically set out in the Code. Section 487.1 does not have a form, but even if it did and used the same words 'taken before me', that would elevate form over substance in a significant way.
column3: The accused was charged with failing to comply with a written test. Application for a DNA warrant was made by the Provincial Court Judge. The accused swore the Information to Obtain before him. The Provincial Court judge was not required to swear the Information before him because s.487.05 of the Code with respect to DNA warrants does have reference to a form and Form 5.01 which is specifically set out in the Code. The officer swore the information to Obtains before the Provincial court Judge. HELD: The accused was found guilty of failing to swear an oath. The court was advised that the officer had to appear before the judge to swear Information. The judge was found to have obeyed the rules of the Criminal Code.
column4: I understand -- and I did when I made the order -- that s.487.05 of the Code with respect to DNA warrants does have reference to a form and Form 5.01 which is related to that, and that’s specifically set out in the Code. I’m of the view, especially because s. 487.1, which is the general warrant provision, doesn’t have a form, but even if it did have a form and it used the same words, “taken before me”, that to require that the Information be sworn before the Provincial Court Judge elevates form over substance in a significant way, particularly in the context of the concerns that I raised in that decision about the potential prejudicial or negative effects of a personal attendance before the judge. It’s my view that those potential negative effects or results outweigh any supposed requirement to swear the Information before the judge. And looking at it in terms of substance, it seems to the Court that to ask the question, “Is there any more truth in the officer’s affidavit of Information because he swore it before a provincial -- before a Commissioner of Oaths or a Notary Public,” the answer is self-evident. [28] THE COURT: But regardless of that side issue, it seems to me the oath is perfectly as valid taken before a commissioner or a notary as it is before me. It gets sworn Information before the judge, on which he or she can act, and it avoids all of the possible problems that relate to the personal attendance, and I take your point about, about the tape recording getting around a good part of that.

column8: The applicant Provincial Court Judge swore an Information to Obtain before him pursuant to s.487.05 of the Code with respect to DNA warrants. The officer was charged with failing to comply with a form and a Form 5.01 specifically set out in the Code. Dismissing the application, that the officer had to appear before the judge to swear the Information. The form indicates that it's an Information that's 'taken before me' pursuant to the Provincial Court judge's order. The court was of the view that the better practice is to put as much as possible in the Information as possible. It's a valid point of view that can be taken around the issue of personal attendance.

column13: This was an application for a DNA warrant under s.487.05 of the Code. The officer swore it before a Provincial Court Judge and the form indicated that it was an Information that had been 'taken before me' before the judge. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The officer was allowed to swear the Information to Obtain the Search Warrant.  2)The Court was of the view that the better practice is to put as much as possible in the Information as possible, particularly in the context of the concerns raised in the decision about the potential prejudicial or negative effects of a personal attendance before a judge. 3)It seems to the Court that the officer has to appear before you to swear it before you. The form indicates, as you have indicated this afternoon, that it's an information that's 'took before me'. 4)It's perfectly valid to ask the question, 'Is there any more truth in the officer's affidavit of Information because he swore it prior to me being the Provincial Court judge?' 5)The court was advised that this was an issue that could be resolved in camera or ex parte as in an ordinary warrant application.

column18: The applicant Provincial Court Judge swore an Information to Obtain before him pursuant to s.487.05 of the Code with respect to DNA warrants. The application for a DNA warrant was made by the prosecutor and was to be made in camera. The court was to direct that the courtroom be cleared. The courtroom was cleared and people could come back in. The officer had to appear before the judge to swear the Information. The form indicated that it was an Information that had been 'taken before me' by the Provincial Court judge. The judge was to swear an Information on an ex parte application pursuant to the s.485.05 Code. HELD: The applicant was granted a personal attendance order. 1)It seems to the court that the officer has to be allowed to swear information on an oath of office. 2)It's perfectly valid to ask the question, 'Is there any more truth in the officer's affidavit of Information because he swore it before me?' The officer's oath is valid. 3)The Court was to advise the officer that it would be a good practice to put as much as possible in the Information as opposed to a form that says'sworn before me'. 4)The officer should not have to answer questions about his or her personal attendance before a judge. 5)The applicant should not be required to swear Information on oath.

column23: HELD: SaskTel brought an application seeking an order striking the defendant's Statement of Claim under Rule 7-9(1)(a) of the Queen's Bench Rules on the basis that it discloses no reasonable claim and for an order for costs. SaskTel was awarded its costs. 1)The power to strike out claims that have no reasonable prospect of success is valuable housekeeping measure essential to effective and fair litigation. It unclutters the proceedings, weeding out the hopeless claims and ensuring that those that have some chance of success go on to trial. 2)On an application to strike, the facts set forth in the Statement of claim are considered to be true unless manifestly incapable of proof. It is incumbent on the plaintiff to clearly plead the facts upon which he relies in making his claim. Having reviewed the pleadings carefully, I conclude that Mr. Schutte's claims against Sasktel and Sasktel Union wage lose, WCB are paying me 1/8 of the wage that use to make, and Imperial Tobacco Canada Ltd. is awarded costs.

column2: The accused was charged with driving while her ability to do so was impaired contrary to s. 253(a) and s. 255(1) of the Criminal Code and driving while over .08 contrary to s. 253(b) and s.255(1) of the Criminal Code. At the conclusion of the trial, the defence brought a motion to exclude the certificate of analysis as the demand flowed from an invalid approved screening device demand. HELD: The defence application to exclude the certificate of analysis based on a breach of s. 8 and s. 9 of the Charter was granted. There being no evidence upon which to convict in regard to the .08 charge, it was dismissed.  1) The Court found a distinction between 'had consumed alcohol' and 'has alcohol in the person's body'. The Court found the words 'had consumed alcohol' to be insufficient for the Court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in the accused's body at the time of the demand. 2) There was no objective basis upon which a reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body could be made. The evidence of alcohol on the breath was not reliable in the circumstances of this case. The admission of having had her last drink was possibly made after the demand and could not be relied on to formulate the required reasonable suspicion. The evidence of bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car and the smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle could not alone support a reasonable conclusion of reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body of the motorist.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving and operating a motor vehicle contrary to s. 253(a) and s. 255(1) of the Criminal Code. The accused was also charged with operating a stolen vehicle contrary s. 254(2) of The Charter. The defence brought a motion to exclude the Certificate of Analysis, such evidence flowing from an approved screening device demand, which infringed the accused's s. 8 and s9 Charter rights. HELD: The accused's application was dismissed. 1)The words 'had consumed alcohol' were insufficient for the court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in the body. 2)The evidence of speeding, bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car and smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle was not sufficient to support a conclusion of a reasonable belief of alcohol in a motorist's body. 3)The officer's opinion, so formed, could not be relied upon to formulate the required reasonable suspicion. 4)The defence application to exclude a Certificate ofalyses based upon a breach of ss. 8and9 of the Charter was granted pursuant to s24(2). 5)The accused's words 'consumed alcohol' are insufficient for a court to determine that the police officer had reasonable suspicion that the accused had consumed alcohol. 6)The Court was not satisfied that the words 'alcohol' could be relied on to formulate a reasonable reasonable suspicion of alcohol within the body of the motorist. The Court was also not persuaded that the word 'alcohol'" could be found to be unreliable.
column4:
Background [1] The accused stands charged that on or about the 16th day of July 2001, at Manitou Beach, in the Province of Saskatchewan, did ...
"while her ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or a drug, operate a motor vehicle contrary to section 253(a) and section 255(1) of the Criminal Code
And
having consumed alcohol in such quantity that the concentration thereof in her blood exceeded eighty milligrams of alcohol in one hundred millilitres of blood, operate a motor vehicle contrary to section 253(b) and 255(1) of the Criminal Code." [3] At the conclusion of the Crown's case, the defence brought a motion to exclude the Certificate of Analyses, such evidence flowing from an invalid approved screening device demand, which infringed the accused's s.8 and s.9 Charter rights. Upon reflection, and having given careful consideration to the cases cited, I am persuaded that the words "had consumed alcohol" are indeed insufficient for the court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in her body at the time of the ASD demand. [29] Although this determination is unnecessary given my conclusion on the previous point raised, on the evidence before me I would clearly find there was no objective basis upon which a reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body could be made. [31] This then leaves only the evidence of speeding, bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car, and smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle. Objectively, these grounds alone cannot support a conclusion of reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body of the motorist. [32] For all of the foregoing reasons, the defence application to exclude the Certificate of Analyses based upon a breach of ss. 8 and 9 of the Charter is granted, pursuant to s. 24(2). [33] Accordingly, there being no evidence upon which to convict in regard to the second count, same is dismissed against the accused.

At the conclusion of the Crown's case, the defence brought a motion to exclude the Certificate of Analysis, such evidence flowing from an approved screening device demand, which infringed the accused's s.8 and s9 Charter rights. HELD: The accused was acquitted of all charges. 1)The evidence of speeding, bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car and smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle was insufficient to support a conclusion of a reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body of the motorist. 2)The words 'had consumed alcohol' were insufficient to establish that the officer had a reasonable reasonable suspicion that the accused had consumed alcohol. 3)The officer's opinion, so formed, could not be objectively upheld on the evidence before him. 4)The defence application was granted pursuant to s24(2). 5)There being no evidence upon which to convict in regard to the second count, same is dismissed against the accused.

column2: The accused was convicted of assault. He contends that the trial judge so concerned himself with the question of credibility of the complainant and the accused that he overlooked his duty to consider evidence of a witness, 'together with the rest of the evidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant's guilt, irrespective of whether he believed the evidence of the complainant.' HELD: Appeal dismissed and conviction accordingly affirmed.  1)Great deference to findings of credibility made at trial should be shown. 2)The trial judge did not say that he found the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the complainant and the accused. He said that he found the Crown's evidence to be credible, and the accused's evidence not to be credible. The Crown's evidence was comprised of both the complainant and the witness. 3)The trial judge's findings are supported by the evidence and his conclusions are not clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable.
column3: The accused was charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He appealed his conviction. HELD: The trial judge did not concern himself with the credibility of the evidence of the complainant and the accused. He simply focused on the credibility with respect to the Crown's evidence. The Crown's case was comprised of both the complainant. The court found the accused guilty of the assault. The trial court overlooked its duty to consider such evidence together with the rest of theevidence with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant's guilt, irrespective of whether he believed the evidence.
column4:
After
a trial before a judge of the Provincial Court, he was convicted of
the charge. His
contention, as I understand it to be, is that the trial judge so
concerned himself with the question of the credibility of the
evidence of the complainant and the accused that he overlooked his
duty to consider such evidence, "together with the rest of the
evidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable
doubt of the appellant\'s guilt, irrespective of whether he believed
the evidence of the (complainant)": Here the trial judge did not, I suggest, say that he found
the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the evidence of
the complainant and the accused. He said he found the Crown\'s
evidence to be credible, and the accused\'s evidence not to be
credible. Upon a consideration of all the evidence in
the transcript thereof, and "having due regard to the advantages
afforded to the trial judge", it cannot be said his findings are
not supported by the evidence, nor can it be said his conclusions
are clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable. In the result, the appeal against the conviction is
dismissed, and accordingly affirmed.

column8: The accused was charged with assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. After a trial before a judge of the Provincial Court, he was convicted of the charge. He now appeals. Besides the complainant and the accused, another person was present at the time of the incident out of which the charge arose. He was the only person other than the complainant, who testified at the trial, to the exclusion of the Crown witness. The trial judge so concerned himself with the credibility of the evidence of the accused and complainant that he overlooked his duty to consider such evidence together with the rest of theevidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant's guilt. HELD: The accused was found guilty of the assault. 1)The trial judge did not neglect his duty in considering the evidence. He found the accused guilty only upon the credibilityof the complainant & the accused. He said the Crown's evidence to be credible, and accused's evidence not to becredible. 2)The court overlooked its duty in the context of the passage from the judgment of Sherstobitoff J.A. in R. v. S.(T.). It was not persuaded that the trial judge overlooked his responsibility in the passage of the judgment.

column2: The appellant appealed from his conviction on a charge of criminal harassment. He alleged that the verdict was unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. In addition, he claimed that the trial judge had erred in admitting as evidence an audiotape of a confrontation between the complainant and the appellant. The Summary Conviction Appeal Court judge dismissed the appeal. The appellant appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that the Summary Conviction Appeal Court judge did not err in the test which he applied in reviewing the trial decision, nor did he err in accepting the trial judge's decision to admit into evidence the audiotape.
column3: The appellant appeals from a conviction in Provincial Court on a charge of criminal harassment. The appellant alleged that the trial judge erred in law by admitting into evidence an item which he declared in voir dire to be the product of a warrantless search, thus violating the appellant's freedom from illegal search and seizures as provided for in s. 686(1)(a) C.C.C., and by further failing to properly review and re-review the evidence, in its entirely, with respect to the trial Judge's findings on credibility, reasonable doubt and other key issues and consequently failed to apply the curative provision in s686(2)(b)(iii) of the Code. Dismissing the appeal, that there was nothing in the transcript to indicate that the appellant applied the wrong test. There was nothing that would raise issues going to the fairness of the trial in the context of miscarriage of justice.
column4: THE COURT: Leave to appeal granted but appeal dismissed per reasons for judgment of Bateman, J.A.: Chipman and Roscoe, JJ.A. concurring. [1] Mr. Shrubsall appeals from the decision of Justice Tidman of the Supreme Court who dismissed his appeal from a conviction in Provincial Court on a charge of criminal harassment (“stalking” - Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46, s.264). I cannot conclude that Justice Tidman erred in accepting the reasonableness of the trial judge’s findings of credibility. [15] I am not satisfied that the trial judge erred in admitting the audiotape nor that it’s admission had any impact upon the fairness of the proceeding. I would grant leave but dismiss the appeal.

column8: The appellant appeals from a conviction in Provincial Court on a charge of criminal harassment. The appellant alleged that the trial judge erred in law by admitting into evidence an item which he declared in voir dire to be the product of a warrantless search, thus violating the appellant's freedom from illegal search and seizures as provided for in s.6 of the Charter. Dismissing the appeal, that there was nothing in his decision to indicate that he applied the wrong test. The tape being non-conscripted evidence of an event about which all lay witnesses could and did independently testify, would not have raised issues going to the fairness of the trial in the context of miscarriage of justice.

column2: This is an appeal by the landlord pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman who, pursuant to s. 47 of the Act dismissed an application by the landlord for a writ of possession. HELD: The matter will be remitted to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants.  1) The tenants who are named in the decision are Vernon and Ivy. There is no reference to Richie whose name appears on the tenancy agreement. 2) Even though the decision states that the Notice of Hearing was properly served, that cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. Ivy and Richie did not appear at the hearing and the decision does not even identify Richie as being one of the tenants. More is required to ensure service of and notice to all the tenants. 3) There are no notes nor is there anything in the decision which would permit the Court to conclude that the issue of service on Ivy and Richie was ever considered by the Rentalsman. The matter must be returned to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants.
column3: This was an appeal by Rich Prop Investments Ltd. pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act. The issues were whether all tenants had proper notice of the termination of the tenancy and the hearing, whether the landlord could give notice of termination of a tenancy without any cause, and whether the issue of service on Ivy and Richie was ever considered by the Rentalsman. HELD: The matter was remitted to the Rentalman for rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants.  1) Even though the decision states that the Notice of Hearing was properly served, that cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. 2) More is required to ensure service to all the tenants than to the notice of cancellation.

HELD: The matter was remitted for rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants.  1) The decision states that the notice of hearing was properly served, that it cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. 2) More is required to ensure service to all tenants.
column19: [1] This is an appeal by Rich-Prop Investments Ltd. (the “Landlord”) pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act, R.S.S. 1978, c. R-22, as am. S.S. 1992, c. 37 (the “Act”) from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman (the “Rentalsman”) who, pursuant to s. 47 of the Act dismissed an application by the Landlord for a writ of possession. In my view the matter must be returned to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants. [28] I direct that the matter be remitted to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants.
column22: This is an appeal by the landlord pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman who, pursuant to s. 47 of the Act dismissed an application by the landlord for a writ of possession. HELD: The matter will be remitted to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants.  1) The tenants who are named in the decision are Vernon and Ivy. There is no reference to Richie whose name appears on the tenancy agreement. 2) Even though the decision states that the Notice of Hearing was properly served, that cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. Ivy and Richie did not appear at the hearing and the decision does not even identify Richie as being one of the tenants. More is required to ensure service of and notice to all the tenants. 3) There are no notes nor is there anything in the decision which would permit the Court to conclude that the issue of service on Ivy and Richie was ever considered by the Rentalsman. The matter must be returned to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants.
