column27: This was an appeal by Rich-Prop Investments Ltd. pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act. The issues were whether all tenants had proper notice of the termination of the tenancy and the hearing, whether the landlord could give notice of termination without any cause, and whether the issue of service on Ivy and Richie was ever considered by the Rentalsman. HELD: The matter was remitted for rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants.  1) Even though the decision states that the Notice of Hearing was properly served, that cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. 2) More is required to ensure service to all tenants.

column2: The primary issue in this application is the respondent's claim to retroactive support. HELD: 1) The Court reviewed the cases from the Supreme Court of Canada regarding retroactive child support and in particular D.B.S. v. S.R.G. et al, 2006 SCC 37. 2) The respondent has been content to accept $380 per month as fair level of child support for both children. What precipitated the respondent's review in July 2006 was Meghan's departure from his home where she began to live independently with the prospect of attending college. What further propelled the continued action on the respondent's part was the publicity attendant with the Supreme Court of Canada's release of its judgment in July 2006. There is no reasonable excuse as to why the respondent did not seek a variation earlier, other than concluding that the respondent accepted $380 per month as reasonable in the circumstances that prevailed from July 2003 to July 2006. 3) There is no evidence of blameworthy conduct on the petitioner's part. There was no agreement or obligation to disclose tax returns. No written request was made pursuant to s. 25 of the Guidelines. No verbal request was made by the respondent which might fall within the definition of 'effective notice'. The increase in the petitioner's level of income over the years 2002 to 2005 is not so dramatic as to constitute blameworthy conduct that privileges the petitioner's own interests over her children's right to an appropriate amount of support. In 2002, the petitioner earned $32,800 and, by 2005, she earned $43,310. An increase of these proportions would not lead the Court to conclude that the petitioner was not contributing to her children's support in a satisfactory manner. The Court's view of the evidence is that the annual increases equivalent to roughly 10% per annum, when adjusted for the annual rate of inflation, are not so significant that the petitioner would have reasonably thought that she was feathering her own nest at the expense of her children. 4) There was no evidence that the children's standard of living was compromised as a direct consequence of the petitioner not taking the initiative to adjust her child support payments annually. Nor was there evidence of financial hardship experienced by the children. 5) To order retroactive support of $4,322, whether payable in a lump sum or by installments over time, would represent a hardship to a wage earner in the petitioner's category. The application for retroactive child support is dismissed.
column3: HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that the respondent's position on the issue was not blameworthy. The respondent's failure to disclose her tax return constituted a breach of their alleged 2003 agreement. To order retroactive support of $4,322.00, whether payable in a lump sum or by installments over time, would represent a hardship to a wage earner in the petitioner's category.
column4: [1] The respondent applies to vary the child support orders of Mr. Justice Kraus dated September 10, 1999, and December 7, 1999, and/or the alleged agreement struck by the petitioner and respondent in or about July, 2003. [3] The order of Kraus J. dated September 10, 1999 is hereby restored pending the determination of the issues by the Court of Queen’s Bench. 1) The respondent’s claim to retroactive support commencing July 1, 2004, a date the respondent advances rather than July, 2003. I cannot find any reasonable excuse as to why the respondent did not seek a variation earlier, other than concluding that the respondent accepted $380.00 per month as reasonable in the circumstances that prevailed from July, 2003 until July, 2006. The respondent argues that the failure to disclose her tax returns on June 30, 2004 and each subsequent year constituted a breach of their alleged 2003 agreement. I have found that there was no such agreement or obligation to disclose. An increase of these proportions would not lead me to conclude that the petitioner was not contributing to her children’s support in a satisfactory manner. [30] When considering the circumstances of Meghan and Ryan over the same period of years, 2003 to 2005, no evidence was provided that their standard of living was compromised as a direct consequence of the petitioner not taking the initiative to adjust her child support payments annually. [32] I do not find the petitioner’s conduct blameworthy. To order retroactive support of $4,322.00, whether payable in a lump sum or by installments over time, would, in my opinion, represent a hardship to a wage earner in the petitioner’s category. I, therefore, dismiss the respondent’s application for retroactive child support.

column2: A 19 year old motorcyclist collided with a dump truck and suffered a dislocated hip, knee injuries and a minor hand injury. He was hospitalized for 22 days. Three years after the accident, continued physical activity caused him pain. Further hip surgery, as well as progressive degenerative arthritis, was likely. Awarding the plaintiff $21,000 for future pecuniary loss, that his employment opportunities were less now than before the accident and he was entitled to lump sum compensation. No weight was given to the plaintiffs actuarial report since there was no history of income and no evidence of projected income from the family hotel business in which the plaintiff was expected to continue. Non-pecuniary damages of $41,000 were awarded.
column3: The plaintiff suffered a posterior dislocation of his right hip, a compound injury involving his right knee with a disruption of the medial collateral ligament and a fracture of his third right metacarpal in the hand. He was hospitalized for three weeks and then placed on a special damages order. General damages awarded for non-pecuniary matters of $41,000 with prejudgment interest at 9% from May 13, 1988 and general damages related to future income losses of $21,000 from which there is no entitlement to prejudgment.
column4: Shawn Edward Nicholson, born October 24, 1969, was operating a 1984 Suzuki motorcycle on the 13th of May, 1988 when he and the motor cycle came into contact with a dump truck driven by Darrell R. MacRae, an employee of the Province of Nova Scotia. His report and evidence is that Shawn suffered a posterior dislocation of his right hip, a compound injury involving his right knee with a disruption of the medial collateral ligament and a fracture of his third right metacarpal in the right hand. This is not a case where evidence has been adduced showing a history of income and the interference in that income capacity due to the injuries. There is no evidence of Shawn\'s projected income from the family business and I appreciate the difficulties in adducing such evidence. I am satisfied that by reason of his hip injury his employment opportunities are less than they were before the accident and in that sense he has suffered a loss of a wider employment horizon. He has suffered a reduction in his capital asset and in the breadth of his employment opportunities and he is entitled to be compensated therefore. I consider the only appropriate way to compensate him is to award a lump sum for this loss which is separate and apart from the non‑pecuniary damage. For the restriction in future employment and financial consequences that will follow from that, I award further compensation of $21,000.00 CONCLUSION The plaintiff, Shawn Edward Nicholson, recovers 75% of the loss of income net of Section "B" coverage agreed in the amount of $1,720.00 with prejudgment interest at 3/4% from the 1st of August, 1988.

column8: The plaintiff suffered a posterior dislocation of his right hip, a compound injury involving his right knee with a disruption of the medial collateral ligament and a fracture of his third right metacarpal in the right hand. He was hospitalized for three weeks and was required to withdraw from the university. He underwent further surgery to repair the damage to his knee and underwent a further reconstruction of the knee. He remained in the employ of the Department of Ariculture and Marketing for approximately 3 years. He continued to complain of stiffness in his hip and pain in his knee. At the conclusion of the trial, the plaintiff awarded $21,000.00 with prejudgment interest at 9.4% from May 13, 1988 and general damages of $41,000 from June 1, 1988. For the restriction in future employment and financial consequences that will follow from that, the ATTORNEY GENERAL awarded further compensation.

column14: Shawn Edward Nicholson, born October 24, 1969, was operating a 1984 Suzuki motorcycle on the 13th of May, 1988 when he and the motor cycle came into contact with a dump truck driven by Darrell R. MacRae, an employee of the Province of Nova Scotia. His report and evidence is that Shawn suffered a posterior dislocation of his right hip, a compound injury involving his right knee with a disruption of the medial collateral ligament and a fracture of his third right metacarpal in the right hand. This is not a case where evidence has been adduced showing a history of income and the interference in that income capacity due to the injuries. There is no evidence of Shawn\'s projected income from the family business and I appreciate the difficulties in adducing such evidence. I am satisfied that by reason of his hip injury his employment opportunities are less than they were before the accident and in that sense he has suffered a loss of a wider employment horizon. I consider the only appropriate way to compensate him is to award a lump sum for this loss which is separate and apart from the non‑pecuniary damage. column2: At issue in the negligence suit was whether the defendant ought to have seen the plaintiff's vehicle in front of him and stopped his vehicle to avoid the motor vehicle collision. The only material difference in testimonies was whether there was a half-ton truck in front of the plaintiff's vehicle when the collision occurred. HELD: The plaintiff's claim was not proven on a balance of probabilities. The physical evidence did not assist and the court was unable to conclude that one version was correct and the other incorrect.
column3: The plaintiff was involved in a low speed collision which occurred in the turning lane of a motor vehicle. The defendant was driving a tractor trailer at the time of the accident and nudged the plaintiff's vehicle in front of it causing damage to the back bumper of the vehicle and some damage to its trunk lid. The plaintiff stopped his vehicle and the plaintiff sought the deductible of $700 plus costs of summons and service costs in the proceedings. The plaintiffs wife was with him that morning and corroborated his version of the facts as to the presence of the half-ton truck in front. The physical evidence did not assist the court in reaching a determination regarding the issues of negligence and legal liability. HELD: The plaintiff's claim was dismissed.  1)The evidence could support either version of events related to the court by the plaintiff and the defendant respectively.  2)The physical evidence could not support either versions of the events put forth by the parties.

column2: The RCMP conducted search of farmland near Canora. They were also shown pictures of the accused who was likely driving white Tempo. The search revealed marijuana grow-op. The accused was later seen by officers driving. The officers chased the Tempo for 41 kms, but the vehicle was driven into the ditch, and the driver escaped on foot. Four years later the accused was arrested in British Columbia and brought to trial. The accused was convicted of three drug offences and two driving offences following a jury trial. He was sentenced to a total of 35 months in prison. The accused appeal both the convictions and the sentence. HELD: The accused argued the convictions were unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. The grounds were: (a) the officer's eye witness identification evidence cannot support a conviction; (b) the trial judge made inappropriate comments about whether the accused could have outrun the officer at the end of the car chase, if he was the driver; (c) an adverse inference should been drawn from the Crown's failure to call the second officer; (d) the trial judge's treatment of the photographs of the accused misled the jury about what had to be proven to establish the accused was driving the Tempo; (e) the jury was improperly lead to place reliance on an assessment of a witness's credibility made by an officer who questioned him about his possible involvement in the grow-op. The Court found: (a) the jury was alerted to the frailties of the officer's identification evidence, and the convictions were not unreasonable in light of the evidence as a whole; (b) it was open to the jury to consider whether the accused could have outrun the officer, and the judge's caution about changes in physical condition over time put the issue into a proper perspective; (c) the judge told the jury that it could draw an adverse inference from the Crown's failure to call the second officer, but the decision lies with the jury and the judge is not obliged to tell the jury that it must draw the inference; (d) when the charge is considered as a whole, the jury was not left with the impression that if it concluded the pictures were of the accused that it somehow followed that he was the driver of the Tempo; (e) the judge's remarks did not improperly influence the jury's assessment of the witness's credibility. The imposed sentences fall within the standard range for similar offences and were not demonstrably unfit.
column3: The appellant appealed his convictions and his sentence, arguing that the former were unreasonable and the latter was too severe. The appellant appealed the sentence arguing that both the convictions and the sentence were unreasonable. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with written reasons. 1)The appellant was not in any way left with the impression that, if the photographs were of the appellant, it would have followed that the driver of the Tempo had been driving it. The trial judge had not advised the jury that the appellant could have outrun the driver. 2)The trial judge was not persuaded by the appellant's argument that the photographs should have been considered as evidence. The appeal court found that the trial judge's comments were not persuasive. 3)The appeal court was not convinced that the Crown's argument was unreasonable. The court was also not persuaded that the defence of the accused's credibility was unreasonable given the circumstances.
column4: Disposition: Dismissed (Orally) [1] Following a jury trial, David Horkoff was convicted of three drug offences and two Criminal Code driving offences. He was sentenced to a total of 35 months in prison. [10] Mr. Horkoff grounds his argument on a number of concerns. They can be summarized as follows: (a) Constable Badger’s eye witness identification evidence cannot support a conviction, (b) the trial judge made inappropriate comments about whether, if it was Mr. Holoboff driving the Tempo, he could have outrun Constable Badger at the end of the car chase, (c) an adverse inference should have been drawn from the Crown’s failure to call the officer who was in the police car with Constable Badger, (d) the trial judge’s treatment of the photographs of Mr. Horkoff misled the jury about what had to be proven in order to establish that Mr. Horkoff was driving the Tempo, (e) the jury was improperly led to place particular reliance on an assessment of Mr. Holoboff’s credibility made by an R.C.M.P. officer who questioned him about possible involvement in the grow-op. However, the jury was alerted to them and we are unable to conclude that Mr. Horkoff’s convictions were unreasonable in light of the evidence as a whole. It was open to the jury to consider, on a common sense basis, whether it was likely that Mr. Holoboff could have outrun Constable Badger. The trial judge’s caution about changes in physical condition over time adequately put that issue into a proper perspective. Assuming this is in fact a situation when an adverse inference could have been drawn, the trial judge was not obliged to instruct the jury that it must proceed to draw the inference. When the charge is considered as a whole, we do not believe the jury was in any way left with the impression that, if it concluded the photographs were of Mr. Horkoff, it somehow followed that he was the driver of the Tempo. Further, the sentences imposed by the trial judge were not demonstrably unfit. [32] The conviction appeals and the sentence appeals are dismissed.

The accused was later seen by officers driving. The officers chased the Tempo for 41 kms, but the vehicle was driven into the ditch, and the driver escaped on foot. Four years later the accused was arrested in British Columbia and brought to trial. The accused was convicted of three drug offences and two driving offences following a jury trial. He was sentenced to a total of 35 months in prison. The accused appeal both the convictions and the sentence. HELD: The accused argued the convictions were unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. The grounds were: (a) the officer's eye witness identification evidence cannot support a conviction; (b) the trial judge made inappropriate comments about whether the accused could have outrun the officer at the end of the car chase, if he was the driver; (c) an adverse inference should been drawn from the Crown's failure to call the second officer; (d) the trial judge's treatment of the photographs of the accused misled the jury about what had to be proven to establish the accused was driving the Tempo; (e) the jury was improperly lead to place reliance on an assessment of a witness's credibility made by an officer who questioned him about his possible involvement in the grow-op. The Court found: (a) the jury was alerted to the frailties of the officer's identification evidence, and the convictions were not unreasonable in light of the evidence as a whole; (b) it was open to the jury to consider whether the accused could have outrun the officer, and the judge's caution about changes in physical condition over time put the issue into a proper perspective; (c) the judge told the jury that it could draw an adverse inference from the Crown's failure to call the second officer, but the decision lies with the jury and the judge is not obliged to tell the jury that it must draw the inference; (d) when the charge is considered as a whole, the jury was not left with the impression that if it concluded the pictures were of the accused that it somehow followed that he was the driver of the Tempo; (e) the judge's remarks did not improperly influence the jury's assessment of the witness's credibility. The imposed sentences fall within the standard range for similar offences and were not demonstrably unfit.
column18: Following a jury trial, the appellant was convicted of three drug offences and two Criminal Code driving offences. He was sentenced to a total of 35 months in prison. He appealed his convictions and his sentence, arguing that the former were unreasonable and the latter were too severe. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with written reasons. 1)The appellant's evidence as to the identity of the driver of the white Tempo was undercut by numerous considerations. The trial judge referred to the contested aspects of the grow-op's testimony in the way she did, her charge as a whole and her comments during the sentencing hearing. 2)There was no evidence that the appellant could have outrun the police officer on the ground that he did not look like he was driving the Tempo. The appellant's argument was that the trial judge had left the jury with an erroneous sense of their significance. The Crown was entitled to introduce both pictures because both had been shown to the complainant before the search. She did not believe the jury would see them as being mug shots. The jury was alerted to them and were improperly led to place particular reliance on an assessment of the appellant's credibility made by an R.C.M.P. officer who questioned him about possible involvement. 3)The appeal was allowed with oral reasons and indicated that brief written reasons would follow.
column19: Disposition: Dismissed (Orally) [1] Following a jury trial, David Horkoff was convicted of three drug offences and two Criminal Code driving offences. He was sentenced to a total of 35 months in prison. [10] Mr. Horkoff grounds his argument on a number of concerns. They can be summarized as follows: (a) Constable Badger’s eye witness identification evidence cannot support a conviction, (b) the trial judge made inappropriate comments about whether, if it was Mr. Holoboff driving the Tempo, he could have outrun Constable Badger at the end of the car chase, (c) an adverse inference should have been drawn from the Crown’s failure to call the officer who was in the police car with Constable Badger, (d) the trial judge’s treatment of the photographs of Mr. Horkoff misled the jury about what had to be proven in order to establish that Mr. Horkoff was driving the Tempo, (e) the jury was improperly led to place particular reliance on an assessment of Mr. Holoboff’s credibility made by an R.C.M.P. officer who questioned him about possible involvement in the grow-op. However, the jury was alerted to them and we are unable to conclude that Mr. Horkoff’s convictions were unreasonable in light of the evidence as a whole. It was open to the jury to consider, on a common sense basis, whether it was likely that Mr. Holoboff could have outrun Constable Badger. The trial judge’s caution about changes in physical condition over time adequately put that issue into a proper perspective. Assuming this is in fact a situation when an adverse inference could have been drawn, the trial judge was not obliged to instruct the jury that it must proceed to draw the inference. When the charge is considered as a whole, we do not believe the jury was in any way left with the impression that, if it concluded the photographs were of Mr. Horkoff, it somehow followed that he was the driver of the Tempo. Further, the sentences imposed by the trial judge were not demonstrably unfit. [32] The conviction appeals and the sentence appeals are dismissed.

column27: Following a jury trial, the appellant was convicted of three drug offences and two Criminal Code driving offences. He was sentenced to 35 months in prison. He appealed his convictions and his sentence, arguing that the former were unreasonable and the latter were too severe. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with written reasons. 1)The appellant was not in any way left with the impression that, if the photographs were of the appellant, it somehow followed that he was the driver of the Tempo. 2)The trial judge was not persuaded by the appellant's argument that, on a common sense basis, the photographs should have been shown to the jury as part of a larger inquiry concerning the identity of the driver. 3)The appeal was allowed on the basis that the trial judge had not erred in her assessment that the appellant could have outrun the police officer. 4)Although the appellant had been convicted of driving a motor vehicle contrary to s.7(2) and s.5(3) of the Criminal Code, the appeal was not allowed on appeal on the grounds that the Crown was entitled to introduce both pictures because they were shown to a witness before the search. She did not believe the jury would see them as being mug shots. The appellant was also not persuaded that, with two or three second head-start after the car chase, the Crown could have successfully outrun Constable Badger. 5)The jury was alerted to them and the jury was improperly led to place particular reliance on an assessment of Mr. Holoboff's credibility made by an R.C.M.P officer who questioned him about possible involvement in the grow-op.

column2: The plaintiff paid its municipal property taxes as assessed for three years. On appeal it was held to be entitled to a refund for each of the three years in the total amount of $420,000. The plaintiff, pursuant to s. 41(I) of the Judicature Act, sought payment of interest on this amount from the date of the payments. Awarding 5 months interest, that the date from which interest is calculated in this type of action is upon completion of the appeal process. An appropriate interest claim under s. 41(I) therefore only exists for the five month period between the Court of Appeal's assessment determination and the refund of the property tax five months later.
column3: The plaintiff municipal tax payer paid its property taxes as assessed for the years 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997 but on appeal was held entitled to a refund for each of the three years in the total amount of $420,177.13. The plaintiff sought interest on the amount owing on the date of the payments and stressed it did not seek the alternative remedy of entitlement to the interest based on unjust enrichment. HELD: The plaintiff was entitled to the refund for the three year period between the Nova Scotia Court of Appeal assessment determination in March 1997 and the payment of the property tax refund in September 1997. An interest rate of 8.75% being a rate equatable to the rate charged by Canada Trust on overdue taxes (prime plus 4.4 %) was an appropriate rate on the principal amount for the five month period between Nova Scotia court of appeal assessment determination and the date the tax payments were remitted because the appeal process has concluded. An appropriate interest claim did exist under s. 41(i) of the Judicature Act, supra on the value of $419,177,13 fro m March 3, 1997 to the date OF the refund on September 5, 1997 and on the unpaid interest until September 6, 1997. The Court held the plaintiff entitled to refund for three years of the total $420.13 in the amount of overpayment of taxes. The court held the defendant entitled to an interest claim on the balance of the $420 in the $400,177 in the value. The defendant was awarded interest on $420 for the 5 month period from the Nova S.A. assessment determination to the payment in September of 1997 as well as on the $5,000 property tax return in September. The amount owing to the municipality was $420 to the province. The claim was dismissed. The parties were awarded costs.

There was no right to a refund of overpaid taxes until March 1997 when the Nova Scotia Court of Appeal rendered its decision upholding the reduction in the assessment. An interest rate of 8.75 % being a rate equatable to the interest rate charged by HRM on overdue taxes (prime plus 4 %) is an appropriate rate on the principal amount of $420,177.13 fro m March 3, 1997 to the date of the refund on September 5, 1997 and on the unpaid interest only from September 6, 1997 to the date of judgment.

column8: The plaintiff municipal tax payer paid its property taxes as assessed for the years 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997 but on appeal was held entitled to a refund for each of the three years in the total amount of $420,177.13. Canada Trust sought interest pursuant to s. 41(i) of the Judicature Act on the amount of the refund from the date it made the overpayments in response to HRM's tax invoices requiring payment of those amounts on the "due dates" in 1994 and 1995. The Nova Scotia Court of Appeal upheld the Utility and Review Board's assessment determination, which translated into $420.13 overpayment of taxes. HRM paid the refund of overpaid real property taxes to Canada Trust, pursuant to S. 90 of the Assessment Act, supra on the principal amount for the five month period between the Nova Scotia court of Appeal assessment determination in March 1997 and the payment of the property tax refund in September 1997 as well as on the unpaid interest until the date of judgment. The plaintiff sought interest on this amount on the balance of the two years plus interest on the outstanding balance. The court held that an appropriate interest claim did exist under s.41(i)(i)of the Judicialature Act for the 5 month period from the time of the appeal determination in February 1997 to the date the refund on September 1997, as well and on unpaid interest after September 1997. The Court held that there was no right to a full refund of the overpaid taxes until March 1997, when the Halifax Regional Municipality rendered its decision upholding the reduction in the assessment. An interest rate of 8.75% being a rate equatable to the interest rate charged by HRM on overdue taxes (prime plus 4.75) is an appropriate rate on the value of the assessed property. The date when it could be said to be an overpayment did not change or revert back to an earlier date when the tax payments were remitted because the appeal process has concluded. The proceeding under the judicature act, supra does not create debt.

HRM paid the refund of overpaid real property taxes to Canada Trust, pursuant to the Assessment Act, supra on the principal amount and on the unpaid interest until the date of judgment. HELD: Canada Trust was awarded interest of 8.75% being a rate equatable to the interest charged by HRM on overdue taxes (prime plus 4 %). Interest could be claimed under s41(i)(i)(ii)(iii)(iv) and (v) from the time the overpayment was to be paid. 1)An appropriate interest claim does exist under s40(i), s45 and s45(i(ii)(iv)(v)). 2)The date when it could be said to be an overpayment does not change or revert back to an earlier date when the tax payments were remitted because the appeal process has concluded. 3)The amount of money owed by Canada Trust in the years 1995, 1997 and 1998 was not remitted until the disposition of the appeal of the assessment. 4)An interest claim was not commenced until March 1997 when the Nova Scotia court of appeal rendered its decision upholding the reduction in the assessment and an appropriate interest was paid in September 1997. 5)The court held that an appropriate rate of interest claim did not exist under ss41(iii)(ii) and ss45(iv)(vi)(v) on the value of the outstanding property tax refund cheque.

HELD: Canada Trust was awarded interest of 8.75% being a rate equatable to the interest charged by HRM on overdue taxes (prime plus 4 %). An appropriate interest claim does exist under s41(i)(i)of the Judicialature Act (a rate equated to the rate charged by Canada Trust on overdue tax (prime minus 4 %)). An appropriate rate was determined to be 8.25% for the 5 month period from the time of receipt or use of these monies until September 1997.  1)An interest claim did exist under a Judicament Act (AIA) s.41(II)(b) which was not intended other statutory provisions to apply or to be read in conjunction with the assessment.  2)The Court found an obligation to refund overpaid taxes until March 1997 but awarded an interest claim on that amount. 3)The date of the appeal was set at the time the assessment decision was rendered. 4)There was no right to a return of over paid taxes until after the appeal provisions of the AIA had been exhausted. The date from which interest is calculated in this action to pursue Canada Trust's right to interest on an overpayment is upon completion of that proceeding.

HELD: Canada Trust was awarded costs. 1)An appropriate interest claim does exist under s.41(i)(i)of the Judicialature Act, supra on the principal amount for the five month period between the Nova Scotia court of Appeal assessment determination in March 1997 and the payment of the Property Tax refund, September 1997 as well as on the unpaid interest until the date of judgment. The date when it could be said to be an overpayment did not change or revert back to an earlier date when tax payments were remitted because the appeal was concluded.  4)The Court found no obligation to pay interest on the outstanding outstanding debt. 5)Costs were to be determined on the basis of the Court's calculations.

column2: The accused plead guilty to one count of using credit card data to fraudulently obtain services contrary to s. 342(3) of the Criminal Code, one count of fraud over $5,000 contrary to s. 380(1) of the Criminal Code for defrauding Sasktel of telephone services and one count of fraudulently personating various persons with intent to gain advantage for himself contrary to s. 403(a) of the Criminal Code. The accused was incarcerated at the time that he committed the offences. The accused opened 52 false accounts with Sasktel, at times using names he obtained from obituaries and at other times using fictious names. He then used the accounts to obtain telephone services. The total loss to Sasktel was $25,915.44. The second scheme involved obtaining credit card information from people outside the prison, ordering goods via telephone to be delivered to third party and using the fraudulent credit cards to pay for the items. The total loss to the credit card companies was $22,695.18. The accused was 47 years old and had spent much of the last 30 years in jail. He had 121 prior convictions on his record, mostly for fraud, property related offences and non-compliance with court orders. In addition to the financial losses, huge amount of resources were expended to investigate the accused's activities. He plead guilty. HELD: A fit sentence in global terms for these offences would be 8 years and 6 months. The accused was given credit for 4 years and 9 months for the time he spent in custody. The accused was sentenced to 2 years and 3 months for the s. 342(3) offence, 1 year and 6 months consecutive for the offence under s. 380(1) and 2 years concurrent for the personation offence under s. 403(a). The Court gave the accused double credit for remand time that was the result of system delays, but imposed 1:1 credit for the 393 days of remand time that were attributable to the accused. The Court held that the high dollar value involved, the pre-meditation and planning involved, the lengthy period of time over which the accused committed the offences, the number of transactions involved and the fact that the accused committed these offences from prison were aggravating factors. In mitigation, the accused offered a guilty plea. The primary factors to be emphasized were denunciation and deterrence.
column3: The accused pled guilty to three counts. The Crown stayed counts and three were stayed. The accused was sentenced to four years and nine months imprisonment. The court reduced the global sentence to eight years and six months. The sentencing guidelines were met. The gravity of the offences was very high because of a number of aggravating circumstances. The dollar value of goods and services realized and the total deprivation inflicted were aggravating factors. The defendant was imprisoned but this had no effect on him. The global sentence was increased to eight year and six month.
column4: COUNT 2 THAT HE, the said MICHAEL CHUDYK between the 25th day of November, A. D. 2006 and the 1st day of February, A. D. 2007 at or near Regina, in the Province of Saskatchewan, did fraudulently and without colour of right, use credit card data that would enable a person to use a credit card or to obtain the services provided by the issuer of a credit card to credit card users contrary to Section 342(3) of the Criminal Code. COUNT 4 THAT HE, the said MICHAEL CHUDYK between the 16th day of February, A. D. 2006 and the 19th day of August, A. D. 2007 at or near Regina, in the Province of Saskatchewan, did by deceit, falsehood or other fraudulent means, defraud Saskatchewan Telecommunications of services and goods, of a value exceeding five thousand dollars, contrary to Section 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. It was decided that a fit global sentence would be eight years and six months. COUNT 2 Incarceration for two years and three months. COUNT 4 Incarceration for one year and six months, consecutive to the preceding sentence. COUNT 5 Incarceration for two years, concurrent with the preceding sentences. [13] The period of time in the years 2008 and 2009 that the accused spent on remand were brought about because of the time constraints which necessarily are a part of the process. For that period, he should receive a credit of double time. Accordingly, the credit should be one for one, or put otherwise, the time actually served on remand. In the result, there should be a credit of four years and nine months and the global sentence should be reduced accordingly. ANALYSIS [15] The gravity of the offences is very high because of a number of aggravating circumstances. column2: This was an appeal from a Supreme Court decision on an interpleader application by the respondent Shubenacadie Band to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owed by the Band to the respondent Francis, an Indian residing on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton, for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Francis had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific, to the various claimants. The trial judge concluded that he was bound by s.89(1) of the Indian Act, which holds that the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour of or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band. He concluded that the money owed Francis by the Shubenacadie band was the property of an Indian on a reserve, and that assignment of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the meaning of s.89(1). He found that the respondent Eskasoni Band was the only Indian entity among the several claimants and ordered the money paid to them. The appellants appealed. Allowing the appeal on the issue of the Indian Act, that s.89(1) does not prevent an Indian from assigning book debts of his construction business to secure business loans. When Indians are in business they hold and deal with their business property in the commercial mainstream on terms no different than those applicable to all Canadians. Nevertheless, the Eskasoni Band is still entitled to the money owed to Francis by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from him and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments. The registration of a general assignment of book debts is constructive notice of the assignment to subsequent assignees falling within the provisions of s.3 of the Assignment of Book Debts Act.
column3: The appellant band council applied to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing under a construction contract entered into by the respondent Band with the respondent for the construction of residential homes on the reserve. The appellant claimed under s. 89(1) of the Indian Act that assignments of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the wording of s.89(1). The appellant argued that s. 88(1)(b) of The Indian Act was applicable and governed the issue he was required to consider. The appeal court held that s89(2) of s89.1 of the Act was not inconsistent with the provisions of s27(2). The appeal judge also held that the appellant had not shown that the assignment pre-dated the notifying assignee but who failed to give notice to the subsequent assignee. The respondent Band Council claimed under a different s. 87(1(d) of S.89.2 of the act that assignments made by the appellant to entities other than the Indian Band were invalid by reasons of s87(1), since it related to procedure only. The applicant Band sought to have the money transferred to the respondent Bank by way of a bank draft payable to the Band in trust. The court held the appellant Band could not effectively transfer an interest in the amount owing to the appellant Bank as there was nothing left upon which the assignment to the bank could operate. The Court held that if the appellant bank had priority over the other bank's bank creditors, it would have priority over its own bank. The application for the sum of $70,000 was dismissed with costs. The Appeal Court held the respondent bank should have priority against the assignment of book debt to the applicant Band. The Act does not expressly or impliedly confer any greater right upon an assignee of chose in action that he had before. The act is intended to prevent an Indian from entering into normal financing agreements in conjunction with the operation of a commercial business. The sum of the $101,636.33 owing by the applicant band to the plaintiff was the property of an Indian on a reserve. It was also held the applicant bank should be entitled to a percentage of the amount due to the Indian on the Reserve. The judge concluded that assignments were included in the wording s.87(2)(b). The application was dismissed. The appeals court held:
column4:
THE COURT: Appeal allowed per reasons for judgment of Hallett, J.A.; Bateman and Flinn, JJ.A. concurring. This is an appeal from a decision of Mr. Justice Edwards arising out of an interpleader application by the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the Shubenacadie Band under a construction contract entered into by the Shubenacadie Band with the respondent Paul Kenneth Francis for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Mr. Francis is an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band, and resides on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton. Section 89(1) states:

"89. (1) Subject to this Act, the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band." The learned trial judge concluded that the sum of $101,636.33 owing by the Shubenacadie Band to Mr. Francis and held at the Council office in the form of a bank draft payable to the Band in trust was the property of an Indian on a reserve. He further held, applying a liberal interpretation of the Indian Act that assignments of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the wording of s. 89(1) of the Act. On the appeal L. Martin (1984) Inc. asserts that Justice Edwards misinterpreted s. 89(1) of the Act and that it is entitled to $70,000 of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his solicitor instructing his solicitor to pay to Martin funds which were due to Mr. Francis from the Shubenacadie Band to the maximum amount of $70,000. I am, however, of the opinion that the Eskasoni Band is entitled to the fund by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from Francis and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments notwithstanding that the holders of the subsequent assignments or directions to pay (which the parties agreed were assignments in the Agreed Statement of Facts) gave notice of the assignments they held to the debtor, the Shubenacadie Band, prior to the Eskasoni Band giving notice to the Shubenacadie Band of its prior registered general assignment of book debts. Conclusion Martin's appeal was successful on the issue raised under the Indian Act but it failed on the priorities issue.

The appellant claimed under s. 89(1) of the Indian Act that assignments of books to entities other than the Indian Band were included within the wording of the Act. The learned trial judge held that this was not the case and ordered that the $101,636.33 be paid to the Eskasoni Band. On appeal L. Martin (1984) Inc. asserts that the learned Chambers judge erred in his interpretation of s.89(1). HELD: The appeal was allowed with costs.  1)The respondent was an Indian and resided on the Reserve in Cape Breton.  2)The appellant was not entitled to any interest in the amount owing to him under the construction contract. 3)The Court held that registration under the Assignment of Book Debts Act did nothing more than prevent an Indian from pledging his personal assets on a reserve on a different terms than his fellow citizens. 4)The Act was never intended by the Legislature to confer privileges on Indians. The Act was intended to insulate the property interests of Indians in their reserve lands from intrusions and interference of the larger society so as to ensure that Indians are not dispossessed of their entitlement.

column18: This was an appeal from a decision of the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the Band under a construction contract entered into by the respondent for the construction of residential homes on the reserve. The respondent had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specified to the various claimants. The appellant claimed under s. 89(1) of the Indian Act that assignments of books to entities other than the Indian Band were not subject to charge, a pledge, a mortgage, attachment, levy, or execution in favour of any Indian or a band. On appeal L. Martin (1984) Inc. asserted that the learned Chambers judge erred in his interpretation of the Act and that it is entitled to $70,000 of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his solicitor instructing him to pay to the Band funds which were due to the appellant from the Band to the maximum amount. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The Act is not intended to prevent an Indian from entering into normal financing agreements in conjunction with the operation of commercial business. The purpose of the legislation is not to remedy the economically disadvantaged position of Indians by ensuring that Indians may acquire, hold and deal with property in the commercial mainstream on different terms than their fellow citizens. By registration the plaintiff has preserved whatever rights it acquired by virtue of the assignment and no more. 2)The assignment as such transferred to the plaintiff no rights in the choses in action which were recognised at common law. The only claimant 'not barred' by the section was the Eskasoni Band being the only Indian entity of the several claimants.  3)The act as to priorities between competing assignees was the same as it was prior to the passage of the Assignment of Book Debts Act. The Act was never intended by the Legislature to require an assignment of general book debts to be registered in the manner provided by the Act or else it was void as against creditors, and subsequent purchasers for value without notice.

The respondent had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specified to the various claimants. The appellant claimed the assignment was done in good faith and for valuable consideration and not for the mere purpose of protecting the book debts therein mentioned against creditors or other purchasers or for the purpose of preventing such creditors from recovering any claims which they have against the respondent. HELD: The appeal was allowed. 1)The Court held that s. 89(1) of the Indian Act was applicable and governed the issue he was required to consider.  2)The respondent was an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band and resided on the Reserve in Cape Breton.  3)The appellant could not effectively transfer an interest in the amount owing to him from his customers as there was nothing left upon which the assignment to the respondent could operate.  4)The Act does not expressly or impliedly confer any greater right upon an assignee of a chose in action that he had before. All rights are to be determined exactly as if the Act had never been passed.

column2: Rule 14.01 – Meaning of “relevant” in Part 5 The plaintiff brought a negligence action against the defendant, stemming from a 2007 fire in premises that the defendant had rented from the plaintiff. The plaintiff sought production of documents related to a 2009 fire at another location rented by the defendant. The defendant resisted on the basis that the documents were not relevant. Held, motion dismissed. Under Rule 14.01, the motions judge must decide relevancy based on the pleadings and evidence produced on the motion as if the matter were raised at trial. The party seeking production must establish relevance. Here, the only evidence was regarding the occurrence of the fires; there was no evidence as to the manner of the defendant's operation of the business in the second location that would establish relevance to the action regarding the first location. The commonality of a fire in separate buildings two years apart does not, by itself, justify disclosure of documents relating to the second fire.
column3: The plaintiff commenced an action against the defendant seeking damages, alleging negligence. After the fire the defendant moved to another location, resulting in destruction of the plaintiff's building. The plaintiff commenced a motion for production of relevant documents pursuant to Rule 14.12. The defendant moved out of a leased premises in the plaintiff’s building in May of 2009 resulting in the destruction of that building. In May of 2010 another fire occurred at the defendant’’ s location resulting in a destruction of another building. After that another fire took place at the defendants’ location resulting, the plaintiff commenced another action against them. The defendants moved to a different location and the plaintiff sought production of all documents relating to the second fire. The plaintiffs’ motion for disclosure was dismissed. No supplemental affidavits or further evidence were provided following discoveries. The commonality of a fire in separate buildings two years apart does not, by itself justify disclosure of documents relating the second one. The fact that the defendant operated out of leased premises two years ago does not justify disclosure.

column8: The plaintiff commenced an action against the defendant seeking damages, alleging negligence. After the fire the defendant moved to another location, resulting in destruction of the plaintiff's building. The defendant was in the business of sorting and baling materials for recycled materials they collected from households. The building was damaged by a fire in October 2007. The plaintiff commenced a action in an action for damages, alleged negligence. In May of 2009 another fire occurred at the defendant's location resulting in the destruction of that building. In 2009 another building was destroyed. The defendants moved to a different location. The plaintiffs sought production of all documents relating to the second fire. HELD: The motion was dismissed. The commonality of a fire two years apart does not, by itself justify disclosure of documents related to the first fire. There is no evidence before the plaintiff as to the manner of operation of the defendant’s business in the second location that would establish relevance to the issues of negligence raised in the pleadings. No supplemental affidavits or further evidence have been provided following discoveries. 1)The commonality did not justify disclosure. 2)The plaintiff had not established the documents were relevant to the present action. 3)Rule 14.01 displaced the former semblance of relevancy test. The range of discloseable documents has been narrowed to relevability. This requires a motions judge to decide relevarancy based on pleadings and evidence produced on the motion as if the matter were raised at trial.

column27: The plaintiff commenced an action against the defendant seeking damages, alleging negligence. After the fire, the defendant moved to another location and destroyed the plaintiff's building. The plaintiff sought production of all documents relating to the second fire. The building was damaged by a fire in October 2007. The defendant moved out of its leased premises in May of 2009 resulting in destruction of that building. In May of 2010 another fire occurred at the defendant's location resulting in the destruction of the plaintiff building. HELD: The motion was dismissed. The commonality of a fire two years apart does not, by itself justify disclosure of documents relating the second one. There is no evidence before me as to the manner of operation of the defendant’s business in the second location that would establish relevance to the issues of negligence raised in the pleadings. No supplemental affidavits or further evidence have been provided following discoveries.  1)The commonality in separate buildings 2 years apart doesn’t justify disclosure. 2)The plaintiff had not established the documents were relevant to the present action.

column2: The defendant was found guilty of attempted murder after he used a handgun to shoot the complainant outside a bar. He had a previous record for non-violent offences., defendant sentenced to nine-and-a-half years imprisonment; aggravating factors included the defendant's possession and use of a handgun in an area where a number of people were close by and that a bullet had found its way into a nearby residence.
column3: The accused were jointly charged with two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder in relation to shootings which occurred in December 2006. The accused had been on bail for 17 months at the time of the offence. HELD: The global sentence was one of years, months incarceration. The court must consider the nature and circumstances of the offense and the character of the accused in order to arrive at a fit and proper sentence. The offence before this Court was particularly serious one. An aggravating factor was that handguns were used in an area where a number of people were close by at the after hours bar known as Vegas. Quite few shots were fired and two persons died as result of the gunfire. The offender was acquitted of the two counts and he is not being sentenced for those offences today. The fatalities are mentioned simply to highlight what the result of indiscriminate gunfire can be. The aggravating factors are that a bullet found its way into an occupied residence across the road from the after hour bar. There was a serious threat to the safety and security of the persons who were congregated on the outside porch of the after-hours bar shortly before the shooting began. There were also threats to the lives of the people who were in the area. The defendant had a prior criminal record for non-violent offences such as fraud, possession of a controlled substance and careless storage of weapon. The firearm was used in the shooting to settle a dispute between two men. The Court found that the defendant possessed a firearm and possessed a high level of mental disability. The sentence imposed today was at the high end of the range set out in R. v. T.H. The principles of sentencing are set out. A sentence of 9 ½ years should be imposed with a credit on a 2 for 1 basis for the defendant's pre-trial custody and a credit for time spent on pre-rial custody. The sentences are set at the low end of that range.

column2: The accused was charged with impaired care and control of a motor vehicle and care and control of a motor vehicle while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The accused was found in the driver's side of a vehicle with his legs near the pedals. His body was slumped over into the passenger side. The vehicle had collided with a power pole and sustained significant damage. The engine was running when the police arrived. There was no one else in the vehicle. The accused was transported to hospital where the doctor suspected he had a brain bleed and recommended the police obtain a blood warrant. The officer who swore the Information to Obtain the warrant indicated that the interior of the vehicle smelled strongly of beverage alcohol and the accused smelled of beverage alcohol. The Justice of the Peace did not sign the Information to Obtain. The issues before the Court were whether there had been a breach of the accused's s. 8 right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure and whether the Crown had proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. HELD: The blood warrant was found to be invalid, meaning that the blood samples were obtained as part of a warrantless search in breach of s. 8. The Information to Obtain the blood warrant did not depose that the officer believed the accused was the driver of the vehicle which had crashed into the power pole or that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. The officer should have included information about the accused's position in the vehicle and that the accused was unconscious. Without this information, the Information to Obtain did not contain reasonable grounds to believe that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253 of the Criminal Code. However, the blood sample evidence was admitted after a s. 24(2) analysis. The Court held that the officer was acting in good faith and that he honestly held the belief that the accused was drinking and driving when he swore the Information to Obtain. The impact on the accused was technical in nature and did not seriously undermine the accused's rights. The Court held that the truth seeking function of the trial process would be better served by admission of the Certificate of Analysis. The Court found that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle at the time of the collision. There was no evidence that anyone else was in the vehicle and the position of the accused when discovered suggested he had been driving the vehicle. The accused was found guilty of driving while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The Court held that his blood alcohol level was between 236 mgs% and 283 mgs%.
column3: The accused was charged with two counts of impaired driving and one count of operating a motor vehicle while over.08. The accused had obtained a warrant to search for blood samples from the Justice of the Peace in January 2009. The warrant specified that the blood samples were authorized to be taken between the hours of 1:22 o’clock a.m. and 5:22 a. m. The Court found that the accused had not deposed that he believed the accused was the driver of the vehicle, that the vehicle was registered in his name and that the rest of his body was slumped across the passenger seat of the car. The Certificate of Analyst was not included in the Information to Obtain and the information was not available to the court. The court found that while the accused's s. 8 rights were violated, the information should be admitted into evidence at trial. The officer who signed the information to obtain was not required to provide his reasonable grounds for belief. The information was omitted from the Information To Obtain as it did not constitute reasonable grounds to the belief that the driver was the sole occupant of the motor vehicle. The evidence was not corroborated by the officer who testified. The Officer who signed it was not necessary to provide a reasonable grounds of belief.
column4:
[1] A trial took place before me regarding Curtis Russell Francis who is charged that on or about the 10th day of January A.D. 2009, at or near Regina, Saskatchewan, he did:

1. While his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug operate a motor vehicle contrary to sections 255(1) and 253(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. I found that it did not and as a result there was a breach of the accused’s rights under s. 8 of the Charter to be free from unreasonable search and seizure. I then conducted an analysis pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter respecting the violation of the accused’s s. 8 rights. I determined that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst dated April 20, 2010, should be admitted into evidence at trial. He did not depose that he believed that Mr. Francis was the driver of any motor vehicle, let alone the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle which was registered in his name and which crashed into a light standard around 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. [35] I am of the view that the information which Constable Strueby deposed in the Information to Obtain, when reviewed as a whole, did not constitute reasonable grounds for the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253. Accordingly, I hold that the Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid. [53] While I have found that the blood warrant was invalid and that the seizure of blood samples from Mr. Francis breached his s. 8 right to be secure against unreasonable search or seizure, I am of the view that Constable Strueby was nonetheless acting in good faith when he obtained blood samples from Mr. Francis. While I have found the Information to Obtain in support of the blood warrant deficient, I am confident that Constable Strueby honestly held the belief that Mr. Francis was drinking and driving and was acting in good faith throughout the early morning of January 10, 2009. [56] With respect to this avenue of inquiry, I am of the view that the breach of Mr. Francis’ s. 8 Charter right was done in good faith and did not seriously undermine the interests protected by the accused. [70] The issue at trial is whether the Crown has proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused, Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle or alternatively was in care and control of the motor vehicle. [71] I am of the view that the Crown has proved beyond a reasonable doubt that Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo vehicle which collided with the power pole on 6th Avenue at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. However, when their evidence is examined as a whole I am sure that Mr. Francis was driving his Tempo vehicle when it collided with the power pole. [78] As I have determined that the accused was the operator of a motor vehicle at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009, with a blood alcohol concentration of between 236 mg% and 283 mg%, I find him to be guilty of count number two.

The accused had obtained a warrant to search for blood samples from the Justice of the Peace on January 10, 2009. The warrant specified that the blood samples were authorized to be taken between the hours of 1:22 o’clock a.m. and 5:22 am. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both counts. The information which the officer deposed in the Information to Obtain did not constitute reasonable grounds for the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s.253. The Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid. 1)The officer did not depose that the driver of the vehicle was the sole occupant of it and was unconscious with his feet located in the driver’s leg area and his body slumped across the seat. 2)The Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst were admitted into evidence at trial.
column9:
[1] A trial took place before me regarding Curtis Russell Francis who is charged that on or about the 10th day of January A.D. 2009, at or near Regina, Saskatchewan, he did:

1. While his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug operate a motor vehicle contrary to sections 255(1) and 253(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. I found that it did not and as a result there was a breach of the accused’s rights under s. 8 of the Charter to be free from unreasonable search and seizure. I then conducted an analysis pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter respecting the violation of the accused’s s. 8 rights. I determined that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst dated April 20, 2010, should be admitted into evidence at trial. He did not depose that he believed that Mr. Francis was the driver of any motor vehicle, let alone the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle which was registered in his name and which crashed into a light standard around 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. [35] I am of the view that the information which Constable Strueby deposed in the Information to Obtain, when reviewed as a whole, did not constitute reasonable grounds for the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253. Accordingly, I hold that the Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid. [53] While I have found that the blood warrant was invalid and that the seizure of blood samples from Mr. Francis breached his s. 8 right to be secure against unreasonable search or seizure, I am of the view that Constable Strueby was nonetheless acting in good faith when he obtained blood samples from Mr. Francis. While I have found the Information to Obtain in support of the blood warrant deficient, I am confident that Constable Strueby honestly held the belief that Mr. Francis was drinking and driving and was acting in good faith throughout the early morning of January 10, 2009. [56] With respect to this avenue of inquiry, I am of the view that the breach of Mr. Francis’ s. 8 Charter right was done in good faith and did not seriously undermine the interests protected by the accused. [70] The issue at trial is whether the Crown has proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused, Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle or alternatively was in care and control of the motor vehicle. [71] I am of the view that the Crown has proved beyond a reasonable doubt that Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo vehicle which collided with the power pole on 6th Avenue at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. However, when their evidence is examined as a whole I am sure that Mr. Francis was driving his Tempo vehicle when it collided with the power pole. [78] As I have determined that the accused was the operator of a motor vehicle at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009, with a blood alcohol concentration of between 236 mg% and 283 mg%, I find him to be guilty of count number two.
column12: The accused was charged with impaired care and control of a motor vehicle and care and control of a motor vehicle while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The accused was found in the driver's side of a vehicle with his legs near the pedals. His body was slumped over into the passenger side. The vehicle had collided with a power pole and sustained significant damage. The engine was running when the police arrived. There was no one else in the vehicle. The accused was transported to hospital where the doctor suspected he had a brain bleed and recommended the police obtain a blood warrant. The officer who swore the Information to Obtain the warrant indicated that the interior of the vehicle smelled strongly of beverage alcohol and the accused smelled of beverage alcohol. The Justice of the Peace did not sign the Information to Obtain. The issues before the Court were whether there had been a breach of the accused's s. 8 right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure and whether the Crown had proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. HELD: The blood warrant was found to be invalid, meaning that the blood samples were obtained as part of a warrantless search in breach of s. 8. The Information to Obtain the blood warrant did not depose that the officer believed the accused was the driver of the vehicle which had crashed into the power pole or that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. The officer should have included information about the accused's position in the vehicle and that the accused was unconscious. Without this information, the Information to Obtain did not contain reasonable grounds to believe that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253 of the Criminal Code. However, the blood sample evidence was admitted after a s. 24(2) analysis. The Court held that the officer was acting in good faith and that he honestly held the belief that the accused was drinking and driving when he swore the Information to Obtain. The impact on the accused was technical in nature and did not seriously undermine the accused's rights. The Court held that the truth seeking function of the trial process would be better served by admission of the Certificate of Analysis. The Court found that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle at the time of the collision. There was no evidence that anyone else was in the vehicle and the position of the accused when discovered suggested he had been driving the vehicle. The accused was found guilty of driving while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The Court held that his blood alcohol level was between 236 mgs% and 283 mgs%.
column13: The accused was charged with two counts of impaired driving and one count of operating a motor vehicle while over.08 contrary to s. 253 of the Criminal Code and s. 255(1) and 253(1)(a) of the Code. The accused had obtained a warrant to search for blood samples from the Justice of the Peace on January 10, 2009. The warrant specified that the blood samples were authorized to be taken between the hours of 1:22 o’clock a.m. and 5:22 am. The Court reviewed the whole of the material presented and determined that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst were not sufficient grounds for the accused’s belief that the accused was the driver of the vehicle. HELD: The Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid. 1)The accused did not depose that he believed that the driver was the sole occupant of the motor vehicle, was unconscious, with his feet located in the driver's leg/foot area and his body slumped across the passenger seat. 2)The information was not sufficient to establish that the warrant was invalid and there was a breach of his s. 8 rights. 3)The officer who swore the information to Obtain did not provide sufficient detail to permit the justice of the peace to determine that reasonable grounds exist for the warrant to issue. 4)The Certificate of Analysis was not deposed that he thought that the person who had been driving the vehicle at the time of the accident (the driver) was in care and control of it. The officer who testified during the voir dire was not required to provide his reasonable grounds for belief. 5)The Court reviewed all of the evidence before it and concluded that the information contained in the Information was not supported by sufficient grounds in support of the warrant.  6)Section 24(2)of the Charter states that the burden of proof rests upon the accused to establish on a balance of probabilities that the search warrant is invalid and that there was an infringement of his rights as guaranteed by s. 16 of the Charter. The information heard on the voire dire of the officer who signed the information could be applied to the trial proper. 7)Section 8(2)(b) is a technical error and is not fatal to the warrant, but rather than being a prerequisite to review, their sole impact is to determine whether there is any basis for the decision of the authorizing judge. The taking of the blood sample from the accused constituted a warrantless search. 8)

column2: This was an appeal of a decision which denied variation of a maintenance award where a lump sum had been previously ordered. The judge determined that since the respondent had paid the lump sum, his obligations were terminated; therefore, the Family Court did not have jurisdiction to hear the application. Allowing the appeal and returning the matter to the Family Court, that orders for child support made under the Family Maintenance Act do not have the finality which they did under other previous legislation. The order is always subject to variation in appropriate circumstances. Accordingly, the Family Court has jurisdiction to vary awards of lump sum child support made pursuant to the Family Maintenance Act.
column3: This was an appeal from the decision of the Family Court Judge Levy. The Court held a pre-trial conference at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. The matter was adjourned with no further order made. The respondent elected to make the lump payment and did so on or about the 2nd of October 1985. The appellant made an application for variation of this order pursuant to s. 37 of the Children of Unmarried Parents Act. The order required the respondent to pay lying-in expenses in the amount of $209. The court held a conference at the respondent's request and the matter was then adjourned. The appeal was heard in a separate proceeding.
column4: Judge Levy held a pre‑trial conference, at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. For all the foregoing reasons, the appeal succeeds and I direct that the matter be sent back to Judge Levy for a hearing on the merits.

column8: This was an appeal from the decision of a Family Court Judge. The Court held a pre-trial conference at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. The matter was adjourned with no further order made. In 1993, the appellant made an application for variation of this order pursuant to s. 37 of the Children of Unmarried Parents Act. The order required the respondent to pay lying-in expenses in the amount of $209 and periodic payments for the support of the child in $100 per two weeks or in the alternative lump sum payment of $7,500 be paid by the 14th day of October 1985 together with lying-ins expenses of $208. The respondent elected to make the payment and did so on or about the 2nd of October, 1985. The appellant made no further payment since that time and has not had contact with the child. Since the merger of the two courts the general principles favouring the claim must yield to the clear, specific intention of the statute and order made under it.
