He held a pre-trial conference at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. The matter was adjourned with no further payment since that time and the respondent had not had contact with the child. In 1993, the appellant made an application for variation of this order pursuant to s. 37 of the Children of Unmarried Parents Act. The order required the respondent to pay lying-in expenses in the amount of $209 and periodic payments of $100 for support of the child in the alternative lump sum payment of $7,500 to be paid by the 14th day of October 1985 together with lying‑in expenses of $208. The respondent elected to make the payment and did so on or about the 2nd of October, 1985. The appellant then made an appeal to the court to have the order varied, rescinded or suspended, and judge may vary, rescind or suspend the order on the basis that the circumstances have changed. The general principles favouring the claim must yield to the clear, specific intention of the statute and order made under it.
column24: Judge Levy held a pre‑trial conference, at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. For all the foregoing reasons, the appeal succeeds and I direct that the matter be sent back to Judge Levy for a hearing on the merits.
column27: This was an appeal from the decision of the Family Court Judge Levy. The Court held a pre-trial conference at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. The matter was adjourned with no further order made. The respondent elected to make the lump payment and did so on or about the 2nd of October 1985. The appellant made an application for variation of this order pursuant to s. 37 of the Children of Unmarried Parents Act. The order required the respondent to pay lying-in expenses in the amount of $209. The court held a conference at the respondent's request and the matter was then adjourned. The appeal was heard in a separate proceeding.

column2: FIAT. Both parents sought sole custody of the one child who had been living alternate weeks with each since June 1997. HELD: 1)The present shared parenting arrangement was to continue until the mother was available for full-time child care. The father would have access on alternating weekends and for a three hour period one weekday provided the child was returned by the bedtime set by the mother. Although both parents genuinely love the child and were equally competent caregivers, neither demonstrated that sole parenting offered an advantage to him. Both had full time jobs. 2)When the mother assumes sole custody the father must pay child support of $226 per month and proportionate share of horse riding lessons ($28 per month).
column3: FIAT. Both parents wanted sole custody of their son. Since they separated in June 1997, the boy had lived alternating weeks with each parent. HELD: The mother's interim share of the cost of $40 per month was $28 per month. The father's obligation under the Federal Child Support Guidelines was $226 per month and the mother's obligation was $26,520 per year. The parties had agreed to joint parenting in 1995. The mother had recently remarried and the father now had sole custody. The child had been cared for by babysitters of their respective families. The parents had been married for four years. Neither had demonstrated that sole parenting offered an advantage to the child. Neither demonstrated that the arrangement offered an unfair advantage to either parent. Both had full-time jobs. The son had been supported during his working hours by babysitter of their choice. The babysitters were members of their families. Neither showed that sole custody offered an advantageous advantage to him. Neither have demonstrated that it offered an edge to the boy. Both have full- time jobs. Both were able to work full-tim jobs. During their working hours the boy has been cared of by babysitting of their own choice. Both are members of the respective families and are equally competent. The arrangement did not work well for the child and neither had demonstrated it offered a disadvantage. Neither has demonstrated that a sole parenting arrangement offered a advantage to his son. Both work full time jobs and have had stable routines. The boy has had a sense of belonging and a predictable routine that involves both parents. The parenting arrangement was not very well suited to the young man. The future plan of the mother offers the boy an enormous advantage. She plans to marry her current companion when both of them are divorced from their present spouses. She will then stay at home and be full-part-time parent to Challen. She is willing that the boy have generous access to his father. Such an arrangement would be far better for the boy than the present shared parenting arrangement. He would have a sense that he was part of a stable family. The Father's obligation in the Divorce Act Regulations [Divorce Act] is $226. The Mother's obligation is $28. HOLD: The father was to pay child support. The burden of child support was reduced to $1,454 per month for the two children's activities. The cost of horse riding lessons was reduced by $40. The fathers proportional share of this cost was $27 per month

column2: After being sexually assaulted, applicant was voluntarily released from Canadian Armed Forces. She applied for and was denied a pension. Civil proceedings were commenced and the Crown defended on the basis that before initiating civil proceedings, applicant was obliged to appeal denial of pension or seek review by Minister of pension rejection. Applicant applied to strike out that portion of defence application allowed. The applicant applied for and was denied a pension. Therefore no pension was at this time payable to her. A review by the Minister would require new information and the appeal period had expired. The applicant should not be denied her right to proceed against the Crown in such circumstances.
column3: The plaintiff was a member of the Canadian Armed Forces. She was voluntarily released from the military and applied for a pension. The Minister of Defence re-assessed her release from the Military and ruled that she should have been released on medical grounds, being disabled and not being able to perform the duties of her trade or employment. The plaintiff sued the Minister of Defense and the Minister for Defence. The Crown brought an application to strike the statement of claim on the basis it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The defence was dismissed. The Court held that the Crown could not meet the onus of proving a pension was payable. The court also held that a defence of a right to sue the government for wrongful dismissal was not a defence under s.111 of the Pension Act. The Queen's Bench Rule applies to cases where the plaintiff ignored the administrative process in favor of civil action and the Court held they had to pursue the administrative proceedings. The limitation period for appealing the Minister's decision expired under the Pension act. The accused was not entitled to a pension under s111. The only defence the Crown had was that the claim disclosed no such cause of claim. The claim was barred because the Crown did not have the proper means to bring it forward. The fact that the plaintiff had not made an application for a defence in the past does not mean that the court cannot now rely on the Crown's argument that it has not exhausted its administrative remedies.
column4: The Crown, having denied her a pension cannot come forward now and say that she is barred in this action because she is now entitled to a pension when they have already decided otherwise. To permit that argument to carry the day would be a traversity of justice and bring the administration of justice into disrepute.

column8: The plaintiff was a member of the Canadian Armed Forces. She was voluntarily released from the military and applied for a pension under s. 271 of the Criminal Code. The Minister of Defence re-assessed her release from the Military and ruled that she should have been released on medical grounds, being disabled and not being able to perform the duties of her trade or employment. The plaintiff sued the Federal Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia. The Crown brought an application to strike the statement of claim on the basis it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The Federal Court, in its decision, held that the Crown had not met the onus of proving that pension was payable. The Court held that s. 111 of the Pension Act or s. 24 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act cannot be read having regard to these authorities to amount to the proposition that having been denied a pension by the government for sexual assault the Plaintiff is now barred from bringing an action for damages against the government claiming that she is now entitled to pension.

column13: The plaintiff was a member of the Canadian Armed Forces. She was voluntarily released from the military and made an application for a pension. The Minister of Defence re-assessed her release from military and ruled that she should have been released on medical grounds, being disabled and not being able to perform the duties of her trade or employment. She sued the Federal Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia. The Crown brought an application to strike the statement of claim on the basis it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The plaintiff brought an action for damages against the Department of Defence (DND) for failing to file a grievance. The defence was that since no pension had been paid or awarded, it followed that no pension was payable. HELD: The plaintiff was barred from bringing this proceeding because she failed to appeal in time. 1)Section 111 of the Pension Act or s.111 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act cannot be read having regard to the authorities to amount to the proposition that having been denied a pension by the government for sexual assault the plaintiff is now barred from bring an action against the government claiming that she is now entitled to pension. 2)The Court held that the rule that recourse to alternative bodies is bar to court actions has been considered by the courts in various contexts and is applicable to the present instance. 3)The plaintiff had not exhausted the grievance procedure provided under the Pensions Act or any other Act and the court would not have jurisdiction as a result of s.18 of the Federal Courts Act. 4)The court found that the Crown must prove facts to bring the case within the ambit of the legislation. The court did not meet that onus.

column18: The plaintiff was a member of the Canadian Armed Forces. She claimed to suffer from depression and post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) due to the sexual assault. The Crown brought an application to strike the statement of claim on the basis it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The Federal Court of Appeal overturned the decision and the plaintiff sued in the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia. HELD: The plaintiff was barred from bringing this proceeding because she failed to appeal in time. The limitation period for appealing the Minister's decision expired under the Pension Act. She was not in receipt of pension benefits. The Court held that s. 111 of the Pensions Act or s.111 of the Liability and Proceedings Act could not be read having regard to the authorities to amount to the proposition that having been denied a pension by the government for sexual assault the plaintiff is now prevented from bringing an action for damages against the government claiming that she is now entitled to pension. The court found that the Crown could not meet that onus because the plaintiff had never made an application for pension.

column2: A sailboat, which was owned by a resident in Nova Scotia and registered in the province, but which was purchased in Finland and kept in the United States and the Carribean, and which was twice in Nova Scotia under customs permits to participate in races, did not have a sufficient presence in the province to be subject to an assessment under the Health Services Tax Act.
column3: The respondent purchased a sailing vessel from the applicant in 1988. The vessel sailed to the Carribean for the winter and returned to Nova Scotia in 1989. The respondent applied to have the vessel taxed at the rate of 7% on a percentage of the purchase price. The applicant Board member concluded that the vessel did not have a sufficient presence in the province to attract tax under s. 7(1) of the Act. Dismissing the appeal, that the Act applies to the respondent. The Act applies only to the vessel. The Board member found that the boat did not meet the statutory definition of 'a substantial presence' in the Province.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal dismissed without costs per oral reasons for judgment of Jones, J.A.; Clarke, C.J.N.S. and Hart, J.A. concurring On January 14, 1991, after reviewing the provisions of the Health Services Tax Act, board member, W.J. Skinner concluded that the vessel did not have a sufficient presence in the province to attract tax under s. 7(1) of the Act. We see no error on the part of the Tax Review Board in concluding that the vessel was not subject to tax in this case. The appeal is dismissed without costs.
column7: A sailboat, which was owned by a resident in Nova Scotia and registered in the province, but which was purchased in Finland and kept in the United States and the Carribean, and which was twice in Nova Scotia under customs permits to participate in races, did not have a sufficient presence in the province to be subject to an assessment under the Health Services Tax Act.
column8: The Minister of Finance appealed an assessment made against the respondent because the vessel was registered in Nova Scotia and had been used in the province. The respondent argued that the province can only impose direct taxation within the province and that temporary presence is not a sufficient condition to attract tax under s. 7(1) of the Act. Dismissing the appeal, that the statutory purpose of s. 2(4) of s7(1)(b) of The Social Services Tax Act is to guard against the methods of avoidance of the purchase tax. The provision equalizes the burden by taxing out-of-province purchases by provincial residents at the same rates as if the purchases had taken place in the Province.

column27: The respondent purchased a sailing vessel from the applicant in 1988. The vessel sailed to the Carribean for the winter and returned to Nova Scotia in 1989. The respondent applied to have the vessel taxed at the rate of 7% on a percentage of the purchase price. The applicant Board member concluded that the vessel did not have a sufficient presence in the province to attract tax under s. 7(1) of the Act. Dismissing the appeal, that the Act applies to the respondent. The Act applies only to the vessel. The Board member found that the boat did not meet the statutory definition of 'a substantial presence' in the Province.

column2: The deceased was a master's student who also worked as a student assistant at the University of Saskatchewan. He became ill while teaching a class. His students helped him to the faculty lounge. He was found in the faculty washroom unconscious and not breathing approximately 30 minutes later. Emergency medical technicians were not able to resuscitate him and he was pronounced dead at the Royal University Hospital. An application for dependants' benefits was submitted over 3 years later. The Workers' Compensation Board denied the claim finding that the deceased was not found dead at work and because of the delay in bringing the claim. The applicant brought an application for an order of certiorari pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 664 and mandamus pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 674. HELD: 1) The Board acted outside of its jurisdiction in denying dependant benefits to the applicant based upon a determination that the deceased was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of The Workers' Compensation Act, 1979. The case law clearly precludes an analysis of s. 30 of the Act as in any way representing a rebuttable presumption. 2) The Board acted outside its jurisdiction in not applying the presumption in s. 30 of the Act in favour of the applicant. 3) The Board waived the right to rely upon the delay in bringing the claim after the Board participated in a variety of levels of proceeding, including two hearings, and only raised the issue of delay at the final hearing. 4) The application was allowed with costs to the applicant on a party and party basis.
column3: The respondent Board refused to grant the applicant dependants' benefits on the basis that it had not received notice of the applicant's death and that the applicant had not been found dead. The respondent Board applied for judicial review by way of mandamus pursuant to s. 664 of the Queen's Bench Rules of Court, remitting the matter of the applicants' claim for benefits back to the Workers' Compensation Board. The applicant had become aware of the potential benefits in early July 2001 during a casual conversation at her workplace. She had been advised that the deceased had suffered a severe aortic aneurysm and that she did not wish to receive benefits within the six month period contemplated in the Workers’ Compensation Act. The Board found that the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant’s claim. The decision was based upon two alternative grounds: the delay in bringing the claim, and the fact that the death was not 'found dead at work'. The respondent board did not have the discretion to make policy that allowed the application of the application. The board did have the power to determine the status of the claim.
column4: [1] The applicant, by way of notice of motion seeks the following relief: a. An Order by way of certiorari, pursuant to Rule 664 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, to quash the decision of the Workers’ Compensation Board dated November 20, 2002; b. An Order by way of mandamus, pursuant to Rule 674 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, remitting the matter of the Applicants’ claim for benefits back to the Workers’ Compensation Board of Saskatchewan to be dealt with according to law; [13] Ultimately, an application for dependants’ benefits was submitted to the Saskatchewan Workers’ Compensation Board by a representative, Mr. Alex Taylor, on behalf of the applicant, on July 16, 2001. The applicant thereupon notified the Board on October 14, 2001 that she wished to appeal the September 18, 2001 denial of her claim, and on October 29, 2001, the Board issued a formal written decision, denying Gloria Truitt’s appeal because “Mr. Truitt was not found dead at his place of employment on March 2, 1998.” Based upon the foregoing application of Sections 45 and 47, or in the alternative Section 30, the appeal is denied. The appeal should be accepted. Accordingly, I am of the view that the Board did act outside its jurisdiction in denying dependant benefits to the applicant based upon a determination that the applicant’s deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of the Act. The majority decision in Henry v. Saskatchewan (Workers’ Compensation Board), supra, clearly precludes approaching an analysis of s. 30 as in any way representing a rebuttable presumption. [36] For the fundamental reasons set forth in the above analysis, I am of the view that the Board did act outside its jurisdiction in not applying the presumption in favour of the applicant. The appeal is denied. [46] I am of the view, for the foregoing reasons, that the Board has waived the right to rely upon the delay in bringing the claim. Here, the Board participated in a variety of levels of proceeding, including two hearings, and only raised the issue of delay at the final hearing. [53] The applicant has demonstrated an entitlement to an order by way of certiorari, pursuant to Rule 664 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, quashing the decision of the Workers’ Compensation Board dated November 22, 2002, and further for an order by way of mandamus, pursuant to Rule 674 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, remitting the matter of the applicant’s claim for benefits back to the Workers’ Compensation Board of Saskatchewan to be dealt with according to law, and so order. Further, there shall be an attendant order of mandamus compelling the Board to perform its statutory duty to apply the presumption set forth in s. 30 of The Workers’ Compensation Act, 1979, supra, in the applicant’s favour. [54] The applicant shall have her costs of the motion, on a party and party basis, to be taxed.

column8: HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant dependants' benefits based upon two alternative grounds: the delay in bringing the claim, and the fact that the deceased husband was not found dead at work. column23: HELD: The application for dependants' benefits was dismissed. The court found that the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant's claim for benefits based upon two alternative grounds: the delay in bringing the claim, and the fact that Truitt was not found dead at work. The respondent Board did not notify the Workers' Compensation Board regarding Truitt’s death. The applicant did not submit an application for benefits to the Board. Ultimately, an application was submitted to the Saskatchewan Workers’ Compensation Board by a representative on behalf of the applicant on July 16, 2001. The notice of motion set forth the grounds on which it was made and the relief sought.  1)The respondent Board was at an impasse and were unable to resolve the appeal. The Board would have complete discretion to make the determination of the matters stated in the presumption. 2)Section 30 does not affect the application of dependants’ benefits. The purpose of s.30 is to provide for compensation to Workers for Injuries sustained in the Course of their Employment.  3)Section 45 is to address those circumstances in which it is impossible to determine whether the death was a result of an injury arising out of and in the course of his employment. Section 45 pertains to the statutory six month claims reporting. 4)S.45 does not bar the applicant from compensation where the board considers that the claim is just and should be allowed.

column2: The defendant seeks a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act. The plaintiff is chartered accountant who was partner with the defendant. 2000 merger agreement signed by the plaintiff indicated that the Courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes between the parties. After the merger, the plaintiff signed new partnership agreement that said arbitration would apply to any disputes between partner and the partnership. HELD: The action was stayed pending arbitration. The plaintiff's statement of claim does not rely on the 2000 merger agreement, the claim is based solely on the new partnership agreement and alleges breaches of the partnership agreement. The partnership agreement clearly states that disputes are to be resolved through arbitration.
column3: FIAT: The defendant sought a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act 1992. The plaintiff joined the partnership of the defendant and became a party to the MNP Partnership Agreement. The merger agreement provided the courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes and claims arising between the parties. The defendant seeks a stay pursuant to ss. 8(8) of the Act. HELD: The action was allowed. The parties agreed to a stay in the action. The court was not bound by the agreement. The agreement was in direct conflict with the arbitration clause of the Agreement. It seeks damages under the new partnership agreement and no relief is sought under the merger agreement. No relief is seeking under the merged agreement.
column4: [1] The defendant, MNP LLP (“MNP”), seeks a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act, 1992, S.S. 1992, c. A‑24.1. Therefore, the action is stayed pursuant to s. 8(1) of The Arbitration Act, 1992, supra, with costs to the applicant.

column8: FIAT: The defendant sought a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act 1992. The plaintiff joined the partnership of the defendant and became subject to the partnership agreement dated June 1, 1999. The merger agreement provided the courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes and claims arising between the parties. The agreement provided that the parties could enter into a new partnership agreement and replace all prior agreements entered into between them including the merger agreement. HELD: The action was stayed pending the application of the Court of Appeal. The Court was not able to stay the action pending the outcome of the arbitration proceeding. 1)The plaintiff's argument was that the statement of claim did not rely on the merger agreements other than for the choice of law. The claim was solely based on the new partnership arrangement and alleged breach thereof. 2)The choice of the law and method of resolution contained in the agreement relates to that agreement and the rights arising to the parties out of it. There was nothing in the claim that alleges the breach of the merger or purports to rely on a merger agreement other than that the choice is law.  3)The Court was unable to decide the issue of whether the agreement was invalid as it was in direct conflict with the arbitration clause of the Agreement. 4)The court was not entitled to determine the matter of a stay.

HELD: The action was stayed pending the application of the Court of Appeal.  1)The plaintiff's argument was that the statement of claim did not rely on the agreement other than for the choice of law. 2)The claim was solely based on the old partnership agreement, alleging breach thereof. HELD: The action is allowed to proceed on the basis that the agreement does not rely on the merger agreement or the choice of law. There are no other provisions in s8(2) that apply to this situation that may result in refusal to stay the proceedings.  1)The Agreement is in direct conflict with the arbitration clause of the Agreement which purports to give an arbitrator the authority to resolve disputes and interpret law according to the Province of Alberta. 2)The plaintiff's argument is that the statement of claim doesn't rely on either the merger or the arbitration agreement other than for the choice thereof. 3)The agreement does have an arbitration clause. The plaintiff submits that that clause is in a direct conflict. 4)The issue must be decided by the courts, and not the arbitrator. 5)The Court shall stay the action unless there is a conflict between the partnership agreement and merger agreement.  6)The arbitration agreement is not a question of law and must be determined by the Court. The Agreement is not in conflict with any other arbitration clause in the Agreement. The only issue here is whether the agreement is in conflict or in a dispute between the parties.  7)The court must decide whether the Agreement is invalid as it applies to the relationship of the parties and the matter is proper one for default.
column19: [1] The defendant, MNP LLP (“MNP”), seeks a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act, 1992, S.S. 1992, c. A‑24.1. Therefore, the action is stayed pursuant to s. 8(1) of The Arbitration Act, 1992, supra, with costs to the applicant.
column22: The defendant seeks a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act. The plaintiff is chartered accountant who was partner with the defendant. 2000 merger agreement signed by the plaintiff indicated that the Courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes between the parties. After the merger, the plaintiff signed new partnership agreement that said arbitration would apply to any disputes between partner and the partnership. HELD: The action was stayed pending arbitration. The plaintiff's statement of claim does not rely on the 2000 merger agreement, the claim is based solely on the new partnership agreement and alleges breaches of the partnership agreement. The partnership agreement clearly states that disputes are to be resolved through arbitration.
column23: FIAT: The defendant sought a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act 1992. The plaintiff was a chartered accountant. By way of a merger/purchase agreement, he joined the partnership of MNP and became subject to the partnership agreement dated June 1, 1999. The merger agreement provided the courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes and claims arising between the parties. The agreement provided that the parties could enter into a new partnership agreement and that the agreement would prevail if there was a conflict between the partners' agreement and the merger agreement. HELD: The action was stayed pending the application of the Court of Appeal.  1)The plaintiff's argument was that the statement of claim did not rely on the agreement other than for the choice of law. The claim was solely based on the new agreement, alleging breach thereof. 2)The agreement was in direct conflict with the arbitration clause, which purports to give an arbitrator the authority to resolve disputes and interpret law according to the Province of Alberta. 3)There were no other provisions in s8(2) that apply to this situation that may result in refusal to stay the proceedings.
column24: [1] The defendant, MNP LLP (“MNP”), seeks a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act, 1992, S.S. 1992, c. A‑24.1. Therefore, the action is stayed pursuant to s. 8(1) of The Arbitration Act, 1992, supra, with costs to the applicant.
column27: FIAT: The defendant sought a stay of the action pursuant to s. 8 of The Arbitration Act 1992. The plaintiff joined the partnership of the defendant and became a party to the MNP Partnership Agreement. The merger agreement provided the courts of Saskatchewan would have exclusive jurisdiction to determine all disputes and claims arising between the parties. The defendant seeks a stay pursuant to ss. 8(8) of the Act. HELD: The action was allowed. The parties agreed to a stay in the action. The court was not bound by the agreement. The agreement was in direct conflict with the arbitration clause of the Agreement. It seeks damages under the new partnership agreement and no relief is sought under the merger agreement. No relief is seeking under the merged agreement.

column2: Family Law – Custody and Access – Best Interests of ChildFamily Law – Custody and Access – Interim – VariationFamily Law – DivorceFamily Law – Evidence – AffidavitThe parties were in a high-conflict situation and brought five interim applications with various requests. They had three children, the youngest being born five days before a previous application. At the initial application the respondent mother was living in the family home and the petitioner was living at the family cottage and expected to move into the new home when it was ready. The petitioner did move into the home, which was a few blocks from the family home. The youngest child was almost a year old and the petitioner was having increased parenting time with him. The parties agreed to have a custody and access report prepared. The issues were: 1) divorce; 2) registration of the middle child in Montessori school. The respondent opposed the child attending the school because he was not yet potty trained. The petitioner advised that the school was okay with the child not being potty trained; 3) to take the child to a speech therapist. The parties ended up resolving the issue before chambers; 4) varying the existing parenting arrangements.  There was an interim order from January 2015 made shortly after the third child was born. The respondent had since hired a full-time nanny. The respondent did not necessarily oppose the petitioner spending more time with the youngest child, but she wanted to be the one to control the developing of that time. The petitioner wanted the child Wednesday afternoon to evening and Sunday from 11:00 am to 4:00 pm. He also wanted increased time with the two older children so that he could get them to their necessary activities and so that they could continue to develop their bond with him; 5) arrears of child and spousal support; 6) the respondent’s request to return the 2005 vehicle. The vehicle had been at the parties’ farm and was damaged beyond repair without insurance. The petitioner then towed the vehicle to the respondent’s home; 7) objections to one of the petitioner’s affidavits; and 8) costs. HELD: The issues were decided as follows: 1) the divorce was granted because the parties had been separated in excess of a year and no satisfactory reasons were argued for not allowing it; 2) the court held that it would be appropriate for the child to be enrolled in the Montessori school. The cost of the program was ordered to be paid by the petitioner. The parties were to agree on the child’s transportation to the school and if they could not agree the petitioner would transport him; 3) the court kept the issue under its jurisdiction so that either party could bring the matter back upon two days’ notice; 4) the pre-trial conference was months away and the court did not find it appropriate to have the matter of increased parenting time proceed to a pre-trial conference, as a stand-alone issue. The court found that it was in the best interests of all the children to have further time with the petitioner as he requested. The court also dealt with transportation for the hockey and the middle child’s skating; 5) counsel agreed that the issue of arrears due under the support provisions would await further discussion at the pre-trial conference with either party having leave to bring the matter back on two days’ notice; 6) the matter was adjourned sine die on two days’ notice; 7) the complaints were not generally well-founded; and 8) the petitioner was entitled to costs of $1,000 in any event of the cause. The respondent was entitled to costs of $200 in any event of the cause. The court declined to send the matter to the high-conflict mediation program.
column3: HELD: The Court granted the application. The Court ordered that the child be registered in the Montessori program and that the cost of the program be paid at the time of trial. The court found no reason for the denial of the divorce. The child was already in the preschool program and was now attending preschool. The mother had hired a full-time nanny and the child was now enrolled in the program. The parties had been separated for 1 year. The father had made significant contributions to the child's education and the mother was of the opinion that the children would benefit from having access to the Montesessori school. The issue of increasing parenting time was brought by the father and was not a new matter brought by him. The order was made to allow the parties to proceed with the child registration. The cost of that program was to be paid by the petitioner.

column2: The Crown elected to proceed summarily and the accused entered a plea of guilty to a charge of assault under S.266 of the Code. He was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment, 18 months probation and a 10 year fire arm prohibition was imposed. He appealed his sentence. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)Because the accused had no related record and given the circumstances of the assault, the sentence of imprisonment was reduced to time already served (15 days). 2)The trial judge erred in imposing the 10 year fire arm prohibition under S.100 of the Code. S.100 requires a conviction on an indictable offence involving violence against a person where the maximum sentence available is 10 years imprisonment or more. 3)The maximum sentence for assault under S.266 is 5 years if the Crown proceeds by indictment and 6 months if, as here, the Crown proceeds summarily.
column3: The accused was convicted of an assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to a term of 6 months imprisonment and to enter into a probation order for a term 18 months on certain specific conditions. A ten-year firearm, ammunition and explosive substance prohibition order was made against the appellant pursuant to s100(1) of the Code. The accused appealed the sentence and reduced the term of imprisonment imposed at trial from 6 months to "time served" and maintained the 18 month probation order subject only to amending the time within which the appellant was to report to the chief probation officer as required by s. 100(1). The appeal against the prohibition order and the 18 months probation order was allowed and set aside.
column4:
On August 4, 1994, the then presiding judge of
the Provincial Court of Saskatchewan sentenced the accused to
serve a term of six months\' imprisonment and to enter into a
probation order for a term of 18 months on certain specific
conditions. As well, a ten-year firearm, ammunition and
explosive substance prohibition order was made against the
appellant pursuant to the provisions of s. 100(1) of the
Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46. This is an appeal against (1) said six-month term
of imprisonment and (2) said s. 100(1) prohibition order. In these circumstances, having regard for the
applicable sentencing principles of protection of society,
punishment, general and specific deterrence, reformation and
rehabilitation, and the need to maintain the public\'s
confidence in the administration of justice, and, after
applying thereto the various applicable factors as discussed
by and with both counsel during the hearing of this appeal, I
allowed the appeal against sentence and reduced the term
imposed at trial from six months\' imprisonment to "time
served" and maintained the 18 month probation order (against
which no appeal was taken) subject only to amending the time
within which the appellant was to report to the chief
probation officer as therein provided. As earlier observed the appellant was charged and
on his plea of guilty thereto was convicted of an offence
contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code which provides as
follows:

266. Every one who commits an assault is
guilty of

(a) an indictable offence and is liable to
imprisonment for a term not exceeding five
years; or

(b) an offence punishable on summary
conviction. more. In the particular circumstances, as the requisite
two pre-conditions did not exist, the Provincial Court judge
erred in making the noted s. 100(1) prohibition order.

HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)Because the accused had no related record and given the circumstances of the assault, the sentence of imprisonment was reduced to time already served (15 days). 2)The trial judge erred in imposing the 10 year fire arm prohibition under S.100 of the Code. S.100 requires a conviction on an indictable offence involving violence against a person where the maximum sentence available is 10 years imprisonment or more. 3)The maximum sentence for assault under S.266 is 5 years if the Crown proceeds by indictment and 6 months if, as here, the Crown proceeds summarily.
column8: The accused was convicted of an assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to a term of 6 months imprisonment and to enter into a probation order for 18 months on certain specific conditions. A ten-year firearm, ammunition and explosive substance prohibition order was made against the appellant pursuant to the provisions of s. 81(1)(a) of the Code. The accused appealed the sentence and reduced the term of imprisonment imposed at trial from 6 months to "time served" and maintained the 18 month probation order subject only to amending the time within which the appellant was to report to the chief probation officer as therein provided. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The sentence imposed was too severe. 2)The appellant had now served 15 days of the sentence. 3)The prohibition order had been lifted. 4)The appeal against the sentence was allowed and set aside.

The accused appealed the sentence and reduced the term of imprisonment imposed at trial from 6 months to "time served" and maintained the 18 month probation order subject only to amending the time within which the appellant was to report to the chief probation officer as therein provided. HELD: The appeal was allowed and set aside. The sentence imposed was too severe and the appellant had now served 15 days of the sentence already served. A prohibition order had been made against him on the basis of his first offence of 1989 when he was convicted for an '08 offence at a time when he had just about 20 years of age. The appellant appealed the prohibition order. On September 29, 1994, the appeal against the sentence was allowed. The appeal against it was set aside and the sentence reduced to a time served order subject to the appellant reporting to the Chief Probation Officer as required by s. 100(1). In these circumstances, having regard for the application principles of protection of society, deterrence, rehabilitation, reformation and re-rehabilitation, and the need to maintain the public's confidence in the administration of justice, the Court allowed the appeal and reduced sentence to time served.

column17: The Crown elected to proceed summarily and the accused entered a plea of guilty to a charge of assault under S.266 of the Code. He was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment, 18 months probation and a 10 year fire arm prohibition was imposed. He appealed his sentence. column2: The wife sought to have the terms of the parties' separation agreement incorporated into the corollary relief judgment following a four year marriage. The husband sought to vary the provisions of the agreement regarding spousal and child support on the basis that the particulars of the agreement did not reflect his net business income derived from self-employment. The husband argued that he had entered into the separation agreement (which provided for joint custody of their young child, gave the wife all of the matrimonial assets with the exception of the husband's vehicle, and provided for spousal support in the amount of $600 per month for 15 years) only as an attempt to have the wife stay in the local area with the child. The wife had since moved with the child to New Brunswick where she was living with her parents and attending university; she was renting out the matrimonial home. Pursuant to the current court order, she was contributing the sum of $140 per month to the husband's access costs. Husband's current income set and child support awarded; the husband shall be responsible for 50 percent of the after tax child care costs; an additional $300 of spousal support ordered per month while the child remains in New Brunswick to address the access costs in the mother's budget; spousal support is reviewable in the event that these circumstances change, and at any rate, upon the completion of the mother's current degree; the mother shall not remove the child from the Province of New Brunswick to live in any other province without the father's consent. Although the court could not interfere with the agreement under s. 29 of the Matrimonial Property Act, the spousal and child support geared at keeping the wife in the local area and ensuring that her needs were addressed had all changed and a new arrangement was necessary to reflect the access costs among other issues. The wife had chosen to move away from child care services provided by the family that were practically free, as well as significant financial support and the ability to work in the furniture business with her father-in-law; she was not now pursuing a line of education which would build on her previous skills. Her educational expenses ought not be the basis for assessing spousal support and the duration of support set out in the separation agreement far exceeded what might be imposed by a court given the years they were together and their income disparity. The court reviewed the husband's history of income and expenses in setting his income for child support purposes.
column3: The petitioner sought a variation of the provisions regarding child support and spousal support in accordance with the Separation Agreement entered into between the parties in 2004. The parties were married for six years and had lived together for six months. The petitioner had commenced divorce proceedings in 2004 and had commenced living with her parents. The husband had commenced a new business and had made significant improvements to the home. The wife had been working part-time as a social worker for the past six years. She had recently moved to Moncton and was seeking a change in the terms of the agreement. The respondent had made no effort to negotiate a mobility restriction clause. The agreement was intended to provide sufficient money to keep the petitioner and her child in the home and to provide for the child's education. The mother had been unable to obtain employment and was now living with the father's parents. She was also unable to access the child. The father had made substantial contributions to the marriage including $5,000 to the wife's credit card balance and $1,000 in the amount of $47,461. The court found that the respondent had not made any effort to change the provisions of the Separations Agreement. The Court found that it was unfair to favour the petitioner over the petitioner. The Separation agreement was not varied under s.29 of the Matrimonial Property Act or treated like an ordinary variation that occurs when circumstances change relating to support orders. The facts before the court were that the parties had agreed to a separation agreement and that the particulars of the Agreement did not and do not reflect his net business income derived from self employment. The Respondent had not indicated that he would accept the terms and the terms in the Separate Agreement. HELD: The Court held that the Sepseparation Agreement was not a formality and that it should not be varied under the Matriarchal Property Act. The Agreement was a valid agreement and the Court was not bound by it.
column4: [3] He seeks a variation of the provisions regarding child support and spousal support. He seeks an increase in access. I am prepared to order while the child remains in Moncton an additional $300 spousal support for a month for a limited term to address the access costs in the mother’s budget that are associated with access.

column2: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol or drug (Code ss.253(a) and 255(1)). The accused admitted to consuming one vodka cooler before driving but argued the signs of impairment were manifestations of his panic attack. No .08 charge was laid, as his readings were .07 and .06. HELD: The accused was found guilty of impaired driving. The evidence did not support the argument that he was in the throws of a panic attack. The blood-alcohol readings show he was below the legal limit but the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol proved beyond a reasonable doubt his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol. As stated in McCallum, the fact that the effects of alcohol may have been exacerbated by the accused suffering from fatigue does not provide a defence to the charge.
column3: The accused was charged with having the care or control of a motor vehicle while his ability to operate a motor car was impaired by alcohol or drugs. The accused was found not guilty. The evidence of the police officers who responded to the scene was to the effect that when stopped by the police he was suffering from a panic attack. The officer who responded had the presence of mind to check the accused's memory of the events prior to and after the driving and arrest was found to be in good standing. The court found that the accused had the care of a vehicle while the accused was impaired. The defence argued that the evidence did not support the accused’s admission that he was in the throws of a panic event. The Court found that while the police were focused on impairment by alcohol, the accused showed signs of impairment displayed by him that were equally consistent with a panic assault. The police officers were focused not on impairment but on the symptoms of impairment by impairment. The blood alcohol content was at.08. The breath test results showed that the defendant was below the legal limit. The trial judge found that evidence of impairment was not supported by the accused. The test results did not raise a reasonable doubt as to his guilt. The issue was whether the accused exhibited symptoms of general anxiety disorder or a panic disorder. The symptoms of the symptoms were the result of either or were equally inconsistent with a Panic Attack. The factors of impairment were the same as those of a Panic attack.
column4: [1] The accused is charged that on the 24th day of September, 2001, at the Prince Albert District in the Province of Saskatchewan, he had the care or control of a motor vehicle while his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or a drug. The defence position is that the signs and symptoms of impairment displayed by the accused were the result of, or were equally consistent with, a panic attack. [20] The blood-alcohol readings testified to show that the accused was below the legal limit but in my view that evidence together with the other evidence involving consumption of alcohol and the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused’s ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol: [21] I find the accused guilty as charged.
column7: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol or drug (Code ss.253(a) and 255(1)). The defence argued that the evidence was not supported by the evidence and that evidence of impairment was not enough to support the defence position.

column2: ,  motions granted. Both appeals are dismissed as a result of the appellant's failure to perfect, including her failure to file necessary materials or comply with the court's directions to do so. While a dismissal of the criminal appeal is a serious remedy, since it means it will never be heard on its merits, the appellant has made it clear that she cannot provide certified transcripts unless the court orders the respondents to pay. The court has already declined to do so. There is no suggestion a further extension of time will result in the appellant perfecting the appeal.
column3: The appellant appealed the June 2011 decision of the Provincial Court which found that she had committed the act of public mischief under s. 140 of the Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, when she reported an offence of assault with weapon to an RCMP officer, causing him to enter an investigation, when the alleged offence had not been committed and she was not criminally responsible. The respondents were to pay the cost of certifying the 1,700 pages of transcript she had typed herself. The appellant applied for an extension of time to appeal the June 2012 decision of Justice Coughlan. The Court dismissed the appeal and ordered the respondents to pay $1,000 to certify the transcript. The court dismissed the appellant's motion to consolidate both appeals and to have the respondents pay to certify transcripts. The respondent motion to dismiss both appeals was granted. The appeal was dismissed for failure to perfect. The order of the respondents was dismissed. The matter was remitted to the respondents for a hearing on December 1. The applicant had not filed her materials on time and had not provided certified transcripts. She had not satisfied that she could provide certified transcripts unless she ordered the respondent to pay. The applicants' motions to dismiss the Criminal Appeal and to require the respondents paid to certify transcript were dismissed.
column4: Held: The appellant’s motion to consolidate both appeals and to have the respondents pay to certify the transcript is dismissed. The appellant’s appeals, CAC 341990 and CA 352311, are hereby dismissed for failure to perfect. I am convinced there is no merit to this, given Ms. Cummings’ position that she cannot provide certified transcripts, unless I order the respondents to pay, which I have indicated I am not prepared to do. [22] I dismiss her Criminal Appeal for failure to perfect. [23] I also dismiss Ms. Cummings’ Civil Appeal for failure to perfect. [24] In summary, Ms. Cummings’ motions to consolidate her two appeals and to have the respondents pay to certify the transcripts are dismissed The respondents’ motions to dismiss her Criminal and Civil Appeals are granted.

column2: The accused youth is charged with driving a motor vehicle while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol or drug contrary to s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code. The issue was whether the evidence was sufficient to prove impairment beyond a reasonable doubt. HELD: The only reliable indicia of impairment were a very strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face. Beyond that, the indicators are either inconclusive, non-existent or the accused offered a reasonable explanation for them. The evidence is so frail as to leave a reasonable doubt as to impairment and the accused was acquitted. 1) The accused was exceeding the speed limit and failed to signal lane changes. His vehicle wandered somewhat in the lane, but did not stray into the other lane. The observations of his driving were made over 2-minute period. The aspects of the driving that were observed may have been the result of driver inattention. 2) The bloodshot eyes may have been the result of chain smoking. Further, the evidence of glazed eyes is inconclusive in the absence of reliable evidence of bloodshot eyes. 3) The evidence of flushed face was reliable evidence of impairment. 4) The evidence of strong odour of alcohol is reliable indicia of impairment, due to the consumption of alcohol by the accused. 5) The accused did not have any problem with balance, but was moving in slow and deliberate manner. If the accused was not displaying difficulty with balance and coordination, then the suggestion that he was moving slowly is not a credible indicator of impairment. The accused did not display slurred speech and appeared to comprehend his legal rights and obligations. He did not display any mental confusion or inappropriate behaviour. In the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for the physical tests administered, the proper method of application and their reliability the Court could not rely on them. 6) The accused blew 80 milligrams on two occasions. However, regardless of the alcohol consumption and the accused blood alcohol concentration, the only reliable indicia of impairment were a strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving contrary to s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code. The issue was whether the evidence was sufficient to prove impairment beyond a reasonable doubt. HELD: The accused was found guilty. 1)The evidence of impairment was not supported by the evidence of the accused's prior driving. 2)The accused did not display any symptoms of impairment. The officer noted that the accused was visiting with his friends and as soon as he was aware of the emergency lights, he began to slow and pull over to the shoulder, being required to do so safely because he had just passed the vehicle. 3)The court found that in the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for these tests, the proper method of application, and to comment on their relative reliability, it was not appropriate for the court to rely upon them on the issue of guilt or innocence, to the prejudice of the defendant. 4)The Court found that the evidence did not support the accused’s impairment beyond the reasonable doubt and that the suggestion that he was moving slowly was not a credible indicator of impairment and will not be given undue weight for that purpose. 5)The test results were inconclusive. The accused did have a reasonable amount of difficulty with balance and coordination. The evidence of his lack of coordination and inability to perform physical tests was not considered a reliable indicator of impaired driving. The test results did not indicate impairment. 6)The officer noted the accused had a very strong smell of alcohol in the vehicle and that he had been drinking beer with his lunch. The police were called to the scene and the accused indicated that he did not remember seeing the previous day during the party nor that he noticed the smell of marijuana. The court concluded that in absence of an expert evidence, the court was not able to decide whether the accused would be guilty or innocent. 7)The only evidence of impaired operation was the alcohol consumption. The Court found the accused did display slurred speech. The defendant appeared to fully comprehend his legal rights and obligations in his communications with the peace officer, peace officer and legal aid duty counsel. The opportunity to make the observations was only during roughly two minutes. The Crown did not show any mental confusion or inappropriate behaviour. The defence did not demonstrate any mental or physical impairment.
column4: [1] The accused youth is charged that on April 27, 2002, near Dundurn Saskatchewan, he did operate a motor vehicle while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol or a drug, contrary to Section 253(a) of the Criminal Code. [2] The issue which arose herein was whether the evidence was sufficient to prove impairment beyond a reasonable doubt. In my view, if the accused was not displaying difficulty with balance and coordination, the suggestion that he was moving slowly is not a credible indicator of impairment and will not be given undue weight for that purpose. In any event, I have concluded that in the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for these tests, the proper method of application, and to comment on their relative reliability, it is not appropriate for the court to rely upon them on the issue of guilt or innocence, to the prejudice of the accused. [39] However, regardless of that alcohol consumption, and the accused’s blood alcohol concentration, the only reliable indicia of impairment were a very strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face. Beyond that, the indicators are either inconclusive, non-existent or the accused has offered a reasonable explanation for them. As a result, the evidence is so frail as to leave a reasonable doubt as to impairment, and the accused must be acquitted.

He appeared to fully comprehend his legal rights and obligations in his communications with the peace officer, peace officer and legal aid duty counsel. 2)The evidence of a very strong smell of alcohol in the vehicle was not a reliable indicator of impairment. He appeared to fully comprehend his legal rights and obligations in his communications with the peace officer, peace officer and legal aid duty counsel. 2)The evidence of a very strong smell of alcohol in the vehicle was not a reliable indicator of impairment. 3)The court found that in the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for these tests, the proper method of application, and to comment on their relative reliability, it is not appropriate for the court to rely upon them on the issue of guilt or innocence, to the prejudice of the accused. 4)The Court found that the evidence of impairment which is alleged by the Crown must be considered in the context of the principles contained in R. v. Stellato (1994), 1994 CanLII 94 (SCC), 18 C.R. (4th) 127, in which the Supreme Court approved the following: 'In all criminal cases the trial judge must be satisfied that the accused's ability to operate motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug. In this case, the accused was operating his vehicle in light traffic. He was exceeding the speed limit and had failed to signal lane changes, which he made in an abrupt manner as he passed the only other vehicle in the immediate vicinity. As well, although the vehicle wandered somewhat within its lane, it did not stray into the other lane of traffic. The officer noted the accused appeared to be fully comprehending his rights and responsibilities in his communication with peace officers, peace duty duty counsel and defence counsel. He did not show any mental confusion, or noteworthy inappropriate behaviour. He conducted himself in a rational and reasonable manner. 5)In any event, the court must carefully review all of the reported tests and observations which inferentially support or negate any impairment of a person's mental and physical capabilities. The evidence of an accused who is not displaying difficulty with balance and coordination, the suggestion that he was moving slowly is not a credible indication of impairment and will not be given undue weight for that purpose.  6)The test results were inconclusive. The accused's bloodshot or watery eyes were not reliable indicators of impairment as they were not consistent with alcohol or drugs. 7)The officer did not offer an opinion as to the reliability of the tests.
column14: [1] The accused youth is charged that on April 27, 2002, near Dundurn Saskatchewan, he did operate a motor vehicle while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol or a drug, contrary to Section 253(a) of the Criminal Code. [2] The issue which arose herein was whether the evidence was sufficient to prove impairment beyond a reasonable doubt. In my view, if the accused was not displaying difficulty with balance and coordination, the suggestion that he was moving slowly is not a credible indicator of impairment and will not be given undue weight for that purpose. In any event, I have concluded that in the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for these tests, the proper method of application, and to comment on their relative reliability, it is not appropriate for the court to rely upon them on the issue of guilt or innocence, to the prejudice of the accused. [39] However, regardless of that alcohol consumption, and the accused’s blood alcohol concentration, the only reliable indicia of impairment were a very strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face. Beyond that, the indicators are either inconclusive, non-existent or the accused has offered a reasonable explanation for them. As a result, the evidence is so frail as to leave a reasonable doubt as to impairment, and the accused must be acquitted.
column17: The accused youth is charged with driving a motor vehicle while his ability to do so was impaired by alcohol or drug contrary to s. 253(a) of the Criminal Code. The issue was whether the evidence was sufficient to prove impairment beyond a reasonable doubt. HELD: The only reliable indicia of impairment were a very strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face. Beyond that, the indicators are either inconclusive, non-existent or the accused offered a reasonable explanation for them. The evidence is so frail as to leave a reasonable doubt as to impairment and the accused was acquitted. 1) The accused was exceeding the speed limit and failed to signal lane changes. His vehicle wandered somewhat in the lane, but did not stray into the other lane. The observations of his driving were made over 2-minute period. The aspects of the driving that were observed may have been the result of driver inattention. 2) The bloodshot eyes may have been the result of chain smoking. Further, the evidence of glazed eyes is inconclusive in the absence of reliable evidence of bloodshot eyes. 3) The evidence of flushed face was reliable evidence of impairment. 4) The evidence of strong odour of alcohol is reliable indicia of impairment, due to the consumption of alcohol by the accused. 5) The accused did not have any problem with balance, but was moving in slow and deliberate manner. If the accused was not displaying difficulty with balance and coordination, then the suggestion that he was moving slowly is not a credible indicator of impairment. The accused did not display slurred speech and appeared to comprehend his legal rights and obligations. He did not display any mental confusion or inappropriate behaviour. In the absence of expert evidence to explain the scientific basis for the physical tests administered, the proper method of application and their reliability the Court could not rely on them. 6) The accused blew 80 milligrams on two occasions. However, regardless of the alcohol consumption and the accused blood alcohol concentration, the only reliable indicia of impairment were a strong odour of alcohol and a flushed face.

column2: The mother moved for the dismissal of the pending permanent care trial, arguing that, applying the reasoning in a recent Court of Appeal decision, the court had lost jurisdiction. No trial had been held on any issue as all matters had proceeded to this point with the consent of the parties. The time for trial had been extended to allow the mother to retain counsel. Application dismissed; the court had not lost jurisdiction; trial to proceed. The Court of Appeal decision stands for the proposition that, once a trial at any stage of the Act is held, no order can have effect beyond the next statutory deadline; however, this is so only when the extensions are included in an order which follows trial. When the best interests of the child require it, an extension of a statutory deadline can be made in order to have a trial completed in respect of any stage of the Act. When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child's best interest for the court to order a rushed trial date.
column3: The mother sought a dismissal of the matter on the basis that the trial date was after the outside disposition date provided in the Act. The Court of Appeal had issued a decision in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia Minister of Community Service v. B.F. that confirmed that the judge had not lost jurisdiction despite the fact that the agency had not yet made a final determination. The mother argued that the time limit exceeded the overall deadline and that the court had lost jurisdiction to hear the matter because the trial was to commence tomorrow. HELD: The Court dismissed the motion. 1)The B.W. case stands for the proposition that once the determination at a particular stage of the proceeding is made at trial or otherwise, and with the exception of reserving the Court's decision, no order can have effect beyond the statutory deadline. 2)The Court of Appeals' decision was accepted.
column4: I have before me a motion in this case under the Children and Family Services Act, S.N.S. 1990. c.5 (which I will hereinafter refer to as the "Act") by which the mother asks for a dismissal of this matter on the basis that I have lost my jurisdiction to hear the case because the trial date is after the outside disposition date provided in the Act. The Court of Appeal issued a decision, subsequent to my ruling, in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia (Minister of Community Service) v. B.F. at 2003 NSCA 119 (CanLII), 2003 N.S.J. 405 which I will hereinafter refer to as B.F. This morning, as mentioned, counsel for the mother made a motion that based on the rule in B.F. I had lost my jurisdiction and must dismiss the matter. When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child’s best interest for a rushed trial date. In summary, the H.W. case stands for the following principle: when the best interests of the child requires it, an extension of a deadline to make a determination at the then stage of the proceeding by trial or otherwise is acceptable and no loss of jurisdiction occurs. In my opinion, the B.F. case stands for the following proposition: once the determination at a particular stage of the proceeding is made at trial or otherwise, and with the exception of reserving the Court’s decision, no order can have effect beyond the statutory deadline. In conclusion, the Court has not lost its jurisdiction in this matter and the trial will commence tomorrow.

column2: The female driver, the accused and two other men were in a vehicle that was stopped on suspicion of being involved in a robbery. A gun and many of the stolen items were found in the vehicle and all the occupants were charged with a number of offences, including robbery. The accused denied being in the area where the robbery occurred but alleged that they had stopped and picked up the two other men. While at the police station, he pulled a ring that had been reported stolen out of his pants and placed it on his finger. At his trial, one of the other men testified that he had pled guilty to the robbery; the driver testified that she had driven directly from her home to where the vehicle was stopped by the police, without stopping; and the complainant testified that he had been lured to the driver's house, where he was ambushed by her and three men, robbed and threatened. Although his descriptions matched the two other males in the vehicle, he positively stated that the accused was not the third person. Accused found not guilty on all charges; the Crown had not proven that he was involved in the robbery or that he should have known there was a gun or stolen property in the car. Although the circumstances in which the accused was taken into custody were more than suspicious, the fact that the complainant had clearly seen the robbers but had made a positive non-identification created an inconsistency that raised a reasonable doubt.
column3: The police stopped a car driven by a young person suspected of having been involved in a robbery with a firearm at a specific address in Sackville. The police stopped the car and found a hand gun under the seat and with stolen property. The accused was found in the car with the driver and two young men in the vehicle. The Crown argued that the accused was simply confused and not able to identify the people involved. The defence argued that because the accused clearly saw the people who robbed him, that the circumstances in which the accused saw the person who had been robbed were more than suspicious. The circumstances in the circumstances were more concerning than the police finding the accused in the courtroom. The court found that the person in the accused's car who had pleaded guilty to the robbery and who fit the general description of one of the robbers was the accused. The evidence from the Crown argued the accused had not been in the court room when the police stopped him and that the two young people in the driver's car had left the location of the robbery. The Court also argued that there was a strong circumstantial evidence that the Crown could have identified the accused with the help of the police. The circumstantials did not support the conclusion that the court could have concluded that the victim had not seen the people he described. The fact that the police found the accused sitting on the bench was more than enough to conclude that the crime was committed by the accused and that he had not simply been picked up by the police but had been picked-up by the other two young males. The trial judge concluded that there were no reasonable grounds to conclude the accused could have been identified with the assistance of the Crown. The only conclusion that could be drawn was that the evidence from both the Crown and the defence was circumstantially inconsistent. The first inference was that because of the circumstances the accused did not see the people in his car that he was not able or willing to identify them. The second inference was based on the fact that he clearly saw his assailants when the Police stopped it in high risk take down and that their identities would be determined. The third inference was also based on his failure to identify himself. The facts were not in dispute. The crime was not committed by him. The two young guys who were in the defendant's car when the robbery was committed were the only people who were there when the others were picked up in at some building, somewhere in Fairview. The last inference was the same: that the defendant was not in the building when the crime took place
column4: [1] On December 13, 2010 the police stopped a car driven by Candace MacDonald. It was suspected of having been involved in a robbery with a firearm at a specific address in Sackville. Had he simply not been able to identify M.M. in the courtroom as one of those people, it could be said that with the passing of a few months that could be accounted for by fading memory. There is an inconsistency in the story that is so important that it raises a reasonable doubt. The Crown has not proven beyond a reasonable doubt that M.M. was involved in the robbery, assault, confinement or threatening of Nykell Brooks. It has not proven that he was involved in the robbery and because of that there is no evidence that he knew or should have known that he was in a car with a gun or stolen property.

column2: The defendant was charged with unlawfully harvesting forest products contrary to s. 79(1)(a) of The Forest Resources Management Act, unlawfully possessing forest products without a licence contrary to s. 79(1)(c) and unlawfully trafficking in forest products contrary to s. 79(1)(f) of the Act. He was acquitted of the first two charges and convicted of the third. He appealed his conviction. He was fined $1,000 with a 40% surcharge. The Crown appealed the sentence. The appellant argued that since he was acquitted of the related charges, it followed that he should not have been convicted of trafficking. The charges had arisen as a result of a lengthy undercover investigation into the activities of the appellant. He was known to be harvesting fire kill in the Nesbitt Forest, which was Crown land. He stored wood on his property and on that of a relative. If the appellant was using it himself, he did not require a permit. The undercover conservation officer purchased fire wood from the appellant, who told the officer that the wood was from Crown land in an answer to officer's question whether it was cut on private land. The appellant did not testify at his trial nor did his relative and so the evidence of the conservation officer was uncontradicted. The evidence presented on his behalf was from individuals who had purchased wood from the defendant. The trial judge held that the charges against the appellant were strict liability offences and once the Crown had demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt that the prohibited acts had been committed, the appellant had to establish on the balance of probabilities that he had been duly diligent and took all reasonable care to avoid offending. With respect to the first two charges, the trial judge held that he was not satisfied that during the period described in the indictment that the Crown had proven the actus reus of the offences but that it had on the third count, based on the appellant's own words to the officer. The appellant argued on appeal that his words could have been taken to mean that he was describing where he harvested wood for his own use and therefore his statement was not an admission that he sold wood to the officer or anyone else from Crown lands. HELD: The Court held that the trial judge erred in his reasoning and conclusion that appellant was guilty of trafficking because he had not been duly diligent. It is only if the actus reus was proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the considerations of whether due diligence had been proven would arise. The conviction could not be maintained because the qualifying actus reus was not proven. However, the other aspect of the evidence, which was not expressly considered by the trial judge and which would sustain a conviction, was if evidence established trafficking via another modality. Since s. 2(dd) of the Act defines 'traffic' to mean 'to offer for sale, barter, deal, solicit or tradeÃ ' and s. 79(1) states that it is an offence to traffic in forest products from Crown land without a licence, then the offence is complete by offering the product for sale without a licence. The appellant led no evidence to establish he had either the required permit to harvest forest products from Crown lands or a licence or any other form of authorization to deal in forest products. Thus, the evidence established beyond a reasonable doubt that the appellant was guilty of trafficking in forest products contrary to s. 79(1)(f) of the Act. The conviction was upheld. Regarding sentencing, the Court held that it was important to deter other offenders. The trial judge's sentence of a fine equivalent to the levy avoided (the provincial charge per cord of wood) was inappropriately low. The Court set the appropriate fine at $5,000 plus a victim fund surcharge of 40% as required by s. 3 of The Victims of Crime Regulations. If the fine was not paid within 60 days, the appellant would serve a term of imprisonment of 90 days.
column3: The defendant appealed his conviction on a charge of unlawfully harvesting forest products and unlawfully possessing forest products. He argued the Crown had proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the wood he sold to an undercover officer was wood harvested from Crown lands. The Crown appealed the sentence imposed on the conviction of unlawfully trafficking in forest products, arguing the fine was unreasonable or insufficiently low and that the evidence established that the accused had unlawfully harvested wood from Crown land. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The evidence of the conservation officers was uncontradicted. 2)The Crown appealed. 3)The Court of Queen's Bench found that a fine of $1,000 with a 40% surcharge was an unreasonably low penalty for the offence the evidence establishes. 4)The acquittals on the charges of unlawfully harvested and unlawfully possessed forest products have not been appealed. 5)The trial judge must show great deference in reviewing the decisions of trial judges, interfering to vary sentence only if the sentence is clearly unreasonable or demonstrably unfit.
