column2: The appellant was granted release pending appeal, on conditions. The Crown applied for a review. The Crown contended that the Chambers judge misinterpreted the definition of custody in granting the application, as the appellant was on day parole at the time of the application. Dismissing the application, that day parole with a requirement to return to a halfway house each night is a form of custody which allows for an application and release under s. 679 of the Code.
column3: The Crown applied for a review under s. 680(1) of the Criminal Code. Following an application for release pending appeal pursuant to s. 679(1), the Crown applied to the chief justice or acting chief justice of the court of appeal for direction that the decision be reviewed by the court's court of appeals. The original order was dated October 1999 and an amended order changing several of the conditions was dated November 8, 1999. The Crown applied on the same date as the amended order. Following the application for a judicial review under the Code, the Crown applies for a written decision granting the release with conditions pending Mr. Wood's appeal scheduled to be heard January 26, 2000. HELD: The appeal is dismissed. 1)The Court of Appeal has no bearing on the decision. 2)The Crown relies upon its submission that the respondent was not in custody, therefore, Justice Cromwell misinterpreted the definition of custody by granting the 679 application. 3)The Chambers judge erred in law in ruling the appellant, at the time the application under s679 of the Code was made, was in custody within the meaning of s.679.
column4: [1] Following an application for release pending appeal pursuant to section 679(1) of the Criminal Code, Justice Cromwell issued a written decision on October 19, 1999, granting the release with conditions, pending Mr. Wood’s appeal scheduled to be heard January 26, 2000. On the same date as the amended order, the Crown applied for a review under s. 680(1) of the Code. [6] Based on the cases cited in the decision of Justice Cromwell, in my opinion, day parole with a requirement to return to a halfway house each night is a form of custody which then allows for an application and release under s. 679 of the Code. The application for direction that the decision of October 19, 1999 be reviewed is refused.

column2: The Agency applied for permanent care of a young child, with no access to the parents. Each of the mother, the biological father and the psychological father sought to have the child placed in their care. The child had been apprehended due to unsafe and unhealthy living conditions. The mother and psychological father no longer lived together and for the past few months, the mother had been maintaining a clean and tidy apartment and attempting to improve her education and had taken parenting courses. The psychological father, with whom the mother had ended a tumultuous relationship, wanted the child returned to his care, stating that he planned on residing with the mother who would assist him in caring for the child. The mother was against this plan. The biological father only reappeared on the scene after the child was taken into care and acknowledged that the child did not know him as her father. Child placed in the permanent care of the Agency with no access to the mother or the psychological father; access ordered to the biological father for a period of six months at which time the access order will expire automatically unless an application to vary is made; the Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment of the biological father. The child continued to be at substantial risk of physical harm due to neglect if she was returned to the mother's care and the child would be at risk of exposure to violence if returned to the psychological father's care due to the tumultuous relationship between the mother and him. Although some improvements had recently been made in the mother's life, she had a history of frequent changes of residence and did not appear able put the child's needs ahead of her own. The Agency had not had an opportunity to assess the appropriateness of a placement with the biological father.
column3: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The agency alleged that the respondent parents had failed to cooperate in addressing the risk factors identified at previous court hearings and acknowledged by the Respondents in consenting to a protection finding. The child was placed in the care of the respondent mother and psychological father. The biological father opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to his care. The mother's sister opposed the request and requested that the child be placed with another family. The respondent parents were to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's sister was to be placed in temporary foster care. HELD: The child remained in the agency's custody. The court found that the circumstances had changed since the previous disposition order and that the parties had failed in addressing risk factors. The Agency was concerned that the biological father was not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing their risk factors which affected the health and safety of their child. This was the basis for the application for a protection order. The father was to have access to her residence.
column4: [1] The Children\'s Aid Society of Cape Breton-Victoria (agency) applied for an order of Permanent Care and Custody, with no provision for access, with respect to the child, S.N.D., born [in 2003]. However, the mother has a history of frequent changes of residences and this period of stability only has been a few months. [53] Although the mother loves her child and wants to care for her she does not seem to be able to put her child\'s needs ahead of her own needs. Therefore, the Court finds that an Order for access is not appropriate with respect to the mother and psychological father. [70] The Court is satisfied that an access Order for a limited period of six months (to expire on April 13, 2006) is appropriate in order to have the father\'s parenting capacity and circumstances assessed. The Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment and the father is to make himself available for an assessment.
column7: The Agency applied for permanent care of a young child, with no access to the parents. Each of the mother, the biological father and the psychological father sought to have the child placed in their care. The child had been apprehended due to unsafe and unhealthy living conditions. The mother and psychological father no longer lived together and for the past few months, the mother had been maintaining a clean and tidy apartment and attempting to improve her education and had taken parenting courses. The psychological father, with whom the mother had ended a tumultuous relationship, wanted the child returned to his care, stating that he planned on residing with the mother who would assist him in caring for the child. The mother was against this plan. The biological father only reappeared on the scene after the child was taken into care and acknowledged that the child did not know him as her father. Child placed in the permanent care of the Agency with no access to the mother or the psychological father; access ordered to the biological father for a period of six months at which time the access order will expire automatically unless an application to vary is made; the Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment of the biological father. The child continued to be at substantial risk of physical harm due to neglect if she was returned to the mother's care and the child would be at risk of exposure to violence if returned to the psychological father's care due to the tumultuous relationship between the mother and him. Although some improvements had recently been made in the mother's life, she had a history of frequent changes of residence and did not appear able put the child's needs ahead of her own. The Agency had not had an opportunity to assess the appropriateness of a placement with the biological father.
column8: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father was residing with the mother and providing care to the daughter. The child was charged with assault in June 2005 when the agency threatened to take the child from her. Court proceedings were not pursued when the biological grandmother consented to an order transferring custody of the child back to the mother. The father opposed the request and requested that the child remain in the care of the Agency. HELD: The child remained in the agency's custody subject to the terms and conditions of the protection finding. The agency reviewed the home visits to L.A.D. and J.C.E.'s homes and found that there was a substantial risk of physical harm caused by the mother's failure to supervise the child and that the risk of harm was higher for the psychological father than for the biological mother. There was no evidence that the biological father had any contact with the child prior to the hearing.
column9: [1] The Children\'s Aid Society of Cape Breton-Victoria (agency) applied for an order of Permanent Care and Custody, with no provision for access, with respect to the child, S.N.D., born [in 2003]. However, the mother has a history of frequent changes of residences and this period of stability only has been a few months. [53] Although the mother loves her child and wants to care for her she does not seem to be able to put her child\'s needs ahead of her own needs. Therefore, the Court finds that an Order for access is not appropriate with respect to the mother and psychological father. [70] The Court is satisfied that an access Order for a limited period of six months (to expire on April 13, 2006) is appropriate in order to have the father\'s parenting capacity and circumstances assessed. The Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment and the father is to make himself available for an assessment.

column13: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The agency alleged that the respondent parents had continually breached conditions of the court order and did not cooperate in addressing the risk factors identified at previous court hearings and acknowledged by the Respondents in consenting to a protection finding. HELD: 1) The child remained in the care of the agency and was eligible to remain in permanent care. 2) There was no evidence of physical harm caused by the mother and psychological father. 3) There were no threats to her safety. The child's safety was put at risk. 4) The burden of proof in proceeding such as this is clearly on the Agency. It is a civil burden of evidence that must have regard to the seriousness of the consequences of the decision.

column18: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father who had minimal contact with the child was added as a party by Order dated September 15, 2005. HELD: The child was placed in the permanent care of the Agency. The agency was concerned that the respondent mother and psychological father were not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing the risk factors which affected the child's health and well-being. The child had been in the Agency's care for three years. The Agency had taken the child into care because of instability in the home, the mother's repeated moves, the father's failure to supervise the child, and the risk that she may suffer harm through being removed from, kept away from, returned to or allowed to remain in the care of this Agency. There were ongoing problems in relation to the prior Supervision Order, including inappropriate parenting by the mother, the psychological father, the biological mother's sister and the 17 year old youth who were in the agency's care at the time of the child being apprehended, and a lack of cooperation between the Agency and the respondent parents.

column23: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child, S.N.D., born in 2003. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father who had minimal contact with the child was added as a party by Order dated September 15, 2005. HELD: The child was placed in the permanent care of the Agency. The agency was concerned that the respondent mother and psychological father were not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing the risk factors which affected the child's health and well-being. The child had a history of domestic violence and was in the care of her mother and a psychological father who resided in several foster and group homes. The father was considered a parent or guardian pursuant to s. 36(1)(b) and 3(1) of the Child Protection Act. The Agency received information concerning inappropriate parenting by the mother and the psychological father. At a risk conference meeting on January 19, 2005 the agency decided to seek an order for access. The Respondent mother and her biological father were to attend and complete a treatment program for alcohol, prescription medication and street drugs. The psychological father was to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's application for party status was adjourned because the parental capacity assessment was not completed until September 12, which did not allow sufficient time for review prior to hearing. The respondent mother was to attend a risk management conference meeting and requested that the child be placed for adoption, compared with the merits of the child remaining with or returning to parent or, guardian.

column27: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The agency alleged that the respondent parents had failed to cooperate in addressing the risk factors identified at previous court hearings and acknowledged by the Respondents in consenting to a protection finding. The child was placed in the care of the respondent mother and psychological father. The biological father opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to his care. The mother's sister opposed the request and requested that the child be placed with another family. The respondent parents were to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's sister was to be placed in temporary foster care. HELD: The child remained in the agency's custody. The court found that the circumstances had changed since the previous disposition order and that the parties had failed in addressing risk factors. The Agency was concerned that the biological father was not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing their risk factors which affected the health and safety of their child. This was the basis for the application for a protection order. The father was to have access to her residence.

column2: The defendant applied for a stay of proceedings on the basis of a violation of his right to be tried in a reasonable time. There had been delay of approximately 14.5 months from the time that he was charged with exceeding the breathalyzer and impaired driving to the date of his trial. Stay of proceedings granted. At his first court appearance the defendant requested the first available trial date and there was no evidence to suggest that an institutional delay of 13 months was the norm in other metro provincial courts. Given the nature of the charges, the technical nature of breathalyzer law and the defendant's stated intention to raise ss. 8 and 9 of the Charter, prejudice could be inferred on the basis that the length of delay was likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered.
column3: This was an application for a stay of proceedings based on a violation of the right to be tried within a reasonable time pursuant to s. 11(b) of the Charter. The accused was charged with exceeding the Breathalyzer and impaired driving contrary to s253(b), and was arraigned on the information (sworn to on September 29, 2002). The accused entered a not guilty plea and requested the first available date for trial and was given the date December 18, 2003. The Defense had verbalized an intention to raise s. 8 and s9 Charter motions and lead evidence to the contrary. The defence had indicated that it would raise a Charter motion and present evidence to contrary. HELD: The application was stayed.  1)There was no evidence before the court that institutional delay of 13 months is the norm in other metro provincial courts. Given the nature of the charges and the technical nature of Breathalyzers, the fact that the Defense has verbalized a intention to bring s.8 and s.9 Charter motion, the presumption that the accused deliberately or otherwise was attempting to escape trial on the merits was inferred. 2)There is no evidence that institutional delays of 13 month are the norm. Given a nature of these charges and technical nature, the factors that inevitably lead to delay or otherwise cause delay are inferred. 3)The length of the delay is likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered given the passage of time that has occurred since the circumstances giving rise to the charges.

column13: This was an application for a stay of proceedings based on a violation of the right to be tried within a reasonable time pursuant to s. 11(b) of the Charter. The accused was charged with exceeding the Breathalyzer and impaired driving contrary to s253(b), and was arraigned on the information (sworn to on September 29, 2002). He retained counsel and was prepared to fight the merits of the case at trial. The Defense had verbalized an intention to raise s. 8 and s9 Charter motions and lead evidence to the contrary. HELD: The application was stayed.  1)There was no evidence before the court that institutional delay of 13 months is the norm in other metro provincial courts. Given the nature of the charges and the technical nature of breathalyzer law, the fact that the Defense has verbalized a intention to bring s.8 and s.9 Charter motion and lead the evidence to a contrary, the length of the delay is likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered given the passage of time that the charges are being brought. 2)There is no evidence that the applicant waived the delay or part of it such that the remainder is not unreasonable. 3)The Court must be mindful of the rights s.11(b)(b) seek to protect and uphold and the purpose of those rights. The primary purpose is the protection of the individual's rights and the provision of fundamental justice for the accused, but the secondary purpose is to protect against the factors that inevitably lead to delay or otherwise cause delay. 4)The length of delay was likely to affect the quantity and quality of defence tendered. The time span was little more than 14 months. 5)The court was asked to infer prejudice on the basis of the length. The length of a delay is not inferred from the time the accused waived his right to a timely trial. 6)The issue before the Court is where the line is to be drawn between the rights of an individual to trial within reasonable time, and the societal right to bring those accused of crime to trial.  7)The fact that there was no prejudice to the accused flowing from the delay does not excuse the delay. The court must do is to balance the interests the system is designed to protect. 8)Prejudice can be inferred on a basis of length. 9)The longer the delay the easier it may be for the court to infer a prejudice. 10)The long delay is of no consequence to the applicant.

column2: The first defendant was the lessee and driver of a motor vehicle that was involved in a motor vehicle accident with the plaintiff. The second defendant was the lessor of the vehicle. The plaintiff brought an action against both the lessor and lessee, arguing that the second defendant was liable, both as the owner of the vehicle under the Motor Vehicle Act and pursuant to common law vicarious liability, for the lessee's negligence. The second defendant successfully applied for summary judgment, with the court finding that the lessor was not liable under the Motor Vehicle Act as the lease was not a 'rental contract' as defined in s. 62 of the Act and the lessor was not an 'owner' as defined in s. 2(ak) and the current state of the law did not suggest that a claim of vicarious liability had a real chance of success between a lessor and lessee. Both the plaintiff and the first defendant appealed. Appeal dismissed; the reverse onus provision in s. 248 does not apply in this case; the argument that the lease was not a conditional sales agreement but rather a rental agreement had no real chance of success and the fact that a vehicle is subject to a lease does not change the fact that there is no vicarious liability at common law between the owner and the driver of a vehicle.
column3: The appellants appealed a decision granting summary judgment to the respondent, Chrysler, granting summary judgement on the basis that it was not vicariously liable for the negligence of the plaintiff. The appellants argued that the Chambers judge erred in failing to properly apply the law in Bazley v. Pinkerton's of Canada Ltd., 2010 SCC (CanLII). Gilbert's claim against Chrysler was that it wasn't vicarly liable for negligence of Giffin. The insurer argued that complex legal issues cannot be decided on summary judgment. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1) The issue here is whether the Chambers Judge erred. 2) The plaintiff was not acting as the servant or agent of Chrysler in the operation of the motor vehicle at the time the accident occurred. The reverse onus provision simply does not apply.  3) The appellant did not demonstrate entitlement to judgment. 4) The court found that the issue was unambiguously determined by the precedents. The Chambers judge did not err in determining that the loss or damages occasioned by the collision of motor vehicles was solely the fault of the owner. The plaintiff had no real chance of success on the issues of this case. column2: The accused was charged with aggravated assault contrary to s. 268 of the Criminal Code; assault causing bodily harm contrary to s. 267(b) of the Code; dangerous driving contrary to s. 249(1)(a) of the Code; and two counts of assault contrary to s. 266(a) of the Code. HELD: 1) On the charge that the accused endangered the life of the complainant by attempting to strike her with a motor vehicle, the Court had strong suspicions that the accused did intend to strike the complainant with the vehicle but could not convict. 2) There was no doubt that bodily harm was caused to the complainant. The accused admits he slung her on the ground and kicked her and, as a result, the court find the accused guilty of assault causing bodily harm. 3) There is no doubt that the accused was operating a truck and that he drove it toward the complainant, who was lying on the concrete, and her daughter. It is unnecessary for the Crown to prove that the lives or safety of others were actually endangered. The offence is proved where the Crown establishes that the driving complained of was dangerous to the public. The offence requires a marked departure from prudent conduct. The offence of dangerous driving was established and the accused was found guilty. 4) The accused was found guilty of two counts of assault.

The accused admits he slung her on the ground and kicked her and, as a result, the court find the accused guilty of assault causing bodily harm. 3) There is no doubt that the accused was operating a truck and that he drove it toward the complainant, who was lying on the concrete, and her daughter. It is unnecessary for the Crown to prove that the lives or safety of others were actually endangered. The offence is proved where the Crown establishes that the driving complained of was dangerous to the public. The offence requires a marked departure from prudent conduct. The offence of dangerous driving was established and the accused was found guilty. 4) The accused was found guilty of two counts of assault.
column18: The accused was charged with aggravated assault contrary to s. 249(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both charges. 1)The offence was proved where the Crown established that the driving complained of was dangerous to the public. The offence requires a marked departure from prudent conduct. The evidence that the accused assaulted the complainant and caused her bodily harm was overwhelming. The Crown had proven the guilt of the accused on this count to my satisfaction beyond a reasonable doubt.  2)The accused operated the motor vehicle in a dangerous manner. It was unnecessary for the Crown to prove that the lives or safety of others were actually endangered. 3)There was no doubt that there was a consensual fight between the accused and the complainant. The accused admitted he slung the complainant on the ground and that he got more aggressive and kicked her on two occasions.
column19: 1. [O]n or about the 21st day of August, A.D. 2003 at or near Fort Qu’Appelle, Saskatchewan ... endanger the life of Marie Louise Bear by attempting to strike her with a motor vehicle, thereby committing aggravated assault, contrary to Section 268 of the Criminal Code. 3. [O]n or about the 21st day of August, A.D. 2003 at or near Fort Qu’Appelle, Saskatchewan operate a motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public, contrary to Section 249(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. 4. [O]n or about the 21st day of August, A.D. 2003 at or near Fort Qu’Appelle, Saskatchewan commit an assault on Darnell Noltcho, contrary to Section 266(a) of the Criminal Code. 5. [O]n or about the 21st day of August, A.D. 2003 at or near Fort Qu’Appelle, Saskatchewan commit an assault on Conlee Kahpeaysewat, contrary to Section 266(a) of the Criminal Code. I have strong suspicions that the accused did intend to strike Bear with the vehicle. However, I cannot convict on suspicion and I am left with a reasonable doubt about the intention of the accused. Therefore, I find the accused guilty as charged on this count. [37] There is no doubt the truck is a motor vehicle and there is no doubt the accused was operating it. The offence requires a marked departure from prudent conduct. [39] Given the evidence which I accept, the accused operated the motor vehicle in a manner dangerous to the public and the Crown has proven each and every ingredient of this offence to my satisfaction beyond a reasonable doubt and I find the accused guilty of this charge. On the evidence, the Crown has proven the guilt of the accused to my satisfaction beyond a reasonable doubt on both Counts No. 4 and 5 and therefore I find the accused guilty as charged on those counts.

column23: The accused was charged with aggravated assault contrary to s. 249(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both charges. 1)The offence was proved where the Crown established that the driving complained of was dangerous to the public. The offence requires a marked departure from prudent conduct. The evidence that the accused assaulted the complainant and caused her bodily harm was overwhelming. The Crown had proven the guilt of the accused on this count to my satisfaction beyond a reasonable doubt and must find the accused not guilty of the charge.  2)The accused operated the motor vehicle in a dangerous manner. It was unnecessary for the Crown to prove that the lives or safety of others were actually endangered. The accused is not expected to operate a motor vehicle that poses a danger to public safety. 3)There was no doubt that bodily harm could have been caused to the complainant if the accused had not slung the complainant on the ground and that he got more aggressive and kicked her on two occasions. 4)The Crown was not able to prove the accused's guilt on all counts except for the one count of assisting in the defence of a person who was injured.

column2: The applicants applied for an order in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the school board to close two schools. The applicants were parents of children who attended one of the two closed schools., application allowed in part; certiorari granted in respect of the decision to close the school which the applicants' children attended; the applicants had no standing to challenge the closure of the second school as they were not directly affected by its closure. The School Board breached its general duty to act fairly in allowing a Board member to vote when he had not attended the public meetings on the issue. The Board did not meet the onus on it to show that the member had appropriate firsthand knowledge of the evidence and submission of the applicants.
column3: This was an application for an order pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 56 in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the Board to close the two schools. All seven applicants are parents of children attending the schools. The applicant has a family of schools that are being considered for possible closure. The Board has identified a designated area of schools for possible permanent closure and has made recommendations to the Minister of Education. The Minister has also made recommendations for the closure of the two school districts. The applicants have children attending these schools. HELD: The application is dismissed. The court found that there was no evidence that the applicants have been directly affected by the closure.
column4: [2] This is an application advanced by seven applicants for an order pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 56 in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the Board to close the two schools. [40] In these circumstances I am of the view that there has not been established the applicants have been directly affected by the closure of Notting Park. [42] For all of these reasons it is my view the applicants should not have standing and an order should issue dismissing the application for an order in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision to close Notting Park. The application to quash the decision to close Northbrook is allowed. [79] An order will issue in the nature of certiorari quashing the decision of the Board to close Northbrook.

column8: This was an application for an order pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 56 in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the Board to close the two schools. All seven applicants are parents of children attending the schools and none of the applicants have children attending Notting Park. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The court found that there had not been established the applicants had been directly affected by the closure of the schools. 2)The applicant had obtained standing for different reasons the judicial discretion to find he had public interest standing. There was no practical possibility that the issue of legality would be raised in other proceedings. 3)The applicants were better plaintiffs with a better prospect of emergence than those who had not joined the application. The court found the applicant did not have a sufficiently direct personal interest to bring him within the general requirement for standing to challenge the exercise of statutory power.

column2: The 18 year old, charged with the second degree murder of two individuals, applied for release from custody. HELD: The accused was released on his own undertakings under a set of strict conditions, including participation in an electronic monitoring program. The onus is on the accused to show cause why his detention in custody is not justified. Criminal Code s.515(10) now permits detention on three grounds. His detention was not necessary to ensure his attendance at court nor for the protection or safety of the public. There was no evidence he posed a substantial likelihood of committing further offences or that he would interfere with the administration of justice if released. There was no other just cause, including maintenance of confidence in the administration of justice.
column3: The Crown opposed the accused's release on the ground that his detention was necessary in order to maintain confidence in the administration of justice. The accused had been involved in sports, participated in the Winter Games, and had purchased some beer. The Crown alleged that the accused had threatened his father and his mother and had threatened to break his phone when he tried to call his father. HELD: The accused was released on a set of strict conditions. 1)The accused was not a person prone to violence or cruelty or who became involved in the community activities. He had strong roots in the First Nation and had strong opinions about the community. 2)The Crown was not satisfied that the detention was needed to maintain a confidence in administration of the justice.  3)The court was satisfied in all of the circumstances that the continued detention of the accused was necessary to maintain trust in the Administration of justice and that his attendance at court was necessary.
column4: [15] I am not satisfied that the detention of the accused is necessary to ensure his attendance at court. [16] I am not satisfied that the detention of the accused is necessary for the protection or safety of the public. There is no evidence that [A.R.S.] poses a substantial likelihood of committing further offences or that he will, if released, interfere with the administration of justice. The accused will be released on his own undertaking on a set of strict conditions. (4) He shall participate in the Electronic Monitoring Program, and shall comply with all Program rules.

column2: The respondent mother applied to lift the stay of execution imposed by Court of Appeal Rule 15(1) when the appellant father appealed the trial judge's decision to award custody of the parties' son to the mother with the child to have access to the father for one extended weekend per month during the school year (see: 2013 SKQB 212). The trial judge had found that both parties had exhibited a lack of interest in their child and there was little to distinguish either of them as the better custodial parent. As the mother had facilitated the father's access to the child and he had not demonstrated the same willingness and that the most important relationship in the child's life was with his sister, who resides with the mother, the trial judge found that it was in the child's best interest to foster that relationship and grant custody to the mother. HELD: The Court granted the application. There would be no harm to the child if the stay was lifted. The father was directed to perfect his appeal and the stay of proceedings arising from Court of Appeal Rule 15(4) was also lifted.
column3: The applicant mother sought a lifting of the stay of execution on the judgment of the trial judge (indexed as 2013 SKQB 212 (CanLII)) which was automatically imposed upon the father's appeal from that decision. HELD: The application was granted.  1)The Court lifted the stay on the decision of the Trial Judge (indexing as 2013SKQB 212) which was automatic imposed upon both parties' appeal from the father’s decision. 2)The court found that the child was at risk of harm if the stay was lifted. 3)The child was to have access for one extended weekend per month during the regular school year and for one half of major school breaks with each party to share and assist in the transportation of their son for the purposes of access.
column4:
Disposition: Application granted [1] The applicant mother seeks a lifting of the stay of execution on the judgment of the trial judge (indexed as 2013 SKQB 212 (CanLII)) which was automatically imposed upon the father’s appeal from that decision. Given the unfortunate circumstances of Mackenzie to this point, it is imperative that Mackenzie be provided the opportunity to have regular and consistent contact with both his parents. [6] In sum, given the facts of this matter, I can foresee no harm to the child or any significant disruption in his life if the stay is lifted. Finally, although I recognise that doing so has the potential to give rise to more problems than it may address, I also lift the stay of proceedings arising pursuant to Rule 15(4).
[8] Costs shall be in the cause.

[6] In sum, given the facts of this matter, I can foresee no harm to the child or any significant disruption in his life if the stay is lifted. Finally, although I recognise that doing so has the potential to give rise to more problems than it may address, I also lift the stay of proceedings arising pursuant to Rule 15(4).
[8] Costs shall be in the cause.
column12: The respondent mother applied to lift the stay of execution imposed by Court of Appeal Rule 15(1) when the appellant father appealed the trial judge's decision to award custody of the parties' son to the mother with the child to have access to the father for one extended weekend per month during the school year (see: 2013 SKQB 212). The trial judge had found that both parties had exhibited a lack of interest in their child and there was little to distinguish either of them as the better custodial parent. As the mother had facilitated the father's access to the child and he had not demonstrated the same willingness and that the most important relationship in the child's life was with his sister, who resides with the mother, the trial judge found that it was in the child's best interest to foster that relationship and grant custody to the mother. HELD: The Court granted the application. There would be no harm to the child if the stay was lifted. The father was directed to perfect his appeal and the stay of proceedings arising from Court of Appeal Rule 15(4) was also lifted.
column13: The applicant mother sought a lifting of the stay of execution on the judgment of the trial judge (indexed as 2013 SKQB 212 (CanLII)) which was automatically imposed upon the father's appeal from that decision. HELD: The application was granted.  1)The trial judge addressed whether it would be in the child's best interests to grant custody to the father or to the mother in accordance with the factors set out in s. 8(a)(i) of The Children's Law Act. 2)Given the facts of this matter, I can foresee no harm to the child or any significant disruption in his life if the stay is lifted. The child is to have access time with the father for the remainder of August, with the mother to share and assist in the transportation of their son for the purposes of access. The incentive on the father to perfect his appeal, should he still wish to do so, is the incentive on him to improve his appeal.

column2: The Mother applied to vary the custody provisions of the decree nisis for divorce which provided for joint custody of the parties' 2 children, aged 11 and 9 years. Under the existing order the children's primary residence was with their Father. A custody investigation conducted in 1990 when the mother had first commenced this application had recommended that the existing arrangement be continued. The Father now intended, however, to move with the children to Ontario to take additional education. HELD: Application dismissed. 1)The Judge found that the move to Ontario was a sufficient change of circumstances to permit a variation application to proceed. She therefore proceeded to consider if the move was in the best interests of the children. 2)The Judge reviewed recent authorities from across Canada dealing with whether a custodial parent should be permitted to move with the children. 3)In the circumstances of this case the Judge was convinced that the move was reasonable and was not motivated by any desire on the part of the Father to thwart the Mother's access.
column3: The mother sought an order varying the judgment for divorce and joint custody to the father and mother. The parties had separated in 1988 and had entered into a separation agreement in which they agreed to joint custody, residence with the father, and generous access to the mother. In 1989 the mother moved from Ontario to Saskatchewan where she was practicing dental practice. She applied to vary the judgment by granting mother sole custody of the boys, or joint custody with principal residence with mother. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The court found that the best interests of the children lie with the mother and the father's access. 2)The father's reasons for moving to Ontario were not unreasonable if the course he wishes to take was not offered at the Dental College of Saskatchewan. 3)The mother had not filed any medical certificate or certificate about his condition. The father had not made any application for variation of access. 4)The Court of Appeal upheld the order.
column4:
This is an application by Twila Faye Brothwell
(mother) for an order varying the judgment of Dickson J. of the
5th of January 1990, in which he gave judgment for divorce and
joint custody to the parents of two boys Matthew, born April 22,
1984 and Luke, born June 3, 1986. The affidavit material filed on this application
shows that the father has informed the mother that he is moving
to Aurora, Ontario, at the beginning of July, 1995 and intends to
enroll in a course at the dental college in Toronto, which will
enable him to teach Public Health Dentistry. issue. I did not form the opinion that his move was to thwart
his ex-wife's access, since there does not seem to be any dispute
about this since 1990, and indeed friends and neighbours from
MacRorie filed affidavits stating how much the boys enjoyed their
visits with their mother and how they fitted in with the people
of that town and environs, and he has, in addition offered
generous access. Because of the reasons given above: father being
the long-time custodial parent, the reasons for the proposed
move, the generous access offered I dismiss the application of
the mother.

column8: The mother sought an order varying the judgment for divorce and joint custody to the father and mother. The parties had separated in 1988 and had entered into a separation agreement in which they agreed to joint custody, residence with the father, and generous access to the mother. In 1989, the mother commenced an application for change in the divorce judgment which would give her sole custody of the boys, or joint custody with principal residence. The father applied to vary the judgment by granting the mother sole custody and access and the mother applied to the Court of Appeal for an order preventing the father from moving out of Saskatchewan for any reason other than a short vacation. The mother opposed the application. HELD: 1)The father's reasons for moving to Ontario were not unreasonable if the course he wishes to take was not offered at the Dental College of the University of Saskatchewan. The evidence showed that the father had been the primary care giver of the children from their early years onward except when they were exercising the access. He had, in addition, offered generous access. 2)The mother's application for variation of custody was not made to thwart the father's access. 3)The court found that the best interests of both parties lie with the child's being with the custodial parent. 4)The Court of Queen's Bench ordered that all children be given joint custody of all four boys. 5)No order was made respecting the mother's wishes to move out of the province. The court found it would be in the children's best interests to have them with the parent. 6)The evidence showed the father was able to manage the boys' needs and provided a generous access policy. 7)The children were to live with the mother for the duration of their stay in Regina. 8)The Father's reasons were not reasonable if he wished to take the boys out of their home and move them to a virtual paradise in Saskatchewan.

column2: The proposed appellants are some of the defendants in an action commenced by Schneider against them on the grounds that he, as representative plaintiff, and others suffered financial losses due to negligence on the part of McMillan. The representative plaintiff and other investors purchased 'cells' in gold exploration prospect owned and promoted by Royal Crown Gold Reserve Inc. based on that defendant's representation that the purchase price was deductible from the purchaser's earned income for income tax purposes and the tax opinions provided by McMillan. McMillan's opinion letters were posted on Royal Crown's website. The representative plaintiff purchased the cells and then filed tax returns claiming deduction, which was disallowed by the Canada Revenue Agency. The representative plaintiff commenced this action claiming that he and others suffered financial losses due to McMillan's negligence. McMillan applied to strike the statement of claim on the grounds that it was devoid of merit pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 173(c) and opposed the certification of the action on the basis that the relationship between them and the representative plaintiff was insufficient to found a recognized duty of care between a lawyer and a non-client. Their application was supported by affidavits indicating that their tax opinions were not to be given to prospective investors. The plaintiff filed an affidavit from another lawyer, who deposed that when he prepared such opinion letters regarding tax consequences he reviewed all the underlying documents and agreements beforehand to protect the reputation of his law firm, knowing that the opinions were often relied upon as marketing tool to potential investors. The Chambers judge dismissed McMillan's application and it brought this application for leave to appeal under s. 8 of The Court of Appeal Act except as provided by s. 39(3) of The Class Actions Act. HELD: The Court dismissed the applications. It held that the Chambers judge was correct in holding that the action was not devoid of merit or vexatious. The judge had reviewed the affidavits and concluded that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client in specific circumstances, including those of this case. McMillan should have been aware of the use made by the mining industry of opinion letters and taken steps to prevent their opinion being used inappropriately for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with their client. The Court also found that the Chambers judge did not err in certifying the claim of negligence as a common issue that predominated over other issues affecting individual members of a class. McMillan's argument that the factual base pled by the representative plaintiff did not establish a common issue to meet the requirements of s. 6(1)(c) of The Class Actions Act failed because, in this case, the class members suffered real losses allegedly as a result of McMillan's negligence. These facts coupled with the case law stating that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client and the plaintiff's affiant's evidence, established a common issue that met the requirements of the Act.
column3: The proposed appellants applied to the Queen's Bench for an order striking the within action on the ground that it was devoid of merit. They also opposed the certification of the within actions on the basis that the relationship between them and the representative plaintiff was insufficient to found a recognized duty of care between a lawyer and non-client. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Chambers judge did not err in his decision to err in relying upon the lawyer's affidavit. The facts, coupled with case law stating a lawyer may owe a duty of caring to a non- client and the evidence of the Respondent's lawyer, did not establish a common issue which met the commonality requirements of the Class Actions Act. 2)The respondent's affidavits were made available to potential investors by Royal Crown. The Chambers judge reviewed the affidavits of the representative and found that the lawyer may have owed a duty to a client in specific circumstances, including those akin to those before him. The evidence of clients using legal opinions provided by their legal counsel as a marketing tool is so common among tax lawyers that the Chambers judge should have taken appropriate steps to guard against their opinion letters being inappropriately used for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with the client or clients. 3)The chambers judge did err in not applying the Rule 173(c) analysis when determining whether the relationship with the representative was insufficient and not a commonality issue. The fact that the respondent and the class members did not have a common understanding of the duty of a lawyer to non--client was not a unique issue. 4)The proposed appeal was prima facie destined to fail and not of sufficient merit to warrant the attention of this Court.
column4: Disposition: Applications Dismissed They also opposed the certification of the within action on the basis that the relationship between them and the representative plaintiff was insufficient to found a recognized duty of care between a lawyer and non-client. [2] The learned Chambers judge dismissed the s. 173(c) application and certified the action as a class action against all defendants. [3] McMillan then applied pursuant to s. 8 of The Court of Appeal Act, 2000, S.S. 2000, c. C-42.1 and Rule 49 of The Court of Appeal Rules for an order granting them leave to appeal from the Chambers judge's certification order and his dismissal of their Rule 173(c) application. [14] With respect to the first question, I am satisfied the Chambers judge correctly held the action against McMillan was not devoid of merit or vexatious. Based thereon, he concluded that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client in specific circumstances, including circumstances akin to those before him. In his opinion, evidence of clients involved in the mining industry using legal opinions provided by their legal counsel as a marketing tool is so commonly known among tax lawyers that McMillan should have been alive to the practice and should have taken appropriate steps to guard against their opinion letters being inappropriately used for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with the client or clients. [20] While McMillan conceded the cause of action in negligence pled by the representative plaintiff met the requirements of s. 6(1)(a) of The Class Actions Act, they maintain the factual base pled by the representative plaintiff does not establish a common issue which meets the commonality requirements of s. 6(1)(c) of The Class Actions Act. In the instance action, class members suffered real losses allegedly as a result of McMillan’s negligence. These facts, coupled with case law stating a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client and the evidence of Mr. Davies, establish a common issue which appears to meet the requirements of The Class Actions Act. In my view, the Chambers judge made no error in his interpretation of the applicable law or the evidence before him, or in his application of the law to the relevant facts before him, which would warrant leave being granted based on arguments advanced by McMillan. [23] In conclusion, I dismiss both applications for leave with costs to be costs in the cause.

The plaintiff filed an affidavit from another lawyer, who deposed that when he prepared such opinion letters regarding tax consequences he reviewed all the underlying documents and agreements beforehand to protect the reputation of his law firm, knowing that the opinions were often relied upon as marketing tool to potential investors. The Chambers judge dismissed McMillan's application and it brought this application for leave to appeal under s. 8 of The Court of Appeal Act except as provided by s. 39(3) of The Class Actions Act. HELD: The Court dismissed the applications. It held that the Chambers judge was correct in holding that the action was not devoid of merit or vexatious. The judge had reviewed the affidavits and concluded that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client in specific circumstances, including those of this case. McMillan should have been aware of the use made by the mining industry of opinion letters and taken steps to prevent their opinion being used inappropriately for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with their client. The Court also found that the Chambers judge did not err in certifying the claim of negligence as a common issue that predominated over other issues affecting individual members of a class. McMillan's argument that the factual base pled by the representative plaintiff did not establish a common issue to meet the requirements of s. 6(1)(c) of The Class Actions Act failed because, in this case, the class members suffered real losses allegedly as a result of McMillan's negligence. These facts coupled with the case law stating that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client and the plaintiff's affiant's evidence, established a common issue that met the requirements of the Act.
column8: The proposed appellants sought an order pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 173(c) striking the within action on the ground that it was devoid of merit and that evidence of clients using legal opinions provided by their legal counsel as a marketing tool was so commonly known among tax lawyers that McMillan should have been alive to the practice and should have taken appropriate steps to guard against their opinion letters being inappropriately used for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with the plaintiff. The Chambers judge dismissed the application and certified the action as a class action against the appellants on the basis that the relationship between them and the representative plaintiff was insufficient to found a recognized duty of care between a lawyer and a non-client. HELD: The proposed appeal was granted or withheld in the amount of $8,000. 1)The facts, coupled with case law stating a lawyer may owe a duty of a non client and the evidence of Mr. Davies, establish a common issue which appears to meet the requirements of the Class Actions Act. 2)Nothing in the Chambers judge's reasons suggests he applied Rule 173c analysis when determining whether'some basis in fact' supported the existence of a recognized obligation of care within the meaning of s. 6(1)(c) of the Act. 3)The Chambers judge erred in failing to properly apply the Anns test or to consider policy reasons that may prevent the imposition of duty on them, are essentially aspects of their defence and not reasons to strike the negligence claim at this juncture. 4)The proposed appeal is prima facie destined to fail and not of sufficient merit to warrant the attention of this Court.
column9: Disposition: Applications Dismissed They also opposed the certification of the within action on the basis that the relationship between them and the representative plaintiff was insufficient to found a recognized duty of care between a lawyer and non-client. [3] McMillan then applied pursuant to s. 8 of The Court of Appeal Act, 2000, S.S. 2000, c. C-42.1 and Rule 49 of The Court of Appeal Rules for an order granting them leave to appeal from the Chambers judge's certification order and his dismissal of their Rule 173(c) application. [14] With respect to the first question, I am satisfied the Chambers judge correctly held the action against McMillan was not devoid of merit or vexatious. Based thereon, he concluded that a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client in specific circumstances, including circumstances akin to those before him. In his opinion, evidence of clients involved in the mining industry using legal opinions provided by their legal counsel as a marketing tool is so commonly known among tax lawyers that McMillan should have been alive to the practice and should have taken appropriate steps to guard against their opinion letters being inappropriately used for the purpose of inducing potential investors to invest with the client or clients. [20] While McMillan conceded the cause of action in negligence pled by the representative plaintiff met the requirements of s. 6(1)(a) of The Class Actions Act, they maintain the factual base pled by the representative plaintiff does not establish a common issue which meets the commonality requirements of s. 6(1)(c) of The Class Actions Act. In the instance action, class members suffered real losses allegedly as a result of McMillan’s negligence. These facts, coupled with case law stating a lawyer may owe a duty of care to a non-client and the evidence of Mr. Davies, establish a common issue which appears to meet the requirements of The Class Actions Act. In my view, the Chambers judge made no error in his interpretation of the applicable law or the evidence before him, or in his application of the law to the relevant facts before him, which would warrant leave being granted based on arguments advanced by McMillan. [23] In conclusion, I dismiss both applications for leave with costs to be costs in the cause.

column2: FIAT. The mother sought to have the ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for the three children of the marriage increased. The last three income tax returns of the father indicated an average gross income of $28,000 after adjustments. His net worth had increased substantially since the original order in 1993 from a net worth of $105,744 after deducting debts of $352,655 to $484,684 after deducting debts of $342,000. He purchased stock totalling $202,061 in 1996 using income generated from the farm. He claimed he could not work full time in the oil field because he was involved in a bison operation. HELD: The respondent was to pay monthly child support of $957 for as long as the children remained children as defined by the Divorce Act. It was appropriate to impute income of $56,000 as the respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income.
column3: FIAT. The applicant mother sought to have ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for three children of the marriage increased. The respondent father filed a tax return showing his net worth had increased substantially since the original order. HELD: The respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income. In the circumstances it was appropriate to impute income to the respondent. The father had a gross annual income imputed at $56,000.00. He was ordered to pay the applicant $957.00 for the support of three children and $857.50 for the monthly child support payable on the first and second and third and fourth and fourth child expenses as his net incomes had increased.

support of $180.00 per month per child for the three children
of the marriage increased. I am satisfied that the respondent's assets are not
being reasonably utilized to generate income. I therefore find that the respondent has a gross annual
income imputed at $56,000.00. He shall pay to the applicant
the sum of $957.00 for the support of the three children of
the marriage payable on the first day of each and every month
commencing as of the 1st day of August, 1997, as long as the
children remain children of the marriage under the Divorce
Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 3 (2nd supp.).
column22: FIAT. The mother sought to have the ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for the three children of the marriage increased. The last three income tax returns of the father indicated an average gross income of $28,000 after adjustments. His net worth had increased substantially since the original order in 1993 from a net worth of $105,744 after deducting debts of $352,655 to $484,684 after deducting debts of $342,000. He purchased stock totalling $202,061 in 1996 using income generated from the farm. He claimed he could not work full time in the oil field because he was involved in a bison operation. HELD: The respondent was to pay monthly child support of $957 for as long as the children remained children as defined by the Divorce Act. It was appropriate to impute income of $56,000 as the respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income.
column23: FIAT. The applicant mother sought to have ongoing child support of $180.00 per month per child for three children of the marriage increased. The respondent father filed his last three income tax returns. The returns indicate that he had an average gross taxable income of $28,000. However, the file also indicates that his net worth has increased substantially since the original order in 1993. HELD: 1)The respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income. In the circumstances it was appropriate for me to impute income to the respondent. 2)The gross annual income imputed at $56,000 was imputed. 3)Costs were not ordered.

column27: FIAT. The applicant mother sought to have ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for three children of the marriage increased. The respondent father filed a tax return showing his net worth had increased substantially since the original order. HELD: The respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income. In the circumstances it was appropriate to impute income to the respondent. The father had a gross annual income imputed at $56,000.00. He was ordered to pay the applicant $957.00 for the support of three children and $857.50 for the monthly child support payable on the first and second and third and fourth and fourth child expenses as his net incomes had increased.

column2: The accused was charged with ten counts including robbery, aggravated assault, assault causing bodily harm, possession of stolen property and trafficking in narcotics. She raised s.9 and 8 of the Charter in objecting to the arrest and seizure of the duffel bag. The voir dire occupied 5 days. HELD: 1)The four requirements set out in R. v. Feeney for a warrantless search were satisfied. The arrest was lawful. The search of the house and seizure of the duffel bag was incidental to the arrest and therefore lawful. 2)The accused had no expectation of privacy with respect to either her friend's residence or the bag. The decision in R. v. Edwards was squarely on point. There was no evidence tying the accused to the gym bag. It was of a different description than the one used in the drugstore robbery. The accused never asserted ownership of the bag or made any claim to any interest or right with respect to it. The gym bag constituted non-conscriptive evidence. 3)If there were any violations of the accused's Charter rights (and it was concluded there were not) they were of a minor nature and not sufficient to engage the provisions of s.24(2) of the Charter. To exclude the evidence would bring the administration of justice into disrepute.
column3: The accused objected to her arrest and seizure of a duffel bag containing a quantity of narcotics. The police seized the bag at the accused's residence. The accused also called evidence on the voir dire but did not testify. HELD: The Court found the arrest was lawful and the seizure was incidental to the arrest. The Court held that the search of the house and seizure were incidental to it and therefore lawful. The court found the accused had no expectation of privacy in the house or in the bag. The evidence was found to be non-conscriptive evidence. The Crown contended that the evidence should be excluded under s. 24(2) of the Charter. The defence argued that the police had no reasonable and probable grounds to justify the search. The judge also rejected the defence of privacy. The officer's belief that this purpose will be served by the search must be reasonable one. The fact that the bag was of a different description than the one used in the Nordon robbery was not grounds for excluding the evidence.

column8: The accused objected to her arrest and to the seizure of a duffel bag containing a quantity of narcotics. HELD: The accused was found not guilty. 1)The accused had no expectation of privacy in this case either as to the residence or the bag. 2)The Court found the arrest was lawful. The search of the house and seizure of the bag were incidental to the arrest and therefore lawful.  3)Section 8 of the Charter requires that an arresting officer must subjectively have reasonable and probable grounds on which to base the arrest. Those grounds must, in addition, be justifiable from an objective point of view. The police need not demonstrate anything more than reasonable and likely grounds. The gym bag constituted non-conscriptive evidence, another factor which must be considered in light of the suggestion that the evidence should be excluded under s.24(2) of the charter.

column2: FIAT: The sole issue before the court is the amount to be fixed for the ongoing s. 7 expenses. The s. 7 expenses claimed by the petitioner include dental work of $112.90 for Kristen, orthodontic work for Brina and costs associated with Brina's post-secondary education. It is uncontroverted that Brina has disabilities that necessitate certain tools such as a computer for her to be successful in her post-secondary training. HELD: 1) The respondent accepts responsibility for his proportionate share of the girls' dental and orthodontic expenses and there shall be an order accordingly. 2) The September 2004 consent order provided that computer repairs and equipment were included in Brina's s. 7 expenses. Accordingly the costs relating to the computer are legitimate s. 7 costs. 2) The crisis prevention class was a reasonable expense incurred on Brina's part and will assist her with her future plans. 3) The Zeller's supplies would normally be covered under the Table support and that expense is disallowed. 4) Brina's s. 7 post-secondary expenses are $7,123.72 and include tuition, crisis prevention class and books, required university books, bus pass, black cartridge for the printer, Shaw internet, Microsoft licence, computer repairs and updated virus protection.
column3: FIAT: The petitioner applies to have arrears fixed with regard to s. expenses related to her daughter's post-secondary education and in addition requests that the amount of ongoing s. 7 expenses be specified. HELD: 1) The respondent accepts responsibility for his proportionate share of the girls' dental and orthodontic expenses. The Zellers supplies, however, would normally be covered under Table support. The expense shall be disallowed.  2) It is noted that the September 28, 2004 consent order provided that computer repairs and equipment were included in the respondent's s.7 expenses. Accordingly, the costs relating to the computer are legitimate s. 7 costs. The costs relating the computer were legitimate s7 costs and the crisis prevention class was a reasonable expense incurred on the respondent’s part and will assist her in her future plans. The $1,865.94 in student and university fees were calculated as calculated as the s. 8 post-graduate education expenses for the 2005/2006 year. The respondent accepted responsibility for the proportionate portion of the girl’ s. seven expenses. 3) The costs related to the computers were legitimate expenses. 4) The Zellerers supplies would normally cover under Table supports. 5) The $7,123.72 calculated by the respondent was calculated as follows:University of Saskatchewan fall and spring terms, $1.865 per month, $3,002.60 in university fees, $2,002 per month in student loans and $1 million in bus pass fees. The s. costs relating with the computer and the bus pass were legitimate costs incurred on respondent”s part. The crisis prevention classes were a reasonable expenditure incurred on Brina’S part and would assist her future plan. The expenses relating to computer repairs were legitimate supplementary expenses. 6) The cost relating to software were legitimate in nature. The cost of the crisis- prevention class would normally not be covered by Table support and the Zeller supplies would be disallow. 7) The expense was disallowed for the respondent to pay 66% of the s7 post-primary education expenses.

column2: The defendant applied to have evidence found during a search of his premises excluded on the basis that the search warrant was invalid. Application dismissed; there was sufficient evidence to constitute reasonable and probable grounds for the issuance of the warrant. Overall the nature of the evidence was compelling with four separate and independent sources all confirming either that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold at his residence; although individually none of the sources was of known or proven reliability, collectively they reinforced and confirmed each other; and the police conducted surveillance which corroborated the information provided by the sources.
column3: The defendant applied for the exclusion of evidence found following a search conducted at his residence pursuant to a warrant issued by fax from the Justice of the Peace Centre in Dartmouth, N.S. The search was therefore warrantless, breached his Charter s. right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure, and that evidence obtained by it should be excluded under s. 24(2) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The nature of the evidence was compelling. The evidence confirmed that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment and that the police conducted surveillance on the building. 2)The information was based on a tip originating from outside the police, was credible and corroborated by police investigation prior to making the decision to conduct the search. 3)The evidence was consistent with the standard of reasonableness established in R. v. Debot, [1989] S.C.R. 1140. 4)The officer did not seek a warrant on the basis of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. 5)The court found that the evidence met the criteria set out in Rach v. Araujo 2000 SCC 65 (CanLII), [2000] SCC), [1989]. The officer did, however, act reasonably and conducted surveillance with the assistance of his own sources. The officer was not required to assess the evidence placed before the justice in light of the trial evidence. The court found the officer was required to evaluate the evidence before the Justice and decide whether the information met the test in Rosh v.Debot, 1989 CanLII 13 (SCC), and therefore that the warrant should have been issued. The judge did not exercise discretion in weighing evidence relied on by the police to justify a warrantless search. The officers did not look at it as whole and decide if there was sufficient reliable evidence which might reasonably have been believed by the Justice on which she could have issued the warrant. The police did not pursue a warrant. They conducted surveillance. The year '2001' in the penultimate paragraph was a typographical error and was intended to read 2002. The defendant was convicted of trafficking under the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act. 4]The officer was unable to state with certainty whether the defendant had purchased drugs or if the defendant's lawyer had advised him or herself that the purchase was made at his home. column4: [1] The defendant has made an application for the exclusion of evidence found following a search conducted at his residence pursuant to a warrant issued by fax from the Justice of the Peace Centre in Dartmouth, N.S. [9] Looking first at the nature of the evidence, over all I find that it was compelling. So four apparently separate and independent sources over the month and a half prior to the warrant application all confirmed, with varying amounts of detail, either that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment, or both. [11] Finally the police did not seek a warrant on the basis of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. Conclusion [12] I find that there was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for issuance of this warrant.

The search was therefore warrantless, breached his Charter s. right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure, and that evidence obtained by it should be excluded under s. 24(2) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. HELD: The application was granted. 1)There was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for issuance of the warrant. 2)The information to obtain the warrant did not meet the test in R. v. Debot, 1989 CanLII 13 (SCC), [1989] 2 S.C.R. 1140, and therefore that the warrant should not have issued. 3)The evidence was compelling. The four apparently separate and independent sources confirmed, with varying amounts of detail, that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment, or both. There was therefore evidence on which the justice of the peace could conclude that this was continuing activity and that it was on-going at the date of the application. 4)There were at least three concerns to be addressed in weighing evidence relied on by the police to justify a warrantless search. The information predicting the commission of a criminal offence was based on a tip originating from a source outside the police, was credible, and the information corroborated by police investigation prior to making the decision to conduct the search.

It met the test of reasonableness and the criteria set out in R., v. Araujo 2000 SCC 65 (CanLII), [2000] SCC. 992. The reviewing judge does not stand in the same place and function as the authorizing judge. He or she does not conduct rehearing of the application for the wiretap. This is the starting place for any reviewing judge, as Garofoli, supra, at p. 1452, found that there are at least three concerns to be addressed in weighing evidence relied on by the police to justify a warrantless search. First, was the information predicting the commission of a criminal offence compelling? Second, where that information was based on a tip originating from a source outside the police, was that source credible? The existence of fraud, non-disclosure, misleading evidence and new evidence are all relevant, but rather than being prerequisite to review, their sole impact is to determine whether there continues to be any basis for the decision of the authorizing Judge.

column2: This was an appeal from the decision of the Nova Scotia Utility and Review Board allowing an appeal from the decision of the Victims' Services Division denying compensation to the respondent on the basis the police had not proceeded with criminal charges for an assault which had occurred. Dismissing the appeal, that the Board had correctly interpreted its jurisdiction and made findings amply supported by the evidence arising from the de novo hearing. Failure of the police to lay a charge against the attacker did not disqualify the applicant from compensation if it was otherwise supported by the evidence.
column3: The appellant applied for criminal injuries compensation pursuant to the Victims' Rights and Services Act. He alleged that he was wrongly assaulted and as result he was entitled to compensation for the losses he suffered. The police investigation indicated that they would not be proceeding with criminal charges. The appellant appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that the Board correctly interpreted its jurisdiction and made findings of fact that were within its jurisdiction. There was ample evidence arising from the de novo hearing to support its findings.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal dismissed from decision of Nova Scotia Utility and Review Board concerning an award of compensation pursuant to the Victims\' Rights and Services Act, per oral reasons for judgment delivered by Clarke, C.J.N.S.; Mr. Glasgow applied for criminal injuries compensation pursuant to the Victims\' Rights and Services Act, S.N.S. 1989, c. 14, as amended. Because the program is unable to confirm through the criminal justice system that you are a victim of crime, we are unable to make a compensation award. There is nothing ln the Act which suggests that a person is not a victim because the police failed to lay a charge. In our opinion the Board correctly interpreted its jurisdiction. Accordingly the appeal is dismissed. DECISION: Appeal allowed
