Empire Life Insurance claims no interest in the funds but is concerned that the claim of Ag Credit to these funds is not clear and that the rights to refund of such surplus may belong to individual borrowers of the company whose lives were insured over the years under the Policy and whom it views as having paid the premiums resulting in the surplus. Thus it seeks to interplead, pay the monies into court and have the Court give directions as to how the determination of ownership will be decided. HELD: The court granted interpleader relief under Queen's Bench Rule 6-75.  1) The court found that insured clients under the policy have an arguable claim to the surpluuses totaling $3.552,819. Since the insurer maintains its claim to these same funds, this is an appropriate case to grant interpleaded relief under Rule 675 of the Queen'sBench Rules.  2) The Court found that the insurer had acted in full compliance with its duty of uberrima fides in bringing the potentially valid claims of the insured clients to the attention of the Court and in resisting the claim that they were entitled to a refund of unearned premium from that point until the next premium due date for such client. 3) The amount of surplus generated by the insurer was $3 million at the time of the Policy termination. The amount that was transferred to two separate Experience Credit Accounts totalling the above-noted surplus was $55,000. 4) It was also found that since the insurer paid premiums with its own money and thus any overpayment of premiums arising under the contract were its property, the interpleading order sought by the insurance company was unnecessary. 5) The fact that the insurance companies had advanced premiums on behalf of the clients and thus the surpuses were the property of the Crown and properly payable to it as the Crown's agent was irrelevant.  6) The costs associated with the application were to be paid into court. 7) The surplus was to the extent the insurer collected monies from the clients for the purposes of paying their insurance premiums. 8) The insurer was entitled to deduct costs from the premiums paid by the clients. 9) The surplum was to be distributed on a pro rata basis to all clients.

column2: The appellant, who received a suspended sentence with a one year probation order, appealed his conviction of assault (Criminal Code s.266) on the grounds the trial judge erred in law in making findings of fact and credibility based on evidence that did not exist (photographs of injuries that were not introduced into evidence at trial); by misapplying the appropriate standard of proof; although correctly articulating the test in R. v. W(D), misapplying that test in determining credibility; by failing to apply the appropriate test for a defence of necessity. The complainant, frightened by the sudden verbal outburst of the appellant, fled into the bush and refused to return because his mood had not changed. The trial judge did not accept the appellant's testimony that he used force only to protect the complainant from natural hazards in that location at night. HELD: The appeal was allowed. The conviction was set aside and a new trial was ordered. 1)Finding that there were photographs to corroborate the testimony of the complainant relating to her injuries was an error of law. No miscarriage of justice resulted from that error, as it was immaterial.  2)The trial judge clearly preferred the testimony of the complainant to that of the appellant but did not state why. It could not be concluded that his belief in the existence of photographs influenced the findings of credibility. Even if it did, there was still ample evidence to support a prima facie case of assault. Again no miscarriage of justice resulted. 3)The trial judge erred in law by failing to properly consider the defence of necessity. The three elements that must be present for a defence of necessity, as determined by the SCC in Latimer, include imminent peril or danger; absence of reasonable alternatives; proportionality between the harm inflicted and the harm avoided. The defence of necessity is considered in cases where there is an air of reality. The only evidence relating to the defence of necessity came from the appellant. It would not be appropriate in the circumstances of this case to substitute an acquittal. Had the trial judge applied the appropriate test, he may have come to a different conclusion.
column3: The appellant was convicted of assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. His sentence was suspended with a 1 year probation order and he appealed. During argument on behalf of the appellant, the trial judge suggested that the trial Judge misapplied the test in determining credibility. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the trial was ordered to a new trial. 1)The trial judge failed to properly consider the defence of necessity. The only evidence presented relating to the defence was that the appellant had referred to photographs depicting the extent, location and nature of injuries suffered by the complainant when no photographs existed or if they were never tendered in evidence. 2)The Court was of the opinion that no miscarriage of justice resulted from the trial court's error of law. 3)The evidence presented was immaterial whether there were injuries. It was immature whether there had been injuries.

Even if it did, there was still ample evidence to support a prima facie case of assault. 2)No miscarriage of justice resulted. 3)It would not be appropriate in the circumstances of this case to substitute an acquittal for a conviction. 4)The court was of the opinion that no substantial wrong or miscarriage of the justice has occurred. 5)It was immaterial whether there were injuries. The conviction cannot be set aside for that error.

column2: The plaintiff sought damages for personal injuries to her lower back, right knee and left ankle sustained when she slipped and fell while grocery shopping in March 2000. The defendant acknowledged the plaintiff fell in its produce department, but did not concede the water on the floor caused her to slip; the cause was, in part, her worn running shoes without laces. Liability and degree of personal injury were in issue. The claim proceeded under the simplified procedure under Part Forty of the Queen's Bench Rules. HELD: The claim was dismissed with costs. 1)The defendant had a duty of care to the plaintiff as owner and occupier. The courts have most often based the duty of care on the invitor/invitee standard. Maxay v. Ramsay Drugs proposed four-part inquiry to determine whether or not an occupier has breached its duty of care. 2)The plaintiff established on a balance of probabilities that she slipped because of water on the floor. The evidence did not support an inference that her footwear caused the slip or was a contributing factor. 3)An adverse inference was not drawn from the defendant's failure to adduce evidence confirming its employee had in fact cleaned the floor. The employee was no longer employed by the defendant. Neither party was able to locate him. 4)Some of her injuries were, in part, the aggravation of pre-existing conditions. The most significant injury was sprain to her left ankle, which had not been resolved primarily because the plaintiff declined to accept available treatment and failed to follow medical advice. The inconsistencies in her affidavit and the physician notes or medical reports respecting her injuries and treatment were not relevant to this decision. 5)A 'sweep log' was kept for each department and employees made regular inspections of the sales floor area in every department. The plaintiff slipped and fell about an hour after the last sweeping. A regular program of maintenance was conducted in the area. The overall policies and practices of regular maintenance and responsibility of each employee were substantially the same if not identical to those considered in the Mollenhauer and Libel group of cases. The defendant met the legal standard of care imposed in the circumstances and was not liable for the plaintiff's injuries. To find otherwise would be to impose a standard that is inconsistent with that previously imposed by this court in almost identical circumstances.
column3: The plaintiff, who was shopping in the defendant's Superstore, fell while grocery shopping. The defendant claimed liability for the injuries sustained when she slipped and fell while shopping in a produce department. The plaintiff's affidavit alleged that there was a small amount of water on the floor and she did not receive more treatments due to the fact that only five physiotherapy treatments were covered by the defendant. The evidence of two assistant managers employed at the time of the accident confirmed the water on floor. HELD: The plaintiff was awarded costs. 1)The defendant did not contest the presence of water in the vicinity of where the plaintiff slipped and fall although it did not concede that it was the water which caused the plaintiff to slip. 2)The plaintiff met the burden of establishing on a balance of probabilities that she slipped because of water. 3)The evidence of the defendant employees who had resigned as employees of the company and were not able to attend the trial testified that they had been paid by the company to clean the floor. 4)The court concluded that the defendant met the legal standard of care imposed upon it in the circumstances and was not liable for the injury suffered by the plaintiff. 5)The defendants did not dispute the presence or the water in a certain area of the store. The defendants claim the defendant exceeded the legal standards imposed upon them in the event of a slip and fell. The court found otherwise. 6)The plaintiffs claim the defendants met the standard of caring imposed upon the defendant in this case that is inconsistent with that imposed by the Court in the Mollenhauer and Leibel group of cases. 7)The Court concluded that there have been many cases that have found slippery substance such as water on a floor of grocery store to constitute an unusual danger. Some of the injuries the plaintiff claimed occurred as a result of her slip and fall appeared to have been at least in part the aggravation of pre-existing conditions.

[1] The plaintiff seeks damages for personal injuries sustained when she slipped and fell while grocery shopping in the defendant's Superstore in Regina on March 28, 2000. The defendant places in issue:

(a) Whether it is liable to the plaintiff for the injuries she sustained in this slip and fall accident; and

(b) The degree of personal injury sustained by the plaintiff as a result of the accident. The plaintiff's affidavit asserted that on March 28, 2000 she was shopping in the produce department of the defendant's Superstore located at 1621 Albert Street in Regina when at approximately 3:45 p.m. she suddenly slipped on a puddle of water on the floor and fell heavily to the ground, injuring her lower back, right knee and left ankle. Suffice it to say that some of the injuries the plaintiff claimed occurred as a result of her slip and fall on March 28, 2000, appear to have been at least in part the aggravation of pre-existing conditions. A "sweep log" was kept for each department and entries of these cleaning activities were made and initialled by the employees performing the work. CONCLUSION [11] The defendant, as owner and occupier of the Superstore, had a duty of care to the plaintiff. On the basis of all of the evidence, I am satisfied that the plaintiff has met the burden of establishing on a balance of probabilities that she slipped because of water on the floor of the store. The evidence does not support an inference that the plaintiff's footwear caused or was a contributing factor to the slip and fall. A regular program of maintenance had been conducted by the defendant in that area of the store. [21] I conclude that the defendant met the legal standard of care imposed upon it in the circumstances and is not liable for the injuries suffered by the plaintiff. To find otherwise would be to impose a standard upon the defendant in this case that is inconsistent with that previously imposed by this Court in almost identical circumstances. [22] Accordingly, the plaintiff's claim is dismissed with costs.

column8: The plaintiff's claim followed the simplified procedure in Part Forty of the Queen's Bench Rules. The plaintiff was shopping in the produce department of the defendant's Superstore when she suddenly slipped on a puddle of water on the floor of the store. She was taken to the Pasqua Hospital Emergency Department where she was bandaged, given painkillers and advised to rest and see her family doctor if her injuries did not improve. The defendant asserted that the fall was caused at least in part by the fact that the plaintiff was wearing running shoes without laces. HELD: The claim was dismissed with costs. 1)The defendant met the legal standard of care imposed upon it in the circumstances and was not liable for the injuries suffered by the plaintiff. 2)There have been many cases that have found slippery substance such as water on a floor of grocery store to constitute an unusual danger. 3)The plaintiff met the burden of establishing on a balance of probabilities that she slipped because of water in the store and that the defendant did not know the water was there, but did know that water and other substances could be on that floor. 4)The evidence of two assistant managers employed at the time of the accident confirmed the cleaning regimen in place at the Superstore. However, there have been numerous cases that found slippery substances on the floors of grocery stores to constitute unusual danger and the defendant was found to have failed to adduce evidence confirming that there were no laces in her running shoes, but denied that they were badly worn or that they contributed in any way to her fall. 5)The defendants did not contest the presence of water. The affidavit evidence confirmed that there was a small amount of water and that it caused the plaintiff to slip. 6)The court found that some of the injuries the plaintiff claimed occurred as a result of her slip and fall appeared to have been aggravation of pre-existing conditions.

column2: The respondent pled guilty to a charge of manslaughter arising out of fatal injuries she inflicted on her 7 month old daughter. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in pre-trial custody and then imposed a sentence of 2 years less 1 day to be followed by 2 years probation. The Crown seeks leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1) Taking into account the mitigating factors and in particular the respondent's post-sentence rehabilitative potential and the absence of evidence of prior acts of violence, a sentence slightly below the range as the one imposed in R. v. Bighead, 2003 SKCA 44 leads the Court to conclude a sentence of 6 years is appropriate, with 26 months credit for remand as imposed below.  2) The sentencing judge was directed to a very narrow range of authorities. In these circumstances this Court cannot find that the judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity of the offence and the degree of the respondent's responsibility. It would be helpful if a more detailed analysis along the lines suggested in R. v. Laberge (1995), 165 A.R. 375 had been given in order to enhance meaningful appellate review. However, this Court is not satisfied the judge failed to properly consider this factor. The Court is satisfied that the limited framework presented by counsel led the judge to err by failing to observe the need for parity in sentence and as a result, the sentence imposed was not similar to sentences imposed on other offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances.
column3: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed on the respondent for manslaughter. The Crown argued the sentencing judge erred in his assessment of the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to address the principles of denunciation and deterrence. HELD: The appeal was allowed on the basis of this latter ground. The sentencing judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity and the gravity the offence, the respondent’s remorse, her abusive background, her mental health problems, her social and economic situation and the fact that she had never properly bonded with the child. The court found that the respondent had a high level of mental health issues and had a history of substance abuse, which led her to commit these offences. The respondent”s past criminal record and her current situation all led her not to seek help when it was apparent the child was injured. The Court found that a sentence for manslaughter with a factor of four years less a day was appropriate given the respondent was a high risk to re-offend and her past criminal history did not warrant a sentence higher than that imposed.
column4: Disposition: Allowed On February 11, 2009, the sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in pre-trial custody and then imposed a sentence of two years less one day to be followed by two years probation. The Crown seeks leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. I am satisfied the appeal should be allowed on the basis of this latter ground. I am, however, satisfied this same limited framework presented by counsel led the judge to err by failing to observe the need for parity in sentencing and as a result, the sentence imposed was not similar to sentences imposed on other offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances. Taking into account the mitigating factors already identified, in particular the respondent\'s post-sentence rehabilitative potential and the absence of evidence of prior acts of violence, a sentence slightly below the range as the one imposed in Bighead leads me to conclude a sentence of six years is appropriate, with 26 months credit for remand as imposed below. Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal is allowed.

column8: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed for the manslaughter of a seven-month-old child. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in custody and then imposed a sentence for 2 years less 1 day to be followed by 2 years of probation. The Crown sought leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: The appeal was allowed on the basis of the following grounds: 1) the sentencing judge erred in his assessment of the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to address s. 718.01 of the Code; 2) the judge failed to give adequate weight to both the seriousness of the offences and the degree of the respondent’s responsibility; and 3) the court found that the respondent had a history of mental health problems, including depression, alcohol and drug use, which resulted in a severe and persistent vegetative state with a severely reduced lifespan; and 4) the respondent was found to have had a dysfunctional upbringing and mental disorder. The court found the respondent did not have a mental disorder or a mental illness which would have resulted in the death of the child; her previous criminal record was not of character which interfered with her ability to appreciate her surroundings, control her actions or understand the consequences of them. The respondent had been diagnosed with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and had a long history of domestic abuse, domestic abuse and sexual assault. The Court found that post-traumatic stress disorder was not a factor in the sentence as it was not aggravating to the respondent. The sentence imposed was based on a very narrow range of authorities, which included a case identifying the appropriate range, a case with dissimilar charge and a case from another jurisdiction with sentence at the low end of the range because of the personal circumstances of the accused. The judge was alive to the seriousness and the extent of her responsibility.
column9: Disposition: Allowed On February 11, 2009, the sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in pre-trial custody and then imposed a sentence of two years less one day to be followed by two years probation. The Crown seeks leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. I am satisfied the appeal should be allowed on the basis of this latter ground. I am, however, satisfied this same limited framework presented by counsel led the judge to err by failing to observe the need for parity in sentencing and as a result, the sentence imposed was not similar to sentences imposed on other offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances. Taking into account the mitigating factors already identified, in particular the respondent\'s post-sentence rehabilitative potential and the absence of evidence of prior acts of violence, a sentence slightly below the range as the one imposed in Bighead leads me to conclude a sentence of six years is appropriate, with 26 months credit for remand as imposed below. Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal is allowed.

column13: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed for the manslaughter of a seven-month-old child. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in custody and then imposed a 2 year less 1 day sentence followed by two years probation. The Crown sought leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: The appeal should be allowed on the basis of this latter ground.  1)The essential facts are not in dispute. The respondent's acknowledgment of responsibility, her expressions of remorse, her abusive background which may have caused symptoms of PTSD, and her socioeconomic situation all contribute to the offence. 2)The sentencing judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to properly consider this factor. 3)The respondent's dysfunctional upbringing or dysfunctional life was put forth by the Crown as an aggravating factor. The judge asked Crown counsel whether it could in fact be a mitigating factor. Counsel responded whether it was mitigating factor or not. 4)The court found the respondent had a high risk to re-offend and had compelling personal circumstances. 5)The sentence imposed did not adequately address the principles of denunciation and general deterrence. The court found that the respondent was in a position of trust and authority and did not seek immediate help when it was apparent the child was injured. 6)The Court found that a reasonable starting point for a custodial sentence for unlawful act manslaughter is seven years. The sentence imposed was based on the factors set out in R. v. Hathway. The Court also found that sentencing guidelines for adults who kill children do not require a detailed analysis of the factors considered in this case.

column2: The accused was charged with four offences relating to a twelve year old girl, including sexual assault and uttering a threat. He was released on bail with a surety. The accused is paraplegic. He moved to British Columbia after his release. He did not appear for trial, and a Canada wide warrant was issued for his arrest. He was arrested and returned to stand trial. The Crown applied to have bail and the surety forfeited. It took the position that the accused had deliberately left the province to avoid trial, and therefore should be responsible for the full $1,000. It also contended that the sureties had a responsibility to ensure the accused's attendance at trial, and that they should also be responsible for the full $1,000. The surety testified that the conditions of the recognizance were not explained to him, and he did not understand the potential consequences of default. Dismissing the applications for forfeiture, that the surety had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance, and was not made aware of those obligations by the authorities. In these circumstances, it would not be just to order forfeiture. With respect to the accused, he is impecunious. His failure to pay any amount ordered against him could lead to imprisonment. As the accused already faces the prospect of imprisonment for failing to attend trial, this would create the potential of double liability for what is in essence the same offence.
column3: The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl. The accused had been released from prison on a promise to appear in court on a charge of sexual assault. He had been injured and was unable to find a living accommodation. He applied for an order for forfeiture of recognizance. The Crown argued that the accused had no concept of his obligations under the recognizee and that it would not be just nor appropriate to order forfeiture. The surety contended that he had been forced to sign a recognizant and that he was not aware that he himself could be subject to imprisonment under s. 773 in the event of default. HELD: The applications for forfeiture were dismissed. The court found that the surety had no idea of his obligation under the agreement and that the fact that he might be subject for a period of time to be unable to pay any amount that may be ordered against him and that an order could be triggered. The fact that the defendant had a disability and was not able to drive made it unnecessary for him to exercise his right to drive. The applicant had no awareness of his responsibilities under the deal and was therefore not able or willing to exercise them. The defendant was not only subject to a severe financial hardship but also to a prospect of losing his employment and a considerable amount of his income. The failure to appear for trial would be a serious and life-threatening prospect for the accused. The sentence for imprisonment under the Criminal Code could be increased to a sentence of imprisonment under ss. 774. The only other penalty for failure to comply with the recognizaance was a fine.
column4: Hall, J. [1] The Crown has applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into by the accused, Lloyd Eugene Bailey, and the surety, Reverend Wrenford Bryant, in the amount of $1,000.00, which was given to secure the release of the accused pending his trial on a number of criminal charges. [3] The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl which allegedly occurred during the month of December, 1997. The offences include sexual assault under s. 271(1)(a) of the Criminal Code, uttering a threat, s. 264.1(1)(a), sexual touching under s. 151 and unlawfully having a weapon contrary to s. 87. [4] It appears that the accused was arrested in December of 1997 and remanded in custody at the Halifax Correction Centre pending posting of bail which was set at $1,000.00 with a surety. [7] The accused did not appear for trial on March 6, 2000 and a Canada wide warrant for his arrest was issued. As to the surety, the Crown submitted that under s. 771(2) of the Criminal Code sureties have a responsibility to ensure the attendance at trial of the person for whom they go bail and are responsible for getting out of prison and, therefore, the surety should be responsible for the full $1,000.00. [19] I conclude that Mr. Bryant had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance. In these circumstances I am satisfied that it would not be just nor appropriate to order forfeiture on the part of Mr. Bryant. [22] Turning next to the case of the accused, for very different reasons I have concluded as well that forfeiture ought not to be ordered against him. The accused is impecunious; he has no income and no assets other than an apparatus worth a few dollars that enables him to drive a motor vehicle. Thus, the accused would potentially be liable for a double punishment for his failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. [25] Accordingly, the applications for forfeiture are dismissed.

The accused is paraplegic. He moved to British Columbia after his release. He did not appear for trial, and a Canada wide warrant was issued for his arrest. He was arrested and returned to stand trial. The Crown applied to have bail and the surety forfeited. It took the position that the accused had deliberately left the province to avoid trial, and therefore should be responsible for the full $1,000. It also contended that the sureties had a responsibility to ensure the accused's attendance at trial, and that they should also be responsible for the full $1,000. The surety testified that the conditions of the recognizance were not explained to him, and he did not understand the potential consequences of default. Dismissing the applications for forfeiture, that the surety had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance, and was not made aware of those obligations by the authorities. In these circumstances, it would not be just to order forfeiture. With respect to the accused, he is impecunious. His failure to pay any amount ordered against him could lead to imprisonment. As the accused already faces the prospect of imprisonment for failing to attend trial, this would create the potential of double liability for what is in essence the same offence.
column23: The Crown applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into the accused. HELD: The applications for forfeiture were dismissed. 1)Since the accused would not be able to pay any amount that may be ordered against him, an order for imprisonment under s773 could be triggered. Section 145 of the Code provides its own penalty for failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. 2)The accused was found to have deliberately left the province to avoid his trial and should be responsible for the full $1,000. The Crown argued that the accused had no concept of his obligations under the recognizee. He mistakenly believed that his responsibilities or liability ended with the accused's first appearance in Court following his release. He was not aware that he himself could be subject to imprisonment under ss. 773 in the event of default and was not made aware of that fact. 3)The application for forfeiture was dismissed.
column24: Hall, J. [1] The Crown has applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into by the accused, Lloyd Eugene Bailey, and the surety, Reverend Wrenford Bryant, in the amount of $1,000.00, which was given to secure the release of the accused pending his trial on a number of criminal charges. [3] The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl which allegedly occurred during the month of December, 1997. The offences include sexual assault under s. 271(1)(a) of the Criminal Code, uttering a threat, s. 264.1(1)(a), sexual touching under s. 151 and unlawfully having a weapon contrary to s. 87. [4] It appears that the accused was arrested in December of 1997 and remanded in custody at the Halifax Correction Centre pending posting of bail which was set at $1,000.00 with a surety. [7] The accused did not appear for trial on March 6, 2000 and a Canada wide warrant for his arrest was issued. As to the surety, the Crown submitted that under s. 771(2) of the Criminal Code sureties have a responsibility to ensure the attendance at trial of the person for whom they go bail and are responsible for getting out of prison and, therefore, the surety should be responsible for the full $1,000.00. [19] I conclude that Mr. Bryant had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance. In these circumstances I am satisfied that it would not be just nor appropriate to order forfeiture on the part of Mr. Bryant. [22] Turning next to the case of the accused, for very different reasons I have concluded as well that forfeiture ought not to be ordered against him. The accused is impecunious; he has no income and no assets other than an apparatus worth a few dollars that enables him to drive a motor vehicle. Thus, the accused would potentially be liable for a double punishment for his failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. [25] Accordingly, the applications for forfeiture are dismissed.
column27: The Crown applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into the accused. The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl. HELD: The application for forfeiture was dismissed. 1)Since the accused would not be able to pay any amount that may be ordered against him, an order for imprisonment under s.773 could be triggered. Section 145 of the Code provides its own penalty for failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. 2)The accused was found to have deliberately left the province to avoid his trial. The Crown submitted that under s771(2) of the Criminal Code sureties have a responsibility to ensure the attendance at trial of the person for whom they go bail and are responsible for getting out of prison. The surety should be responsible for the full $1,000. 3)The Court found that the accused had no concept of his obligations under the recognizizance. He mistakenly believed that his responsibilities or liability ended with his first appearance in Court following his release. Certainly he was not aware that he himself could be subject to imprisonment under the s773 in the event of default and was not made aware of that fact.

column2: An application for certiorari and mandamus. In issue is whether the Youth Court judge has the discretion to refuse to appoint counsel to represent a young person having regard to the provisions of s.11(4) of the Young Offenders Act. The meaning of the word 'unable' in s.11(4)(b) was in issue. The youth was facing a variety of charges including failure to comply with conditions of an undertaking; failure to attend court; possession of property obtained by crime; obstructing a police officer. He requested the Youth Court appoint counsel after his Legal Aid lawyer withdrew. Both parents were on social assistance. The matter was adjourned to investigate the possibility of an aunt providing financial assistance but the youth advised in April that she was unable to do so. HELD: The application was dismissed. The Youth Court judge did not err in refusing to direct counsel be appointed. The Youth Court judge's discretion is not limited solely to considerations of financial inability. The youth disentitled himself to continued Legal Aid representation by his own misconduct.
column3: The applicant Youth Court judge refused to direct the applicant have counsel appointed to him. The issue was whether the Court had discretion to refuse having regard to s. 11(4)(b) of the Young Offenders Act, which states:Where a young person at his trial or at hearing or review is unable to obtain counsel, the youth court judge has every right to determine inability and has discretion to determine on a case by case basis whether such inability exists. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Youth Court's discretion to decide inability is not limited solely to considerations of financial inability. 2)The youth court's discretion is not solely to the considerations of a financial inability and the court is entitled to inquire into the foundation.

column13: This was an application for orders of certiorari and mandamus concerning a decision of a Youth Court judge not to appoint counsel to represent a young person. The issue was whether the Court had discretion to refuse having regard to s. 11(4)(b) of the Young Offenders Act. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The youth court judge did not err in refusing to direct that the applicant have counsel appointed to him. 2)The Youth Court's discretion to determine inability is not limited solely to considerations of financial inability. In R. v. J.H. the young person was facing a variety of charges including failure to comply with conditions of an undertaking, failure to attend court, possession of property obtained by crime and obstructing peace officer. The young person's parents were both on social assistance and would likely be unable to provide financial assistance. 3)The young person had no resources to obtain counsel through Legal Aid initially. He advised the court that his aunt was unable to assist him financially. The Youth Court Judge then asked why the youth did not stick with his Legal Aid lawyer. The youth argued that the Court was limited to inquiries regarding the ability of a parent or family member to provide assistance. If the result of the inquiry is that the youth person has no financial resources whatsoever available to him, counsel must be appointed. The use of the word'shall' means the court has no jurisdiction to decline the request. 4)The court was of the view that the Youth Court was not in a position to refuse the application on the basis that it was not a case where the youth court had jurisdiction to inquire into the means of the parents. It was also of the opinion that once a youth makes a request of the youth Court for representation by counsel the language of s.11(4(b) on plain reading makes it abundantly clear that the exercise of discretion is no longer an option and the making of an order becomes mandatory. 5)The Court held that because the Act makes inability to obtain a counsel the touchstone for the analysis, the youth judge has every right to determine ability and has discretion to decide on case by case basis whether it exists.

column2: The respondent expropriated a parcel of land owned by the appellant. Prior to a hearing, all claims for the case were settled for the sum of $20,000. The appellant's solicitor presented solicitor and client accounts of $19,420 plus taxes. The respondent directed taxation, and the appellant's solicitor submitted further accounts for services and disbursements of the taxation hearing amounting to $7,212.24. The taxing master received expert opinion that a reasonable fee for the services, exclusive of taxation costs, would be $10,000. He proceeded to tax the account at $14,000, disallowed any costs of the taxation hearing, and disallowed a claim for interest on interim accounts submitted by the solicitor. The appellants appealed. Dismissing the appeal and confirming the taxation, that the taxing master did not make any errors in law. He was entitled to consider as one of the relevant factors the relationship of the total account to the recovery.
column3: The appellant sought to expropriate land for the purpose of widening the Bedford Highway. The City Council passed a resolution to expound upon the land for a retaining wall. The expropriation resolution was filed at the Registry on September 7, 1993. The appellant applied to have the solicitor-client account taxed at $19,420 plus taxes. The solicitor-general account was taxed at the rate of $20,000 plus taxes and the amount awarded by the City was reduced to $14,000. The appellants appealed the decision of the Taxing Master to reduce the solicitor's account to $4,000 from $20.00. HELD: The appeal was dismissed and the taxation of costs confirmed. 1)The appellant's argument that the taxing master erred in principle was not supported by the evidence. 2)The taxing Master was not in error in stating that as a generalization, legal charges must bear some reasonable relationship to the value of the matter at issue. Once such error is shown the judge hearing the appeal may exercise all the powers set out in Rule 63.40. 3)The court found that the appellant's appeal was not of a sufficient proportionate proportionate to the amount taxed. The taxing officer was not acting in error.

The Taxing Master is not in error in stating that as a generalization, legal charges must bear some reasonable relationship to the value of the matter at issue. column2: The police observed the appellant's vehicle rub another vehicle and followed him to where he parked without difficulty. While taking the appellant to where the incident occurred, the officer noted slight smell of alcohol and bloodshot eyes. The appellant failed the ALERT test and refused the breathalyzer. The refusal charge was dismissed and the appellant was convicted of impaired driving. The appellant appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction quashed. The evidence of impairment was too weak to convict the appellant. The officer told the accused that if he passed the ALERT test, he would be sent on his way. Thus, she must not have thought that the appellant's ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired. Failure to act cannot be considered by the trial judge as part of the reasonable and probable grounds.
column3: The appellant was charged with impaired driving and driving while his ability was impaired by alcohol or drug. The appellant had been drinking, had a slight accident, and failed the roadside screening device. While the appellant was driving, the police officer observed the smell of alcohol and noted certain other features about the appellant. The officer requested the appellant take an 'alert' (an approved screening device having read to the appellant the requisite demand). When the appellant failed the test, the officer requested that the appellant retake the Breathalyzer. The appeal was allowed and the conviction quashed. The trial judge did not address the factors that were considered relevant to the accused's ability to drive the motor vehicle. He had apparently concluded that in the event the appellant passed the screening device he was quite capable of continuing to drive.
column4: A. I explained to him that this was just a roadside screening device and it was just an indicator for me, and that if he passed it he would be sent on his way and we’d look after the accident, and that if he failed I would be reading him a Breathalyzer demand and requesting him to come back to the Halifax police headquarters... [17] I have concluded that the evidence was weak to the point where there was virtually no choice but to acquit, and accordingly the appeal is allowed and the conviction quashed.

column8: HELD: The appeal was allowed and the conviction quashed. The trial judge did not address fully the various indicia of impaired driving beyond the findings that the accused had been drinking, had a very slight accident, and failed the Breathalyzer demand. The officer had failed in his testimony to give evidence of the words used in the demand. He had apparently concluded that in the event the appellant failed the screening device he was capable of continuing to drive. Failure to act cannot be considered by the trial judge as part of the reasonable and probable grounds.

column2: The 46-year-old female plaintiff sought damages for injuries suffered as a result of a motor vehicle accident. Her car was stopped by a flagman as a result of highway work when the defendant's vehicle struck her from behind. Awarding $15,000 for the whiplash injury and $75,000 for back injury as general damages. This amount was reduced to $25,000 due to a pre-existing condition. The court was satisfied there were degenerative changes in the plaintiffs spine which were accelerated by the accident. The pain problems were caused or contributed to by the defendant's negligence. An award for lost wages was also reduced by a factor of 33.%.
column3: The plaintiff was injured in a motor vehicle accident. The accident occurred when the plaintiff was stopped on a highway by a flagman to allow piece of heavy machinery to back out onto the roadway. The plaintiff was unable to work due to a back condition. She underwent degenerative changes in her spine which caused her to miss some time from work. She was unable or unwilling to work because of the injuries suffered. She had been working for nine years prior to the accident. She suffered from osteoarthritis, a chronic back condition which required treatment of steroids, a hip replacement and pain medication. She also suffered from chronic lung disease, which required treatments of such nature as to prevent her from returning to work. The defendant admitted liability for the injuries he caused her. The court awarded the plaintiff $25,000 for the back injury. The amount for loss of income was fixed at $30,305.12. The total award was fixed $70,305 for the injury and $5,875 for the lower back injury as well as the $25k for the whiplash injury.
column4: This is an action for damages for injuries suffered by the plaintiff as a result of a motor vehicle accident which occurred on May 31, 1988. On the totality of the evidence presented, I am satisfied that at the time of the accident the plaintiff was undergoing degenerative changes in her spine. I find that the plaintiff has discharged its burden of establishing, on a balance of probabilities, that the described pain problems were caused, or contributed to, by the defendant\'s negligence. I find that for this injury the plaintiff is entitled to an award in the amount of $15,000. With respect to the lower back injury, I find that the plaintiff is entitled to an award in the amount of $75,000; however, not all of this is attributable to the defendant\'s negligence. I find that the defendant is liable for 33.33 percent of this sum and, accordingly, the plaintiff shall receive $25,000 for her lower back injury. As to loss of income, I find that the plaintiff has lost income in the amount of $102,753.92 for the years 1988 to 1992. The defendant is liable for 33.33 percent of this sum which translates to $34,251 less $3,945.88 for section B benefits paid to the plaintiff.

column2: The appellant landlord and mother appeals from a decision of the Hearing Officer of the Office of the Residential Tenancies dismissing her claim for possession. The landlords are mother and son. The mother lives out of province for a number of years. She returns in summers to reside in the premises. This year she wanted to return to her premises on a full time basis. She found that her son had rented out a portion of the house to a Tenant and had signed a 3 year lease. She sought an order that the Tenant vacate the premises. The Hearing Officer found he had no jurisdiction to deal with the dispute between the two landlords. He found he could only deal with the situation between the landlords and the tenant and found that the tenant had signed a lease in good faith and is entitled to the rights the lease affords and is entitled to remain in the premises. HELD: There was no valid tenancy agreement. The Act only applies to tenancy agreements and to circumstances where rental units or residential property is validly rented by a landlord to a tenant. In the circumstances, the Hearing Officer did not have jurisdiction to deal with this dispute. However, the Hearing Officer did err in law in determining that the tenant was entitled to the rights that the lease affords. 1) A room in a house is a rental unit capable of being the subject of a tenancy. 2) Clearly there was no participation by both owners in entering into this lease agreement. Mr. Koch's evidence would lead to the opposite conclusion. There was no express consent of principal and agent.  3) The facts as described by the Hearing Officer do not support an agency by estoppel. This can arise where one person has acted so as to lead another to believe that he or she has authorized a third person, without any actual authority, to act on his behalf and that other person, in such belief, enters into a transaction with that third person. The tenant here was not aware that the mother was an owner and the mother did not lead the tenant to believe that her son was authorized to act on her behalf.
column3: The Hearing Officer of the Office of Residential Tenancies appealed a decision of the Hearing Officer. The Hearing Officer found that there was no valid tenancy agreement between the landlord and the tenant. The hearing officer found that the tenant had not signed a written tenancy agreement and that the hearing officer erred in finding that the landlord had breached the tenant's rights by serving notice to vacate. The appellant sought an order for possession of the rental unit. The applicant also sought an Order for the Hearing officer to withdraw the notice to leave. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The Court found that no valid lease agreement existed between the tenant and the landlord. The Court found no agreement between both owners. 2)The tenancy agreement was not invalid. The Act applies to tenancy agreements and to circumstances where rental units or residential property is validly rented by a landlord to a tenant. 3)The Hearing officer did not err in law in deciding that the tenants had not entered into a lease agreement. The tenant had signed a 3-year lease and the lease was validly leased. 4)The Act applies only to tenancy arrangements and to situations where rental unit or residential properties is validially rented by landlord to tenant. 5)The court found that a tenancy agreement is not invalid if the tenant is not aware that the owner or landlord is an owner and the hearing Officer did not erred by law in finding the landlord did not have jurisdiction to deal with this matter. 6)The tenant had no express or implied consent by the landlord to vacating the rental. The court found no express consent of the landlord or tenant.

Mr. Koch's evidence would lead to the opposite conclusion. There was no express consent of principal and agent.  3) The facts as described by the Hearing Officer do not support an agency by estoppel. This can arise where one person has acted so as to lead another to believe that he or she has authorized a third person, without any actual authority, to act on his behalf and that other person, in such belief, enters into a transaction with that third person. The tenant here was not aware that the mother was an owner and the mother did not lead the tenant to believe that her son was authorized to act on her behalf.
column8: HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The hearing officer found that there was no valid tenancy agreement between the landlord and the tenant. The Hearing Officer erred in law by declaring that she did not have the jurisdiction to deal with the matter. The tenant appealed. The Court held that a written tenancy agreement must contain the standard legal names of the landlord, the tenant and the hearing officer. It was immaterial whether the landlord had any authority from the tenants to do so. There was no express or implied consent of the tenant or landlord. The court found that the tenancy agreement was not valid and that the Hearing Officer did not err in law in finding that the landlord was acting for himself. The tenants had a right to have their property looked after.

The appellant claims that the Landlord has breached the rights of the tenant by serving notice to vacate and seeks an order for possession of the rental unit. The hearing officer found that there was no participation by both owners in entering into the lease agreement.  1) The Act applies to tenancy agreements and to circumstances where rental units or residential property is validly rented by a landlord to a tenant. 2) There was no express or implied consent of the landlord or tenant in entering the tenancy agreement. The Act also defines landlord as 'the owner's agent or another person who, on behalf of the owner, grants to another person the exclusive right of tenancy to a rental unit' (see s. 2(f)(i) of which the landlord is the landlord to the tenant). 3) Section 19 of the Act outlines the requirements for written tenancy agreements. One of the requirements is that a written tenancy agreement must contain the standard legal names of a landlord and the tenant. The Hearing Officer did err in law in declaring that the landlord had not provided the tenant with a written agreement that substantially complies with the provisions of s. 7(f) and s. 8(e) of the Residential Tenancy Act. 4) Section 70 of the Code of Regulations and the tenancy agreements between the landlord and tenant refer to a tenancy agreement between the tenant and the landlord. The tenant had signed a 3-year lease in 1960 and had a year lease. She sought an order of vacate in order that she could move into her new home. 5) Section 7 of the Regulations applies to rental units and other residential property. Section 20 of the ACT provides that to create a fixed term tenancy of three months or longer, the tenant must enter into a written lease. Section 21 provides that the hearing officer may make an order respecting a rental agreement, rental unit, or a lease, or an order made pursuant to s. 33. column2: The Plaintiff's 1989 Ford F150 1/2 ton truck caught fire and burned in his garage. This model of truck was subject to a recall by Ford to correct a fuel line defect. The Plaintiff called several expert witnesses who testified that, in their opinion, the leaking fuel line was the cause of the fire. Ford called one witness who was the designer of of the truck's fuel system and a Ford employee. He testified that the defective fuel line could not have leaked sufficient fuel to cause the fire. He also admitted, however, that his prior written report contained errors. Rebuttal evidence called by the Plaintiff indicated that the check valve in the fuel pump designed to prevent siphoning from the fuel tank in the event of a leaking fuel line did not operate as the Ford witness had testified. HELD: Judgment for the Plaintiff. The Plaintiff had proved on a balance of probabilities that the leaking fuel line was the cause of the fire. The Plaintiff's experts' evidence was accepted over that of the Ford expert. No independent experts had been called by Ford.
column3: The plaintiffs claim for damages from a fire in their garage which they allege was caused by an electric static discharge through the fuel tube of a truck they purchased from Ford. The plaintiffs allege the fire was caused as a result of a'static discharge' through the U-shaped fuel tube in the truck. HELD: The plaintiffs' claim was dismissed. 1)The plaintiffs' evidence was accepted beyond a reasonable doubt that the fire started due to an electricstatic discharge through a U- shaped fuel tube. 2)The plaintiff plaintiffs' theory as to how the fire actually started was accurate. 3)The evidence was that the plaintiffs had proven beyond a balance of probabilities that the truck was caused solely by an electrical static discharge. 4)The defendant's theory as as to where the fire originated was accurate and the plaintiffs' case was not proven beyond the balance of probability.
column4:
The plaintiffs Clarence Gill and Shirley Gill
("Clarence and Shirley") claim against Ford Motor Company of
Canada Limited ("Ford") for damages from a fire in their
garage which they allege was caused by combustion of vapours
from gasoline leakage from the fuel tube of a new truck they
purchased from Ford.  CONCLUSION I accept the expert testimony of the plaintiffs and

the fire was caused by an electric static discharge through

column18: The plaintiffs claim against Ford for damages from a fire in their garage which they allege was caused by an electric static discharge through the fuel tube of a truck they purchased from Ford. HELD: The Court accepted the expert testimony of the plaintiffs and the defendant in preference to the plaintiff in that the plaintiffs' theory as to how the fire started is accurate. 1)The plaintiffs have proven beyond a balance of probabilities that the fire occurred because of an electrical static discharge from the U-shaped fuel tube in the truck. 2)The Court accepted expert testimony by the plaintiffs in particular Fowler and MacPherson. 3)The evidence from Ford and the Field Review Committee of Ford was accepted. 4)The plaintiff's theory of the fire was accurate. The evidence from the plaintiffs was that due to extreme weather conditions the electrical insulating qualities of the nylon fuel line were reduced to an extent that the accumulated static electricity discharged through the line. During this static discharge, pin holes would be created and gasoline would leak out. The vapours would then be drawn to the area underneath the Ford truck where the gasoline was pooled. This would likely be in the wash tray which was located under the vehicle and which Clarence used to wash his truck. The recall notice delineated the problem with the fuel system which was consistent with the plaintiffs theory. 5)There was no evidence that the defendant had ever tested such a vehicle in these circumstances to see if the fire could result in a fire. The plaintiff's evidence was dismissed.

column2: FIAT. The father sought to reduce the support contained in the 1997 divorce judgment which incorporated the parties' interspousal agreements regarding custody, access and child and spousal support. The parties were married in 1985 and separated in 1995. The mother was on leave from her employment. When his federal government management position was declared redundant, the applicant received a retiring allowance of $75,646 in May 1997. The respondent opposed the application on the basis there had been no change in circumstances since the judgment was granted; she had no other income than the support payments and child tax credit; alternatively, there were special provisions in the parties' separation agreement which would permit the court to award an amount that differs from the amount prescribed by the Guidelines.HELD: 1)The judgment the applicant sought to vary was made after the coming into force of the Guidelines. It did not however include a determination of child support made in accordance with the Guidelines. There was no change in the childrens' or mother's circumstances. The applicant was unemployed but was still benefiting from his retiring allowance at the time of the order which he no longer enjoyed. A variation was warranted as there had been a change in the father's financial means and circumstances. The Guideline support obligation for two children is $341 per month.  2)It could not be concluded on the evidence presented that there was any special provision in the parties' agreement that directly or indirectly benefited either child. The provision for child support in a specified amount greater than that provided in the Guidelines was not a 'special provision' as contemplated by s17(6.2) of the Divorce Act given the change in circumstances of the applicant whose annual income had dropped from $55,500 to $24,000 a year.  3)No order was made as to costs.
column3: FIAT. The parties separated in 1995 and in 1997 entered into an interspousal agreement. The respondent had custody of the children and the applicant had access on reasonable notice. The applicant sought to vary the child support provisions of the judgment to an amount that corresponded with the Federal Child Support Guidelines. HELD: 1)The parties agreed that child support payable by the applicant would be in accordance with an interim order made in June 1996. The interim order required the applicant to pay child support in the amount of $341 per month for the two children. 2)The respondent did not have a special agreement with the applicant. The agreement was made after the coming into force of the Guidelines. 3)The applicant had experienced significant reduction in his income since 1997 and had been unable to obtain employment which compensated him at a level commensurate with that received while employed by the federal government. 4)The child support obligation was $341 for the respondent. 5)The mother was unemployed. She was now on leave from her employment with the federal Government. She had requested a transfer to the federal federal government from the federal one. She claimed special provisions in an order, judgment or written agreement respecting the financial obligations of the spouses, or the division or transfer of their property, directly or indirectly benefit the children. The mother claimed special provision for child support of $20 per month continuing until April 1998. The father claimed special special provision of $5 per month. 6)The father was to pay $341.

column2: This is an appeal from a judgment in which the trial judge held that the sale of farm land by the then 79 year old appellant was valid and that her solicitor in the transaction was not negligent. The appellant widow agreed to sell four quarters of farmland, including residence and some grain bins on the land, to the respondents by lease option agreement. The total price was $120,000. The terms were favourable to the purchasers, the monies being paid over years with most deferred until the final year. There was no interest. However, the appellant was permitted to reside in the house for her lifetime if she paid the utilities and the property taxes. The trial judge noted that the appellant resided on the land for years and there was no complaint made until the appellant's daughter, from whom the contract had been concealed by joint agreement between the appellant and the purchasers, found out what had happened. The sole issue on appeal was the applicable standard of review in H.L. v. Canada (Attorney General) [2005] 1 S.C.R. 401. HELD: Appeal dismissed. 1) There is no doubt that the central facts as found by the trial judge regarding the contract, the competence of the appellant and the relationship with and the conduct of the purchasers was supported by probative evidence. It is impossible for an appeal court to interfere with those findings, even if the Court had wished to. 2) With regard to the allegation of negligence against appellant's lawyer, contrary to what the appellant suggest, an independent meeting is not absolutely necessary for the solicitor to ensure comprehension of the contract. It is of course desirable, but the critical matter is for the solicitor to satisfy himself that the client comprehends the transaction. The trial judge found that the appellant understood all aspects of the contract. The matter of the timing of the private meeting between the appellant and her lawyer is not relevant, given that the appellant after the meeting continued to be prepared to enter into and perform the contract. If she had manifested some unease after she signed the agreement and then met with her lawyer but before the delivery of the contract to the purchasers, other issues and no doubt other evidence would have been considered in determining when the contract became effective in the circumstances. The claims against the appellant's solicitor are without a factual basis.
column3: This was an appeal from a judgment in which the trial judge held that the sale of farm land by the then 79-year-old appellant was valid and that her solicitor in the transaction was not negligent. The appellant sought to set aside the transaction under various heads of contract law including duress, undue influence, unconscionability, equitable fraud and mistake. The claims against the solicitor were without a factual basis. The trial judge made critical findings of fact which negate any attempt to overturn what is on its face valid contract. The central facts on the terms of the contract, the competence of the appellant and the relationship with and conduct of the solicitor was supported by probative evidence. The issue before us was whether the standard of review had been met. HELD: The appeals against both the Clements and the solicitors were dismissed. 1)The issues raised in the grounds of appeal are factual and the sole matter of significance was whether there was a standard of reviewing in H.L. v. Canada (Attorney General). The standard of reviews in HL. was met. 2)The trial judge concluded that the plaintiff, when she entered the contract had full capacity. He saw no reason on the evidence to doubt her competence and that the contract was advantageous to the Clement family. 3)The appellant made no effort to attack the contract. She signed the contract before the solicitor and after her signature was affixed to it. The evidence was clear that the appellant had not been fully aware of the value of the land at the time of the signing. 4)The evidence was not relevant to the issue of whether the central facts were supported by the probative and probative findings. The issues were whether the court could interfere with the findings of facts. 5)The court found that the issues raised were factual and that there was no question the standard was met in HLL v.Canada. The court found the respondent McLaughlin was not shown to have breached or failed any professional obligation. The contract was beneficial to the appellant. The fact that she had the right to keep the residence and yardsite for as long as she wanted could easily have led her to exclude or disregard the value. The judge concluded the contract is not necessary to satisfy the appellant's critical findings. 6)The issue of timing was irrelevant. The meeting was necessary to ensure the contract met the standard.

The claims against the solicitor are without a factual basis. The trial judge made critical findings of fact which negate any attempt to overturn what is on its face valid contract. The central facts on the terms of the contract, the competence of the appellant and the relationship with and conduct of the solicitor were supported by probative evidence. There was no doubt that the contract was effective in the circumstances. The appeals against both the Clements and the solicitors were dismissed. On these facts no possible attack on the contract exists. On the issues raised in the grounds of appeal, the sole matter of significance was whether the central facts of the agreement, the competencies of the appellants and their relationship with the solicitor, were supported. There is no doubt the contract became effective because the appellant met the solicitor privately and was prepared to proceed. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The issues were factual and the standard of review in H.L. v. Canada had been met. 2)The trial judge concluded that the plaintiff, when she entered the contract had full capacity. He saw no reason on the evidence to doubt her competence and that is fully supported by her testimony at the trial when she was in her late 80's. The contract was advantageous to the appellant as it allowed her to keep the residence and yardsite for as long as she wanted. The parties then lived with the contract for at least two years. 3)The appellant made much of the fact that she signed the contract before the solicitor for the appellant. She also sought relief against her solicitor for negligence.
column24:
Disposition: Dismissed (Orally)
 [1] This is an appeal from a judgment in which the trial judge held that the sale of farm land by the then 79-year-old appellant was valid and that her solicitor in the transaction was not negligent. In those circumstances it is impossible for us as a court of appeal to interfere with these findings, even had we wished to. [17] Again, as with the attempts to set aside the contract, the claims against the solicitor are without a factual basis. [18] Accordingly, the appeals against both the Clements and the solicitors are dismissed.
column27: This was an appeal from a judgment in which the trial judge held that the sale of farm land by the then 79-year-old appellant was valid and that her solicitor in the transaction was not negligent. The appellant sought to set aside the transaction under various heads of contract law including duress, undue influence, unconscionability, equitable fraud and mistake. The claims against the solicitor were without a factual basis and the appellant sought relief against her solicitor for negligence. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The issues raised in the grounds of appeal are factual and the sole matter of significance was whether the central facts on the terms of the contract, the competence of the appellant and the relationship with and conduct of the Clements was supported by probative evidence. There was no doubt that it was. 2)The appellant was not shown to have breached or failed any professional obligation. The evidence was clear that the meeting with the solicitor was successful. 3)The court was not able to interfere with the findings of fact. 4)On these facts no possible attack on the contract exists.

column2: The respondent landowner haphazardly painted his buildings in order to protest a decision of Halifax city council. The city charged the respondent under the unsightly premises provisions of the Halifax City Charter. At trial, the court held the wording of the City Charter could not support the charge, and that a conviction would violate the respondent's s.2(b) Charter rights to freedom of expression. The city appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that the trial judge did not commit an error in law. S.363(3) of the Halifax City Charter, under which the respondent was charged, refers to land as opposed to buildings, and cannot be interpreted to include the exterior finishes of buildings, a category already dealt with in s.363(6), which covers the unsightliness of buildings caused by neglect, not overt actions.
column3: The respondent owned several buildings on Robie Street. These one time family homes were converted into apartment units. In 1994 the respondent's proposal to replace these buildings with high density apartments was rejected by Halifax City Council. The respondent repainted the buildings in haphazard and multi-coloured fashion. HELD: The Crown appealed. 1)The trial judge found that when the legislators turned their minds to the unsightliness of buildings, they drafted subsection 6. This section deals with unsightly properties. The appellant alleged that the unsightsliness was caused by the owner's overt actions. 2)The learned trial judge made no error in law.
column4: This is a reference to land as opposed to buildings. In the case at bar the appellant alleges that the unsightliness was caused by the owner\'s overt actions. I therefore find that the learned trial judge, when interpreting s. 363(3) made no error in law. The Crown\'s appeal is dismissed.

column2: The appellant was convicted of sexual assault. The court disbelieved his evidence, principally because it was found to be internally inconsistent. The court found that the appellant had attempted to portray himself as being good to the children but had admitted on cross-examination that the children had been removed from the home due to allegations of physical abuse and lack of food. There was no evidence before the court as to the truth of these allegations and the appellant had stated in his evidence that everyone thought that he treated the children badly. The appellant appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction set aside; new trial ordered. The trial judge misapprehended the evidence because she attributed to it a relevance that it could not have in law or in logic. The appellants evidence about the involvement of Childrens Services did not permit the judge to draw any inference that the children had, in fact, been badly treated or that the appellant was responsible for such treatment. The misapprehension, examined in the context of the judges reasons as a whole and the entire record was substantial, material and played an essential part in the judges reasoning leading to the conviction; the misapprehension had given rise to a miscarriage of justice.

column2: In a contract of employment, which involved an agreement changing the plaintiff from 'expatriate' to 'local' status, a termination clause providing that the agreement could be terminated upon 3 months' notice was held to be inadequate language to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice. The plaintiff had correctly interpreted the clause as relating to the termination of the agreement, not of his employment. The agreement provided that it was governed by the laws of the province of Alberta. The plaintiff had been employed by the defendant for 12 years and was awarded compensation in an amount equivalent to 18 months notice less the three months pay he already received and any income from his new employment over the balance of the 15 months. He was also awarded the loss resulting from the difference in vacation and loss of an auto allowance for the 15 months. For emotional trauma, which lasted only briefly, he received $500.
column3: The plaintiff was an expatriate and a member of the Royal Navy. He was assigned to Canada as an expat and worked for several years as a surveyor. He later became a manager of a company in Nova Scotia. The company offered him monies that had been paid to the plaintiff in the past and he refused to take them. He became depressed and went into deep depression. The defendant gave him two days written notice of termination without cause. He applied for and was granted a position with the plaintiff. The plaintiff was awarded a salary of $67,389.00. He claimed that this was a reasonable time to move. The clause of the agreement did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, but rather to termination. The lawyer for the plaintiff testified that he had no recollection of the meeting with the defendant and that he was advised that the contract would terminate on 30 days notice. He also claimed that he did not take the position because he believed there would be no alternative employment. The court found that reasonable notice must be given.
column4: I find that based on the plaintiff's knowledge of the defendant's practises at the time that he signed the agreement in 1985, that his interpretation that clause #7 did not relate to termination of his employment, but rather to termination of the written agreement, was correct. I find that the terminology was unclear in that termination of employment was not specifically mentioned in the clause and had not been discussed with him previously in preparing the '85 or '84 or earlier contracts. After taking into consideration all of the arguments made by the plaintiff, I find that Mr. Legorburu is entitled to eighteen months notice. I also award the loss resulting from the difference in vacation for fifteen months, and loss of automobile allowance for fifteen months. I award $500.00.
column7: In a contract of employment, which involved an agreement changing the plaintiff from 'expatriate' to 'local' status, a termination clause providing that the agreement could be terminated upon 3 months' notice was held to be inadequate language to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice. The plaintiff had correctly interpreted the clause as relating to the termination of the agreement, not of his employment. The agreement provided that it was governed by the laws of the province of Alberta. The plaintiff had been employed by the defendant for 12 years and was awarded compensation in an amount equivalent to 18 months notice less the three months pay he already received and any income from his new employment over the balance of the 15 months. He was also awarded the loss resulting from the difference in vacation and loss of an auto allowance for the 15 months. For emotional trauma, which lasted only briefly, he received $500.
column8: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a Canadian company. He was given a salary of $67,389.00. He later became a District Manager of the Halifax Office. He worked for several years for the defendant company as a consultant. He eventually became a permanent employee of the company. The defendant offered him a position as a senior geophysicist in the Halifax office. He refused the offer and became depressed. He sought to leave the company and seek employment elsewhere. He applied for and was granted a position with the company's regional manager in Nova Scotia. The contract did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, but rather to a termination of the agreement. The down turn in the economic situation was caused by the down turn. When the plaintiff went to Argentina to establish an office for the plaintiff, he was given three months notice of termination without cause. He then applied to the Federal Civil Service for a position in the Newfoundland office. The company refused to give him the position and he was awarded a lump sum payment of $1,000.00 for each month he worked there. He also applied for employment with the plaintiff in the position of District Manager in Halifax. He received a salary in the amount of $55,000 and was awarded one-half of his regular salary. He did not have a permanent residence in Halifax and was advised to stay in Canada. The agreement between the parties was signed in 1985 and was amended in 1986 to include a provision that the defendant could terminate without notice or specifying the notice required. This clause did not reference termination of employment by DNV, it related to termination.
column9: I find that based on the plaintiff's knowledge of the defendant's practises at the time that he signed the agreement in 1985, that his interpretation that clause #7 did not relate to termination of his employment, but rather to termination of the written agreement, was correct. I find that the terminology was unclear in that termination of employment was not specifically mentioned in the clause and had not been discussed with him previously in preparing the '85 or '84 or earlier contracts. After taking into consideration all of the arguments made by the plaintiff, I find that Mr. Legorburu is entitled to eighteen months notice. I also award the loss resulting from the difference in vacation for fifteen months, and loss of automobile allowance for fifteen months. I award $500.00.

column13: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a Canadian company. He was given a salary of $67,389.00. When he went to Argentina to establish an office for the defendant company, he became frustrated and depressed. The defendant offered him monies that had been paid to him by his previous employer. He refused the offer and went into deep depression. When the company sold the company, the plaintiff became depressed and sought employment elsewhere. He applied for and was granted a position with the plaintiff's former employer. The contract was terminated without cause. The down turn in the performance of the plaintiff was attributed to the clause in the agreement which stated that the defendant did not have cause to dismiss the plaintiff. HELD: 1)This clause did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, it related to termination.  2)The plaintiff was not entitled to reasonable notice and since such notice had not been given, he was entitled to damages.
