column18: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a Canadian company. He was given a salary of $67,389.00. When he went to Argentina to establish an office for the defendant company, he was told that he could leave the company on three months notice but that the company had no right to give him a further six months notice of termination. He applied to the Federal Civil Service and was granted a position with the company in Montevideo. The defendant refused to allow him to leave and the plaintiff applied for and was awarded $55,000.00 in salary and benefits. When the company decided to terminate the agreement, the plaintiff was terminated without cause. He claimed that the clause of the agreement did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, but rather to his continued employment as a manager of the Halifax Office with responsibility for Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. He also claimed that it was unnecessary for him to take the agreement to lawyer as he did not perceive it as a way to fire him. HELD: The defendant was found to have breached the implied term of reasonable notice.

column23: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a Canadian company. He was given a salary of $67,389.00. He applied to the Federal Civil Service and was granted a position with the company in Montevideo. The defendant then gave him a two-year appointment as District Manager of the East Coast Area with duties which included examination of newly constructed ships, ships in service, and oil platform construction and commissioning. When the company decided to terminate the agreement, the plaintiff applied to be transferred to Nova Scotia. He received a letter from the defendant stating that the agreement would terminate on 30 days notice but only that if the company desires to terminate it it shall give 30 days' notice. He argued that this clause did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, it related to the termination of the agreement. He claimed it was unnecessary for him to take the application to lawyer as he did not perceive it as a way to fire him. HELD: The agreement was terminated without notice or specifying the notice required.

column27: The plaintiff was an expatriate and a member of the Royal Navy. He was assigned to Canada as an expat and worked for several years as a surveyor. He later became a manager of a company in Nova Scotia. The company offered him monies that had been paid to the plaintiff in the past and he refused to take them. He became depressed and went into deep depression. The defendant gave him two days written notice of termination without cause. He applied for and was granted a position with the plaintiff. The plaintiff was awarded a salary of $67,389.00. He claimed that this was a reasonable time to move. The clause of the agreement did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant, but rather to termination. The lawyer for the plaintiff testified that he had no recollection of the meeting with the defendant and that he was advised that the contract would terminate on 30 days notice. He also claimed that he did not take the position because he believed there would be no alternative employment. The court found that reasonable notice must be given.

column2: The petitioner seeks child and spousal support. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in July 2004. With respect to spousal support the agreement provides that it is the intention of the parties that spousal support will be based on a division of income until July 1, 2011.HELD: 1) The petitioner seeks a spousal support order in which the court is asked to impute income and then apply the provisions of their interspousal contract to determine quantum. The interspousal contract does not contemplate variation of the spousal support obligation in the event of a material change of circumstance. It will be for the trial judge to determine the intention of the parties when the agreement makes reference to the adjustments which 'will consider Technologies likely future earnings based upon whether Paul's contract is renewed with the Provincial Government'. This is not an appropriate case in which to make an order for interim spousal support. The petitioner is entitled to support under the agreement and in the circumstances as they presently exist. 2) With regard to child support, there is no question that Melanie remains a child of the marriage while she is attending her educational program. Insofar at the respondent's income is concerned, the gross income to the corporation is $65,000 per year. The respondent provided a pay stub for May 2006. It is not really a pay stub, but extrapolating from that statement the court concluded that the respondent's gross taxable income from the corporation as a result of the $65,000 contract is approximately $53,000. Child support will be ordered based on $53,000 on an interim basis.
column3: HELD: The petitioner was granted child support and spousal support pending trial. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in 2004. The respondent was to pay $65 per month in spousals. The petitioner's expenses were to be calculated based upon her anticipated future earnings. The court noted that the parties had not reached an agreement on the basis of the interspouse contract. The issue of costs remained.

column8: The petitioner sought child support and spousal support pending trial. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in July 2004. The agreement provided that the respondent would pay child support in the amount of 40% of the net income of the corporation and $125,000 per month for the support of their two children. The respondent was employed with an annual salary of $100,000. In April 2004 the husband's employment was terminated. He received severance package of $74,000 from Canada Pension. The petitioner claimed his only source of income was $490 per month. The court dismissed the application, saying that the interspouse contract does not contemplate a variation of the spousa support obligation in the event of a material change in circumstances. HELD: The agreement was set aside and the petitioner was entitled to support under the agreement and the circumstances as they presently existed. 1)In the circumstances, this was not an appropriate case in which to make an order for interim spousals support. In the circumstances it was not appropriate to make such an order pending trial on the basis of the petitioner's income. 2)The respondent was to pay $65,000 in spousas per month to the petitioner for the duration of the marriage. The amount payable by way of equal monthly payments to the respondent was reduced to $40,000 by the time the agreement was made. 3)The parties had signed a comprehensive agreement which dealt with parenting issues, child support, child care and the division of family property. Under the agreement, the respondent received lump sum spousousal and ongoing support of $5,000 and $1,000/month from October 2001 to July 2002. The husband carried on business through Exodus Technologies Inc. The sole source of revenue of revenue earned by the respondent's efforts as a computer consultant in 2005. In 2005 he earned $124,128. 4)The petitioner was to continue to work in the field of computer consulting. She was to attempt to obtain part-time employment. 5)The agreement was not intended to vary the spouse's income until July 2011.  6)In this case the petitioner is entitled to a spouseal support order in which the Court is asked to impute income and then apply the provisions of their interspoleal contract to determine quantum. The intersponseal contract does contemplate variation of spouso support in case of material change of circumstance.

column2: HELD: The accused was granted a curative discharge. The court found that the accused had met the required onus of this type of application in accordance with R. v. Ahenakew. The accused’s conduct over the past 18 months satisfied the court on the balance of probabilities that hers was an exceptional case and that a curative discharge would not be contrary to the public interest. The court imposed numerous conditions on her, including that she could not have or consume alcohol and should report to a probation officer, receive addiction counselling, participate in AA meetings and provide proof of her attendance to her probation officer. Her driver’s license was cancelled and she was prohibited from driving for two years.
column3: The accused entered a guilty plea to driving while her blood alcohol content was over 80 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood and asked to be granted curative discharge pursuant to s. 255(5) of the Criminal Code. The accused had two prior convictions for drinking and driving. The first conviction resulted in a custodial sentence and a fine. She had been convicted of driving while over the legal limit and had been imprisoned for another drinking and drive offence. She remained sober for only a few months before resuming old habits. The second conviction resulted into a custodian sentence and programming. The court found that the accused had shown that her case was the exceptional case contemplated in Ashberry and Ahenakew and that a curative release would not be contrary to the public interest. HELD: 1)Although it can never be said with certainty that the defendant will not drink and drive again, her conduct over the last 18 months suggests that it is probable she will not. 2)A curative order would not interfere with the public's interest. 3)The Court was satisfied that the Court had shown the exceptional circumstances contemplated in the Ashberry case. The Court was also satisfied that her conduct had shown her that hers was the case contemplated.

The accused had two prior convictions for drinking and driving and had been through the Impaired Driver Treatment Centre. HELD: 1)The accused was granted a conditional discharge. 2)The Court was satisfied that the accused had shown that her case was the exceptional case contemplated in Ashberry and Ahenakew. 3)The court was satisfied on a balance of probabilities that she would not drink and drive again, her conduct over the last 18 months suggests that it is probable she will not.
column22: HELD: The accused was granted a curative discharge. The court found that the accused had met the required onus of this type of application in accordance with R. v. Ahenakew. The accused’s conduct over the past 18 months satisfied the court on the balance of probabilities that hers was an exceptional case and that a curative discharge would not be contrary to the public interest. The court imposed numerous conditions on her, including that she could not have or consume alcohol and should report to a probation officer, receive addiction counselling, participate in AA meetings and provide proof of her attendance to her probation officer. Her driver’s license was cancelled and she was prohibited from driving for two years.
column23: The accused entered a guilty plea to driving while her blood alcohol content was over 80 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood and asked to be granted curative discharge pursuant to s. 255(5) of the Criminal Code. The accused had two prior convictions for drinking and driving and had been through the Impaired Driver Treatment Centre for two years. After her first conviction, she was convicted of driving while over the legal limit. She returned to Saskatchewan to be near her family but she continued to drink heavily. She remained sober for only a few months before resuming her old habits. Although it can never be said with certainty that the accused will not drink and drive again, her conduct over the last 18 months suggests that it is probable she will not. A curative release would not be contrary to the public interest. HELD: 1)The accused was granted a three-year suspended driver's licence immediately cancelled and she was prohibited from driving on any street, road, highway or other public place for 2 years commencing today. 2)Costs were to be paid on or before June 30, 2016.
column27: The accused entered a guilty plea to driving while her blood alcohol content was over 80 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood and asked to be granted curative discharge pursuant to s. 255(5) of the Criminal Code. The accused had two prior convictions for drinking and driving. The first conviction resulted in a custodial sentence and a fine. She had been convicted of driving while over the legal limit and had been imprisoned for another drinking and drive offence. She remained sober for only a few months before resuming old habits. The second conviction resulted into a custodian sentence and programming. The court found that the accused had shown that her case was the exceptional case contemplated in Ashberry and Ahenakew and that a curative release would not be contrary to the public interest. HELD: 1)Although it can never be said with certainty that the defendant will not drink and drive again, her conduct over the last 18 months suggests that it is probable she will not. 2)A curative order would not interfere with the public's interest. 3)The Court was satisfied that the Court had shown the exceptional circumstances contemplated in the Ashberry case. The Court was also satisfied that her conduct had shown her that hers was the case contemplated.

column2: Two years after the divorce, the wife applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties' Corollary Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms of Minutes of Settlement. Pursuant to the Corollary Relief judgment, the husband was currently paying the wife $4,350 per month as spousal support. The wife now wished to increase the monthly support to a figure which would more closely resemble that assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines, along with a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the underpayment of spousal support for the past two years. She also sought removal of a clause which provided for the discontinuation of support if the husband's professional income dropped below $80,000. The parties had been married for approximately thirty years and had one child, who was now independent. Application dismissed; the parties' current circumstances did not constitute a significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties when the Agreement was signed. Both parties' income had increased since the divorce and the wife was not deeply in debt, as she alleged; there was no pressure exerted and no oppression during the course of negotiations; the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines are not law and allow for exceptions to the general formulas provided, one such exception being the assumption of debt by one of the parties (the husband in this case); the spousal support figure recognized the husband's reasonable expectation of retirement and the fact that he was experiencing health problems; it was completely foreseeable at the time that the Agreement was signed that, given the wife's age, she might experience difficulty in finding employment in her narrow field; the subsequent increased value of one of the husband's properties was not a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the Agreement.
column3: The parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation and had one child, a daughter. The parties separated in May 2001 when the respondent moved from the matrimonial home and they were divorced in February 2003. At the time of their separation, the respondent applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties' Corollary Relief Judgment. The applicant applied to have the respondent vary the terms of the agreement incorporated in the Corollaries Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms in the Agreement. The respondent argued that the Agreement was sound when it was signed, that there have been no material changes in the circumstances of either of the Parties since it was executed or since it has been made an order of the Court and that the Respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant. HELD: The respondent was granted the order to vary spousals. 1)The parties had been married for 29 years and had been engaged for over 30 years. The divorce settlement had left the applicant deeply in debt. 2)The respondent did not have to take advantage or take advantage. 3)The Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines are not law. The agreement was not law and the court was unable to conclude that the agreement was in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Act. 4)The agreement was based on a reasonable expectation of retirement. The amount of spousa received by the parties was minimal. The husband's income was modest while the wife's debt was substantial. 5)The court was not able to conclude the Agreement wasn't in substantial compliant with the Act because the parties were not married for more than 29 years. 6)The Court was not obliged to substitute what it might have ordered had the parties proceeded to trial. The exceptions listed were those that were not intended to be an exhaustive list and each case must be decided on its own facts.
column4: [1] The Applicant, Marie-Louise Stening-Riding, has applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Corollary Relief Judgment dated February 20th, 2003. At the same time as their divorce was granted a Corollary Relief Judgment was also granted which incorporated the terms of an agreement signed by the parties dated January 30, 2003. She proposed that the monthly support be increased to a figure that more closely resembles that which would be assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines and that she receive a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the “underpayment” of spousal support since the 1st of February 2003. [27] I find that there was no pressure exerted by the Respondent upon the Applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the Agreement and I find further that the Respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the Applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court in Miglin (supra). [35] Although the parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation, in determining the appropriate spousal support terms, one has to take into account a number of factors including the Respondent’s age, his health (which has not been good) and the reasonable expectation of retirement. The Applicant should have been aware that whereas she was in her late fifties when she received her doctorate the prospects of her obtaining a full-time teaching position at a university in the narrow field of her expertise were far from great. It was completely foreseeable that she would have difficulty and perhaps no chance at all of obtaining such a position. [47] The incomes of both parties have increased since the Agreement was signed but that too was a foreseeable event. I do not consider the increased appraised value of the Respondent’s real estate to be a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Agreement. [54] In conclusion, the current circumstances of the parties are not a “significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties” when they signed their Agreement. The application is dismissed.

HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Agreement was sound when it was signed, that there had been no material change in the circumstances of either party since it was executed and the respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant. 2)The agreement was not law. The Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines allow for exceptions to the general formulas provided in the guidelines and one exception mentioned was the assumption of debt by one of the respondent's parties. 3)Although the parties had been married for almost 29 years, the parties’ divorce settlement had left them deeply in debt. The respondent had taken steps to reduce the amount of his household expenses. The applicant had borrowed $150,000 from the respondent to purchase a new home. 4)The parties had agreed that the respondent’s monthly support was increased to $5,500 from $4,535. 5 and that she would receive a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the underpayment of spousals since the 1st of February 2003 when the respondent retired. 5)The respondent was asked to remove the clause that permits the respondent, his age, his health and his retirement benefits to be 'unfettered'. The court was left to take into account a number of factors including the applicant, her circumstances and the circumstances and that the employment market is difficult, particularly for a woman of her age. The court found that the parties did consider their respective circumstances and took heed to all of the objectives in Miglin (supra). 6)The court found no pressure exerted upon the applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the Agreement and that variation of the spOUSAL support provisions was not only justified but required. The agreement was sound and the parties were engaged in a reasonable relationship. The husband was able to earn a modest mortgage and pay his rent at a reasonable income. The wife was able and willing to contribute to the amount owing to the respondent. The amount owing by the applicant was less than half of what the respondent was earning at the time the parties separated.

column2: HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that the 51 months between the charges and the scheduled trial was sufficiently long to warrant an inquiry into the reasonableness of the delay. As the accused had specifically and voluntarily waived almost five months of the delay, the court deducted that amount, leaving 46 months to be considered. The various types of delay were considered by the court: 11.5 for inherent delay; 15.5 months to be attributed to the actions of the accused; 10 months to be attributed to the Crown; and 10 months to institutional delay. The court found that the accused had not suffered prejudice and as most of the delay was attributable to adjournments sought on his behalf, the court found that the overall delay in this case was not unreasonable.
column3: The accused was charged with 56 offences set out in eight Informations. The accused alleged that he was falsely represented to the RCMP and that he had been advised that he should seek a stay of proceedings. The Informations were sworn in two weeks prior to the preliminary hearing date. The preliminary hearing dates were vacated and the Charter application was heard. Dismissing the application for a stay, that the accused has not established on a balance of probabilities that there has been a breach of his right to be tried within reasonable time.
column4:
As a result I have dismissed the application for a stay of proceedings. The Crown opposes his release from custody. I am of the view that such a period of time is sufficiently long so as to warrant an inquiry into the reasonableness of the delay. [36] Overall, I am of the view that Mr. Ali has not been particularly concerned with or prejudiced by
the delay. [37] When I take that into account, and balance the prejudice Mr. Ali has suffered with the reasons for
the delay and society’s interest in having these 56 charges resolved by a trial on the merits, I am not satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the overall delay in this case is unreasonable. The
application for a stay of proceedings is dismissed.

column2: The accused was charged with failing to appear at his trial on a charge of impaired driving. The impaired driving charge was subsequently stayed. When the charge of failing to appear came on for trial the accused claimed a 'lawful excuse' for his failure to appear on the impaired driving charge. His excuse was that the next shift at work had failed to arrive on time and that this had made it impossible for him to get to court on time. This excuse was rejected and he was convicted. He appealed. HELD: Appeal dismissed.  1)Whether an accused has a lawful excuse is determined with reference to common law principles. It normally includes all of the defences which the common law considers sufficient reason to excuse a person from criminal liability. 2)The Court was unable to say that the finding by the trial judge that the accused had no lawful excuse for failing to attend court, was not supported by the evidence; nor could it say her conclusions were clearly wrong so as to make the decision unreasonable.
column3: The accused was charged with an impaired driving offence. He attended court and indicated he would be retaining a lawyer. The Crown stayed the original impaired driving charge. The accused applied to overturn his conviction by arguing that the trial judge ought to have accepted his excuse for not appearing. HELD: The appeal was allowed on appeal. 1)The accused had failed to attend court by failing to attend. The trial judge rejected the accused's submission that he had a 'lawful excuse' for not attending court. 2)The trial judge accepted the accused\'s submission that the accused had a lawful excuse for failing to appear. The court challenged the finding on appeal as to whether the accused advanced a 'lawsful excuse'. 3)The common law defences are not frozen in time. They can be developed and tailored to fit changes in the law and new offences. 4)The court reviewed comments of the Supreme Court of Canada in R. v. Holmes (1988), 41 C.C.C.; 497 which indicate that a 'lawful excuse" includes all defences the common law considers sufficient to excuse a person from criminal liability. It can also include excuses specific to particular offences. The word 'excuse' is used in this broad meaning in s7(3) [now s8(3)] of the Criminal Code, which provides that all common law justifications and excuses continue to be available under the Code. The common law defence defences are flexible and tailored for a change in the current law and a new offence. 5)The Court of Appeal could redefine the meaning of 'excused' for example by expanding it to provide new excuses or excuses specific offence, or by narrowing it to include only certain excuses. 6)The Supreme Court comments in R v.Holmes (1988) indicated that a "lawful explanation" includes any defences the Common Law considers sufficient reason to excuse person from a criminal liability and can also including excuses specific thereto.

column2: A notice to vacate rented premises contained an erroneous address. The Rentalsman granted a writ of possession and after the issuance of the writ, amended the writ to correct the address without notice to the tenant. The tenant appealed. HELD: Appeal allowed. There had not been compliance with s. 23(1)(b) of the Act. The notice to vacate was therefore ineffective and the consequent writ of possession was quashed. Given the tenant's obstructionist tactics he was denied his costs of the appeal.

The tenant did not attend and in his absence a writ ofossession was authorized in respect to the premises. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the Rentaledman's writ of possess was quashed. There was no costs of the appeal.

column2: This judgment applies to both QBG No. 1040/98 and QBG No. 1041/98 respecting the contract between the city and Triple P Holdings and the January 21, 1997 contract between the plaintiffs and the defendants. The first breach of contract concerned a failure to apply the rotation of truckers described in the arrangement between the city and Truckers Association. The second breach alleged the defendants took too many hours on the total contract. Both matters were tried together. The defendants pleaded there was no privity of contract between the city and plaintiffs, therefore the plaintiffs could not enforce terms agreed to by the city and Triple P. HELD: Both actions were dismissed. 1)The case did not turn on the issue of privity. While the plaintiffs were not actual parties to the contract with the city, certain benefits were intended to pass through the general contract to members of the Truckers Association. 2)There was no contractual obligation in the 1997 agreement which required the defendant to adhere to any particular arrangement on the rotation of work. The contract between the defendants and city was not incorporated by specific or general reference. The first sentence of s.9 of the 1997 tender for rental of truck specifications was more consistent with what was actually done by the defendants than with the interpretation put on it by the plaintiffs. They failed to make out a case that the contract term was as alleged or that any breach occurred.  3)Had a case been made out, further evidence of damages would be required. The damages claimed were excessive and did not properly take into account actual operating expenses, the net affect of mitigating factors, and reliable calculation of the administration of the rotation of work.
column3: The plaintiffs sued the City of Regina and Triple P Holdings claiming breach of contract and preventing them from enforcing the terms of the contract. The plaintiffs had constructed their cases in reliance upon the overall affect of both contracts with specific emphasis on the contract of January 1997. The defendants had pleaded that there was no privity of contract between the plaintiffs and the City and that the plaintiffs were prevented from enforcing it. The plaintiff argued that there is no contractual obligation in the agreement of January 21, 1997 which requires the defendants to adhere to any particular arrangement on the rotation of work and the contract between them and the city is not incorporated by a specific or general reference. HELD: The case was dismissed. While the plaintiffs are not actual parties to the contract with the City, the general thrust of all of the evidence was that certain benefits were intended to pass through the general contract to the members of the Independent Truckers Association. The factual evidence was in conflict but the defendants made some effort to include the plaintiffs in the rotation. Problematically, for the plaintiffs there is a no contractual obligations in the Agreement of January, 1997 that requires the plaintiffs to adhere strictly to any arrangement on rotation of the work and that contract between Regina and the defendants is not incorporating by specific reference. The issue of privity could have been a critical issue in different circumstances but in the end this case will not turn on the question of privitity. column2: FIAT The Plaintiffs purchased a Robin's Donuts franchise from the Defendants. They later tried to sell the franchise without success. Eventually they turned the franchise back and sued for damages alleging that the Defendants had interfered in their attempts to sell the franchise and had wrongfully refused to consent to a sale negotiated by the Plaintiffs. The Defendants counterclaimed for unpaid royalties and rent. The parties each prepared and served their Statements as to Documents. Both parties then applied for production of additional documents under Rule 212. The Defendant also sought further particulars of certain matters referred to in the Plaintiff's Defence to Counterclaim under Rule 164. HELD: Applications allowed. Both of the parties were ordered to produce some of the documents requested. 1)A party must disclose all documents which may contain information which either directly or indirectly enables the other party to advance his case or to damage the case of his adversary.  2)The test of relevance on discovery is wider than that of admissibility at trial. 3)Documents brought into existence with the dominant purpose of using them in order to obtain legal advice or to conduct or aid in the conduct of litigation which is in reasonable prospect at the time of their creation are privileged. 4)Particulars are appropriate only (i)to enable a party to properly plead in response or (ii)to eliminate surprise. 5)The Court found that further particulars were appropriate in this case on the second ground, given the vague nature of the impugned paragraph in the Plaintiff's Defence to Counterclaim.
column3: FIAT. The plaintiffs sought an order for production of documents by the defendants. The defendants sought an Order for an Order of Conditional Production. The second and third applications were brought by the plaintiffs who sought an ordered order in respect to the plaintiffs documents and in addition, an order that the plaintiffs provide further and better information. HELD: 1)The documents sought were privileged and must be produced. 2)The requested documents were not privileged. 3)The plaintiffs sought a like-off order in relation to the documents. 4)The court ordered production of the documents as they pertain to the franchise agreement, lease, advertising, signage, and other documents. 5)The Court ordered production. 6)The plaintiff was entitled to production of all documents. 7)The document was not privileged because it contained a threat. 8)The defendant was not required to produce all documents in his possession. The documents were relevant only to enable a party to properly plead in response and eliminate surprise. 9)The application was dismissed. 10)The order for the production of document was granted. 11)The defendants were not required. The court ordered the production and production of any documents.

HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Court held that the test to be applied was'may', not'must', in relation todocuments which may contain information which either directly or indirectly disables the party requiring the affidavit(here production) either to advance hisown case or to damage the case of his adversary. 2)The court held that discovery has wide scope. 3)Plaintiffs brought an application to compel the defendants to produce documents.  4)Each party may at any time before the action is set down for trial deliver notice in writing, requiring from any other party further and a better statement of the nature of the claim or defence or further a better particulars of any matter of which particulars should properly be given and such notice shall clearly state the particulars required. The plaintiffs' original reply that it was not bound by the rule had no merit.  5)The documents were to be produced in any event of the cause and fixed those costs at $200.  6)The plaintiffs were to produce all documents in their possession and to disclose all facts within his knowledge which are material to plaintiff's case. The words'shortfalls' and 'deficiencies' do not add much more. The plaintiffs should be able to describe with some clarity the nature and source of the shortfalls and deficiencies along with the dollar value of same. This limited information will likely do much to avoid surprise and should therefore be provided.

column2: FIAT: The former vice-president of the Saskatchewan Labour Relations Board commenced an action for damages alleging wrongful conduct by the Government of Saskatchewan. He alleges his term was not renewed through the influence of certain unions with the Department of Labour. He participated in an interview where he suggested that the Department of Labour required members of the Board to read the newsletter of the Saskatchewan Federation of Labour. When Wal-Mart became aware of these circumstances, it filed this application. Wal-Mart alleges the Board is biased or, at the very least, there is justification for a reasonable apprehension of bias against Wal- Mart. It argues that the only way to rectify the situation is to prohibit the Board from holding hearings involving Wal-Mart. The Union applies pursuant to Rule 319 of the Queen's Bench Rules to strike almost all the material filed by Wal-Mart. HELD: The application of Wal-Mart is dismissed. The Union will have taxable costs, but only of the application by Wal-Mart and the Union's application to strike the material filed.  1) The affidavit filed by Wal-Mart swears that the affiant has 'personal knowledge of the facts and matters herein deposed to' and then he goes on to swear that various exhibits are attached to his affidavit. This achieves nothing more than compel the court to examine the exhibits to determine their admissibility. The affiant does nothing more than provide copies of 27 documents. 2) There is no necessity for the admission of the documents. There is no basis upon which to conclude that it is necessary to accept the proffered documents as evidence.  3) It is alleged there was interference with the Board and that it was required to read publications which were highly disparaging of Wal-Mart. Yet there is absolutely no evidence before the court to prove the allegations. Many newsletters contain negative comments about Wal-Mart. column2: The Crown appeals an order from Provincial Court declaring that the accused is unfit to stand trial. The accused was charged with 29 offences arising out of failures to comply with multiple bail conditions. He was also charged with two indictable thefts. He is 22 years old and suffers from fetal alcohol spectrum disorder, attention deficit disorder and substance abuse. He was diagnosed as mildly mentally retarded and is considered incapable of handling the responsibilities that would enable him to live independently and will always need a protected living environment and sheltered employment. He was found unfit to stand trial on some previous property offences and is still under the supervision of the Provincial Review Board. The trial judge was satisfied that the accused met the first two criteria for fitness to stand trial Ã» he understood the nature of the charges against him and the possible consequences of being found guilty and he understood the difference between a guilty and not guilty plea. The focus of the decision was whether the accused had the capacity to communicate with counsel. The judge found that the accused would not be able to provide instruction to counsel during the trial process due in part to the fact that he is very distractable and could not sufficiently follow court proceedings to instruct counsel. HELD: Appeal allowed. The verdict of unfit to stand trial is set aside and a new trial ordered. The trial judge applied too stringent a test on concluding that the accused was unfit to stand trial and when the proper test is applied, it is apparent that the accused has the capacity to instruct counsel within the meaning of the Code. The trial judge's concern about the accused's distractable nature does not accord with the limited cognitive capacity test. The Courts have applied a test of 'limited cognitive capacity' for determining fitness. This test requires that, with respect to communicating to counsel, the accused is only required to be capable of recounting the fact of the alleged crimes. Limited cognitive capacity does not require analytic ability or the need for the accused to appreciate his own best interests. The authorities establish a very low threshold for fitness to stand trial in keeping with the policy objectives of the Criminal Code and the right of the accused to make full answer and defence.
column3: HELD: The appeal was allowed. The court found that the trial judge misapprehended the evidence, misstated the evidence and applied the wrong legal test for fitness, applied the right to an unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. The Court found that, although the accused had been diagnosed with a mental disorder, the trial court erred in finding that the accused was unfit to stand trial. The accused was found fit to stand because he had shown that he was able to reason on higher cognitive levels, because of his lack of abstraction, and because of being 'locked in his delusional system'. The accused had shown signs of depression, anxiety and some form of paranoid schizophrenia. The trial judge concluded that the evidence did not support his conclusion that the defendant was unfit.
column4: Disposition: Appeal allowed Smith J.A. [1] This is an appeal by the Crown from an order of a Provincial Court Judge declaring that the respondent is unfit to stand trial. [37] I am in respectful agreement that, on the whole of the judgment, it is apparent that the trial judge applied too stringent a test in concluding that Mr. Jobb was unfit to stand trial, and that, when the proper test is applied, it is apparent that Mr. Jobb had the capacity to instruct counsel within the meaning of the Code. [44] It is my conclusion that the appeal must be allowed, the verdict of unfitness to stand trial set aside and that there be a new trial on the offences which are the subject of this appeal.

column13: The Crown appealed an order of a Provincial Court Judge declaring that the respondent was unfit to stand trial. The Crown contended that the trial judge misapprehended the evidence, misstated the evidence and applied the wrong legal test for fitness, applied the incorrect burden of proof and made a finding that was unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1) The limited cognitive capacity test is correct in Canada and the Court held that it requires a person to be able to comprehend the nature of the proceedings and to make rational decisions. 2) The respondent had been diagnosed with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder, attention deficit disorder and substance abuse/dependence disorder. He had been previously convicted of two counts of theft and one count of obstruction. 3) The trial judge was correct in distinguishing R. v. Trecroce, supra, on the basis that the accused suffered from delusions so pervasive and irrational that he was unable to reason on higher cognitive levels, because of his lack of abstraction, and because of being 'locked in his delusional system.' 4) The limitation of cognitive capacity tests in Canada is a very low threshold for fitness. The test is not intended to displace the presumption of innocence to which he remains entitled. The real question to be determined in this case is whether the learned trial judge erred in holding that, although the appellant can communicate with his own defence, he is unable to exercise analytical reasoning in making a choice to accept the advice of counsel or in coming to a decision that best serves his own interests. 5) Given the respondent’s limited capacity, it is not necessary that he be capable of recounting the facts of the alleged crimes and that he has sufficient mental fitness to participate in the proceedings in a meaningful way. 6) The test of “limited cognitive capacity” for determining fitness is not a test to be applied in keeping with the policy objectives of the Criminal Code and, in particular, with the right of the accused to make full answer and defence to the allegations with which he is charged.

The trial judge's concern about the accused's distractable nature does not accord with the limited cognitive capacity test. The Courts have applied a test of 'limited cognitive capacity' for determining fitness. This test requires that, with respect to communicating to counsel, the accused is only required to be capable of recounting the fact of the alleged crimes. Limited cognitive capacity does not require analytic ability or the need for the accused to appreciate his own best interests. The authorities establish a very low threshold for fitness to stand trial in keeping with the policy objectives of the Criminal Code and the right of the accused to make full answer and defence.
column18: This is an appeal by the Crown from an order of a Provincial Court Judge declaring that the respondent is unfit to stand trial. The Crown submits that the trial judge misapprehended the evidence, misstated the evidence and applied the wrong legal test for fitness, apply the wrong burden of proof and made a finding that was unreasonable and not supported by the evidence. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1) The limited cognitive capacity test is correct in Canadian criminal law. It requires only that an accused be capable of recounting the facts of the alleged crimes and that he is able to appreciate his own best interests. 2) The test of 'limited cognitive capacity' for determining fitness is a very low threshold for fitness in keeping with the policy objectives of the Criminal Code and, in particular, with the right of the accused to make a full answer and defence to the allegations with which he is charged. It is not necessary that the accused be able to reason on higher cognitive levels, because of his lack of abstraction, and because of being 'locked in his delusional system.' 3) There are strong interests, both public and personal, in an accused being fit to proceed to trial. A person who is found not guilty by reason of a mental disorder is presumed to be fit to be tried. However, a person who suffers from a severe mental disorder (e.g. schizophrenia, attention deficit disorder, or ADD) may be excluded from the trial. 4) The respondent has not been convicted in relation to any of the allegations. The real question to be determined in this case is whether the learned trial judge erred in holding that, although the appellant can communicate with counsel in a manner that would be in his best interests, he would be unable to exercise analytical reasoning in coming to a decision that best serves his own interests. 5) There is a strong interest in ensuring that persons suffering from a mental disability are able to follow and understand the nature and functions of the persons involved in them. The trial judge was correct in distinguishing R. v. Trecroce, supra, on the basis that he understood the nature of the offences and the possible consequences of them. He was also correct in concluding that the appellant could not make rational decisions beneficial to him. 6) The limitation of the capacity test strikes an effective balance between the objectives of fitness rules and the constitutional right of an accused to choose his own defence and to have trial within a reasonable time. column19: Disposition: Appeal allowed Smith J.A. [1] This is an appeal by the Crown from an order of a Provincial Court Judge declaring that the respondent is unfit to stand trial. column22: The Crown appeals an order from Provincial Court declaring that the accused is unfit to stand trial. The accused was charged with 29 offences arising out of failures to comply with multiple bail conditions. He was also charged with two indictable thefts. He is 22 years old and suffers from fetal alcohol spectrum disorder, attention deficit disorder and substance abuse. He was diagnosed as mildly mentally retarded and is considered incapable of handling the responsibilities that would enable him to live independently and will always need a protected living environment and sheltered employment. He was found unfit to stand trial on some previous property offences and is still under the supervision of the Provincial Review Board. The trial judge was satisfied that the accused met the first two criteria for fitness to stand trial Ã» he understood the nature of the charges against him and the possible consequences of being found guilty and he understood the difference between a guilty and not guilty plea. The focus of the decision was whether the accused had the capacity to communicate with counsel. The judge found that the accused would not be able to provide instruction to counsel during the trial process due in part to the fact that he is very distractable and could not sufficiently follow court proceedings to instruct counsel. The court was cautioned that on motions of this kind the Court ought to guard against the pursuit of what have been termed 'fishing expeditions'—speculative quests for information without any real expectation about the outcome of the quest or its relevance to the case. Here, however, the defence has already indicated that issues around s. 8 and s. 9 of the Charter will be raised at trial. Defence now wants further disclosed of information, for the use of preparation for and pursuit of inquiry. To pursue the fishing analogy so often used in the authorities, the Purpose of such an inquiry will in part be to determine whether, in comparison with the guarantees given by the Charter, the investigation in this case 'cast too wide a net'. The Crown will also make timely disclosures of the names of the drivers stopped be disclosed and that the actual notes of the officer to be reproduced. They will also be made available for purposes of evidence at trial if required and shown to be relevant to the proceedings as they unfold.

column2: The accused was convicted by a jury of sexual assault and assault with a weapon. He was sentenced to 2 years in a federal penitentiary plus 2 years probation. He appeals both conviction and sentence. The accused and complainant met in a bar for the first time and then went to the accused's apartment. The complainant is a sex trade worker and was of the view that the accused was prepared to pay for sex. The accused stated that he did not know the complainant was a prostitute and thought she had 'picked him up'. Upon arriving at the appellant's home, he refused to pay for sex and the complainant refused consensual sex, at which point the appellant forced himself upon her, forcibly restrained her, removed her clothing and touched her body in a sexual manner, choked her and struck her in the face. As she tried to escape, the appellant struck her three times in the back with a baseball bat. The appellant argues there were two problems with the jury charge: 1) that the trial judge should have addressed the jury further with respect to the various types of inconsistencies and contradictions in the complainant's testimony and explained their significance, and 2) the trial judge should have mentioned a number of additional inconsistencies. HELD: Appeal against conviction dismissed. The issues with the jury charge do not give rise to intervention by this Court. While there is a general obligation on the trial judge to instruct the jury by reviewing the evidence and addressing inconsistencies, how the obligation is fulfilled will vary from case to case. There is no absolute formula automatically giving rise to a new trial. Much depends on the context of the whole trial and such things as the nature of the inconsistency and whether it goes to the essence of an element of the offence. The trial judge's charge was entirely correct in the circumstances of this case. Appeal against sentence is allowed and a sentence of 2 years less 1 day is substituted. The sentence imposed by the trial judge was based on a consensus between the crown and defence counsels. Both were of the view that a sentence in the federal system was more appropriate since it would permit the appellant to access sex offender treatment. After sentencing, the appellant, who is an immigrant, was informed that with a sentence of 2 years, he would have no appeal against an order declaring him inadmissible to Canada. If a sentence of less than 2 years is imposed, he will be guaranteed the opportunity to appear personally or by counsel on his appeal of such an order. The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence's unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on sentence appeal.
column3: The accused was convicted of sexually assaulting the complainant contrary to s. 271 of the Criminal Code and using a weapon to wit a baseball bat contrary to ss. 267(a) of the Code. He was tried by a jury, which convicted him. He appealed both conviction and sentence. HELD: The appeal against conviction was dismissed. 1)The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence's unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on a sentence appeal. 2)The Court found that the loss of the appellant's immigration appeal rights is disproportionately severe collateral sanction, which was unforeseen by the appellant and his counsel at the sentencing hearing and apparently unintended by the police. 3)The accused will be guaranteed the opportunity of appearing personally or having legal counsel on his appeal of an order.
column4: Disposition: Conviction Appeal Dismissed (orally) Sentence Appeal Allowed (orally) [1] Kareem Almajidi was charged with sexually assaulting D.K. contrary to s. 271 of the Criminal Code and also assaulting her, using a weapon, to wit a baseball bat, contrary to s. 267(a) of the Code. He was tried by a jury, which convicted him. He was sentenced to two years in a federal penitentiary plus two years probation. He appeals both conviction and sentence. [10] Secondly, appellant\'s counsel argues that the trial judge should have mentioned these additional inconsistencies or discrepancies: [22] In my respectful view, the charge that followed two days later was entirely correct to the circumstances of this case. [26] For these reasons, the appeal against conviction is dismissed. Apparently, if a sentence of two years less a day is imposed, Mr. Almajidi will be guaranteed the opportunity of appearing personally or having legal counsel represent him on his appeal of such an order. The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence\'s unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on a sentence appeal. [30] Thus, we would dismiss the appeal from conviction and allow the appeal from sentence. The sentence of two years is set aside, and a sentence of two years less a day imposed in its place.

HELD: The appeal against conviction was dismissed. 1)The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence's unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on a sentence appeal. 2)The evidence of the Crown and the defence was not adequately addressed by the trial judge. 3)The trial judge was of the opinion that counsel for the defence had done most adequately and was properly advised on the issues of credibility and fact-finding and determining issues of relevance were solely their tasks. The trial judge stressed the reasonable doubt standard and he concluded his charge with the direction consistent with R. v. W.(D.). 4)The appeal against sentence was dismissed on the basis that if a sentence of two years less a day was imposed, the accused would have no appeal against an order declaring him inadmissible to Canada.
column9: Disposition: Conviction Appeal Dismissed (orally) Sentence Appeal Allowed (orally) [1] Kareem Almajidi was charged with sexually assaulting D.K. contrary to s. 271 of the Criminal Code and also assaulting her, using a weapon, to wit a baseball bat, contrary to s. 267(a) of the Code. He was tried by a jury, which convicted him. He was sentenced to two years in a federal penitentiary plus two years probation. He appeals both conviction and sentence. [10] Secondly, appellant\'s counsel argues that the trial judge should have mentioned these additional inconsistencies or discrepancies: [22] In my respectful view, the charge that followed two days later was entirely correct to the circumstances of this case. [26] For these reasons, the appeal against conviction is dismissed. Apparently, if a sentence of two years less a day is imposed, Mr. Almajidi will be guaranteed the opportunity of appearing personally or having legal counsel represent him on his appeal of such an order. The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence\'s unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on a sentence appeal. [30] Thus, we would dismiss the appeal from conviction and allow the appeal from sentence. The sentence of two years is set aside, and a sentence of two years less a day imposed in its place.
column12: The accused was convicted by a jury of sexual assault and assault with a weapon. He was sentenced to 2 years in a federal penitentiary plus 2 years probation. He appeals both conviction and sentence. The accused and complainant met in a bar for the first time and then went to the accused's apartment. The complainant is a sex trade worker and was of the view that the accused was prepared to pay for sex. The accused stated that he did not know the complainant was a prostitute and thought she had 'picked him up'. Upon arriving at the appellant's home, he refused to pay for sex and the complainant refused consensual sex, at which point the appellant forced himself upon her, forcibly restrained her, removed her clothing and touched her body in a sexual manner, choked her and struck her in the face. As she tried to escape, the appellant struck her three times in the back with a baseball bat. The appellant argues there were two problems with the jury charge: 1) that the trial judge should have addressed the jury further with respect to the various types of inconsistencies and contradictions in the complainant's testimony and explained their significance, and 2) the trial judge should have mentioned a number of additional inconsistencies. HELD: Appeal against conviction dismissed. The issues with the jury charge do not give rise to intervention by this Court. While there is a general obligation on the trial judge to instruct the jury by reviewing the evidence and addressing inconsistencies, how the obligation is fulfilled will vary from case to case. There is no absolute formula automatically giving rise to a new trial. Much depends on the context of the whole trial and such things as the nature of the inconsistency and whether it goes to the essence of an element of the offence. The trial judge's charge was entirely correct in the circumstances of this case. Appeal against sentence is allowed and a sentence of 2 years less 1 day is substituted. The sentence imposed by the trial judge was based on a consensus between the crown and defence counsels. Both were of the view that a sentence in the federal system was more appropriate since it would permit the appellant to access sex offender treatment. After sentencing, the appellant, who is an immigrant, was informed that with a sentence of 2 years, he would have no appeal against an order declaring him inadmissible to Canada. If a sentence of less than 2 years is imposed, he will be guaranteed the opportunity to appear personally or by counsel on his appeal of such an order. The jurisprudence supports the proposition that a sentence's unintended effect on immigration status can be a relevant factor on sentence appeal.

column2: The accused was found guilty of the following offence: for a sexual purpose touching A. M. a person under the age of fourteen years directly with a part of his body contrary to s. 151(a) of the Criminal Code. After reviewing the circumstances of the offence and the offender, in addition to sentencing principles as set out in the case law and statutes, the Court found that this was not a case where a conditional sentence served in the community is available or appropriate. The Court found the appropriate sentence, given all the circumstances, is a term of 9 months to be served in a correctional institute in Canada, to be followed by a 1 year term of probation containing the standard conditions. HELD: The accused is sentenced to 9 months incarceration. Pursuant to s. 109(1) of the Criminal Code, a firearm order was made for 10 years prohibiting the accused from possessing any type of weapon. The accused shall also supply a sample of his DNA for analysis. There is an order under s. 490.012(1) that the accused comply with the Sexual Offender Information Registration Act. The accused is also prohibited, pursuant to an order under s. 161(1)(a), from attending a public park or swimming area where persons under the age of 14 years are present or can reasonably be expected to be present, day care centre, school ground, playground or community centre for a period of 3 years.
column3: The accused was found guilty of a charge of sexual interference contrary to s. 151(1) of the Criminal Code. The accused had been in a residential school for three and one-half years and had been previously convicted of sexual assault. He had been living with his step-grandmother for 10 years. The court ordered that he be placed on probation for 10 year and ordered to provide sufficient samples of his bodily substances so that a DNA analysis could be conducted. The Court also ordered that the accused comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act and a Sex Offenders Registration Act. HELD: The Court found that the sentence imposed was a term of imprisonment of 9 months to be served in a correctional institute. The length of the sentence requested was increased to 20 years.
column4:
[1] On June 5, 2009, this Court, in a written judgment (the “Judgment”) found the accused guilty of the following offence:



COUNT 1 THAT HE, the said S. C. [sic], on or between the 20th day of May and the 22nd of December, A. D. 2005 at Muscowpetung First Nation, Saskatchewan did for a sexual purpose touch A. M. [sic] a person under the age of fourteen years directly with a part of his body, to wit: his hand, contrary to Section 151(a) of the Criminal Code. CONCLUSION [34] This is not a case where a conditional sentence served in the community is available or appropriate. [38] In all of these circumstances, the court has concluded that an appropriate sentence to be imposed upon S.C., for his conduct in this case, is a term of imprisonment of nine months to be served in a correctional institute of Canada. [39] The sentence of imprisonment imposed by this judgment will be followed by a one year term of probation containing the standard conditions that the accused keep the peace and be of good behaviour, appear before the court when required to do so by the court, that he will notify the court or a probation officer in advance of any change of name or address and will promptly notify the court or the probation officer of any change of employment or occupation. [41] The Crown has satisfied the court that this offence is an offence to which s. 109 of the Criminal Code applies and therefore a mandatory prohibition order shall issue prohibiting S.C. from possessing any firearm, cross-bow, prohibited weapon, restricted weapon, prohibited device, ammunition, prohibited ammunition and explosive substance during the period of 10 years after his release from prison. [42] A further order shall issue pursuant to s. 487.051(2) of the Criminal Code authorizing and ordering you to provide sufficient samples of your bodily substances so that a DNA analysis may be conducted. The court further orders, pursuant to s. 487.012 of the Criminal Code, that S.C. comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act, S.C. 2004, c. 10, the length of such order to continue for 20 years. An order will therefore issue pursuant to s. 161(1)(b) prohibiting S.C. from seeking, obtaining or continuing any employment, whether or not the employment is remunerated, or becoming or being a volunteer in a capacity, that involves being in a position of trust or authority towards persons under the age of 14 years.

column2: All parties agree that this case turns on the interpretation of article XIV, subsection 14.01 of the joint venture agreement. They also agree that the subsection is a right of first refusal clause. It is clear that the subject matter of the clause is a 'Participating Interest in the Program Land or a Project Area'. HELD: Appeal dismissed orally. The appellant relies on the words in parenthesis 'the Parties being absolutely prohibited from selling, assigning, transferring, conveying or otherwise disposing of any interest other than all of part of its Participating Interest' to establish its case that the voting agreement contravenes the terms of the joint venture agreement. However, subsection 14.01, with the words in parenthesis deleted, creates a complete right of first refusal. In our view, the words in parenthesis, rather than being intended to create substantial new contractual obligations, were intended, as is buttressed by the parenthetical structure, merely to recall to the parties their dedication of assets to the joint venture, and their inability to dispose of them qua separate assets. Thus, the phrase in parenthesis is mere surplusage in that it does not add or subtract substantively to subsection 14.01 or the joint venture agreement as a whole. Accordingly, the voting agreement is not caught by subsection 14.01.
column3: The parties agreed that this case turned on the interpretation of article XIV of the joint venture agreement. The provisions of the agreement provided that the parties could use the words 'participating interest' in the joint project area to refer to the project area and that the voting agreement did not include a 'transfer of assets' clause. The words in parenthesis, rather than being intended to create substantial new contractual obligations, were intended, as is buttressed by the parenthetical structure, merely to recall to the parties their dedication of assets to the joint joint venture, rather of selling their vote by so doing. The voting agreement secured the follow up steps under the original commitment by Kensington which would be implemented over a lengthy period. The parties argued that the provision of 'participation interest' did not constitute a sale of voting rights. Dismissing the appeal, that the words in a parenthesis were intended to add a whole new meaning to the phrase 'participatory interest' and not to add any substantive or substantive new obligations. The phrase 'transfer' was not intended to include a whole or a part of the project's potential to be developed or developed. The word 'participated interest' was used to add to the meaning of'subject matter' of the clause 'participate interest' to add the phrase to the definition of 'contributive interest' or'substantial new contractual obligation'. The phrase was not meant to create a whole 'favourable' or surplus of assets or to add an alternative meaning to a whole `gift' to the word'share' or to subtract a whole lot of assets from the meaning 'participant interest' which would not be a whole right of first refusal under the terms of the Joint Venture Agreement.

column2: FIAT: The applicant defendant seeks an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act setting aside the plaintiff's pre-judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into court from the defendant's bank account in December 2005. The issue is whether the plaintiff's claim is a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act, and if so, whether the affidavit filed in support of the issuance of both of the pre-judgment garnishees complies with s. 3(2) of the Act. HELD: The plaintiff has not strictly complied with the provisions of s. 3(2) of the Act, and the garnishee summons are a nullity.  1) In an application to set aside a pre-judgment garnishee, the court is not to consider potential defences to the action or the existence of triable issues as grounds for setting aside a garnishee summons. 2) The court examined whether or not the affidavit showed, with the required precision, the amount of the debt or liquidated demand. Although there is reference in the statement of claim to an agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0 % per month, compounded monthly, there is no mention of interest in the Operating Agreement. 3) Of more concern is the four-page invoice attached to the affidavit supposedly attached to confirm the amount of the debt owed by the defendant. The invoice is vague and is of no assistance to the court in clarifying the precise amount of the debt owing. Unlike the information provided in the affidavit of Kuznitsoff v. Hilltop Ford Equipment Sales Ltd. (c.o.b. Hilltop Equipment Sales), wherein the affidavit charted the alleged gross profits by listing the equipment, date of sale, model number, sale price, cost and gross profits on a line by line basis, the contents of the affidavit here is severely deficient in showing with precision the amount of indebtedness owing.
column3: FIAT. The applicant defendant sought an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act setting aside the plaintiff's pre-judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into Court from the defendant's bank account at Biggar and District Credit Union on December 7, 2005. The issue was whether the claim was a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act and if so, whether the affidavit of the affidavit filed in support of the issuance of both of the pre- and post-judgments garnishee summons complies with s.3(2) of The Act. HELD: 1) The statement of claim discloses a prima facie claim for debt or liquidated damage pursuant to the Attachment Of Debts act and if not, if the affidavit is true copy of an invoice dated October 31, 2005, there is no mention of interest in the Operating Agreement of September 10, 2001. 2) The four-page invoice attached to the affidavit attaches as exhibits copy of the Operating agreement dated September 10/2001 and copy of a copy of invoice dated November 31/2005. 3) Although there is reference in the statement of claims to an agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0% per month, compounded monthly, there was no mention in the Statement of Claim that interest was to be paid in the rate of 2.5% per monthly. 4) The contents of the affidavits filed in supporting the pre and postjudgment warrants were not complete. 5) The plaintiff's claim disclosed a primitive claim for a debt or a liquidation demand pursuant to ss. 3.3 and s. 2 of the act and the garnislee summons were null. 6) The affidavit of Shirley Scott, in support the pre, pre and pre-judicial garnishes, were not filed with the Court. The affidavit was a copy and not a copy. The four pages invoice were not marked as being a copy or a fax.  7) Although the statement and affidavit of Ms. Scott had reference to interest in an Operating Agreement, there were no mention either in the operating agreement or in the Opinions. 8) Although a statement of Claim discloses prima-facie claim, the contents of Ms.' affidavit are severely deficient in showing with precision the amount of indebtedness owing. 9) The 4-page sales chart was a true copy and the sales page was not a fax

[2] The issue is whether the plaintiff’s claim is a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act, and if so, whether the affidavit of Shirley Scott, filed in support of the issuance of both of the pre‑judgment garnishees, complies with s. 3(2) of that Act. HELD: 1) The statement of claim discloses a prima facie claim for debt or liquidated damage pursuant to the Act. 2) Although there is reference to interest in the Operating Agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0% per month, compounded monthly, there is no mention of interest in that Operating Agreement of September 10, 2001. 3) The four-page invoice attached to the affidavit attaches as exhibits copy of the operating agreement dated October 31, 2005 and a copy of an invoice dated November 5, 2005, supposedly attached to confirm the amount of debt owed by the defendant in the amount $24,155.94. 4) There is no reference in the Statement of Claim to an agreement that interest was to be paid on such account at the rate of 2.5 per month compounded monthly. column14: [1] The applicant defendant, New York Taxi Co. Ltd., seeks an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act, R.S.S. 1978, c. A‑32, setting aside the plaintiff’s pre‑judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into Court from the defendant’s bank account at Biggar and District Credit Union on December 7, 2005. [2] The issue is whether the plaintiff’s claim is a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act, and if so, whether the affidavit of Shirley Scott, filed in support of the issuance of both of the pre‑judgment garnishees, complies with s. 3(2) of that Act. Unlike the information provided in the affidavit in Kuznitsoff v. Hilltop Ford Equipment Sales Ltd. (c.o.b. Hilltop Equipment Sales) (1998), 176 Sask. R. 293 (Q.B.), wherein the affidavit charted the alleged gross profits by listing the equipment, date of sale, model number, sale price, cost and gross profits on a line by line basis, the contents of Ms. Scott’s affidavit is severely deficient in showing with precision the amount of the indebtedness owing. [14] The Plaintiff has accordingly not strictly complied with the provisions of s. 3(2) of the Act, and the garnishee summons are a nullity.
column17: FIAT: The applicant defendant seeks an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act setting aside the plaintiff's pre-judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into court from the defendant's bank account in December 2005. The issue is whether the plaintiff's claim is a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act, and if so, whether the affidavit filed in support of the issuance of both of the pre-judgment garnishees complies with s. 3(2) of the Act. HELD: The plaintiff has not strictly complied with the provisions of s. 3(2) of the Act, and the garnishee summons are a nullity.  1) In an application to set aside a pre-judgment garnishee, the court is not to consider potential defences to the action or the existence of triable issues as grounds for setting aside a garnishee summons. 2) The court examined whether or not the affidavit showed, with the required precision, the amount of the debt or liquidated demand. Although there is reference in the statement of claim to an agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0 % per month, compounded monthly, there is no mention of interest in the Operating Agreement. 3) Of more concern is the four-page invoice attached to the affidavit supposedly attached to confirm the amount of the debt owed by the defendant. The invoice is vague and is of no assistance to the court in clarifying the precise amount of the debt owing. Unlike the information provided in the affidavit of Kuznitsoff v. Hilltop Ford Equipment Sales Ltd. (c.o.b. Hilltop Equipment Sales), wherein the affidavit charted the alleged gross profits by listing the equipment, date of sale, model number, sale price, cost and gross profits on a line by line basis, the contents of the affidavit here is severely deficient in showing with precision the amount of indebtedness owing.
column18: FIAT. The applicant defendant sought an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act setting aside the plaintiff's pre-judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into Court from the defendant's bank account at Biggar and District Credit Union on December 7, 2005. The issue was whether the claim was a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act and if so, whether the affidavit of Shirley Scott, filed in support of the issuance of both of the garnishee summons, complies with s.3(2) of that Act. HELD: 1) The statement of claim discloses a prima facie claim for debt or liquidated damage pursuant to the Act. The affidavit attaches as exhibits a copy of the Operating Agreement dated September 10, 2001 and copy of an invoice dated October 31, 2005; the four-page invoice attached to the affidavit as Exhibit “C” supposedly attached to confirm the amount of debt owed by the defendant in the amount $24,155.94.  2) Although there is reference in the statement of claims to an agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0% per month, compounded monthly, there is no mention of interest in the operating agreement of September 10, 2001. 3) The four pages invoice attached as exhibits copy of a bank account dated October 30, 2005, and the four page four page invoice dated November 1, 2005 are true copies of the bank account. 4) There is no reference to interest in any of the statements of claim filed by the applicant or statement of defence and counter-claims. Although there was a reference in an agreement between the parties to interest at the rate of 2.5% compounded monthly there was no mention in the Statement of Claim of Interest in September 10/2001. 5) Of more concern to the Court was the invoice.  6) The contents of the affidavit appeared to be deficient in showing with precision that amount of the indebtedness owing on the judgment, the debt or the liquidation demand as the case may be, as outlined as the second purpose of the affidavits filed pursuant the Act by the applicants.  7) Although the statement and affidavit of the applicant and/or 101020738 Saskatchewan Ltd. did reference interest in an Operating Agreement in September, 2001, there were no references in that Operating Agreement.

column23: FIAT. The applicant defendant sought an order pursuant to s. 10 of The Attachment of Debts Act setting aside the plaintiff's pre-judgment garnishees in which $2,291.90 was paid into Court from the defendant's bank account at Biggar and District Credit Union on December 7, 2005. The issue was whether the claim was a liquidated demand within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act and if so, whether the affidavit of Shirley Scott, filed in support of the issuance of both the garnishee summons and the statement of defence and counterclaim complies with the Act. HELD: 1) The statement of claim discloses a prima facie claim for debt or liquidated damage pursuant to the Attachment Of Debts act and the affidavit attaches as exhibits copy of the Operating Agreement dated September 10, 2001 and copy of an invoice dated October 31, 2005; 2) Although there is a reference in the Statement of Claim to an agreement that interest would be paid at 2.0% per month, compounded monthly, there is no mention of interest in the operating agreement of September 10/2001. 3) The four-page invoice attached to the affidavit as Exhibit C supposedly attached to confirm the amount of debt owed by the defendant in the amount $24,155.94. 4) There was no reference to interest in any of the statements of claim filed by the applicant. Although there was reference in an agreement to an interest rate of 2.5% compounded monthly there was no mention in either of the operating agreements of September and October. 5) Of more concern to the Court was whether or not the content of the affidavit was shown with the required precision with respect to the amount owing on the judgment, the debt or the liquidation demand as the case may be, as outlined as the second purpose of an affidavit filed under s.3(2) of that Act by Chief Justice Bayda. It is trite law that a plaintiff has a statutory right to garnish the defendant’s funds before the validity of the claim has been determined if the action is for a debt or a liquidative demand. The Court has not considered the contents of the affidavits of the applicant, filed by, or statement of defense and counter-claim.
