column2: The mother of two boys, ages 12 and 13, applied to vary access to add a condition that the father only be allowed to drive with the boys in the HRM, on roads with a speed limit of 80km/hr and under. She asked the Court to continue conditions that prevented him from consuming marijuana less than 8 hours before driving, and required him to consider the boys' wishes regarding access and transportation. The father argued that all restrictions relating to the transport of the children should be removed. The father had MS, and a medical marijuana licence. His driving was evaluated yearly, and the report arising from the latest evaluation did not appear to address his marijuana use. An independent assessment of the children's wishes showed they enjoyed time with their father, but worried about his ability to drive under the influence of marijuana. The unrepresented mother sought costs. Conditions continued; variation granted. If he leaves the HRM, the father is to arrange for public or other transportation. Costs awarded to the mother in the amount of $800. In terms of the driving issue, it was not fair to place the entire burden of the transport issue on the children. The Court was not satisfied from the evidence that the father's marijuana use was benign, and there was also a concern about the symptoms of his MS, especially on long trips. While in the HRM, if the boys became concerned about driving with their father, they could take a bus home or call their mother. If outside of the HRM, it would be more difficult for them to get home. In terms of costs issue, the mother was the successful party. Although she was unrepresented, she did have to take considerable time off work. She was also inconvenienced because the father was late in filing documents, despite having been given clear time-lines by the Court.
column3: The parties were to meet in person on April 3, 2008 to discuss the issues of access and maintenance. The parties had previously signed a variation application in which the applicant sought to have the respondent's access restricted. The respondent had previously requested that the remaining provisions of the Varied Corollary Relief Judgment be changed to allow access with the children. The applicant had previously asked that the access be restricted to two days per week, two evenings per week and eight hours prior to driving. The petitioner had also requested that all restrictions on his transport of the children be removed including the provision restricting his marijuana use to eight hours before driving. HELD: The respondent was not satisfied that the respondent’s use of marijuana was benign and without potential risk to his children. He was not able to drive safely on routes that permit speeds over 80 km per hour if the drive was lengthy. The appellant’ s medical condition and marijuana use were not factors in the decision to allow the respondent to opt out of the Corollaries Relief Judgment.

Ms. Crewe requested a change to the Varied Corollary Relief Judgment dated

April 3, 2007. She requested that the remaining provisions of the Varied Corollary Relief Judgment continue in effect and that she receive a cost award. I am not satisfied that Mr. Crewe’s use of marijuana is benign and without potential risk for his children. I am not satisfied he is able to drive safely on routes that permit speeds of over 80km per hour if the drive is lengthy. I am not satisfied it is in the best interest of Matthew and Mitchell to ignore these risks or to place the entire responsibility for monitoring their safety on their young shoulders. Returning from a trip outside of the Municipality would require a request that their mother transport them or a requirement that they stay where they are until their father was sufficiently recovered to drive safely. I find that this would be too much responsibility to put upon these adolescents and I find it to be in their best interest that there be restrictions on their father’s driving while they are passengers in his vehicle. column2: The Respondent and the Applicant had a violent argument after which the Applicant and the child left the matrimonial home and moved to Transition House. The Applicant sought and obtained an emergency intervention order under The Victims of Domestic Violence Act from a Justice of the Peace giving her exclusive occupation of the matrimonial home and restraining her husband from having any contact with her or their daughter during the currency of the order. This order was then brought before a Queen's Bench Judge as required by s.5 of the Act for review. The reviewing Judge refused to confirm the order and directed a rehearing as permitted by the section. The matter then came before this Judge for the rehearing ordered. HELD: Order vacated.  1)An emergency intervention order is granted by a Justice of the Peace under s.3 of the Act without notice to the person whose conduct it restrains and without any representations from that person or on that person's behalf. It is an extraordinary remedy to be granted only where serious and urgent circumstances indicate a need for prompt action to protect the victim. 2)Absent such urgency, the application should be one for a 'victim's assistance order' brought to a Queen's Bench Judge in Chambers under s.7 in accordance with The Queen's Bench Rules. 3)In this case the domestic violence complained of occurred on January 28. column2: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, the plaintiff, a supplier of materials to the sub-contractor sued the general contractor and the surety under the terms of a labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the sub-contractor. The Bond contained a provision limiting the liability of the surety and the principal to make payment to any claimant not having a contract directly with the principal. Dismissing the action with costs, that there was no evidence of intention to contract, valuable consideration, or binding promise to pay between the general contractor and the supplier. With respect to the principal, as the Bond limits the liability of the surety and principal to make payment to a claimant such as the plaintiff not having a contract directly with the principal, liability is limited by the Bond to the amount which the principal would have been obliged to pay to the plaintiff if the provisions of the Mechanics' Lien Act applied to the work. As the contract was with the Crown, and the Act is not binding on the Crown, the general contractor was not obliged to pay anything to the plaintiff. Therefore, the supplier was not entitled to recover against the surety under the Bond.
column3: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, a supplier of materials to the sub-construction company sued the general contractor and surety under the terms of a Labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the sub contractor. HELD: The claims of the plaintiff against the general contractors and London Guarantee were dismissed. 1)The Mechanics' Lien Act does not expressly state that it binds the Crown. The Act does apply to this contract or this work. 2)If the Mechanics' lien Act had been applicable, the plaintiff would not have been entitled to recover anything due to the third party statutory liens. 3)If a Mechanics'Lien Act was applicable, a contractor would not be entitled to claim anything due the third parties' liens because the amount owing by the contractor to its subcontractor would have been less than the amount owed by the subcontractor. 4)If there was a Mechanics's Lien, the supplier of material to the subcontractors would not automatically recover anything from the general contract. The plaintiff would pay the costs of London Guarante which will be a single amount as may be agreed upon between counsel or, if agreement is not possible, will be set by the Court at the time an Order for Judgment is taken out.
column4: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, a supplier of materials to the sub-contractor sued the general contractor and the surety under the terms of a Labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the sub-contractor. However, I find no intention to contract, no valuable consideration, and no promise to pay. Paragraph 4 of the Labour & Material Payment Bond limits the liability of the surety and the principal to make payment to a claimant such as Hazmasters not having a contract directly with the principal. Liability is limited to the amount which the Principal would have been obliged to pay to the claimant if the provisions of the Mechanics\' Lien Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, c.277, applied to the work. The Mechanics\' Lien Act does not expressly state that it binds the Crown. In the result, if the Mechanics\' Lien Act had been applicable, Hazmasters would not have been entitled to recover anything due to the third party statutory liens. The claims of Hazmasters against Rideau Construction and London Guarantee are both dismissed.

column18: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, a supplier of materials to the sub contractor sued the general contractor and the surety under the terms of a Labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the subcontractor. HELD: The claim was dismissed. 1)If the Mechanics' Lien Act had been applicable, the plaintiff would not have been entitled to recover anything due to the third party statutory liens.  2)Hazmasters was not a claimant to a lien by virtue of its being a general contractor. 3)The amount of the principal amount owing under the contract would have been less than the amount demanded by Revenue Canada and Labour Standards as against the applicant. The Act does not expressly state that it binds the Crown.  4)The mechanics' lien was binding on the Crown unless it expressly states that the Crown is bound.  5)The plaintiff was not entitled by default to recover any amount from the defendant.  6)The defendant was not obliged to recover a principal amount under the lien.  7)The Mechanics'Lien Act did not explicitly state that a contract or work done by a claimant under the Lien was bound by the Crown or by the provisions of the Act.  8)The only authority cited with respect to the purpose and effect of Clause 4(4) of the Bond is Johnson Controls Ltd. et al v. Dineen Construction (1996 CanLII 10616), which considered a provision identical to that in Davison v. MacLean (1993), 10 C.L.R. (2d) 178 (N.S.C.) is authority for the proposition that third party claims from Revenue Canada or the Province of Nova Scotia take priority over claims of mechanics lien claimants to holdback. Therefore, if the Mechanics’ Lien act applied, the amount available to all subcontractors of All Ports would be 10% of the value of the work performed by All Ports to the date of abandonment. Since those third parties claims total an amount greater than the sum of the holdback, potential lien claimant such as Hazmasters would not be entitled to claim any amount.

column2: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for the installation and monitoring of temperature monitoring equipment for its meat cutting business. The defendant monitored the temperature in the freezer and cooler at the business. The plaintiffs sued because their freezer failed and meat spoiled after a circuit breaker at the business tripped off. The defendant had received no alarm. The plaintiff asserts that the defendant breached the contract by failing to properly monitor the temperature in the freezer. HELD: The contract between the parties was solely for installation and monitoring. The contract did not include any obligation on the defendant to maintain or repair the equipment at the plaintiff's business. The Court was satisfied that the defendant was monitoring the signal from the plaintiff's business on the dates in question and no alarm was received. It is not possible to say with any certainty why the defendant did not receive an alarm, but the Court was not satisfied that the plaintiff was regularly having its monitoring equipment serviced or repaired. The plaintiff has not proven that the defendant breached the contract. The action is dismissed.
column3: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for temperature monitoring equipment and month to month monitoring of the temperature in the freezer and cooler of the business. The defendant refused to pay the plaintiff $1,190.26 per month and the plaintiff sued. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant breached the contract by failing to monitor the temperature at the business and by failing not to respond to the plaintiff. The court dismissed the action. Based on the original contract between the parties and ongoing payments, the court was satisfied that the contract was solely for the monitoring of temperature in a business and did not include any obligation on the defendant to maintain or repair the monitoring equipment at the premises. The defendants did not breach the contract as no alarm was received by them so it could be reported to Sturgis Meats. The plaintiffs claim that the plaintiff failed to provide proper monitoring equipment to the defendant and that the monitoring system was not properly maintained. The breach of the contract is not proven on a balance of probabilities. The action is dismissed.
column4: OVERVIEW: [1] In 2006, Sturgis Meats entered into a contract with Gardon Securities. Mr. Wegner later discovered that this resulted from a circuit breaker at the business being tripped off. ANALYSIS: [16] Sturgis Meats has the onus of proving on a balance of probabilities that Gardon Securities breached the contract between the parties by failing to properly monitor the freezer temperature at Sturgis Meats on or before August 14, 2010. [21] Based on the original contract between the parties (Exhibit P-1), and ongoing payments being made in 2010 by Sturgis Meats, I am satisfied that the contract between the parties was solely for the monitoring of the temperature in the cooler and freezer at Sturgis Meats, and did not include any obligation on Gardon Securities to maintain or repair the monitoring equipment at Sturgis Meats. [22] I am further satisfied, and find, that an employee of Gardon Securities was monitoring the signal from Sturgis Meats on the dates in question and that no freezer alarm was received before the alarm of August 15, when the computer monitoring system was working properly. Nor am I satisfied, on the evidence, that Sturgis Meats was regularly having their monitoring equipment serviced or repaired. [25] Given that I find the explanation of what happened in this case, as given by Mr. Stoll, to be at the least as plausible as that presented on behalf of Sturgis Meats, I am not satisfied on a balance of probabilities the plaintiff has proved that the defendant breached this contract by failing to monitor the freezer temperature and by failing to respond to Sturgis Meats. [26] This action is dismissed.
column7: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for the installation and monitoring of temperature monitoring equipment for its meat cutting business. The defendant monitored the temperature in the freezer and cooler at the business. The plaintiffs sued because their freezer failed and meat spoiled after a circuit breaker at the business tripped off. The defendant had received no alarm. The plaintiff asserts that the defendant breached the contract by failing to properly monitor the temperature in the freezer. HELD: The contract between the parties was solely for installation and monitoring. The contract did not include any obligation on the defendant to maintain or repair the equipment at the plaintiff's business. The Court was satisfied that the defendant was monitoring the signal from the plaintiff's business on the dates in question and no alarm was received. It is not possible to say with any certainty why the defendant did not receive an alarm, but the Court was not satisfied that the plaintiff was regularly having its monitoring equipment serviced or repaired. The plaintiff has not proven that the defendant breached the contract. The action is dismissed.
column8: HELD: The action was dismissed. The plaintiff had not proven that the defendant breached the contract by failing to monitor the temperature in the freezer and cooler of the business. The defendant had also failed to notify the plaintiff that the meat was spoiled. The court found that the plaintiff had failed to provide proper monitoring equipment to the plaintiff and that the breach of the contract was caused by a circuit breaker at the business being tripped off.

column13: HELD: The action was dismissed. Based on the original contract between the parties and ongoing payments, the plaintiff was satisfied that the contract covered both the installation of temperature monitoring equipment at the business and the month to month monitoring by Gardon Securities of the temperature in the freezer and cooler at this business. The plaintiff did not receive such an alarm generated by the rising of the freezer temperature at Sturgis Meats. It is possible that there was a so-called glitch in the defendant's computer system. However, it is equally possible that the reason no alarm was received by the defendant was that the monitoring equipment was not properly maintained and adjusted. Given the exclusion clause in the contract which am satisfied is enforceable, the issue becomes whether there was cause beyond Gardon's control which resulted in no freezer alarm being received by them so it could be reported to the plaintiff.

column27: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for temperature monitoring equipment and month to month monitoring of the temperature in the freezer and cooler of the business. The defendant refused to pay the plaintiff $1,190.26 per month and the plaintiff sued. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant breached the contract by failing to monitor the temperature at the business and by failing not to respond to the plaintiff. The court dismissed the action. Based on the original contract between the parties and ongoing payments, the court was satisfied that the contract was solely for the monitoring of temperature in a business and did not include any obligation on the defendant to maintain or repair the monitoring equipment at the premises. The defendants did not breach the contract as no alarm was received by them so it could be reported to Sturgis Meats. The plaintiffs claim that the plaintiff failed to provide proper monitoring equipment to the defendant and that the monitoring system was not properly maintained. The breach of the contract is not proven on a balance of probabilities. The action is dismissed.

column2: The parties had three children during their marriage. After the marriage ended in 1988, the husband respondent, medical specialist, moved from Moose Jaw to Ontario where his annual income was about $175,000. The children stayed with the petitioner wife in Moose Jaw. She was not able to work as registered nurse until she upgraded her education, which she slowly did as she could afford it. She and the children lived on very little income and relied upon social assistance because the respondent often did not pay child support. The parties were regularly in court. In 1994, the respondent left his position in Ontario and moved to Milwaukee, believing his prospects were better in the U.S. However, he lost his position in Milwaukee and opened his own clinic. His income dropped to as little as $15,000 in 2001. In this application, the respondent applied to vary two support orders, one made in 1998 and the other issued in 2001. He sought to expunge the arrears in respect of each and a declaration that the three children are no longer children of the marriage. His reason for seeking to have the arrears expunged was because he, now 72, wanted to retire in the next couple of years. The petitioner, 63, deeply in debt and on long-term disability, was still caring for one of their children because he suffers from schizophrenia. HELD: The Court held that two of the children had ceased to be children of the marriage as of 2002 and 2008 respectively. With respect to the third child, the Court found that as a result of the serious and long-term mental health problems suffered by him, he remained a child of the marriage. The Court then found that the respondent's arrears in respect of the 1998 child support order were $7,000. Based upon the respondent's imputed income of $109,000 per year established by the Court in its 2001 order, and the dates upon which the two children ceased to be so under the Divorce Act, the Court calculated the amount of child support owed by the respondent at $186,300. The Court rejected the respondent's argument that he could not afford to pay the arrears because his expenses left him with an income surplus of only $13,000. The Court discounted most of the claimed expenses and found that the respondent had $58,000 at his disposal and therefore had the ability to pay his arrears. The Court found that the respondent had chosen to minimize his earning capacity by staying in the U.S. in private practice and thus the respondent could not assert that the Court should use his actual income rather than his imputed income to vary the amount of child support he was ordered to pay in 2001. The undue hardship that the petitioner had suffered for 25 years constituted the most compelling reason for the Court to refuse to reduce or expunge the respondent's arrears. The application was dismissed and the respondent ordered to pay arrears and to pay child support in the amount of $927.
column3: FIAT: The respondent sought to vary two orders issued in 1998 and 2001. He wants to expunge the arrears in respect of each and also seeks a declaration that their three children are no longer children of the marriage. HELD: 1) The arrear of child support owed by the respondent was $186,746. The petitioner had been working as a registered nurse for several years prior to the separation and had received some money from Social Services to help pay for her university education. The respondent had not been paying child support for some time and had been unable to obtain employment that could pay him handsomely. He had been paying the arsars for years and had now retired. The court found that the respondent did not have the ability to pay the arrars because he could have taken employment that paid him at least $110,000 a year. He knew that he was expected to maximize his earning capacity but simply chose not to. 2) The respondent was found to have been acting erratically. The Court found that he did not owe child support on the two orders. The arsors owed by both orders were dismissed. The parties were entitled to an amount of child care and support. The father was found not to have the financial means to pay child support. 3) The court considered the following factors: 1. The applicant had $58,000 left over after paying his living expenses in 2011. He was entitled to $1,689 after paying ongoing monthly child support of $1.689 after that date. He did not need to take employment that would pay him more money. He would have been able to pay more child support if he had taken employment which paid him less money. The fact that he had a pension income of $109,000 did not mean that he would not have been unable. The child support arreared owed by him was reduced by $1 to $183,738. The mother was entitled not to pay any more child care expenses. The husband was entitled only to $5,427 for the child support he owed in 2011 and $58 for the children's care in 2012. The wife was entitled $1 per month in child support until she died. The children were entitled $2,000 in child care. The spouse was entitled a portion of the child care costs. column4: 3) The respondent seeks to vary two orders, one that was issued in 1998 and the other that was issued in 2001. He wants to expunge the arrears in respect of each and also seeks a declaration that their three children are no longer children of the marriage. I do not accept that assertion. Thabani suffers from a serious psychotic illness and has lived with the petitioner continuously. 22) In summary, I find that Mandela ceased to be a child of the marriage on June 30, 2002 and Bogani ceased being a child of the marriage on June 30, 2008 (June 30 being the approximate date of the end of the school year). Thabani continues to be a child of the marriage. 26) The arrears under the 1998 order are $7,008 and the arrears under the 2001 order are $176,738 ($186,300 - $9,562). 33) Considering the above, I cannot find that the respondent does not have the ability to pay the arrears, which I have calculated to be $183,746. 1. The respondent’s application to reduce or expunge child support arrears is dismissed. 2. As of April 30, 2013, the respondent’s arrears under the orders of Madam Justice Wilkinson dated March 7, 2001 and July 20, 1998 are fixed at $183,746. 4. The child Thabani remains a child of the marriage. 5. Commencing June 1, 2013 and continuing on the first day of each month thereafter until further order of the Court, the respondent shall pay basic child support in the amount of $927 per month.

He was expected to maximize his earning capacity but simply chose not to. 2) The petitioner had been working as a registered nurse for several years prior to the separation. She was unable to work as a nurse until she upgraded her education. 3) The applicant had the ability to pay child support because he could have taken employment that paid him at least $110,000 a year. He knew that he could take employment that would pay him more than $200,000. He did not have the means to do so. 4) The court found that the respondent had the financial capacity to pay the arrenars. He had the means, but not the ability, to avoid or diminish his support obligation. 5) The Court found that it was impossible for the respondent to have the ability and the ability of him to pay his child support. 6) It found that he had not shown that he was incapable of paying his child's arrear. 7) The application to vary the two orders was granted. The respondent was ordered to pay $1,683 in monthly child support and $176,746 in arreary. 8) The order was not varied and the respondent did not appear to be able to pay. The Court did not find that the applicant had any financial capacity.

The court considered several factors, including the fact that the petitioner had been diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and depression, the ongoing needs of the child and the ongoing need of the mother.

With respect to the third child, the Court found that as a result of the serious and long-term mental health problems suffered by him, he remained a child of the marriage. The Court then found that the respondent's arrears in respect of the 1998 child support order were $7,000. Based upon the respondent's imputed income of $109,000 per year established by the Court in its 2001 order, and the dates upon which the two children ceased to be so under the Divorce Act, the Court calculated the amount of child support owed by the respondent at $186,300. The Court rejected the respondent's argument that he could not afford to pay the arrears because his expenses left him with an income surplus of only $13,000. The Court discounted most of the claimed expenses and found that the respondent had $58,000 at his disposal and therefore had the ability to pay his arrears. The Court found that the respondent had chosen to minimize his earning capacity by staying in the U.S. in private practice and thus the respondent could not assert that the Court should use his actual income rather than his imputed income to vary the amount of child support he was ordered to pay in 2001. The undue hardship that the petitioner had suffered for 25 years constituted the most compelling reason for the Court to refuse to reduce or expunge the respondent's arrears. column18: FIAT: The respondent seeks to vary two orders issued in 1998 and 2001. He knew that he was expected to maximize his earning capacity but simply chose not to. The fact remains that rather than seek employment that could pay him handsomely, he chose to flail away in private practice for years and earn much less than he otherwise would have. 3) The Court found that, in the absence of some special circumstance, the respondent will have few lean years until he has paid off the child support arrear. 4) The petitioner had $58,000 left over after paying his living expenses in 2011. 5) The father had not been paying child support for 12 years. column2: An unrepresented university student appealed his conviction for uttering threats after he sent an email to his computer science professor requesting his assistance to de-bug a program contained in an attachment. The attachment was text file with lot of extra characters, including messages that read 'good job, but am going to kill you' and 'I am so horny.' Although the professor had not taken the content of the attachment as threat, he had sent it on to university officials as he had been requested to alert them to any odd or unusual behaviour by the student. The student later advised the professor that he had typed the messages because he thought someone was monitoring what he was typing and he was trying to get reaction out of them. He also testified that he had not intended to send that particular attachment to the professor. Appeal allowed; conviction quashed. The trial judge erred in permitting inadmissible evidence to be adduced from the university administration to the effect that the accused had a psychiatric illness and, in failing to intervene when the Crown assumed that the student had put his character in issue and cross-examined him as to alleged prior acts of misconduct and other extraneous matters, the cumulative effect of which was fatal to the trial judge's findings of credibility. The case against the student was entirely circumstantial and it was equally open to infer that the words had been typed in the file to get a reaction from people that the student, rationally or otherwise, believed to be monitoring his keystrokes and did not constitute a threat to cause death to the professor.
column3: The appellant was a student at St. Francis Xavier University when he sent an email to his computer science professor with an attachment. Although the professor did not take the content of the attachment as a threat, he sent it to university officials as he had been requested to alert them to any odd or unusual behaviour by the appellant. The police were contacted and a charge was laid against the appellant of uttering a threat to the professor to cause his death, contrary to s264.1(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. The appellant did not have a lawyer when he stood his trial in 2008 in Provincial Court. The trial judge rejected the appellant's testimony as not being credible, as not having an explanation by the accused, and he also rejected the evidence given by the Crown. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The court found that the appellant did have a reasonable doubt as to the purpose of the e-mail and that the words were meant to be read. The evidence was rife with hearsay and very prejudicial to the appellant’s credibility. The Crown did not call a witness. The appeal raised issues of admissibility of evidence, admisseness of evidence and the appropriateness of questions asked of the appellant in cross-examination, and the impact on the integrity and fairness of the trial. The words spoken in jest were meant for a purpose. The accused had not knowingly threatened anyone or anyone. The only issue the trial judge identified was what was the intention of the accused when he first received the email was whether he intended the message to be sent to the student or to the faculty member. The Court found that he had not done so. The issue was whether the accused intended the student to read the contents of the email, as he did not run it as he de-bugged it. The question was whether it was reasonable to expect the accused to take the e.mail seriously and to give due consideration to a conditional discharge. The respondent was not counsel at trial and the court found the accused did not provide sufficient evidence to justify calling the accused. The judge found that it was unreasonable to expect him to take seriously the evidence of the other accused.
column4: [1] The appellant was a student at St. Francis Xavier University in Antigonish, Nova Scotia. [2] The appellant did not have a lawyer when he stood his trial on May 14, 2008 in Provincial Court. Counsel was retained and an appeal commenced from conviction and sentence, alleging improper admission of evidence, unfair and prejudicial cross-examination of the appellant and a failure to give due consideration to a conditional discharge. [45] The evidence of Mr. MacAulay certainly suggested that the appellant had a psychiatric illness and was a dangerous person requiring mandatory hospitalization before and after the October 24 email. This includes the suggestion that the appellant had a psychiatric illness, both before and after the email was sent, as long ago as 2005. [98] Taking into account all of the circumstances, including the words used; the fact they appeared in an attachment as part of a computer program containing other unusual phrases; there was no animosity between the person who received the attachment, Professor Van Bommel and the appellant; and no reason for the appellant to want to intimidate or provoke Van Bommel, it is equally open to infer that the words had been typed in that file to get a reaction from people that the appellant, rationally or otherwise, believed to be monitoring his key strokes, and did not constitute a threat to cause death to Martin Van Bommel, nor can it properly be concluded that the appellant intended to do so. Instead I quash the conviction and enter an acquittal.

column2: The court granted the defendant's application for summary judgment of claim. Costs were at issue. Costs awarded in the amount of $5,000 plus disbursements; although the hearing was less than 2 hours in length, there were a number of steps taken prior to the application, including two days of discovery examination.
column3: The defendant applied to strike pleadings and for summary judgment on the grounds that mere intentions, negotiations, and pleadings of a cause of action failed to create a cause. The written release of the decision left counsel to attempt to reach an agreement with respect to costs and disbursements failing which the court would receive representations from both parties. The defendant applied for a judgment for costs and for disbursement. The originating notice action was filed July 21, 2003 and therefore the new tariff of September 29, 2004 does not apply. The plaintiff made an offer of settlement in the amount of $5,000 inclusive of costs which take to be an attempt to have the action simply go away due to the heavy costs of litigation. The sale price of the property which was approximately $2,000,000 was not, in my view, the appropriate amount involved and it was very difficult and in fact, impossible for the court to really get a handle on what amount of loss of profits was being pursued or to what extent the defendants were at risk. The court would be able to reach agreement with costs and receive representations.
column4: [1] Application to strike pleadings and for summary judgment granted in Chambers February 15, 2005 upon the court concluding that mere intentions, negotiations, etc., and pleadings of a cause of action failed to create a cause of action. column2: The accused was charged with a number of break and enters. After hearing evidence, the Crown advised the Court that it intended to call 'Ace' to the stand. Ace had been subpoenaed and had been sitting in the Court listening to other Crown witnesses. Defence counsel objected and claimed the Crown had not disclosed this witness. Ace was also a client of defence counsel and so defence counsel would not be able to cross-examine Ace. HELD: The Crown failed to provide proper disclosure to defence counsel, the non-disclosure had an adverse effect of the accused's ability to make full answer in defence and the appropriate remedy was to refuse to allow the Crown to call Ace as a witness.
column3: The accused was charged with break and enters of homes. He pleaded guilty to three of the charges but denied involvement in three of them. Defence counsel objected on this basis but Defence argued that the Crown had not disclosed their intention to call the witness and that they should not be permitted to do so. The accused argued that if the Crown informed the defence of its intention to use the witness, it ambushed him and his client and that the defence should not have been permitted to call him. HELD: The accused was not entitled to a defence of his right to full answer. The defence had not established on a balance of probabilities that the impunged non-disclosure has prejudiced or had an adverse effect on the accused's ability to make full answer and defence. The prejudice to the accused’s right to make a full answer, defence flows from not being told that the accused would be a Crown witness. The Crown was also entitled to call a client of the Crown. The Court found that the Court had not been advised of the accused and that it was not able to cross-examine the witness.
column4: In addition, Ace Carlos Whitecap is also a client of Mr. Bendig’s and he would not be able to cross-examine Whitecap effectively or at all. 6. In my view there has been a failure to disclose. In my view the defence has met this test. The prejudice to the accused’s right to make full answer and defence flows from not being told that Ace Carlos Whitecap would be a Crown witness. In my view, the only appropriate remedy is to refuse to allow the Crown to call this witness.

column8: The accused is charged with break and enters of homes. He pleaded guilty to three of them but denied involvement. After hearing evidence from the home owners, co-accused, and peace officers who investigated the incidents, the Crown advised the court of its intention to call one of the accused to the witness box. Defence counsel objected on this basis but also argued that the Crown had ambushed him and his client and that they should not be permitted to do so. The Crown argued that if the Crown informed the defence of the Crown's intention, the defence should have been able to cross-examine the witness effectively or at all. HELD: The accused was not permitted to give evidence in this trial. The accused's right to full answer and defence was prejudiced by not being told that the accused would be a Crown witness. The prejudice to the accused's ability to make full answer, defence flows from not being informed that the defence would not be allowed to call this witness. 1)The accused was entitled to prepare his defence on the basis of the witnesses the Crown is actually going to call. The defence had met this test. 2)The Crown had not disclosed their intention to use the witness. It was also aware that the witness was a client of the defendant. The defendant's client was also a client. 3)The defence had not established on a balance of probabilities that the impunged non-disclosure had prejudiced or had an adverse effect on the accused’s ability to answer the question. 4)The only remedy was to refuse to allow the Crown to call the witness to give testimony. The stay of proceedings is out of the question and the accused will not be able to give his evidence. The court must take into account all aspects of the failure to disclose, including the nature of the charge, delay, adjournments to date and at who's request, the nature and nature of evidence not disclosed and the Crown explanation for the omission. The point in time at which the accused has sufficient time to consider the evidence and the crown's case before election or plea is at the beginning of trial, an adjournment may be ordered. The judge should have sat through the entire Crown case in order to be as effective as possible in the cross-examination of the witness and the fact that the defendant had been subpoenaed by the Crown and, unknown to the prosecution, had been sitting in court listening to the other Crown witnesses. The Court must also take into consideration all the factors of failure to disclosure.

column2: A class action was certificated at Queen's Bench on the basis of breaches of The Consumer Protection Act and a breach of duty of care. The defendants were granted leave from the Court of Appeal to appeal the portion of the certification order dealing with alleged breaches of The Consumer Protection Act only. The certification on the basis of duty of care was upheld. As a result, a situation existed where the class action process could continue on only part of the claim until the appeal of consumer protection act issues was heard. HELD: Rule 15 of The Court of Appeal Rules is engaged and the entire certification judgment is stayed pending the disposition of the appeal. If the plaintiffs wish to apply to lift the stay they must do so to a judge of the Court of Appeal.
column3: FIAT: By order and judgment dated March 29, 2010, the Court certified the within action as a class action. The defendants were granted leave to appeal only that portion of the certification order that pertained to the cause of action relating to alleged breaches of the Consumer Protection Act, S.S. 1996, c. C-30.1 (the CPA). All other aspects of the leave to appeals application, including that relating to the breach of duty of care cause of actions, were dismissed. The situation now exists that the class action will definitely advance although, until after the appeal concerning the CPA cause of Action is finally determined, it is not known whether the class actions will proceed on the basis of one cause of the action or two.

The situation now exists that the class action will definitely advance, although, until after the appeal concerning the CPA cause of actions is finally determined, it is not known whether the class actions will proceed on the basis of one cause or two. HELD: 1) Rule 15 of the Court's Appeal Rules states that unless otherwise ordered by a judge, the service and filing of notice of appeal stays the execution of any other judgment or order pending the disposition of the appeal. Where there is an appeal pending, the court may order the certification to be stayed. 2) Rule 9 of the Rules states, in part: 15(1) Rule 7 of the rules states that a judge may order an entire order of a court to stay proceedings pending a disposition of a judgment. 3) Rule 8 of the Rule 9 Rules states: Where an order is granted, the entire order may be lifted. 4) The Court may order a stay of proceedings pending an appeal of a certification order.

The situation now exists that the class action will definitely advance although, until after the appeal concerning the CPA causes of action is finally determined, it is not known whether the class actions will proceed on the basis of one cause or two. HELD: 1) Rule 15 of the court of appeal rules states that unless otherwise ordered by a judge, the service and filing of notice of appeal stays the execution of any other judgment or order pending the disposition of the appeal. Where there is an appeal pending on only one aspect of a certification order, the court may order the certification process to be stayed. 2) Rule 9 of the Rules states that a stay of action may be granted in the event that the matter is pending before a Court of Appeals judge in the jurisdiction of this appeal.  3) Rule 10 of the rules does not give an order of stay to an entire class action unless it is granted by a different judge. 4) Rule 8 of The Rules states, in part: 15(1) Rule 7 is reserved for orders of a judge in an event of this nature.
column19: [1] By order and judgment dated March 29, 2010, I certified the within action as a class action. [10] Accordingly, I find that the certification order is stayed pending appeal, subject to the Court of Appeal lifting the stay should it see fit.

column2: An appeal of an award of $1,245. The tenant's father contacted him about the hearing while he was out of the country. The father appeared at the hearing and objected to service of the hearing notice. HELD: The appeal was allowed. The award was set aside and a new hearing was ordered. The Deputy Rentalsman committed an error in law by denying 10 days notice. The Landlord and Tenant Act s.60(5.1) empowers the Rentalsman to validate a defective service provided the notice came to the attention of the person to be served. The day the notice was received and the day of the hearing must be excluded in calculating the notice period (Interpretation Act s.24(4)). In this case the tenant received only 8 days notice. No costs.
column3: An appeal by a tenant against a decision awarding his former landlord $1,245.00. HELD: The appeal was allowed; the award was set aside; and there was ordered that there be a new date fixed by the Rentalman. There will be no costs.

column2: Civil Procedure – Appeal – Leave to AppealLand – Certificate of Pending Litigation The appellant sought leave to appeal the chambers decision not to vacate the certificate of pending litigation registered on behalf of her estranged husband, who was deceased. The respondent’s solicitors filed the certificate of pending litigation after his death. The appellant transferred the land subject to the certificate of pending litigation into her name only and entered into an agreement to sell the land, which could not proceed with the certificate of pending litigation. HELD: The appeal was of sufficient merit and it was not prima facie frivolous or vexatious. The appeal, however, was not found to be of sufficient importance to the practice of law or the Court of Queen’s Bench to warrant determination by the Court of Appeal. There was no new, controversial or unusual issue of practice raised by the appeal. The issues were determined to be better left for resolution by the Court of Queen’s Bench after hearing vive voce evidence at trial.
column3: The wife sought to appeal from a chambers judge's decision not to vacate a certificate of pending litigation registered on behalf of her estranged husband. The husband's estate was represented by his executors. The wife had filed a notice of appeal in the matter prior to his death, and subsequently transferred the lands into her own name and entered into an agreement to sell them. The chambers judge did not consider whether the order appealed was interlocutory or final in nature. The proposed appeal does not raise a new or controversial or unusual issue. Nor does it raise a particular in its implications. The only issue raised was whether the judge exercised his discretion within the criteria set out in Rimmer Adshead. HELD: The proposed appeals are of sufficient merit to warrant determination by a panel of this Court. 1)The proposed appeal doesn't raise a 'new or controversial' issue. The court is one of review only: review to determine if the judge abused his discretion. Given the nature of the impugned order, it does not bear heavily or favourably on the former. 2)The court is not a party to the debate on the merits. The Court is not one to speculate on the future course of litigation. The appeal is of sufficient importance to the proceedings before the Court of Queen's Bench, or to the field of practice or the state of the law, or the administration of justice generally, to warrant a determination by panel of the Court. 3)The proposal would involve revisiting an interlocutorutory order that preserves the status quo pending final decision after trial. The draft notice of appeals is not confined to whether the chambers judge exercised the discretion within criteria which bear upon the proper exercise of his judicial discretion. 4)The draft notice is not limited to whether a chambers court exercised its discretion within its criteria which are case sensitive. Rather, it invites the Court to retry matters and, to some extent, reweigh evidence so as to supplant the chambers judges findings and conclusions. Appellate review of discretionary decision is one for review for vitiating error; it is not hearing de novo. 5)The Court is hard pressed to conclude the proposed appeal is sufficient importance. The matter is of interest to the Court before it, or at the field or the court of practice, or in the administration, to a panel. The governing criteria may be reduced to two each of which features a subset of considerations provided it constitute conventional considerations rather than fixed rules, that they are case sensitivity, and their point by point reduction is
column4: Disposition: Dismissed [1] Shirley Mae deBalinhard wishes to appeal from the decision of the chambers judge (indexed as 2014 SKQB 239 (CanLII)), made pursuant to s. 47 of The Queen’s Bench Act, 1998, SS 1998, c Q-1.01, not to vacate a certificate of pending litigation registered on behalf of her estranged husband, John Canagy deBalinhard, against title to certain lands. [5] Turning to the first criterion, given the circumstances of this matter the proposed appeal is not prima facie frivolous or vexatious. The proposed appeal does not raise a new or controversial or unusual issue of practice. In sum, while there may be legitimate issues raised in the prospective appeal, on the whole, I find the issues would be better resolved by a judge of the Court of Queen’s Bench after hearing viva voce evidence at trial. [10] In short, while the proposed appeal might be of sufficient merit, it is not of sufficient importance to warrant determination by a panel of this Court. The application for leave is dismissed.

column2: The accused was charged with assault causing bodily harm. The complainant willingly took part in a fight club after which the accused followed him and engaged in a second physical altercation with him. During the fight, the parties fell into a dresser, onto the floor and out a window. At some stage of the fight, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture, which was the basis of the charge. Accused not guilty of assault causing bodily harm. The confrontation between the accused and the complainant was one continuing episodic event and the complainant's actions were provoked by the accused. However, no causal relationship was shown between the blows of the accused and the broken nose sustained by the complainant. There were too many variables and probabilities as to how the complainant's nose might have become broken.
column3: The accused was charged with assault causing bodily harm to the complainant. The complainant sustained a nasal fracture. The accused did not deny that he was hurt but argued self defence. HELD: The accused was found guilty of assault causing grievous bodily harm. 1)The accused did nothing to provoke the complainant or to cause bodily harm, but rather engaged in a verbal altercation with the complainant in the basement. 2)The complainant was the aggressor. The blows were aimed at the complainant's face. The assault was violent and resulted in a broken nose. 3)The court found that there were too many variables and probabilities to establish a self-defence defence. The fall into the glass window, the fall into dresser and the fall to the floor were all unprovoked and unlawful assaults. The court found the accused had not provoked the complainant by his conduct. 4)The Court found that the accused did have an honest belief that the assault was provoked by the complainant and that it was occasioned by blunt trauma. The Court found the offence was not justified. 5)The evidence did not support the accused's contention that the complainant was injured but that there are too many factors and probabilities.
column4: However, at some stage of their contact, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture for which he sought and received medical attention. I find the accused, Craig Nickerson, not guilty, as charged, and will enter an acquittal on the record.

HELD: The accused was found guilty. 1)The accused did not have a reasonable belief that the complainant was injured but argued self defence. 2)The blows were not intended to cause death or grievous bodily harm. The blows were intended to be repelling force if the force he uses is not intended or are necessary to preserve himself from harm. 3)There were too many variables and probabilities. The fall into the glass window; the fall into dresser and the fall to the floor were all unprovoked and unlawful assaults. The accused must not have intended or were capable of causing grievous harm.
column9: However, at some stage of their contact, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture for which he sought and received medical attention. I find the accused, Craig Nickerson, not guilty, as charged, and will enter an acquittal on the record.

column22: The accused was charged with assault causing bodily harm. The complainant willingly took part in a fight club after which the accused followed him and engaged in a second physical altercation with him. During the fight, the parties fell into a dresser, onto the floor and out a window. At some stage of the fight, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture, which was the basis of the charge. Accused not guilty of assault causing bodily harm. The confrontation between the accused and the complainant was one continuing episodic event and the complainant's actions were provoked by the accused. However, no causal relationship was shown between the blows of the accused and the broken nose sustained by the complainant. There were too many variables and probabilities as to how the complainant's nose might have become broken.

column2: The accused plead guilty to one count of aggravated assault, a breach of undertaking for failure to keep the peace and be of good behaviour and failing to comply with a condition of a youth sentence by failing to report to his youth worker. The victim came out of his house because he was concerned that someone was trying to damage his vehicle. The victim had baseball bat when he confronted the accused and group of young people. One of the accused's friends was pushed and fell backwards hitting his head. The accused said the victim hit him on the back with the bat. The accused got the bat and hit the victim five times in the head. The accused and another youth also kicked the victim while he was down. After the assault, the accused and his friends fled, leaving the victim in the alley. The victim suffered serious injuries including shattered jaw, every bone in his face was broken, his skull was fractured and he suffered brain bleed and lost teeth. He is also going to lose his eye, has memory loss and had to sell his business because he cannot work. The Crown applied to have the offence declared a serious violent offence and sought a sentence of 24 months, being 16 months secure custody followed by 8 months community supervision. At the time of the offence the accused was 17 years and months of age. He identified as Metis youth, but had no connection to cultural activities and claimed he had not been subjected to racism or poverty. His parents were separated. He was not attending school or working at the time of the offence. He had an extensive criminal record including 17 entries for compliance related convictions, previous property related convictions, for obstructing police offences and one for uttering threats. He had served five open custody sentences. HELD: The offence was declared a serious violent offence. The victim will be significantly and permanently disabled as a result of the offence and there can be no doubt that the accused caused intentional and grievous bodily harm to the victim. The court held that the egregious nature of the assault, serious harm done to the victim and the fact that the youth was subject to release conditions with respect to a weapons offence at the time he committed the assault were aggravating factors. In mitigation, the accused had entered a guilty plea, was cooperative with the police investigation, had done well in pre-sentence detention and had expressed remorse for his actions by submitting an apology letter to the court. The accused was sentenced to 24 months secure custody followed by 18 months probation. He was given 2:1 credit for the time he was on remand, leaving 18 months custody of closed custody to serve of which 12 months would be actual custody and 6 months would be community supervision. The court held that a lengthy custodial sentence was necessary to provide meaningful consequences and to achieve meaningful progress for the accused. A period of secure custody and supervision would give the accused access to psychological counselling and programming, an opportunity to work on his education and a chance to engage with support services in the community prior to release from custody. Given the accused's violent response in this case, it was clear that intensive programming is required.
column3: The accused, a 17 year old Metis youth, was charged with aggravated assault thereby endangering the life of a victim and breach of his undertaking to keep the peace and be of good behaviour, contrary to s. 145(3) of the Criminal Code and failing to comply with a condition of a youth sentence that he report to his youth worker, contrary, s. 137 of the Youth Criminal Justice Act. HELD: The accused was sentenced to 24 months custody followed by a period of probation with credit for pre-sentence detention and 6 months community supervision. The accused will be permanently disabled. The court designated the offence as a serious violent offence pursuant to s 42(9) of The Youth Criminal Code. The young person did not oppose the Crown's application. The Court noted that the young person had expressed remorse for his actions in his letter and expressed his regret for the assault. The offence was a serious and life-altering violent offence. The offender will be significantly and permanently disabled as a result of the offence. Mitigating is the early guilty plea, thereby saving the complainant the additional anguish of having to testify at a trial. While in pre- sentence detention, the young offender has done reasonably well. While the accused remained in detention, he remained in a mental institution and suffered from severe anxiety and depression. The Crown appealed the sentence. HOLD: The court found the accused was at a high risk to re-offend violently. The sentence would allow the time frame required for the young to stabilize and engage with support services prior to his release in the community. The lengthy sentence would assist in participating in programming for substance abuse, as well as in programming, programming, anger management and anger management. The youth sentence would enable the time frames required for him to stabilize, engage with and engage in support services before his release. The length of sentence would be appropriate for a youth sentenced to a minimum of 24 months. The sentencing guidelines for youth sentenced were set out in R. v. J. (W.J.); R. (R. v.) (CanLII), 2010 SKPC 88 (CanlII), and the sentencing guidelines were followed. The offences were committed in a secure facility. The victim was to be permanently injured. The defendant was to have a further 12 months custody. The judge noted that there was a reasonable risk of him being convicted of the assault and that the accused would be able to rehabilitate and reintegrate into society.

SENTENCE [63] On the aggravated assault (Information 44662780), it is my view that the appropriate sentence is a secure custodial sentence of 24 months to be followed by a period of probation. Affording him credit of 6 months for pre-sentence detention, I impose a sentence of an additional period of 18 months, 12 months of which will be served in closed custody followed by 6 months of community supervision.
column27: The accused, a 17 year old Metis youth, was charged with aggravated assault thereby endangering the victim contrary to s. 268(1) of the Criminal Code and failing to comply with a condition of a youth sentence that he report to his youth worker. The accused had been subject to release conditions in relation to a weapons offence. HELD: A sentence of 24 months to be followed by a period of probation with credit for 6 months of pre-sentence detention and 6 months community supervision. The young person did not oppose the Crown's application. A period of custody was necessary to provide meaningful consequences and to achieve meaningful progress for the accused. A long term custodial sentence would allow the time frame required for the young person to stabilize and engage with support services prior to his release in the community. A lengthy sentence would assist in participating in programming for substance abuse, as recommended by Dr. Quinn, and for anger management. A young person with a history of violent behaviour would be at a high risk to re-offend. Given his extreme and violent response, it is clear that intensive programming is required. The court imposed an additional period of 18 months, 12 months of which will be served in closed custody followed by 6 months in community supervision, with 6 months being concurrent sentences of probation. The Crown applied under s. 42(9) for a determination that the aggravated assault be designated as a serious violent offence pursuant to s42(9). The young accused had expressed remorse for his actions in his apology letter and expressed his regret for the assault. The youth was to receive credit for two days for each day spent in detention and a further 6 months for a period in a weapons court. The victim will be permanently disabled as a result of the offence.

column2: An appeal under s.33.1 of the Municipal Board Act from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board, one in a series of appeals heard at the same time dealing with the application of a newly introduced market adjustment factor (MAF) to assessments for municipal tax purposes. In issue was whether the assessor erred in law by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the Assessment Manual in determining the MAF for the appellant's shopping centre properties by using a single sale to calculate the MAF; and by creating as a commercial building neighbourhood the grouping of fully enclosed shopping centres which encompassed the entire city. HELD: 1)The assessment was set aside and the matter was remitted to the assessor to be dealt with according to the manual. Both issues were dealt with in Cadillac Fairview v. Saskatoon (TWL CA00074) and the same reasoning applied. 2)The appellant conceded that the question of whether the various expansions of the shopping centre resulted in abnormal functional economic obsolescence was a question of mixed law and fact and was thus beyond the scope of this appeal. 3)The second branch of the appeal was dismissed. Whether the committee erred in law by saying the definition of functional obsolescence did not apply to an add-on type of construction was beside the point since that was not the ground for the decision. The decision was not the result of any wrong interpretation of the manual but was the result of the appellant's failure to establish to the committee's satisfaction the facts on which it based its case. The decision was therefore beyond the Court of Appeal's jurisdiction to review.  4)There was no order as to costs as success was divided.
column3: This appeal was taken under s.33.1 of The Municipal Board Act, s.23.2. It is from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board. It was one of a series of appeals heard at the same time dealing with the application of a newly introduced market adjustment factor to assessments for municipal tax purposes. HELD: The appeal was allowed on the same basis as the previous appeal. 1)The issues raised by the appellant in this case were exactly the same as those raised in another judgment, issued concurrently with this one. 2)The appellant only raised two issues: 1)Did the assessment Appeals Committee err in law by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the assessment manual in determining the market adjustment factors for the appellant properties by using a single sale to calculate the market adjust factor? 3)Did it err in principle in concluding that abnormal functional obsolescence does not apply to an add-on type of construction, or by finding that there must be an inability of an improvement to perform the function for which it is used? 4)The decision was arrived at not as a result of any wrong interpretation of the manual but as a consequence of the appellant's failure to establish to the satisfaction of the committee the facts on which it based its case.

column8: This appeal was taken under s.33.1 of The Municipal Board Act, s.23.2. It was from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board. HELD: The decision was arrived at not as a result of any wrong interpretation of the manual, but as a consequence of the appellant's failure to establish to the satisfaction of the committee the facts on which it based its case.  1)Market Mall was built in 1966 and underwent expansions in 1979, 1982, 1987 and 1992. The assessor calculated MAF of 0.94 for the mall. If it had been grouped with all other commercial retail buildings in its commercial building neighbourhood, its MAF would have been 0.65. 2)The appellant only raised two issues: 1)Did the Assessor err in law by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the assessment manual in determining the market adjustment factor for the appellant properties by using a single sale to calculate the market adjust factor?  2)Did he err in his interpretation of abnormal functional obsolescence as defined in the Manual? 3)Did his decision in respect of add-on construction erred in law? 4)Did it err in principle in concluding that the definition does not apply to add-ons, or by finding that there must be an inability of an improvement to perform the function for which it is used? 5)The appeal was allowed on the same basis as the previous grounds of appeal.

column2: The Director of Labour Standards issued a certificate against the City of Regina certifying that it owed a transit employee $318.41 in wages for hours worked in weeks containing a statutory holiday in excess of 32 hours as provided in the Labour Standards Act. The City applied for a review. HELD: The City's application was allowed. Under the terms of the collective agreement in force, the employee was actually paid 4 hours pay in excess of the Act's requirements for each of the weeks in question. Pursuant to section 72 of the Act, therefore, these particular terms of the collective agreement applied since they were, when considered in light of the balance of the agreement, more favorable to the employee than the requirements of the Act.
column3: The City applied to review the Director's certificate of adjustment for unpaid wages filed in March 1994. The Director had previously filed a letter reducing the assessment to $318.41 (including annual holiday pay). The City brought this application to review. HELD: 1)The certificate was issued pursuant to s. 60 of the Labour Standards Act. The City was not required to pay the employee at the rate of time and one-half for hours worked over 32 hours in any week which had a public holiday. 2)The documents satisfied the Director that pursuant to the terms of the agreement, the City paid the employee 87 hours of pay in excess of the Act's requirements for hours working in week containing a holiday; and 3)it paid the transit employee 4 hours pay in the amount of $5,000.00.  4)The provisions of the Agreement should govern and not those of the CAX Act.
column4:
The Director of the Labour Standards Branch of the
Department of Labour issued a certificate pursuant to s. 60 of
The Labour Standards Act, R.S.S. 1978, c. L-1 (the "Act"),
stating that the City of Regina (the "City") owed its transit
employee, Albert Morgan, $511.08 in wages. At the hearing,
the Director filed a March 8, 1994, letter reducing the
assessment to $318.41 (including annual holiday pay). By ss. 10(1) and 6(2) of the Act, an employer is
required to pay an employee at the rate of time and one-half
for every hour worked in excess of 32 hours in any week
containing a public holiday ("holiday"). and 2. for each of the specific weeks questioned by the Director
it paid Morgan 4 hours pay in excess of the Act\'s
requirements. the Act. The City\'s application is allowed, and the
certificate is amended to show that there are no wages due or
owing to Albert Morgan.

column8: The City of Regina applied to review the Director's certificate of adjustment for unpaid wages. The Director had previously filed a letter reducing the assessment to $318.41 (including annual holiday pay). At the hearing, the Director filed a March 8, 1994, letter, which reduced the assessment by $318 to reflect the city's obligations under s.60 of the Labour Standards Act to pay the transit employee $511.08 in wages. HELD: The application was allowed and the certificate was amended to show that there were no wages due or payable to the employee. There was no order as to costs. 1)The documents satisfy the City that pursuant to the terms of the agreement the City paid the employee 87 hours of pay in excess of the Act's requirements for hours worked in week containing holiday; and 2)it paid the individual 4 hours pay in the amount of 4 hours in excess. The documents satisfy that the agreement was more favourable to the employees than the Act.  2)The provisions of the Agreement should govern, and not those of, the Act, as amended. The City's application is allowed, the certificate is amended to admit that there are no wages owing to the Transit employee. 3)The City filed various documents including copies of the collective bargaining agreement it has with the Amalgamated Transit Union, Local #588, which covers Morgan's employment with the City, and asked me to compare the agreement's holiday pay with the agreement.

column13: The City applied to review a certificate issued pursuant to s. 60 of the Labour Standards Act declaring that the City of Regina (the "City") owed its transit employee $511.08 in wages. The Director filed a March 8, 1994 letter reducing the assessment to $318.41 (including annual holiday pay). The City brought this application to review the assessment. HELD: The provisions of the agreement should govern, and not those of the Act. 1)Nothing in this Act or in any order or regulation made under this Act affects any provision in any Act, agreement or contract of service or custom insofar as it ensures to any employee more favourable conditions, more favourable hours of work or more favourable rate of wages than the conditions, the hours and wages provided for by the Act or by any other order. 2)The material did not satisfy the Court that pursuant to the terms of the collective bargaining agreement the City paid the employee 87 hours of pay in excess of the act's requirements for hours worked over 32 in week which had a holiday in it. 3)There was no difficulty in concluding in light of the Caxton decision that the provisions of s. 72 of the Agreement should govern. 4)In light of Caxton, a decision of the Court of Appeal, it should not be left open to demonstrate that a provision (in an agreement) on its face less favourable than its counterpart in the Act is more favourable than the latter.

HELD: 1)By ss. 10(1) and 6(2) of the Act, an employer is required to pay an employee at the rate of time and one-half for every hour worked in excess of 32 hours in any week containing a public holiday. 2)The City filed various documents including copies of the collective bargaining agreement it has with the Amalgamated Transit Union, Local #588, which covers Morgan's employment with the City, and asked me to compare the agreement's holiday pay with the Act's. 3)The documents satisfy the Director that pursuant to the terms of the agreement, the City paid the employee 87 hours of pay and 1. for each of the specific weeks questioned by the Directorit paid Morgan 4 hours overtime. 4)The provisions of the Agreement should govern, and not those of, the Act. The City's application was allowed and the certificate was amended to show there were no wages due or payable to the employee.
