column2: The plaintiff lawyer commenced an action for fees and disbursements in the amount of $4,647.85. The proposed garnishee, SPMC, paid $337.46 into court and brought an application for an order pursuant to Rules 411 and 415(1) of the Queen's Bench Rules of Court. An order that any further amounts due and owing from SPMC to the company be paid into court to be disposed as directed by the court was granted with taxed costs to SPMC. Labour Standards filed notice of potential wage claims. The plaintiff obtained default judgment and made an ex parte application for payment out of the monies paid into court by SPMC. HELD: The applicant/plaintiff was to be paid all monies paid into court by SPMC with respect to the two files together with accrued interest less the amount previously paid out. The claim by the Minister of Labour was dismissed. Although the monies paid into court according to the decision in Polyco Window Manufacturing Ltd v. Prudential Assurance Co create a fund from which creditors must be paid, the claim by the Minister of Labour as of the date of the application was not a proven claim. No certificate had been issued and no judgment had been entered as of that date. A judgment had been filed by the plaintiff. He was the only party entitled to the monies.
column3: The plaintiff commenced an action against the defendant for fees and disbursements in the amount of $4,647.85. On March 9, 1999, the plaintiff obtained a garnishee summons issued prior to judgment against the said defendant and served it on Saskatchewan Property Management Corporation (SPMC). The plaintiff then made an ex parte application for payment out of the moneys which had been paid into court by SPMC. The court, however, in view of the third party claim by the Director of Labour Standards directed that the application for payments out should be made by notice of motion and that all parties interested in the funds should be served. The matter was reserved for decision on that date.
column4: [1] The plaintiff, Daniel Tapp ("Tapp"), is a practising lawyer in the Province of Saskatchewan. [2] On March 9, 1999, Tapp obtained a garnishee summons issued prior to judgment against the said defendant and served it on Saskatchewan Property Management Corporation ("SPMC"), the proposed garnishee. [3] As a result of that garnishee, the sum of $337.46 was paid into court on April 26, 1999, to the credit of Q.B.G. 639 of 1999. On April 13, 1999, an application was made by SPMC on Q.B.G. 969 of 1999 for an order pursuant to Rules 411 and 415(1) of the Queen's Bench Rules of Court that the sum of $2,521.68 and any further amounts due and owing from SPMC to the defendant company be paid into court and disposed of as the court may direct in full satisfaction of SPMC's obligations to the various parties who may have had a claim against the money. [8] Although I agree with counsel for the Minister of Labour that the moneys paid into court according to the decision in the Polyco Window Manufacturing Ltd. v. Prudential Assurance Co., 1994 CanLII 5009 (SK QB), [1994] 5 W.W.R. 659 (Sask. Q.B.) create a fund from which creditors must be paid; in this instance however, the claim by the Minister of Labour as of the date of the application was not a proven claim. A judgment by Tapp had been filed in May, 1999, so that on June 17, 1999, he was the only party entitled to the moneys. [9] The claim by the Minister of Labour with respect to the funds paid into court as of the date of the application is therefore dismissed. The applicant/plaintiff, Daniel Tapp, shall therefore have payment out to him of all moneys paid into court by Saskatchewan Property Management Corporation with respect to Q.B.G. 639 of 1999, and Q.B.G. 929 of 1999, together with accrued interest less that amount which was previously ordered paid out as costs to SPMC by Justice Wright in the amount of $324.33.

column8: The plaintiff commenced an action against the defendant, 626170 Saskatchewan Ltd., for fees and disbursements in the amount of $4,647.85. On March 9, 1999, the plaintiff obtained a garnishee summons issued prior to judgment against the said defendant and served it on Saskatchewan Property Management Corporation (SPMC). The plaintiff was the only party entitled to the moneys. On April 13, 1999 SPMC served a garnishhee summons on SPMC. On May 27, 1999 Tapp obtained a default judgment against SPMc. Tapp then made an ex parte application for payment out of the mones which had been paid into court by SPMCs. The court, however, in view of the third party claim by the Director of Labour Standards directed that all parties interested in the funds should be served. HELD: The claim was dismissed. 1)The plaintiff was only party to the proceedings. 2)The claim by SMPC with respect to the funds paid into Court was dismissed as no party was entitled to them. 3)The Minister of Labour had not obtained a judgment against either defendant company and had not filed an application to tax the money. 4)Although the plaintiff had obtained judgment against both parties, he had not been the party to any claim against the money as of the date of the application. Although the plaintiff's claim had been proven at trial, no judgment had been issued against either party.

column2: On appeal from 106 SaskR 277. 47 year old respondent, former President and Chief Executive Officer of STC, had been awarded $165,000 (18 months) for wrongful dismissal. He had successively served three Crown Corporations over a period of ten years. On appeal held the award of damages was not inordinately high. The court however reduced the damages by $16,500 as it disagreed with the trial judge's determination regarding mitigation of damages. Appeal allowed to the extent of reducing the damages from $165,000 to $148,500.
column3: This was an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. The trial judge assessed the damages on the general principles, first, that the object of these awards is to compensate for the loss of income sustained in consequence of the wrongful dismissal; second, that their measure is prima facie the amount that would have been earned had the employment continued subject to deduction of such amounts as in the ensuing months are either earned or should have been. The salary was not included in the total amount awarded. The severance terms of the contract were arrived at with an eye to his earlier service. The judge found that the appellant's year of service with the corporation was spent on the basis his annual salary was $102,000, not $110,000. The appellant resisted the attribution on pragmatic grounds, arguing that the company had not paid him any salary; that there was no guarantee the company was going to earn profit; that it needed working capital; that the annual value of the CEO Benefit Package provided to the appellant was mere fledging. The court found that attributing even the net income to the appellants for the purpose of mitigation was not an appropriate way to do so.
column4: This is an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. In consequence Mr. Larsen obtained a judgment for damages against the corporation in the basic amount of $165,000, an amount it contends is exorbitant. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. And so we have decided to reduce his damages by some $16,000 to $17,000. It follows, then, that the appeal will be allowed to the extent of reducing this head of damages from $165,000 to $148,500.

column8: This was an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. The trial judge assessed the damages on the general principles, first, that the object of these awards is to compensate for the loss of income sustained in consequence of the wrongful dismissal; second, that their measure is prima facie the amount that would have been earned had the employment continued subject to deduction of such amounts as in the ensuing months are either earned or should have beenearned in light of the duty upon persons suffering losses to keep them to minimum; and third, that while the plaintiff had been employed by the defendant for less than a year, he had been in the employ of the Crown in the right of the Province for about a decade and had met his legal duty to mitigate but had not succeeded.

For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. And so we have decided to reduce his damages by some $16,000 to $17,000. It follows, then, that the appeal will be allowed to the extent of reducing this head of damages from $165,000 to $148,500.
column22: On appeal from 106 SaskR 277. 47 year old respondent, former President and Chief Executive Officer of STC, had been awarded $165,000 (18 months) for wrongful dismissal. He had successively served three Crown Corporations over a period of ten years. On appeal held the award of damages was not inordinately high. The court however reduced the damages by $16,500 as it disagreed with the trial judge's determination regarding mitigation of damages. Appeal allowed to the extent of reducing the damages from $165,000 to $148,500.
column23: This was an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. The trial judge assessed the damages on the general principles, first, that the object of these awards is to compensate for the loss of income sustained in consequence of the wrongful dismissal; second, that their measure is prima facie the amount that would have been earned had the employment continued subject to deduction of such amounts as in the ensuing months are either earned or should be earned in light of the duty upon persons suffering losses to keep them to minimum.

column2: The accused successfully challenged the sufficiency of the grounds to issue a search warrant that was used to search her residence. Although the Information to Obtain was based on information from an anonymous, unproven source, the source's information was corroborated by independent information as to the accused's employment and residence. The only corroboration of the presence of a crime (a suspected marijuana grow operation) was from a FLIR test. The court found that the evidence did not rise above the level of suspicion, albeit strong suspicion. Corroboration of the employment and residence of the accused did not provide particular support for the informant's credibility; neither were results of the FLIR test and the presence of covered windows sufficient corroboration. The Crown appealed. Appeal allowed; new trial ordered. Although the trial judge articulated the proper test and began by analyzing whether the warrant could have been issued, the issue was later mistakenly transformed into whether he, himself, would have issued it. By weighing the probative evidence, the trial judge effectively substituted his views for those of the issuing justice and wrongly required the issuing justice to draw proper inferences as opposed to reasonable inferences.
column3: The Crown appealed the warrant issued to search a residence of the respondent. The respondent challenged the validity of the warrant, alleging that it was issued without sufficient information. The judge agreed and quashed the warrant. The Crown appealed. HELD: The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered. The court found that the judge erred in law in applying the Garofoli test. The officer who applied for the warrant was found to have exceeded his or her authority to apply the test. He then proceeded to weigh the evidence; thus effectively substituting his views for those of the issuing JP. The appeal should be allowed and ordered a new Trial. The Court found that although the warrant could have been issued, it was not issued because of the lack of corroboration regarding the alleged illegal acts. The evidence obtained as a result of the search was wrongly excluded and had it been admitted, the result would not necessarily have been the same. The Judge also substituted his view of the evidence for that of the issued JP.
column4: Held: The appeal is allowed and a new trial is ordered, as per reasons for judgment of MacDonald, C.J.N.S.; Cromwell and Fichaud, JJ.A. concurring. Therefore, I would allow the appeal and order a new trial. [21] In a thorough and careful analysis, the judge unquestionably articulated the appropriate legal principles. In reviewing his judgment as a whole, regrettably, I believe that what began as an analysis of whether the warrant could have been issued became transformed into an exercise where the judge ultimately considered whether he would have issued it. In other words, respectfully, the judge in the end substituted his view of the evidence for that of the issuing JP. It follows that the appeal should be allowed and a new trial ordered. [32] I would allow the appeal and order a new trial.

column8: HELD: The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered. The court found that the judge had erred in law in quashing the warrant. The judge substituted his view of the evidence for those of the issuing JP. The appeal should be allowed and ordered a new Trial. The Court found that even had the warrant been properly quashed, the police conduct did not justify excluding the evidence obtained in the search. The evidence obtained as a result of the search was wrongly excluded and the result would not necessarily have been the same. The Crown appealed. It argued that the court erred by using the standard of review and that the decision to issue the warrant was made in error. The issue was whether the issuing judge had to draw proper inferences as opposed to reasonable inferences, and if so, whether the warrant could have been issued based on the relevant information. HELD: A new trial was ordered. 1)The judge was correct in his assessment that there was insufficient evidence to establish a reasonable and probable ground for a search. 2)The court substituted his opinion of the judge for that of issuing JP and found that, in a thorough and careful analysis, the judge unquestionably articulated the appropriate legal principles. 3)On the evidence presented, the court concluded that the search warrant was quashed. The warrant was validly issued and there was no allegation that it was otherwise unreasonable. 4)In a review of the facts, the Court found no breach of s.6(1) of the Charter and no basis on which to exclude the fruits of the investigation. The fact that the evidence was found to be probative did not result in a finding of a violation of the officer's rights under s.9 of the Criminal Code. The officer who reviewed the evidence did not substitute his view for the officer that he would have issued the warrant but rather substituted his views for those held by issuing JP in a dissenting opinion. 5)The Court found the following principles apply to the appeal: 1)A review of facts to determine whether a search warrant should be issued is an appropriate exercise where the judge ultimately considered whether he would.  6)The evidence obtained from the information to Obtain was not sufficiently strong or probative to determine if evidence of a crime could be found in the impugned place. In a review the judge must have considered whether the officer could have issued a warrant.

column13: HELD: The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered. The court found that the search warrant was quashed in error. The judge clearly acknowledged that this information was probative and that he substituted his views for those of the issuing JP. However, in a thorough and careful analysis, the judge unquestionably articulated the appropriate legal principles and the court found them to be sufficient to establish a reasonable and probable ground for a search. The Crown appealed. It argued that the judge erred in law in applying the test that a judge must draw proper inferences as opposed to reasonable inferences. HELD: A new trial was ordered.  1)The court applied the standard of review established in R. v. Garofoli for the review of an information to Obtain but did not substitute his view of the evidence for that of the issued JP. 2)The judge was to consider whether he would have issued the warrant but instead whether the warrant could have been issued based on the relevant information. 3)On the evidence presented, it was concluded that the warrant was validly issued and the evidence obtained as a result of the search was wrongly excluded and the result would not necessarily have been the same.

column2: The plaintiff, who was injured in a rear-end motor vehicle accident, applied for summary judgment and an interim payment of damages. Application for summary judgment granted; application for interim payment dismissed. There was no 'air of reality' to the defendant's defence; whether or not the plaintiff's brake lights were working, to strike her vehicle from behind on these facts meant that the defendant was either travelling too close or didn't have enough care and control of his vehicle. The plaintiff was making a significant claim for damages but she suffered from numerous previous injuries and conditions relating to her health; any damage assessment would depend largely upon credibility and the medical evidence at trial; to assess interim damages in this case would be a most difficult task and would only be a haphazard guess. The plaintiff's claim was also complicated by the fact that it could possibly be subject to the 'minor injury' cap on damages.
column3: The plaintiff was operating her motor vehicle when she was struck from behind by the defendant. The defendant claimed that the tail lights were working when he took the vehicle to be appraised and took it in for repair. The plaintiff applied for summary judgment on the ground that there was an arguable issue to be tried on the facts presented, which was that the defendant was travelling too close or didn't have enough care or control of his vehicle and consequently the collision occurred. The defence argued that there were other factors that could contribute to the plaintiff's health problems. The court granted the application. The costs of this appeal and of the application before Judge Burke were ordered to be costs in the cause of the action.
column4: [1] This is an application for an Order for summary judgement pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rule 31.01. We must accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of His Honour Judge Burke dated June 14, 1976. [6] In this particular application involving a rear-end collision, there is a heavier burden upon the Defendant. I am satisfied there has to be an “air of realty” to the defendant’s argument. In any event, I am satisfied when you read the material there was no “air of reality” to the defendant’s argument. [15] I am not satisfied the defendant has met the required burden and I allow the application. Judgement is entered against the respondent/defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. The plaintiff is making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant’s counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant’s affidavit, one concludes there is a significant amount of other factors relating to the health of the plaintiff. I am satisfied any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and medical evidence at trial. In my opinion to assess any amount in this case at this point in time would be a most difficult task and would only be a haphazard guess. [23] The plaintiff’s damage claim is further complicated in this particular matter as a result of the recent amendments in 2003 to the Insurance Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, C-23, especially as it would relate to non-pecuniary general damages. [25] On a review of the material supplied for this application, I am not satisfied that this is an appropriate case to order an interim payment at this point in time and I decline to do so. [26] However, as I said before, I would order summary judgment be entered against the defendant with damages to be assessed.

column8: Civil Procedure Rule 13.01 states that an application for an order for summary judgment pursuant to Rule 13 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rule 31.01 is an attempt to determine whether or not the plaintiff's injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident resulted in her suffering injuries. The defendant argues there is a significant amount of other factors relating to the plaintiff’s health including a pre-existing condition, depression, anxiety, anxiety and other problems she is having with her health. HELD: The costs of this appeal and of the application before Judge Burke be costs in the cause of the action. 1)There was an 'air of realty' to the defence of the plaintiff. 2)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to the defendant‘s counsel and reads the material attached to his affidavit the defendant was travelling too close or didn’t have enough care or control of his vehicle and consequently the collision occurred. The bald statement in the pleadings does not disclose the existence of an actual or probable defence and cannot fend off an application. 3)The evidence submitted by the plaintiff was found to be unreliable. 4)It was not the function of the court in determining the matter of an interim judgment to make findings of credibility or even to dwell on them. It was necessary for the defendant in his pleadings or by way of affidavit or other evidence to assert facts capable, if proven at trial, of rebutting the presumption that the collision resulted from his negligence. 5)There had to be an air of reality to the argument. The evidence submitted in the affidavits did not meet, nor suggest how the defendant hoped to meet, the plaintiffs assertion that she had been stopped for 45 seconds. 6)The defendant argued there was a 'air to reality' to his argument. 7)The court was satisfied the plaintiff had met the required burden and allowed the application. 8)The costs of the appeal were ordered to the cause.

HELD: Judgment was entered against the defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. 1)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant's counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant's affidavit the defendant was travelling too close or didn't have enough care or control of his vehicle and consequently the collision occurred. 2)The defendant argued there was a significant amount of other factors relating to the health of the plaintiff. 3)The evidence submitted by the plaintiff submitted by way of her affidavits and affidavit did not disclose the existence of an actual or probable defence and could only be a haphazard guess. 4)If the brake lights did not work then the defendant drove straight into the rear of plaintiff's car. If the traffic light turned red then the plaintiff’s vehicle was supposed to stop as well. 5)The bald statement in the pleadings does not disclose an 'actual or probable' defence and cannot fend off an application. 6)Costs in the cause of the action were set aside.
column24: [1] This is an application for an Order for summary judgement pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rule 31.01. We must accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of His Honour Judge Burke dated June 14, 1976. [6] In this particular application involving a rear-end collision, there is a heavier burden upon the Defendant. I am satisfied there has to be an “air of realty” to the defendant’s argument. In any event, I am satisfied when you read the material there was no “air of reality” to the defendant’s argument. [15] I am not satisfied the defendant has met the required burden and I allow the application. Judgement is entered against the respondent/defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. The plaintiff is making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant’s counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant’s affidavit, one concludes there is a significant amount of other factors relating to the health of the plaintiff. I am satisfied any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and medical evidence at trial. In my opinion to assess any amount in this case at this point in time would be a most difficult task and would only be a haphazard guess. [23] The plaintiff’s damage claim is further complicated in this particular matter as a result of the recent amendments in 2003 to the Insurance Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, C-23, especially as it would relate to non-pecuniary general damages. [25] On a review of the material supplied for this application, I am not satisfied that this is an appropriate case to order an interim payment at this point in time and I decline to do so. [26] However, as I said before, I would order summary judgment be entered against the defendant with damages to be assessed.
column27: This was an application for an order for summary judgment pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13.01 and an interim payment under the Civil Procedure Rules 31.01. The plaintiff was operating her motor vehicle at the time of the accident and said in her affidavit that she was struck from behind by one of the defendants named in the action. The defendant argued there was a significant amount of other factors relating to the plaintiff’s health, including the fact that she had not been able to establish the motor vehicle accident resulted in her suffering injuries. HELD: Judgment was entered against the defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. 1)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to the defendant”s counsel and reads the material attached to his affidavit the defendant was travelling too close or didn’t have enough care or control of his vehicle and consequently the collision occurred. 2)The evidence submitted by the plaintiff submitted by way of her affidavits caused the court difficulty in determining the amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and medical evidence at trial. 3)Costs in the cause of the action were to be set aside.

column2: The Crown applied for an order forfeiting a vehicle pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act. The registered owner applied for an order declaring her interest in the vehicle was not affected by any forfeiture order. The owner was passenger when 28.3 pounds of marijuana was discovered in the trunk of her Lincoln. She was found not guilty of trafficking and possession of marijuana for the purpose of trafficking. The driver was found guilty of possession for the purpose of trafficking. The trafficking charge against him was judicially stayed. HELD: An order of forfeiture issued pursuant to s.16(1). The application for relief was dismissed. 1)It was not necessary to address the Charter submissions with respect to s.19(3) because Crown counsel consented to the respondent's application being viewed as an application for relief from forfeiture under s.20. 2)It was impossible to conclude the respondent 'appeared innocent of any complicity' in the offence for which the driver was convicted and that she 'exercised all reasonable care to be satisfied' that the Lincoln was not likely to be used in the commission of the offence. 3)Section 11 of the Charter applies only when person has been charged with an offence. There was no charge against the respondent at this time. 4)The Act distinguishes between three types of persons who might own, or have an interest in, conveyance which is 'offence-related property': the interest of person convicted of the offence is forfeitable pursuant to s.16(1); if the person has been neither convicted nor charged and appears innocent of any complicity in the offence; someone charged with the offence which gave rise to the forfeiture application (as here). The forfeiture is not, except with respect to an offender, arbitrary. In view of the provisions available under the Act to obtain relief from forfeiture it cannot be concluded that empowering a court to grant an order of forfeiture constitutes cruel or unusual punishment.
column3: The Crown applied pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. The Crown alleged that Brooks consented to Brooks' submission being viewed as an application by her for relief from forfeiture pursuant to S.20(4) of The Controlled Drug Act. Brooks applied pursuant pursuant to ss.19(3) of s.20 for an ordered declaring her interest in the Lincoln not affected by any forfeiture order. HELD: The Crown's application was dismissed. 1)The Court must first consider the gravity of the offence, the personal characteristics of the offender, the nature and extent of their property interest and the extent or value of the interest. 2)The court must first determine the gravity and gravity of an offence, its gravity, the gravity, its personal characteristics and the interests of the person. 3)The accused was found innocent of any complicity in the offence of which she was convicted. 4)The evidence adduced at trial was not rebutted. 5)The defendant did not show any complicity or complicity in any designated substance offence. The evidence was not adducible. 6)The sentence imposed on Brooks was grossly disproportionate.
column4: [3] The Crown has now applied, pursuant to s. 16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act, S.C. 1996, c. 19 (the "Act") for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. [4] Brooks has, in effect, applied pursuant to s. 20(4) of the Act for an order declaring that her interest in the Lincoln is not affected by any forfeiture order. Consequently, the charges against her must be dismissed. [38] In view of the provisions available in the Act to obtain an order of relief from forfeiture, it cannot be concluded that empowering a court to grant an order of forfeiture constitutes cruel and unusual treatment or punishment of any person who may have an interest in the property sought to be forfeited.  Consequently, the application of Brooks must be dismissed and an order of forfeiture will issue pursuant to s. 16(1) of the Act.

column8: The Crown applied pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. The Crown alleged that Brooks consented to Brooks' submission being viewed as an application by her for relief from forfeiture pursuant s.20 of the Act. Brooks argued that s.19(3) contravenes the guarantees contained in s.11(d) and s.12 of the Charter. HELD: The Crown's application was dismissed. 1)The Court must first consider the gravity of the offence, the personal characteristics of the offender, the nature and extent of their property interest, and the extent or value of the interest. 2)It is not necessary to address the Charter submissions with respect to s 19(3), however, because Crown counsel consented. 3)The court must consider, inter alia, whether the punishment is necessary to achieve a valid penal purpose. 4)Section 20(4) provides the court with the authority to make an order of relief from a forfeiture order. The Court must consider whether the applicant (a) is innocent of any complicity in the designated substance offence and (b)exercises all reasonable care to be satisfied that the property is not likely to be used in the commission of the offense. 5)The test for determining whether a sentence is disproportionately long is very properly stringent and demanding. A lesser test would tend to trivialise the Charter and would be counterproductive. 6)The burden of proof is on the court to determine whether the sentence is disproportionate.

column2: The son of unmarried parents, who had graduated from high school, was working part-time, living with his mother and had not made a final decision on a further course of study sustained a serious brain injury just a few months after his 19th birthday. He required extensive rehabilitation and would not regain his pre-accident physical and intellectual capacity. The mother successfully applied for a reinstatement of child support which had been discontinued by consent, pre-accident, when the son was residing with the father. The son, now 23 years old, was upgrading his high school marks at the time of the hearing and hoped to be admitted to a community college program. The father appealed. Appeal dismissed; the judge's decision to award support was not premised upon a finding that, pre-accident, the son had made a clear decision to pursue a further course of study but on the fact that the son intended to pursue his education and had not withdrawn from parental charge at the time of the accident. There was no evidence to support the allegation that the usual Guideline amount was 'inappropriate' in this case; the Act prohibited the consideration of public income assistance when fixing child support; given the uncertainty about the son's future, this was not an appropriate case for a time-limited order.
column3: The father of a child applied for child support. The mother had moved out of the father's home and was living with the father. The father had been in the father’s custody since June 2001. The child had not made any firm plans on his future career path and was now pursuing a university education. The parties had been involved in a dispute regarding the father and the child’ s future educational future. The court found that the father had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent’S charge at the time of the accident. The support was terminated by agreement, the consent order providing that the child would be in the custody of his mother. The Court found that although the father was aware of the child, the child had made no efforts to withdraw and was not able to withdraw. The evidence showed that the son had not abandoned his educational plans and was taking a hiatus before continuing his education.
column4: Held: Appeal dismissed, with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed, as per reasons for judgment of Bateman, J.A.; Roscoe and Cromwell, JJ.A. concurring [1] This is an appeal from an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act, S.N.S. 1989, c. 160 as amended, requiring the appellant father, Gilbert Roland Hill to pay maintenance for his son James Anthony Davis. On the basis of the outlined circumstances, I find that James, at the time he attained the age of 19 years, had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from the charge of his parents, since it was his intention at that time, and still is his intention, to further his education at a post-secondary educational institution. I am not persuaded that the judge erred in concluding James had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent’s charge at the time of the accident. I have concluded the order for support was not premised on James’ continuing dependency as a result of his pursuit of post-secondary studies. It is not an appropriate case for a time-limited order. [35] In summary, I am not persuaded there was any evidentiary basis upon which the judge could conclude that the Guideline amount was “inappropriate” and therefore depart from it. [36] I would dismiss the appeal with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed.

The respondent had made great strides but had not and will not regain his pre-accident physical and intellectual capacity. The support was terminated by agreement, the consent order providing that James would be in his father's custody with reasonable access.
column19: Held: Appeal dismissed, with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed, as per reasons for judgment of Bateman, J.A.; Roscoe and Cromwell, JJ.A. concurring [1] This is an appeal from an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act, S.N.S. 1989, c. 160 as amended, requiring the appellant father, Gilbert Roland Hill to pay maintenance for his son James Anthony Davis. On the basis of the outlined circumstances, I find that James, at the time he attained the age of 19 years, had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from the charge of his parents, since it was his intention at that time, and still is his intention, to further his education at a post-secondary educational institution. I am not persuaded that the judge erred in concluding James had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent’s charge at the time of the accident. I have concluded the order for support was not premised on James’ continuing dependency as a result of his pursuit of post-secondary studies. It is not an appropriate case for a time-limited order. [35] In summary, I am not persuaded there was any evidentiary basis upon which the judge could conclude that the Guideline amount was “inappropriate” and therefore depart from it. [36] I would dismiss the appeal with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed.
column22: The son of unmarried parents, who had graduated from high school, was working part-time, living with his mother and had not made a final decision on a further course of study sustained a serious brain injury just a few months after his 19th birthday. He required extensive rehabilitation and would not regain his pre-accident physical and intellectual capacity. The mother successfully applied for a reinstatement of child support which had been discontinued by consent, pre-accident, when the son was residing with the father. The son, now 23 years old, was upgrading his high school marks at the time of the hearing and hoped to be admitted to a community college program. The father appealed. Appeal dismissed; the judge's decision to award support was not premised upon a finding that, pre-accident, the son had made a clear decision to pursue a further course of study but on the fact that the son intended to pursue his education and had not withdrawn from parental charge at the time of the accident. There was no evidence to support the allegation that the usual Guideline amount was 'inappropriate' in this case; the Act prohibited the consideration of public income assistance when fixing child support; given the uncertainty about the son's future, this was not an appropriate case for a time-limited order.
column23: This was an appeal from an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act requiring the appellant father, Gilbert Hill, to pay child support in the amount of $2,000. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. 1)The appellant father had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent's charge at the time of the accident. He had made great strides but had not and will not regain his pre-accident physical and intellectual capacity. The support was terminated by agreement, the consent order providing that James would be in his father's custody, with reasonable access by his mother. 2)The order was not premised on James' continuing dependency as a result of his pursuit of post-secondary studies. It simply states that the dependency continues if the child is 'unable, by reason of illness, disability or other cause, to withdraw or provide himself with reasonable needs.' It is not an appropriate case for a time-limited order.

column2: This was an application under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms for an order declaring that the mandatory retirement of the two appellant university professors was invalid and denied the rights of the appellants as guaranteed under ss. 15(1) and (7) of the Charter, and an order for reinstatement and back pay. Dismissing the application, that (1) pursuant to s. 32 of the Charter, the Charter did not apply to these employees since the university was not a subordinate body of government, and was not being controlled by government, but was an independent institution; the fact that the university's governing statute provided that teaching staff were 'deemed to be persons employed in the public service of the Province' for the purposes of their pension plan did not constitute governmental control such as to warrant the application of the Charter; and (2) the proper forum for this application was the Human Rights Commission. The court also considered the retroactive effect of the Nova Scotia decision in Sniders v. Nova Scotia (Attorney General), which struck down the provision in the Nova Scotia Human Rights Act precluding anyone 65 years or over from making an age discrimination complaint. The court concluded that the Sniders decision did have a retroactive effect to the date when s. 15 of the Charter came into force.
column3: This was an application under s.15(1), 24(1) and 52(1)(b) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms for an order declaring that the mandatory retirement of the applicants by the respondent was invalid and infringes, denies and is inconsistent with the rights of the applicant as guaranteed under s15(a) and (7) of The Charter of the Rights and the Freedoms and that the applicants be reinstated as full-time members of the Faculty immediately and that pay to the applicants as employees since the date of their mandatory retirement plus interest, and costs of the proceeding. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Charter of rights and Freedom is designed to bind governments, not private actors. The respondent is a wholly independent institution of post secondary education which manages, administers and controls its property, revenue, business and affairs through its Board of Governors and administration department. 2)The respondent is not a wholly autonomous institution of pre-secondary education which is a subsidiary of the respondent. The Board of Directors and administration are vested in the respondent by the Statute. 3)The collective agreement in effect in 1987 provided for the appointment of a full-timer as a full time member of the faculty at a substantially lower salary than he had been receiving, though presume he was also receiving his pension. The agreement changed in 1988 to provide for the hiring of all employees of the Board of Director and every full-timer employee of the board was deemed to be persons employed in the public service of the Province and such employment was deemed public service. The collective agreement was never made public. 4)The applicants' contention that this creates the degree of governmental control to warrant the application of the charter is untenable. The section by 'deeming' is only bringing employees who are not in the private service within the definitions required to be under that pension plan and such 'deemed' is not for the purposes of that Act. 5)The Court of Appeal decision could come at any time.

column8: This was an application under s.15(1), 24(1) and 52(1)(b) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms for an order declaring that the mandatory retirement of the applicants by the respondent was invalid and infringes, denies and is inconsistent with the applicants' rights as guaranteed under the Charter. In cases involving arrests, detentions, searches and the like, to apply the Charter to purely private action would be tantamount to setting up an alternative tort system. This was an attempt to short-circuit the anticipated lengthy process under the Nova Scotia Human Rights Act by calling the Charter into play both to declare the right and to grant the specific remedy requested so that, if successful, the applicants could resume work at the beginning of the September 1990 university term. HELD: The application was granted on all fours with respect to the application to the Supreme Court of Canada in three cases. 1)The respondent is a wholly independent institution of post secondary education which manages, administers and controls its property, revenue, business and affairs through its Board of Governors and administration department. 2)There is no evidence of governmental control that could be regarded as an exercise of government power sufficient to bring the respondent within the application of the charter. 3)The applicant's contention that this creates the degree of governmental jurisdiction to warrant the application is untenable. The section by 'deeming' is only bringing employees who are not in the public service within the definitions required to be under that pension plan. The respondent is not an arm of the government but rather is a fully dependent institution of higher learning. 4)The court found that the respondent has a vested interest in the collective agreement between the respondent and the Faculty Association. The collective agreement does not indicate governmental control. It is governmental action. 5)Subject to s.17, for all purposes of the Pulic Service Superannuation Act the President, the members of the teaching staff and every full-time employee of the Board shall be deemed to be persons employed in the Public Service of the Province and such employment shall be considered public service. 6)The Court of Appeal held that the Charter applies only to government action. The Court of Queen's Bench held that if the Charter were held not to apply that would be fatal to this application. 7)The Supreme Court held that there was no evidence that governmental control could be considered as an act directly mandated by government and calculated to affect the public, but the performance of a private, consensual act between two parties.

column13: This was an application under s.15(1), 24(1) and 52(1)(b) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms for an order declaring that the mandatory retirement of the applicants by the respondent was invalid and infringes, denies and is inconsistent with the applicants' rights as guaranteed under the Charter and that the applicants be reinstated as full-time members of the Faculty of the respondent immediately. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The respondent is a wholly independent institution of post-secondary education which manages, administers and controls its property, revenue, business and affairs through its Board of Governors and administration department. The respondent is not designated as an agency of the Crown. 2)In cases involving arrests, detentions, searches and the like, to apply the Charter to purely private action would be tantamount to setting up an alternative tort system. In the area of private discrimination, an entirely new system of civil liability in competition with the dispute resolution mechanisms of the Canadian Human Rights Act would result. 3)The applicants' contention that this creates the degree of governmental control to warrant the application of the charter is untenable. The section by 'deeming' is only bringing employees who are not in the public service within the definitions required to be under that pension plan. The purpose of this legislation is to regulate the activities of private persons and institutions, while relationships between individuals are left to the regulation of human rights codes, other statutes and common law remedies, such as the libel and slander laws. 4)The provisions of the Public Service Superannuation Act (PSSA) do not indicate governmental control. Rather, they stem from a collective agreement between the respondent and the Faculty Association. The collective agreement in effect in 1987 provided for the appointment of a full time member of the Board at a normal retirement date of June 30, 1988. The Board's duties were to deal with hiring of all employees, including faculty, and deal with their terms and conditions of employment. The only real relationship between the government of Nova Scotia and the respondent is that the former provides the respondent with certain funding, 95% of which is unrestricted as to use with the remaining 5% restricted to capital renovations, purchases and other purposes. 5)The collective agreement was a holdover from the former circumstances that prior to the independent establishment of the University under its own statute, employees of the university were part of the Civil Service of the Province and such employment shall be deemed to be public service.

column2: HELD: The court found the following with respect to each issue: 1) the grandmother was a person of sufficient interest regarding the children pursuant to s. 6 of The Children’s Law Act, 1997 and had standing to bring her application for custody; 2) it would be in the best interests of the children, now aged ten and nine years of age, to have their primary residence with their grandmother as she was their psychological parent. They had resided with their grandmother for most of their lives and it was important to maintain their relationships with their school and friends. The respondent would have regular weekly parenting time with the children; and 3) the evidence was inadequate to consider child support.
column3: The third party was the maternal grandmother of the two children. The parties separated in early 2016. The mother had been living with the grandmother for 18 years. The father had been in the grandmother's home for 18 year. The grandmother had moved into the grandmother’s home after the mother’d separated from the father. The relationship between the grandmother and the father had deteriorated over the years. In addition, the father was granted supervised access to the children. In the interim, the grandmother had been granted custody of the children and the parties’ youngest child, Haydn, had been moved into her grandmother”s home. The grandparents” relationship was not established until the mother died. HELD: The grandmother was a person of sufficient interest. The designation was made pursuant to s. 6 of the Children’S Law Act, 1997. The court had no difficulty determining that the grandmother was of sufficient interests regarding the children as she had been with the father for seven years.

After the parties separated, the mother moved into the grandmother's home after the mother's separation from the father. The father was granted supervised access to the children for three weekends in a row with no access on the fourth weekend. The grandmother argued she was a person of sufficient interest to have custody of the children. HELD: The court found that the grandmother was not a person with sufficient interest. The court ordered that the father's access be supervised by his aunt and that the children should remain in the grandmother’s home.

The paternal grandmother was the primary caretaker of the children and she ensured that the children attended school and did everything she could to support the children as their mother was dying. The maternal grandmother was not an issue for the court.

column2: An application pursuant to s197 of the Automobile Accident Insurance Act for an order setting aside SGI's termination of the applicant's income replacement benefits. The applicant suffered soft tissue injuries to his cervical spine when his vehicle was struck from behind by an uninsured driver. He received a partial income replacement benefit from SGI on the basis he was not able to perform some but not all of his farm duties. HELD: 1)SGI was not entitled to terminate Sawkiw's benefits pursuant to s185(d), (e), (f) or (g). SGI's failure to make a suitable rehabilitation program available to Sawkiw prior to October 1/97 and its failure to reassess his level of income replacement benefits as at September 14 where significant factors contributing to his desperate circumstances. SGI was requiring Sawkiw to attend daily physiotherapy of 3 to 4 hours duration with approximately 2-1/2 hours of additional travel time. It is common knowledge that pain can be exhausting; that daily physiotherapy can be exhausting; that daily travel of 2-1/2 hours can be exhausting; that the physical demands of farming can be exhausting; and, that the mental demands of managing a farm and coordinating and organizing the work of others on a farm can be exhausting. It was far from clear how SGI expected Sawkiw to devote approximately 6 to7 hours per day to his treatment program and still have the mental and physical reserves to devote any time or energy to his farming oprations. He could only reasonably be expected to participate in daily physiotherapy if he was receiving a full, rather than a partial income replacement benefit. 2)The benefits were properly terminated pursuant to s129(1)(e) the first day of his full time employment in Alberta. However, from September 14/97 to the date of termination Sawkiw was entitled to be paid full income replacement benefit without adjustment for a partial return to work. Sawkiw was entitled to the difference and interest from the date such additional benefits should have been paid until the date of this judgment. 3)SGI was to arrange for an assessment by the rehabilitation centre forthwith. If it is found that as a result of the accident Sawkiw is not able to hold the employment he held at the time of the accident, SGI is encouraged to consider his condition as a relapse under s142(1)(a). Under the terms of this judgment the final income replacement benefit will be other than one made pursuant to s139 or 140. 4)Sawkiw was entitled to his solicitor and client costs respecting services rendered and disbursements incurred from the date of filing his notice of motion to the date this judgment is received. He was also entitled to his costs associated with preparing and filing his notice of motion set at $600 being the maximum amount payable under the Personal Injury Benefits Regulations.
column3: The respondent SGI applied to the court pursuant to s. 197 of the Act for an order setting aside the termination of benefits. The respondent SGE had terminated the benefits of a farmer who had suffered soft tissue injuries to his cervical spine. The farmer had received a partial income replacement benefit from SGI on the basis that he was not able to perform some but not all of his farm duties. The farm was not performing well and the farmer was required to attend physiotherapy. The plaintiff was also diagnosed with depression and unable to work. The court found that SGI was not entitled to terminate the benefits pursuant to the s. 185(d), (e), (f) or (g) of the Personal Injury Benefits Regulations. HELD: The benefits were to be terminated. The Court found that the benefits were not terminated because the farmer could only reasonably be expected to participate in daily physiotherapy in Yorkton if he was receiving a full income replacement benefits. SGI will therefore arrange for the farmer to forthwith be assessed by Wascana.

[1] David Sawkiw\'s ("Sawkiw") income replacement
benefits under The Automobile Accident Insurance Act, R.S.S.
1978, c.A-35, (the "Act") were terminated by the respondent,
Saskatchewan Government Insurance, ("SGI") and Sawkiw has
applied to this court pursuant to s. 197 of the Act for an
order setting aside such termination. driver. Sawkiw is a farmer and pursuant to the Act, he
received a partial income replacement benefit from SGI on
the basis that he was not able to perform some but not all
of his farm duties.  As at September 24, 1997 Sawkiw could only
reasonably be expected to participate in daily physiotherapy
in Yorkton if he was receiving a full, rather than partial
income replacement benefit. Wascana. To the contrary, the court finds that SGI\'s failure
to make a suitable rehabilitation program available to
Sawkiw prior to October 1 and its failure to reassess his
level of income replacement benefits as at September 24
were significant factors that contributed to Sawkiw\'s
desperate circumstances in October, 1997 and resulting
conduct on October 1 and thereafter. The court therefore
finds that SGI was not entitled to terminate Sawkiw\'s
benefits pursuant to s. 185(d), (e), (f) or (g). Accordingly, pursuant to s. 198(3)(b), the court

replacement benefits are properly terminated effective the
first day of his employment in Alberta. However, for reasons
previously stated, for the period September 24, 1997 to the
date of termination pursuant to s. 129(1)(e) the court finds
that Sawkiw was entitled to be paid a full income
replacement benefit without adjustment for a partial return
to work. SGI shall therefore pay to Sawkiw the difference,
if any, between the amount paid to Sawkiw for the period
September 24 to October 23, 1997 and the amount required to
be paid pursuant this judgment for the period September 24
to the date of Sawkiw\'s commencement of employment in
Alberta. Sawkiw shall also be entitled to interest on such
amount from the date such additional benefits should have
been paid until the date of this judgment. If
it is found that as a result of the accident, Sawkiw is
currently unable to hold the employment that he held at the

column8: The respondent Saskatchewan Government Insurance applied to the court pursuant to s. 197 of the Act for an order setting aside the termination of benefits. Sawkiw was entitled to the difference and interest from the date such additional benefits should have been paid until the date of this judgment. 3)SGI was to arrange for an assessment by the rehabilitation centre forthwith. If it is found that as a result of the accident Sawkiw is not able to hold the employment he held at the time of the accident, SGI is encouraged to consider his condition as a relapse under s142(1)(a). Under the terms of this judgment the final income replacement benefit will be other than one made pursuant to s139 or 140. 4)Sawkiw was entitled to his solicitor and client costs respecting services rendered and disbursements incurred from the date of filing his notice of motion to the date this judgment is received. He was also entitled to his costs associated with preparing and filing his notice of motion set at $600 being the maximum amount payable under the Personal Injury Benefits Regulations.
column23: The respondent Saskatchewan Government Insurance applied to the court pursuant to s. 197 of the Act for an order setting aside the termination of benefits. The applicant had received a partial income replacement benefit from SGI on the basis that he was not able to perform some but not all of his farm duties. HELD: The application was set aside. The court found that SGI was not entitled to terminate the applicant's benefits under s. 185(d), (e), (f) or (g) of the Personal Injury Benefits Regulations.  1)SGI could only reasonably be expected to participate in daily physiotherapy in Yorkton if he was receiving a full, rather than partial, benefit. 2)The applicant's injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident resulted in his being unable to perform farm duties and he was currently unable to hold the employment that he held at the time of the accident. 3)The application for review was prepared following the hearing of this application. 4)The Court found that the termination was appropriate because the applicant had not been receiving appropriate psychological assistance and full income replacement benefits prior to October 1/97. 5)The court was not prepared to find that the applicant caused his early discharge from the Yorkton Physiotherapy Secondary Treatment Centre or failed, without valid reason to attend his scheduled assessment at Wascana. 6)It was not clear as to how SGI expected the applicant to devote approximately to hours per day to his treatment program and still have the mental and physical reserves to devote any time or energy to his farming operations.

column27: The respondent Saskatchewan Government Insurance applied to the court pursuant to s. 197 of the Act for an order setting aside the termination of benefits. The respondent SGI had terminated the benefits of a farmer who had suffered soft tissue injuries to his cervical spine. The farmer had received a partial income replacement benefit from SGI on the basis that he was not able to perform some but not all of his farm duties. HELD: SGI was not entitled to terminate the benefits under s. 185(d), (e), (f) or (g) of the Personal Injury Benefits Regulations. 1)SGI could only reasonably be expected to participate in daily physiotherapy in Yorkton if he was receiving a full, rather than partial, benefit. If it was found that the farmer was currently unable to hold the employment that he held at the time of the accident, SGI would be entitled to interest on such an amount from the date such additional benefits should have been paid until the date of this judgment. 2)The court found that SGI's failure to make a suitable rehabilitation program available to the farmer prior to October 1 and its failure to reassess his level of income replacement benefits as at September 24 were significant factors that contributed to Sawkiw's desperate circumstances in October 1997 and resulting conduct in October and thereafter. 3)The termination of the benefits was not allowed to occur because of the farmer's injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident. If the farmer had been receiving appropriate psychological assistance and full rather that partial income replacements, he may not have felt forced to abandon all efforts at rehabilitation intended to assist him in ultimately carrying on his pre-accident employment in order to take up alternate employment in Alberta.

column2: The appellants applied for leave to amend their notice of appeal in regard to an order requiring them to post security for costs with respect to certain interlocutory applications. The application was opposed, inter alia, on the basis that the allegations which underlie the proposed amendment were not justiciable issues before the trial judge, were irrelevant on the application and were not ruled on by the trial judge. Application to amend the notice of appeal allowed; the amendment is reasonably necessary for the presentation of the appeal and will not occasion prejudice to the respondent. The respondent's opposition to the application fundamentally misconceived the role of a chambers judge who is asked to grant leave to amend a notice of appeal. It is not the role of a chambers judge to rule on the substantive merits of the arguments the appellants wish to make. The focus in this situation is on whether there is any prejudice to the respondent as a result of this issue being raised by amendment rather than in the original notice of appeal.
column3: The appellants applied for leave to amend their notice of appeal. Leave was required because the notice was filed more than 20 days ago: Rule 62.04(4). The application is opposed by the respondent 2301072 Nova Scotia Limited and the intervenor 230102 Dominion Bank. The appellants wish to add as ground that the respondent, the plaintiff in the main action, is not a 'lawful plaintiff' and, therefore, not entitled to security for costs. The respondent and intervenor oppose the amendment on three grounds: first, that the allegations of champerty and maintenance that underlie the proposed amendment were not justiciable issues before the chambers judge, were irrelevant to the security for cost application, were not ruled on by the chambers Judge and should not be raised on appeal; and second, that while the torts of chammperty and upkeep had been eliminated by the common law, the issues of chamsperty and Maintenance were not reasonably necessary to the appellants' presentation of their appeal. The position advanced by the appellant and the respondent in opposition misconstrue, fundamentally, the role of a chambers judge of this Court who is asked to grant leave to amendment a notice of appeals. These points each relate to the substantive merit of the arguments the appellans wish to make on appeal if leave to add the notice of Appeal is granted. The permitted amendment is to add to the notice the following ground of appeal: 1) that the allegation of chperty and maintainance were not necessarily reliable issues, were unnecessary to the secure for costs application, and should be raised by way of an application to quash this ground of appeals; and 2) that while there was prejudice to the respondent or intervenor as a result of the appellation raising these issues, those arguments are for a panel and not chambers judge to consider. The amendments are reasonably necessary for the presentation of the appeal and will not interfere with the date set for filing the appeal book or result in any wasted effort to address the appeal as originally framed. Leave to amend the notice is granted on the condition that the appeal is filed as previously ordered. Leave is granted in the cause of the application. Leave for amend is granted if leave is granted by the chamber judge. Leave of amend is required to add a ground of argument that the appellas wish to include in the notice a ground that was raised by the respondents and the interlocutory applications in which they will be the moving parties. Leave granted is granted

column2: Accused pleaded guilty at opening of trial to one count of distributing child pornography in the form of written works. The accused was active on a pedophile website and posted 11 stories describing sexual activity between men and infants and pre-teen girls. HELD: Accused received 15 months imprisonment followed by 3 years of probation with addition orders including providing DNA samples and being added to the Sex Offender Registry. The Court accepted that the internet has led to the accelerated proliferation of child pornography, making it an increasing social problem. The social harm of such material is borne almost exclusively by infants and children, the most defenceless members of society. For this reason, denunciation and deterrence are the dominant sentencing principles. The defence submitted that the writings do not actually harm children in their making and, therefore, should not be subject to the same denunciation as pornographic images. The Court rejected this argument because it cannot be assumed that the writings do not stimulate the demand for images and since not all pedophiles are voyeurs only some will act on their desires and anything that stimulates this desire places children at risk in the real world. Aggravating factors in this case were 1) the fact that the accused extolled pedophilia and wrote hard core child pornography and encouraged others to the same. 2) The accused was a high profile contributor to the web site and he remains unrepentant Ã» he does not believe there is anything wrong with writing these stories and only stopped because the law requires it. A conditional sentence would not represent sufficient denunciation or deterrence. Mitigating factors in this case included a lack of criminal record, the guilty plea and the fact that the accused is looking after his elderly mother.
column3: The defendant pled guilty at the opening of trial to distributing child pornography contrary to s. 163.1(3) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The defendant was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment to be followed by a term of probation of 3 years, as well as the additional orders made available pursuant to s485.051 of the Code. The court found that the defendant had abided by his release conditions over the past two and half years, had no previous criminal record, and was now serving the useful social purpose of looking after his ailing mother who lives on an isolated acreage and who will be punished if he is incarcerated. The defendant had no criminal record and did plead guilty albeit at the trial. The mitigating factors referred to by the defence included the fact that the accused had no prior criminal record but had been involved in a sexual offence for several years, and that he was a good citizen. The sentencing order was made pursuant to ss.485.012 of the C.C. Code. It was ordered that the offender be subject to an order pursuant to which he be subject subject to a form 52 requiring him to comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act, 2004, and use a computer system within the meaning of subsection 342.1 of s. 342.2(2) for the purpose of communicating with a person under the age of 14 years. The sentence was based on the mitigating factors that the court found were significant mitigating factors.
column4:
Mr. Houston was a high profile
contributor to the website during the time he was active, and he remains
unrepentant, meaning he does not yet believe there is anything wrong with writing
such stories, but simply agrees to stop doing so because the law requires it. [18] Based on the circumstances of this offence, and the circumstances
of the offender, I conclude that a conditional sentence would not be a fit sentence
on the facts in this matter, although I agree Mr. Houston qualifies for the same to
the extent a fit sentence would not exceed two years, and I agree on the limited
information available that he would not endanger the community if one were
imposed. A conditional sentence also would not be
strong enough to deter others who might be inclined to engage in the activity of
distributing child pornography. [19] I have taken into account the mitigating factors referred to by
counsel for the defence, such as the fact that Mr. Houston has no criminal record,
and did plead guilty, albeit at the opening of trial, along with the other material I
have referred to in the foregoing in arriving at what I consider to be the
appropriate length of sentence. Mr. Houston, I sentence you to 15 months
imprisonment, to be followed by a term of probation of three years, as well as the
additional orders I am about to make. Canada: (1) Pursuant to s. 490.012 of the Criminal Code, it is ordered you be
subject to an order which will issue in Form 52 requiring you to
comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act, 2004,
S.C. c. 10, for a period of 20 years, which is the mandatory time
specified in s. 490.012(1) for a person convicted of distributing child
pornography. (2) Pursuant to s. 487.051 of the Criminal Code an order shall issue in
Form 5.03 which authorizes the taking of samples from you for
forensic DNA analysis.

HELD: The defendant was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment to be followed by a term of probation of 3 years, as well as an order requiring him to comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act, 2004 for a period of 20 years. The defendant had no previous criminal record and was now serving the useful social purpose of looking after his ailing mother who lives on an isolated acreage and who will be punished if he is incarcerated. The mitigating factors referred to in the pre-sentence report were that the defendant abided by his release conditions over the past two and a half years, had no prior criminal record, and is now serving a useful social role of looking After His Mother who is also a victim of child pornography. A conditional sentence would not be a fit sentence in this matter, as the defendant qualifies for the same to be given to the parent by the parent, and the limited information available that he would not endanger the community if one were imposed. However, a conditional sentence also would not deter others who might be inclined to engage in the same activity.

column17: Accused pleaded guilty at opening of trial to one count of distributing child pornography in the form of written works. The accused was active on a pedophile website and posted 11 stories describing sexual activity between men and infants and pre-teen girls. HELD: Accused received 15 months imprisonment followed by 3 years of probation with addition orders including providing DNA samples and being added to the Sex Offender Registry. The Court accepted that the internet has led to the accelerated proliferation of child pornography, making it an increasing social problem. The social harm of such material is borne almost exclusively by infants and children, the most defenceless members of society. For this reason, denunciation and deterrence are the dominant sentencing principles. The defence submitted that the writings do not actually harm children in their making and, therefore, should not be subject to the same denunciation as pornographic images. The Court rejected this argument because it cannot be assumed that the writings do not stimulate the demand for images and since not all pedophiles are voyeurs only some will act on their desires and anything that stimulates this desire places children at risk in the real world. Aggravating factors in this case were 1) the fact that the accused extolled pedophilia and wrote hard core child pornography and encouraged others to the same. 2) The accused was a high profile contributor to the web site and he remains unrepentant Ã» he does not believe there is anything wrong with writing these stories and only stopped because the law requires it. A conditional sentence would not represent sufficient denunciation or deterrence. Mitigating factors in this case included a lack of criminal record, the guilty plea and the fact that the accused is looking after his elderly mother.

The fact that he disclosed his stories were largely fantasies of what he would do with those two girls when he was incarcerated would not represent sufficient denunciation. column2: The plaintiff filed a number of duplicate claims on behalf of a number of individuals. The issue was whether the claims should be issued. HELD: Section 7(1) of The Small Claims Act provides that a Provincial Court Judge acts as a gatekeeper to insure that claims comply with the Act before they are issued. In this role, the Provincial Court judge is exercising a quasi judicial function. Counsel for the plaintiff has clearly indicated that the claim is a test case. The plaintiff seeks declaratory relief. A substantial amount of the claim involves an allegation of breach of contract, but neither the plaintiff nor the proposed defendants were signatories to the contract. Accordingly, they would not be entitled to the benefit of the agreement. As virtually all of the potential issues raised by these claims are declaratory in nature, they are outside the jurisdiction of the Provincial Court. Any litigation over these issues must be done in the Court of Queen's Bench.
column3: The plaintiff sought summonses to advise of certain matters relating to the timing of the release of his decision in this matter. The plaintiff had submitted 18 claims for issuing by the defendant. The defendant had refused to issue summons and had refused the application under Rule 173 of the Queen's Bench Rules for issuing of the claims. The judge refused to order the defendant to appear before him on a conference date and ordered that the claims be dealt with by the plaintiff. The court declined to issue the summons and instead ordered that a return date be set for the defendant's application under the Small Claims Act for issuing the summons. The parties were to meet in person at the City of Prince Albert to discuss the issues. The applicant had submitted a claim for payment of $10,000 in the amount of $20,000.00. The application for payment was refused. The claim for $10 million in the sum of $5,000 was dismissed. The Court declined to order summonses as requested. The issues raised by the claims were declaratory in nature and outside the jurisdiction of the Provincial Court. The defendants should be given an opportunity to argue the issues identified. The issue of whether the defendant should be issued summonses was a vexing one. The only remedy was to issue a summons to the defendant and provide notice to the parties. The date for the summons was set in consultation with the office of the proposed plaintiff.
column4: [4] First, it is noted that a substantial portion of the relief being sought by the Plaintiff relates to matters that are, prima facie, outside the jurisdiction of the Provincial Court. [36] In summary, then, given that virtually all the potential issues raised by these claims are declaratory in nature, and therefore outside the jurisdiction of the Provincial Court, I will decline to issue the summonses as requested. The issues raised by these claims are important issues to the potential Plaintiffs, and may well be worth litigating, but that litigation, in my view, must be done in the Court of Queen’s Bench, by either issuing a new claim, or by way of enforcement proceedings of the claim upon which the agreement referenced above was made.
