column2: The respondent seeks an order for interim spousal support. The parties were married in January 1991 with three children and ceased to cohabit in December of 1996. The respondent is 52 years old and unemployed. In the past, he has been diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic and suffering from a personality disorder but is currently, according to his physician, of sound mind. He qualifies since 1987 for a disability pension under CPP by reason of his mental disability which provides for a basic income of $580 plus GTS rebate for a total of $630 per month. The petitioner lives on a section of farm land which was brought into the marriage by the respondent, of which one quarter contains the matrimonial home. The petitioner and children live in that home. The petitioner is 39 years old and is also unemployed because she is an incomplete quadriplegic. The farm land is rented out from which the petitioner receives rental income. The petitioner enjoys an income of $3,400 per month while the respondent receives $630 per month. HELD: The petitioner is ordered to pay the respondent the annual sum of $6,000 paid in monthly installments of $500. There is no juridical reason why the petitioner should obtain the total revenue owned by the respondent particularly when he brought the land into the marriage. In fact, fairness and equity would suggest just the opposite, at least in respect to one half of the revenue. Accordingly, the Court makes an order on the basis of the respondent's ownership of the land rather than order payment of spousal support.
column3: FIAT. An application for interim spousal support. The respondent was 52 years old and was unemployed. He had been diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic and suffering from a personality disorder. In the past he had been medically diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenics and suffering a personality condition. The parties were married in 1981 and ceased to cohabit in 1996. The petitioner qualified for disability pension under the Canada Pension Plan by reason of his mental disability. She qualified for a disability pension by reason for his mental illness. The husband had been granted a monthly income of $630. The balance of $6,000 should be paid to the respondent by monthly payments in the amount of $500. HELD: The court concluded that relief should be granted but in the circumstances it should not take the form of spousa support.
column4: [1] This is an application wherein the respondent seeks an order for interim spousal support. [9] I can find no juridical reason why the petitioner should obtain the total revenue from land owned by her spouse, particularly when he brought the land into the marriage. Accordingly, I choose to make an order on the basis of the respondent’s ownership of the land rather than order payment of spousal support. This sum should be left with the petitioner to meet those obligations which presently form part of her monthly expenses as set out in her financial statement. Conclusion [18] In the result, it is ordered that the petitioner pay to the respondent the annual sum of $6,000.00, which shall be paid in monthly installments of $500.00 commencing April 1, 1999.

column8: FIAT. The respondent sought an order for interim spousal support. HELD: The Court concluded that relief should be granted but in the circumstances it should not take the form of spousa. The petitioner did not have the means to make the indicated payments. The balance of $6,000 should be paid to the respondent by way of monthly payments in the amount of $500.  1)The respondent did not need financial assistance. It was suggested that because of his mental disability he could live in a group home and the cost would be relatively low. 2)There was no requirement that the respondent live in group home as there was no basis upon which he could order or expect such. The children were adequately provided for. 3)The court found that there was a sufficient total of means to enable the petitioner and the children to enjoy a reasonable standard of living and the respondent to enjoy an improved standard.

column2: Wills and Estates – Executors – RemovalCivil Procedure – Wills and Estates – Applications – Requirements The applicant applied for an order that the respondents renounce their right to probate the last will of the deceased testator, Anne Reiter, or in the alternative, for an order that they be terminated as executors of her estate. The testator died in January 2015 and application for probate had not yet been made. The deceased’s will had bequeathed all her property to her husband, Michael Reiter, who died in October 2015. The respondents were named executors of his estate. A simultaneous application had been brought by the same applicant to remove the respondents as executors of his estate (see: 2016 SKQB 15). The applicant had failed to serve the respondents with notice of this application or the alternate executor and beneficiaries named in the will. In addition, the applicant had misunderstood that she could rely upon evidence filed in another action that was also before the court in this application. HELD: The application was adjourned. The applicant was instructed to serve notice of the application and the adjournment on the alternate executor and the named beneficiaries. As the applicant had not understood that evidence from another action could not be considered by the court on this application, the applicant was also required to file further affidavit evidence. She was instructed to serve the material on the respondents, the alternate executor and the beneficiaries.
column3: The applicant applied for an order that the respondents renounce their right to probate the last will and testament of the deceased and for an ordered order that they be terminated as executors of the estate for an amount in the amount of $4,000. column2: The parties were in a relationship for over 5 years though they never married. The petitioner now seeks access to the respondent's daughter from an earlier relationship. The parties' relationship was tumultuous and included some incidents of domestic violence, which the child may have been exposed to. There are concerns regarding the interactions between the respondent's daughter and the petitioner's own children. The petitioner must establish, firstly, that he has 'sufficient interest' to bring this application, per s. 6(1) of The Children's Law Act, 1997. HELD: The application for access is dismissed. In determining whether a non-family applicant is a person with a sufficient interest, the Court must consider a variety of factors including: the extent or degree of the applicant's involvement in the child's life, the duration of that involvement, the level of intimacy and the quality of the relationship between the applicant and the child, how the relationship between the applicant and the child was represented to the world, and whether the applicant provided financially for the child. The petitioner has demonstrated that he is a person of sufficient interest; the relationship between the parties was not short and, during its lifespan, the petitioner formed a close bond with the child and was involved with her life. The community viewed them generally as father and daughter. However, the Court cannot conclude that requiring the child to visit the petitioner would be of any benefit to her. This child has already had to contend with multiple 'fathers' and multiple 'siblings', many of whom have been only temporary or fleeting personalities in her life. The confusion that this has no doubt caused her should not be further compounded by requiring her to make even more adjustments in her understanding of what 'family' means. Access to the petitioner is not in the best interests of this child.
column3: The parties were separated in 2007. They lived together for five and one-half years. The parties moved to a new home in 2007 and the child was only a toddler at the time. The child had been with her mother for three years. She moved with her father to live with her sister and her two older children. The father of the children had been convicted of assaulting his estranged wife and had been sentenced to life imprisonment. The mother had moved with the children to a different home. The daughter had been involved with the father of her two younger children. She was also involved in activities with the other children. HELD: Access to the father was not in the best interests of the child. 1) The child was not a person of sufficient interest. The court should consider a variety of factors including the extent or degree of the applicant's involvement in the child's life, the duration of that involvement, the level of intimacy and quality of the relationship between the applicant and the children, how the relationship was represented to the world and whether the applicant provided financially for the child 2) The court must consider a wide range of factors. The threshold for determining a person has a sufficient interest is lower than that for determining that a person had a 'family or blood relationship' (which is defined as one in which one person has demonstrated a settled intention to treat the child as his own) and the factors enumerated in s. of the Act. The Court should consider the extent of the application, the extent and degree of his involvement in a child's upbringing, the type of parenting, the relationship with the child, the family's interests, the parenting style of the parties, the circumstances of the situation, the court's decision to grant access to the child and the court’s order for the application to be dismissed. 2) Access to a non-family applicant was not considered in the circumstances. The applicant had demonstrated that he was a person with a sufficient Interest. The evidence did not support his position. 3) The father was found not to be a person who had a sufficient interests under s. 7. The relationship between him and the applicant was long and intense. The children lived with his mother and his sister for three and a half years. They were involved in many activities with their mother. The two youngest children were involved with activities with her. The parents were involved as parents. 4) The Court of Appeal further said that the father had a reasonable expectation that the children would be better served with him. The fact that the child
column4: The first that must be considered is the position taken by Lawrence that because he is a “step-parent” to Trista, he does not need to establish that he falls within the category of persons having a “sufficient interest” to bring this application. Accordingly, since Lawrence is not a parent as defined in the Act, he must demonstrate that he is of a person of sufficient interest to have standing to bring this application. 47: [47] ... In determining whether a non-family applicant is a person with a sufficient interest, the court should consider a variety of factors including, but not necessarily limited to: (a) the extent or degree of the applicant’s involvement in the child’s life, (b) the duration of that involvement, (c) the level of intimacy and the quality of the relationship between the applicant and the child, (d) how the relationship between the applicant and the child was represented to the world, and (e) whether the applicant provided financially for the child.... 33) In this case, I am satisfied that Lawrence has demonstrated that he is a person of sufficient interest with respect to Trista. While the date of their separation is in dispute, it was conceded by Melodie that she and Lawrence cohabited for a period of at least five years, albeit with periodic interruptions. The relationship, in one form or another, spanned the years 2000 to 2007, commencing when Trista was barely a toddler. Trista referred to Lawrence as “dad”, and the community generally viewed them as “father and daughter” and part of a larger family. 35) In this case, I cannot conclude that requiring Trista to visit with Lawrence will be of any benefit to her. 40) Lawrence’s application for access is dismissed.

In determining whether a non-family applicant is a person with a sufficient interest, the Court must consider a variety of factors including: the extent or degree of the applicant's involvement in the child's life, the duration of that involvement, the level of intimacy and the quality of the relationship between the applicant and the child, how the relationship between the applicant and the child was represented to the world, and whether the applicant provided financially for the child. The petitioner has demonstrated that he is a person of sufficient interest; the relationship between the parties was not short and, during its lifespan, the petitioner formed a close bond with the child and was involved with her life. The community viewed them generally as father and daughter. However, the Court cannot conclude that requiring the child to visit the petitioner would be of any benefit to her. This child has already had to contend with multiple 'fathers' and multiple 'siblings', many of whom have been only temporary or fleeting personalities in her life. The confusion that this has no doubt caused her should not be further compounded by requiring her to make even more adjustments in her understanding of what 'family' means. Access to the petitioner is not in the best interests of this child.

column19: The first that must be considered is the position taken by Lawrence that because he is a “step-parent” to Trista, he does not need to establish that he falls within the category of persons having a “sufficient interest” to bring this application. column2: In the evening, the accused inmate and his two co-accused inmates placed themselves in close proximity to the complainant inmate at table at the Penitentiary. The co-accused threw hot liquid from the cup directly into the complainant's face and the three inmates commenced stabbing the complainant with weapon. second complainant inmate attempted to intervene to assist the first complainant and the accused and co-accused began to stab the second complainant. The first complainant suffered severe first and second degree burns to his face and to his shoulders as well as numerous puncture wounds and lacerations but was not critically injured. The accused was charged with aggravated assault on the first complainant and common assault on the second complainant. None of the inmates testified at trial other than the accused. The accused testified that he felt he was being shunned in the Block and had received threats from the first complainant and others in the complainant's group who were brandishing shanks earlier that day. The defence argued that the Crown failed to prove that the injuries caused to the first complainant fell within the definition of 'wound, maim, disfigure or endanger life'; and that the acts done to the first and second complainants were in self-defence as contemplated by s. 34 of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was convicted of both counts. 1) In relation to the accused's defence of self-defence pursuant to s. 34(2) pertaining to the first complainant, the Court found the accused did not believe that he was being assaulted within the meaning of the law and, even if he did hold this belief, such a belief was not reasonable in the circumstances. Further, the Court did not accept, on a subjective or objective basis, that the accused reasonably believed that the first complainant had the present ability to carry out the threat, notwithstanding that the physical aspect of the assault need not be imminent or immediate. Lastly, the Court found that the accused did not believe that he had no other option. The accused admitted that he had other options but chose not to avail himself of them. 2) The Court found it did not need to assess the application of s. 37 of the Code in relation to the common assault charge. Rather, the Court found s. 27 of the Code applicable and determined that the second complainant was legally justified to use as much force as was reasonably necessary to prevent the commission of an offence which would be arrestable without warrant. The Court found the second complainant was clothed in legal justification and the accused was not entitled to the protection of s. 34(1) because the accused provoked the assault, and the force he used was more than necessary to defend himself as the accused was armed with a shank and the second complainant was not.
column3: The accused was charged with aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the prison. The accused and the two alleged victims were inmates at the prison and were being held on 'B' Block. Given that the incident was captured by security videos, there is no doubt as to what happened. The issues raised by the accused pertain to how his actions ought to be characterized. HELD: The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault. The Court found that the accused's actions against the victims were done in self-defence as contemplated by s. 34(2) of the Criminal Code. The court found that, in all of the circumstances, the accused inflicted injuries to the victim that fit within the category of an aggravated assault, and also constitute grievous bodily harm. The Crown applied the test of'self-defences' under s. 21(1)(b) of s.22(1) of The Criminal Code, which established that the offences were committed in self defence. The test of identity was not the end of the analysis. The trial judge found that there was no issue as to identity. The only issue was how the accused would define self-defense under s34(2). The accused's action against the victim was done in a self- defence.
column4: [1] The accused, Frederick Junior Knife (the “accused” or “Knife”), is charged with one count of aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the Saskatchewan Penitentiary at approximately 8:30 p.m. on September 1, 2008. [33] I will next deal with the argument that Knife’s actions against Dorion were done in self‑defence as contemplated by s. 34(2) of the Criminal Code. [63] Accordingly, I conclude that the accused did not believe that he was being assaulted, within the meaning of the law, and that, even if he did hold this belief, which I find not to be the case, such a belief was not reasonable in the circumstances. Nonetheless, I reject both the subjective and objective components of the second prong of the test for the same reasons that I rejected the first prong of the test. However, as I stated previously, I do not accept, on a subjective or objective basis, Knife reasonably believed that Dorion had the present ability to carry out the threat, notwithstanding that the physical aspect of the assault need not be imminent or immediate. [71] Firstly, dealing with the subjective element, I find that Knife did not believe that he had no other option. However, I do not need to assess the application of s. 37 because I find that s. 27 of the Criminal Code is applicable. Consequently, I find that Demeria was clothed in legal justification when he entered the fray. I find, as well, that Knife is not entitled to the protection of s. 34(1) because Knife provoked the assault, and the force he used was more than necessary to enable him to defend himself. It is obvious from the video recordings that Knife was armed with a shank, whereas Demeria was not, and that stabbing Demeria and holding him so that he could not get away, as Dreaver and Knife were doing, was far more force than was necessary to enable him to defend himself. Conclusion [90] In the final analysis, I find that the Crown has made out all of the elements of both counts beyond a reasonable doubt and, therefore, find Frederick Junior Knife guilty of both Count 1 and Count 2 as specified in the indictment.

column8: HELD: The accused was charged with aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the penitentiary at approximately 8:30 p.m. on September 1, 2008. The accused and the two alleged victims were inmates at the prison and were being held on 'B' Block. Given that the incident was captured by security videos, there is no doubt as to what happened. The issues raised by the accused pertain to how his actions ought to be characterized. The s. 34(2) defence is to deal with the argument that the accused's actions against the victims were done in self-defence as contemplated by s.34(2). HELD: 1)The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault. The Court held that the existence of an actual assault is not a prerequisite for the defence under s.33(2), as it is not currently available to the accused. 2)The court found that the Crown had failed to establish that the injuries inflicted were not serious enough to be considered 'aggravated'. 3)The Court found that, in all of the circumstances of this case, the accused inflicted injuries to the victim that fit within the category of an aggravated assault, and also constitute grievous bodily harm. 4)The Crown must establish the mental element. The Crown established that bodily harm was objectively foreseeable by the defendant because he was concerned about Dorion. The defendant admitted that he was the main threat to Dorion and that his intention was to hurt him so that he would not hurt himself. 5)The evidence established that the defendant was a joint principal offender and that he reasonably believed that Dorion assaulted him. 6)The defendant was found not guilty of any of the three elements of the offence.

The s. 34(2) defence is to deal with the argument that the accused's actions against the victims were done in self-defence as contemplated by s.34(2). HELD: 1)The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault. The Court held that an assault may be made by a person doing, or omitting to do, acts for the purpose of aiding a principal to commit an offence. The concept of 'parties to the offence' is conceptually possible to be liable as both 'joint principal offender' and'secondary offender' within s. 265(1)(b) that reads in full as follows: 2)A person commits an assault according to the Criminal Code when he attempts or threatens to apply force to another person, if that person makes the attempt or threat has or causes the other person to believe on a reasonable basis that he has the present ability to carry out that purpose. The Crown must establish the mental element. The mens rea requirement for aggravated assault is an objective foresight of bodily harm. The court held that the existence of an actual assault is not a prerequisite for defence under s.33(2), but rather 'did the accused reasonably believe, in the circumstances, that she was being unlawfully assaulted.' 3)The court found that, in all of the circumstances of this case, the accused inflicted injuries to the victim that fit within the category of an aggravated assault, vis-à-vis Dorion. The defendant was transferred to Saskatchewan Penitentiary because he wanted to be closer to his family.

The Court found the second complainant was clothed in legal justification and the accused was not entitled to the protection of s. 34(1) because the accused provoked the assault, and the force he used was more than necessary to defend himself as the accused was armed with a shank and the second complainant was not.
column23: HELD: The accused was charged with aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the penitentiary at approximately 8:30 p.m. on September 1, 2008. The accused and the two alleged victims were inmates at the prison and were being held on a range designated for gang members. Given that the incident was captured by security videos, there is no doubt as to what happened. The issues raised by the accused pertain to how his actions ought to be characterized. The s. 34(2) defence is to deal with the argument that the accused's actions against the victims were done in self-defence as contemplated by s.34(2).
column24: [1] The accused, Frederick Junior Knife (the “accused” or “Knife”), is charged with one count of aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the Saskatchewan Penitentiary at approximately 8:30 p.m. on September 1, 2008. [33] I will next deal with the argument that Knife’s actions against Dorion were done in self‑defence as contemplated by s. 34(2) of the Criminal Code. [63] Accordingly, I conclude that the accused did not believe that he was being assaulted, within the meaning of the law, and that, even if he did hold this belief, which I find not to be the case, such a belief was not reasonable in the circumstances. Nonetheless, I reject both the subjective and objective components of the second prong of the test for the same reasons that I rejected the first prong of the test. However, as I stated previously, I do not accept, on a subjective or objective basis, Knife reasonably believed that Dorion had the present ability to carry out the threat, notwithstanding that the physical aspect of the assault need not be imminent or immediate. [71] Firstly, dealing with the subjective element, I find that Knife did not believe that he had no other option. However, I do not need to assess the application of s. 37 because I find that s. 27 of the Criminal Code is applicable. Consequently, I find that Demeria was clothed in legal justification when he entered the fray. I find, as well, that Knife is not entitled to the protection of s. 34(1) because Knife provoked the assault, and the force he used was more than necessary to enable him to defend himself. It is obvious from the video recordings that Knife was armed with a shank, whereas Demeria was not, and that stabbing Demeria and holding him so that he could not get away, as Dreaver and Knife were doing, was far more force than was necessary to enable him to defend himself. Conclusion [90] In the final analysis, I find that the Crown has made out all of the elements of both counts beyond a reasonable doubt and, therefore, find Frederick Junior Knife guilty of both Count 1 and Count 2 as specified in the indictment.
column27: HELD: The accused was charged with aggravated assault and one count of common assault relating to a violent incident that took place in the maximum security unit of the penitentiary at approximately 8:30 p.m. on September 1, 2008. The accused and the two alleged victims were inmates at the prison and were being held on 'B' Block. Given that the incident was captured by security videos, there is no doubt as to what happened. The issues raised by the accused pertain to how his actions ought to be characterized. The s. 34(2) defence is to deal with the argument that the accused's actions against the victims were done in self-defence as contemplated by s.34(2). HELD: 1)The accused was found guilty of aggravated assault. The Court held that the existence of an actual assault is not a prerequisite for the defence under s.33(2), as it is not currently available to the accused. 2)The court found that the Crown had failed to establish that the injuries inflicted were not serious enough to be considered 'aggravated'. 3)The Court found that, in all of the circumstances of this case, the accused inflicted injuries to the victim that fit within the category of an aggravated assault, and also constitute grievous bodily harm. 4)The Crown must establish the mental element. The Crown established that bodily harm was objectively foreseeable by the defendant because he was concerned about Dorion. The defendant admitted that he was the main threat to Dorion and that his intention was to hurt him so that he would not hurt himself. 5)The evidence established that the defendant was a joint principal offender and that he reasonably believed that Dorion assaulted him. 6)The defendant was found not guilty of any of the three elements of the offence.

column2: The accused was charged with failure to provide forthwith a breath sample contrary to Criminal Code s.254(5). HELD: The accused was found not guilty. The court accepted the evidence of the accused where there was a discrepancy between the testimony of the officer and the accused. The mental element of the offence of refusal consists of intentional non-compliance. The officer in his conversation with another officer said he could not understand why he was not getting a proper sample. There was a reasonable doubt that the officer did understand why he was not getting a proper sample and could not provide the accused with adequate instructions.
column3: The accused was charged with failing to comply with a demand made to him by a peace officer pursuant to s. 254(2)(a) of the Criminal Code to provide forthwith a sample of his breath as in the opinion of Cst. Rozario. The accused chose not to disclose in his disclosure information the name of the 'ride along' nor even that there was a ride along. The officer testified that he observed the accused's vehicle swerve to the right and then to the left more than necessary as he approached it. The police vehicle swerved to the side of the highway more than it should have and the accused blew outside the mouthpiece. The officers testified that they had to stop the vehicle to check the driver's licence and registration. The RCMP officer testified on the Promise to Appeal served that he stopped the second test as the accused was blowing outside the gum. He said he thought he might have difficulty blowing a sufficient sample for the officer. The second test was stopped as the officer was blowing. The third test was done as the police vehicle slowed down and the officer explained to the accused that he needed a steady breath and that it was his last chance. The first test was performed as the vehicle swiped to the other side of a highway more frequently than necessary. The driver was given a warning that the vehicle was approaching and the police officer engaged the emergency lights. The vehicle stopped and the second breath test was run. The breath sample was given to the officer as a condition of his licence. The court accepted the evidence of the accused.
column4: [1] Andre Detillieux stands charged that on or about the 11th day of November, 2001 at Paddockwood District in the Province of Saskatchewan did without reasonable excuse, fail to comply with a demand made to him by Cst. Rozario, a peace officer pursuant to Section 254(2)(a) of the Criminal Code, to provide forthwith a sample of his breath as in the opinion of Cst. Rozario was necessary to enable proper analysis of his breath to be made by means of an approved screening device contrary to Section 254(5) of the Criminal Code. For reasons which I will discuss later in this decision, where there is discrepancy between the testimony of the officer and that of the accused, I accept the evidence of the accused. At minimum, I have a reasonable doubt that the officer did understand why he was not getting a proper sample. [13] Therefore, I find the accused not guilty of the charge.

column8: The accused was charged with failing to comply with a demand made to him by a peace officer pursuant to s. 254(2)(a) of the Criminal Code to provide forthwith a sample of his breath as in the opinion of Cst. Rozario. The accused chose not to disclose in his disclosure information the name of the 'ride along' nor even that there was a ride along. HELD: The accused was found guilty. 1)The officer's lack of cander in giving his testimony in this regard has raised doubts in my mind as to his forthrightness in respect to other important details in this matter. For reasons which I will discuss later in this decision, where there is a discrepancy between the testimony of the officer and the accused, I accept the evidence of the accused.  2)The accused did not intentionally try to avoid providing an adequate sample. He was attempting to supply sample as directed by the officer. The officer gave his evidence in forthright manner and accept it without reservation. The police officer did not understand why the accused was not getting a proper sample. 3)The court accepted the accused's evidence that he stopped the second test as the accused blew outside the mouthpiece again. He waited for the ready light to come on. He said he thought he was having difficulty blowing a sufficient sample for the officer, but then realized that he needed a steady breath and that his lips had to be sealed. He ceased the test. 4)For reasons which were discussed later in the decision where there was discrepancy between testimony of both the officer's and accused's testimony, I accepted the evidence. The court accepted that the accused had not told the young, inexperienced officer of why he thought that he may have been having difficulty with blowing a sample for a roadside screening device. The young officer testified that he had helped his son skin a deer which his son had just shot. He had to use his prescribed inhaler then and again at the party where he had had his two or three beers. The last call came when they were at the pines just north of Prince Albert. After that the officer slowed down. He did not inform the accused of anything. Eventually at the detachment the accused said he was surprised when he was informed that he would be charged with refusal. He wrote on the Promise to Appeal served on him: “I did not refuse breath sample.” 5)The police officer was aware of the speed at which the accused drove and that he was only told once how to give proper sample although he

column2: This was an appeal from the conviction of the appellant that he broke and entered a used car dealership and stole a vehicle, contrary to s. 348(1)(b) of the Criminal Code. The theft was reported to police by a passing motorist who saw the vehicle being driven off the car lot early in the morning. The vehicle was spotted on the highway, and when stopped, was exited by two individuals. Two officers followed tracks through a wooded area, and noted that in two areas the tracks broke through ice on a brook. Shortly thereafter the appellant came out of the woods on a nearby road; his lower body was wet and chunks of ice and snow clung to his clothing. The imprint of his footwear resembled that of the tracks in the snow. The appellant was convicted, based on the doctrine of recent possession. He argued there was no evidence he was in recent possession of the stolen vehicle. Dismissing the appeal, that there was sufficient evidence to support the findings of fact made by the trial judge. The judgment of the trial judge was consistent with R. v. Kowlyk (1988), 43 C.C.C. (3d) 1 (S.C.C.).
column3: The appellant was convicted of break, enter and theft. He had stolen a used car dealership truck from the lot at 12:15 o'clock in the morning. The police were called to the scene and the accused ran from the vehicle and made tracks in the snow. The accused was charged with theft. Dismissing the appeal, that although the evidence was circumstantial, the facts he found to be proved led to no other reasonable inference than the guilt of the appellant.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal dismissed from conviction for break, enter and theft contrary to s. 348(1)(b), per oral reasons for judgment of Clarke, C.J.N.S.; This is an appeal from the conviction of the appellant that on March 11, 1995, he broke and entered a used car dealership office in Antigonish and committed the offense of theft of a 1994 Chev Blazer contrary to s. 348(1)(b) of the Criminal Code. A review of the record and a re-examination of the evidence persuades us that there was sufficient evidence to support the findings of fact made by the trial judge, that the appellant was in possession of the Blazer at the time he fled, and also that the inferences he drew and the conclusion he reached. Accordingly, the appeal from conviction is dismissed.

column8: This was an appeal from a conviction for break, enter and theft contrary to s. 348(1)(b) of the Criminal Code. A motorist who saw the vehicle being driven from the lot at 12:15 o'clock in the morning reported that it had been stolen. Two constables followed the tracks of the vehicle through wooded area. The accused ran from the vehicle and made the tracks in the snow which were followed by the police. Shortly before 2:00 a.m., the accused came out of the woods on the Williams Point Road. His lower body was wet and some chunks of snow were clinging to his clothing. The police said the imprint from his footwear resembled the imprint found in the tracks they followed through the snow. Allowing the appeal and ordering a new trial, that the doctrine of recent possession may be succinctly stated in the following terms. Upon proof of the unexplained possession of recently stolen property, the trier of fact may but not must draw an inference of guilt of theft or of offences incidental thereto. Where the circumstances are such that a question could arise as to whether the accused was thief or merely possessor, it will be for the officer to decide.
